From the story, the characters, the boss fights, and the endgame, Grindblue Fantasy has once again delivered a solid product. With the current state of gaming being riddled with incomplete trash and buggy messes, this game manages to feel like a complete package. It's been quite a while since I've had a game pull me in so hard that I play it exclusively for weeks.
cagliostro is literally me

endgame as of currently is way to dragged out where you will be forced to fight the exact same boss multiple times to progress. It also sucks that interesting / powerful equipment is locked behind a completely RNG and time gated mechanic with no way to really target farm through active gameplay. Matchmaking is also archaic, and the control scheme for M/KB is also annoying since you can't navigate menus with the mouse at all. But the mid game was enjoyable. So idk get it on sale for 40 / 50 dollars.

Playing this after FF16 and I can say it definitely charming, atmospheric, and detailed. The art style is fantastic and exploration is fairly similar to FF16, but the customization options for your squad are top notch. I wasn't planning on binge playing this game but time just zooms by having fun.

As a long time fan of the GBF mobile game and the Monster Hunter series, this game was pretty much all I could ask for. It might not be perfect, but you can see the polish and effort that went into the game. Controls are snappy, and the gameplay loop is satisfying if you enjoy mastering movesets and long term grinds. Easily recommended.

Update: Now that I'm over 100 hours and have a bunch of the end game sigils and weapons, I will say that the game feels a bit easier than I would have liked, even with the final proud fights. I still spent the better part of three weeks really enjoying it, and learning movesets of different characters is still a good time. 

If they add a lot of post launch challenging content, this game could be a real contender for something like GotY. But as it stands now, it's simply a game that's a good time, and definetly worth the box price, even if people who have spent thousands of hours in Souls/ Monster Hunter games won't have much challenge after seeing the fights once or twice.

Went in expecting Jrpg, got a highly addicting anime monster hunter. The story definitely takes a backseat to the action and an incredibly polished endgame. The main quest is maybe 10-15 hrs long thanks to having zero filler, but completing post game takes most people about 70-100hrs. The characters play very different from one another and are basically the monster hunter version of changing weapons. This was definitely a sleeper hit for me. If you like action RPGs, get this game for sure. If you want a story focused JRPG, pass on this one unless it goes on sale. Highly recommended.

Good game. If you've ever played a Tales of game, this is very much like them. Just prettier and with a touch more variation in what characters you can use and their combat styles. Plus multiplayer if that's your thing.
One negative thing this brings from the tales games is the noisy battles where everyone is screeching move names over and over. It could have done without that part.
Surround sound doesn't work but that's pretty common among Japanese games.
It feels like a sequel in every sense, but the prequel is a mobile game (though this game is definitely not). In that respect, it's probably better than it has any right to be.
It's a fun game with nice graphics and gameplay. Play it if you like Tales or even the Ys series.

Among the garbage triple A releases, this diamond stands out for being a feature complete game with no major bugs or performance issues, no ingame micro transactions, controversial software (like kernel level anti cheat or anti tamper DRM) and most importantly it was made to be fun.

The story is straight forward, yet compelling enough to keep you interested. It feels like your typical anime where friendship beats evil, but it never overstates its welcome and honestly its a nice change of passe, especially in a market where most releases these days aim for a doom and gloom type of vibe.

The graphics of the game are stylised to look like an anime (obviously) and it achieves this with great success. Its one of the things that will make this title age like fine wine. The world has been beautifully crafted and contains a varied selection of levels, ranging from your typical ancient forest, deserts and laval caverns to gothic designed castles. This all is paired with a fantastic OST, which never really becomes overbearing. Personally I liked most of them with exception of the final boss in proud mode.

That said, the true star of the show is the gameplay. While this might look like your basic hack and slash title, it couldn't be further from the truth. Based on the character you play, your whole gameplay plan changes. You have perfect input characters like Zeta and Siegfried, charge characters like Vaseraga and Percival, ranged mages like io, meter characters like katalina and vane, puppet characters like Rosetta, finally if you really want that button smash experience, you still have characters like Charlotte.

Gameplay revolves around having a balanced team that allows you to enter link time and sky art reliably. Ofcourse you can also play with a single character, but thats more for challenge runs. You're expected to have a balanced team where every character fills a roll (CC / DPS / Support / Stunner / Debuffer) and while every character leans towards a certain archetype, all of them multi class in some way or another, so feel free to choose whatever character you like to have in a team and play with friends in COOP.

Ofcourse, the game isnt without its flaws. When it comes to the technical aspects of the game, it lacks settings and has forced TAA. FoV cant be adjusted and there is no official support for ultrawide screens. Camera auto adjustments cant be fully disabled, which can become annoying in certain fights. Though since this game lacks an anti cheat or anti tamper DRM, most of these issues can be easily rectified with a mod.

The other issue the game suffers from is RNG in the late game. Grinding for the optimal sigil setup for a character is rather time consuming, since for the most part its all RNG based. You can determine what base sigil you get by doing specific quest, but the secondary attribute will always bee random. That said, you can consume bad sigils and roll for new ones and if you dont like the results, you can simply savescum by just going to the title screen without saving and afterwards playing a quest. This also applies to mastery.

The main issue comes from the final boss fight that drops a random terminus weapon, which isnt even guaranteed (at least you dont get dupes). This is incredibly enraging, cause you can repeat this quest 50+ times and not get what you want and since the drop rates are not guaranteed, you can go for 10 cycles without getting a single drop. This is especially egregious, since the final boss fight is one of the few bad bosses in the game in my opinion.

This all though pails in comparison to the RNG involved in getting two of the most vital sigils in the game, war element and supplementary damage. These sigils are important, since this game has a mechanic called damage cap, which means that at a certain point, normal damage boosting sigils no longer have any benefit. The two sigils I mention are the only ones that bypass this limitation, which as you can imagine make them very valuable on any character. That said, these sigils can only be obtained through drops called curio, which only drop once per quest and its not even guaranteed.  Pair that with below single digit drop rates and you get a recipe for disaster. Some players can get their sigils in their first 60 curios, while others like myself might have to roll upwards of 2000 to get one of these sigils to drop, which is infuriating.

With all of that said, I still believe this game is a solid 7.5/10, which in my book is solid. The only thing stopping this game from being an amazing release, is the RNG involved when it comes to sigils.

Granblue is superficial fun, and I don't mean that as an insult.

At the core of Relink is very satisfying gameplay mechanics centered around nearly two dozen different playable characters, all with their own unique styles.  When you find yourself content with one character, there are many more waiting for your attention.  Pair this with some very beautiful graphics, both in battle and out, and it paves the way for a ton of fun, especially with friends.

However, there are downsides.

For starters, in order to play with friends, you essentially have to get through several hours of single-player content first.  While it's possible to do so before that, you won't have access to everything.  And even then, that wouldn't be quite so bad if the story wasn't incredibly shallow.  But once you clear the story, you'll spend a lot of your time fighting RNG, whether it be for particular Sigils, materials, or endgame weapons.  The worst part of all this is you will take all this time making your character better, not so you can take on harder content, but rather so you can clear the content you've already cleared faster and/or easier.

This game is great, i've been playing it nonstop at 34 hrs here.

I'll start with my criticism for what i think are the negatives of this game
- The story is not very long ( 12-15 hrs)
- There are a bunch of reused bosses throughout the story and late game content

Now, this game has (in my opinion) some of the best combat out of any party-based rpg. It feels like Final Fantasy 16, Genshin Impact, and Monster Hunter mixed together. Theres a solid roster of characters that play differently and can add value to your party as companions. It has a addictive gameplay loop of going out on missions to fight bosses for materials to upgrade and craft new gear, similar to monster hunter, and its amazing. The story is kind of short but there's harder difficulties and way higher gear tiers and much more content to do. Not to mention there's co-op that works well.
I love this game and highly recommend it to any Final Fantasy, Monster Hunter, or Genshin Impact fans.

Tldr; I like the franchise but, gameplay left me frustrated. The dodge and guard does not make sense in this game. It does not feel fluid, compare with Nier, Bloodborne, or Sekiro which use the same. Finished them and unlike this game, I still wanna play it when I lost, why, because I know the mistake I did when my char dies.

To do a successful dodge, I need to instill Goku's ultra instinct and if I want to cheap by guarding, it has limit. To add, HP does not really matters with hit mostly can down me in 3 hits, in addition, there is no iFrame after getting hit like most games (MonHun) and dodge had cooldown after 3 attempts so if I didn't out of the cont AOE circle, might as well pray I went to heaven. Another thing to add, the Developer was doing a demo stream before and even them are having problem doing it when trying to showcase it, yet, they didn't think that's a problem.

Let's say I made the dodge successfully, it really does not matter as most of the time the BOSS atk are continuous, so out from Lion's mouth jz to know a Crocodile mouth is waiting. Continue if I got the perfect dodge and become invisible, there is no countdown until when the buff last and so I can't tell when I should be prepared to do another dodge.

Lastly, enemies atk is not telegraphed properly. They will give the usual glint that an atk is coming, but the wind up is questionable. Imagine someone said that they will poison your drink but didn't tell when, so you become aware of every water you drink. In addition, you got a choice to announce that it is poisoned but whenever it is wrong, you got slapped and the time you know it, you already lost the chance to announce it (3x dodge). Then, the enemies jz throw as many as atk they can do, like Neo fighting the Agents in the Matrix but you are not Neo.

Hitbox is also questionable. There are times I was out of the AOE area yet still got hit. I believe it is due to the weapon goes over. So, if the character forgot to cut their nails and it is inside the AOE, it damage the whole body, not just the nail. This contribute with perfect dodges.

The game is insanely polished. It's rare to get a full JRPG experience like this nowadays. Fairly unique as well. The is an ever increasing spectacle with great set pieces but avoiding to fall into the trap of making it not interactive or filling it with QTEs. Post game is a mix between PSO, Monster Hunter and a bit of Dragon's Crown with a similar look as the old original gacha game. Just more streamlined and 0 micro transactions.

My only issue with this is the roster choice again, forcing the entire fujo knight squad and randos like Ghanda instead of Ilsa, Bea, Aliza, Naoise or the infinite number of great characters they have, instead of Lance and Vane again.

Another small annoying thing is the utter pointless censorship. And with pointless I mean they cover like 1% more of someone's skin which you usually see in ports to china or SEA. New players that aren't familiar with the franchise might be a bit lost at the start because all the characters and such are already established and I doubt people will read journal lore to catch up.

Very fun and polished game. All lines are voiced. Japanese VAs are top of the line.

Gameplay is very satisfying. There are many different characters to choose from and it takes forever to fully build them, but they have different skills and playstyles. 

Bosses are ok, not amazing nor bad, but re-used a bit too much. 

Music department is lacking a bit, nothing to write home about.

Multiplayer experience is a mixed bag for me. When it works it is fun, but it is sometimes hard to find any people to play with on specific missions with MM. When MM to lower level missions the game adjusts character power so it is not one shotting everything, but I think that mechanic nerfs too much sometimes and takes away the whole point of building used character.

Story is dogwater. First 6 chapters are almost digestable, but anything chapter 7+ makes 0 sense. AI, given few iterations, would write something better. I cannot believe so much effort and polish went to this game just to tell such chaotic, idiotic, nonsensical story, without good (or any resonable) pacing and with terrible villains. Misstranslation of some dialogues is not helping either.

Overall it is ok. It heavily depends on what you expect to get from the game.



EDIT after "enjoying" endgame for 40+ hours:

Endgame grind is crazy. It takes forever to upgrade weapons and get best sigils. It took me around 30h to get last weapon for the character I wanted and upgrade it. It is random so depending on luck it may be faster or even slower. Farming last boss 150 times is not fun. I got weapons for half of characters. Best case scenario first try drops you the weapon, worst case statistically is around 400 runs. I cannot even imagine how many hours it will take to upgrade all characters. Clear influence of endless grind in the gatcha game that is the source material here. It should not be that bad in fully priced game! Even with 10x rates of drops I would be still having only half of rooster geared at this point... 
Then again I am not sure why I even farmed that much, since I already killed last boss 150 times.

The more I play the game the less I like it.

Any extra click in UI required to replay the mission will drive you crazy! Since you will have to grind same boss 10 times to get a single material piece to upgrade your weapon (and other boss 150+ times to get the weapon you want). 

It has same issues every single JRPG has, stupid & useless drop screens and point counting screens after the battle. Useless animations when fight starts and ends (useful first 10 times, the more you play the more annoying they are and you feel that time is being wasted). 

Boss battles will lock your movement and teleport you around the battlefield when phases change - this doesn't seem bad until it happens to you many, many times, but it will since you will have to grind same stupid bosses again and again and again. 

Not to mention lock-on system that doesn't work well with multiple enemies on the screen and camera that will kill you in fights when there is more than 1 boss on the field. 

Trading/upgrading system is pretty messy because it requires a lot of different mats for no reason, other than to make things more complex and harder to remember.

I am still leaving this as recommended, but be aware of what you are siging up for end-game wise.

Kinda of like a watered down budget knock off of a Tales game crossed with bare bones shallow as a puddle Monster Hunter game. It kinda works except the game retains way to much of its gacha roots. Drops rates are just way to low for no reason. There is way to much emphasis on maining a character rather letting you use the large and diverse styles of the characters.
The camera is abysmal and no matter settings you use it remains totally awful. Upgrades that you need for things while you are playing the story are not available until way after you need them, deep into proud mode and they are already completely obsolete. I want to like this game but it just makes me annoyed more than anything. There is also a bug that stops some drops from registering so you will probably need to use SAM complete them.
The controller stopped working like every 15 minutes for the first week which was pretty annoying. They thankfully patched that but they still dont have dual sense support even though the game is on PS which is pretty slack. The inventory system is inherently broken in regards to sigils. There is no way to get rid of them without generating more and you get stuck in a self sustaining infinite feedback loop. The knickknack cap needs to be increased atleast 10x and the game needs a use all knickknack voucher option as well just for basic QOL. The save system is also a complete dumpster fire as well. And lastly but not least attack canceling and exploits shouldn't be the optimal way to dps for like 90% of the roster. It totally sucks that actually getting good at most characters is completely pointless since just running up and jumping and spamming triangle in some cases does 500% more damage. The combat, voice acting and art in general is really good but it's just unfortunately let down in many other areas.

I wrote a review initially but decided to delete it for a more full review. Mainly because this game is a 10-20 single-player story tutorial followed by a 100+ hour end-game progression grind. Note, about 20-25% of my hours are AFK farming lol.

tl;dr - This is a 5/5 game for me personally. Granted, I'm into games with character/weapon variety, buildcrafting, boss encounters, and co-op. In general, if you like Monster Hunter, you'll probably like this game. It feels like a mix of Genshin/Nier Automata combat with Monster Hunter battles and progression. Also, the music is EPIC.
-----
The game drops you into what feels like the middle of the Granblue Fantasy story, and it's serviceable. The plot is very anime trope-y, and nothing to write home about. Honestly, the story is there to teach you the game and drip feed you boss mechanics. There are Fate episodes which are bits of text that give you more insight on each character plus give you free stats/sigil slots. If you want to see more, check out the Granblue anime which has 2 seasons.

The gameplay loop revolves around starting a quest with a party of four characters and completing a particular objective. Most of these will be boss fights, especially in end game. Each character (of which there are 20 currently) has a mechanic and passives specific to them which dictate their playstyle, along with up to 4 out of 7 skills to choose from (with one exception who has 12ish skills).

The end game grind is where the game is really at. Aside from mastering your chosen character, you will be upgrading your weapons, upgrading masteries (akin to skill trees), and farming for sigils. To achieve all this, you'll be taking on lots of quests, the most exciting and challenging of which are boss fights. These fights feel like raid bosses you would find in an MMO, requiring you to dodge attacks, pull off certain mechanics, and pass DPS checks.

The variety of characters plus the different ways to customize each character combine to give a huge degree of options to suit your playstyle.

Aside from all this, the game released in a relatively polished technical state. I haven't had any crashes, and matchmaking has been mostly great (most players are going to be at the higher difficulties, so matching at lower ones may not happen). Also, I feel like it's not talked enough but the music is BANGER. Every boss fight feels incredibly epic in part thanks to the great soundtrack. 

The other nice thing is that future content has already been announced, to include a boss raid in March and two new characters in April.

Minor gripes to keep in mind:
- The game will feel easy if you're used to boss battlers. Maniac (2nd hardest) is where you might sweat a little and fail some boss quests, but will mostly be alright. Proud ends up being a big difficulty spike, where you might fail more than you win if you're not careful.
- Getting the best gear in the game is a lot of RNG. This is especially so with each character's final weapon. Only one fight drops it, and not only is there only a chance to drop, but there's also a chance for it to be your main character's weapon. IE, it might not drop, and if it does, it might not be for the character you want.
- This also leads to one other gripe. You'll be fighting the same bosses a lot in order to farm, which might get stale if you're not into the grind. I hope they add more bosses in the future.
- If you plan on playing mostly solo, know that you're increasing your grind for character mats 3-4 fold. This is because every quest always has 4 characters. If you matchmake, you just have to worry about building the character you control and the other three players are the same. If you're solo, you have to build up the three AI characters in addition to your own character.
- Characters all have battle talk, and it might be grating or annoying if you're not used to it. Imagine Xenoblade Chronicles level of battle talk lol.
- The story is basically a really cliche anime. I thought it was fun, but it's not something to expect to be good..

Overall, I love this game. There's a lot to sink your teeth into, and the character variety really adds to the game for someone that likes to rotate and switch out every now and then. There is also confirmed future content through May, and this isn't even a live-service game.

If you're at all into character progression, boss raid encounters, and a whole lot of grinding, I highly recommend giving this game a go.

Good game that would work really well as an mmorpg (at least it doesn't kick you every time you complete a mission in multiplayer like some other games though), this is the kind of experience I hoped PSO2 NGS would provide, but instead it just did everything the original PSO2 did but worse. Anyway back to this game, really beautiful settings, that makes this world feel lived in without having to make an oversized open-world area. The areas feel the perfect size for the amount of things you have to do there while still looking great. The controls feel a little clunky, and should be more customizable (without having to use the steam controller configuration thing, which won't change the button icons on screen). But still enjoyable once you get used to it.

You can max every skill out for every character if you grind missions enough, but before then the skill tree is nice as it lets you go down a few different paths to max out different skills first. There are some characters that play similar roles, but generally most of them play differently still even then. I hope more content is added in the future with more content, and characters with more different playstyles.

Maybe there could be more content to experience the story of previous games in a new way, but in multiplayer, rather than being locked to single player only. Just so we dive more in the backstory of how the main characters got here, without having to  play the first GBF game.

I think some of the different gameplay we were introduced to in the story could be utilized more as possible mission types for multiplayer too. Overall though this was a really fun game, and I hope to see even more added onto it eventually, and more games like it. There is enough content don't get me wrong, it's a full game worth of content. I'm just saying I crave more like it.

Fun and addicting as fuck. I can't remember the last time I binged a game so hard and genuinely couldn't put it down. Rather than the comparisons to Monster Hunter I'd compare it more to something like Phantasy Star Online, Stranger of Paradise, and Toukiden - if you enjoyed those, you'll feel at home here. It kinda feels like an MMO-lite (complete with the hellish grind) action game but for 4 players, and I'm here for it.

The story was not for me, and is honestly some real generic anime garbage that was painful to wade through at times, but once you can finally play with friends - the gameplay loop is where it's at. Every time I'd start getting tired of the grind or how my character plays, I'd just play a different one and have a blast again. They all feel quite distinct and I haven't disliked any of them, when I normally do in similar games. Beyond just building for pure damage, there's a lot of room for goofy gimmick builds, which is always fun. There's just so many ways to consistently get a bit more powerful even in the endgame, it's an endless crack loop. But dear god, whoever decided it was a cool idea to have us kill [strike]Training Dummy[/strike] Proto Bahamut hundreds of times to obtain all of the endgame weapons, especially when several fights before it were both more interesting and difficult, is a bit of a dunce.

Aside from the story and a mild annoyance with sigil management, the only other gripe I have with the game is (unfortunately a big one) - a lack of different enemies, and difficulty. There's not much challenge when you become so powerful so quickly in the endgame, that there comes a point where you can just faceroll most things without even bothering to pay attention to much. Sure, you can impose difficulty on yourself by going in undergeared or with certain sigils - but I honestly just wish there was an extra difficulty that was actually challenging with more going on and doesn't let you die 20 times in a fight with zero repercussions, especially when the combat is on the simple side. We need a G rank. 

I hope that beyond the planned updates they consider doing a larger expansion one day, because the base here is so damn good, and I don't want this to be the end of it.

[strike]edit: Discovered that the game locks getting 100% achievements behind a $15 DLC with no content since it includes a weapon, that's fucking demonic. I still love the game, but damn that's sad.[/strike] They fixed it, nice.

Okay, I know I haven't played this game to completion, but seven hours in and to be honest I just don't feel the desire to continue playing any further.

Mostly I'm writing this review because I was tricked by a lot of people in the positive reviews section who compared the game to Monster Hunter.

It's not. It's really, really not. The only similarity it has with Monster Hunter even slightly is that you go to a hub area to prep, and then select a mission and head out. Other than that, it's a completely linear action game, with a very thin veneer of RPG mechanics on top that offer little more than make the experience grindy but ultimately unrewarding. Perhaps if I knew that going in, my review wouldn't be so negative.

Granblue: Relink isn't a BAD game, don't get me wrong, but it has far, far too many actual issues for me to consider it a good one. To get the positives out of the way, the combat feels punchy, the character synergies are quite good, and the MMO-meets-action style of combat is unique, kinda like a smoother and more streamlined Phantasy Star. That, and the main story's campaign missions have quite a lot of production value, both in its (poorly written) cutscenes and in its set piece battles.

But the core thing holding it all together just isn't good.
For starters, the best part of the game is hands-down the campaign (though it's really just a series of corridors where you have to survive waves of enemies), whilst the side missions in the co-op range from boring to tedious. This is a bad thing because the game has clearly been designed to be played in co-op from the get-go (although it's functional in single player), yet you don't even truly unlock the co-op mode until you complete the game. That is to say, each chapter unlocks a miniscule handful of 3-minute-long missions that somehow feel too long and too short at the same time. It's only these missions that can be played in co-op, not the campaign which is far more interesting and better paced, and worse is that you can't progress through the co-op missions to unlock new ones. If you bought this game to play with a friend like I did, you better hope all your friends have the patience to spend upwards of 12 hours of EXTREMELY linear missions to finish the story before you sit down to play together. Otherwise you're going to be playing for about 15 minutes at a time before you have to venture out for a half-to-an-hour quest solo before you can continue playing co-op with the scraps that is the side content.

Moreover, it doesn't take long for you to realize how stale the combat actually becomes. While each character does function differently, which is pretty nice and gives you incentive to switch between fights, all combat really boils down to is pressing the same combo for each character over and over again, then dodge, then use the Link skill when the meters fill. It is very flashy and has a nice feedback to it, but mechanically it's very drab and uninteresting. There's no real need to switch up your tactics, to change how you're fighting an enemy depending on the scenario or the location you're in, save for when you come to a boss fight which MAY offer some additional objectives, but those are few and far between.

Lastly, and I get that this part is where your mileage may vary, so far the story was just lousy. A lot of people are claiming that the issue lies in the localization, but I really don't think that localization is the issue as opposed to just the story and world itself. I'll probably come back and finish the story eventually just to see where it goes, and I won't be making a comment on the story other than it seems to just have literally every trope in the book so far. But as it stands this just isn't the 10/10 JRPG people are making it out to be. It's not even an RPG to begin with, for that matter.

(1) Story/Lore: Unfortunately/too short and could be longer. Lore is great.
(2) Contents: Unfortunately/too little missions or quests to do and things can get really repetitive.
(3) Game play: Excellent/nothing to complain about.
(4) Character/Art Design: Fantastic and you can see the effort placed into the character's drawings.
(5) Difficulty: Well done, and also fun to see multiple bosses making the mission rather funny and messy.
(6) Farm/Grind Element: Acceptable/Understandable.

Some thoughts: 
(1) The true beginning of this game is after you've finished the main story. Everything will start to get harder and you will be expected to do some grinding along the way.
(2) There are RNG (i.e. luck element involved in terms of getting the genes and loot drops), but since you'll be doing lots of grinds, having a healthy mindset will make you last longer.
(3) This game expects you to go grindy and farming. The game may not be for you if you are expecting a no grind and no farm.
(4) The game is an action game that requires skills. So yes, you will just have to 'get better' if you cannot complete a particular mission.

This game makes me wish steam let us have a mixed rating instead of up or down.
90% of this game is utterly fantastic. The combat is fluid and snappy. Every character is unique with its own moveset and skills. The bosses are great and the story, although generic, is passable. This game is an odd mix of Tales combat with Monster Hunter progression and does amazingly at both.

However, that last 10% can make or break you. Where the game falls flat is the post-game (proud mode) progression. The endgame grind consists of some of the worst gacha-style mechanics with drop rates less than 1% effectively capping progression on super rng. This is made worse due to the multiple layers of this gacha-style mechanics and low drop rates for upgrade materials. This in turn makes the end game a grind fest of doing the same few missions at an excessive rate for no real progression.

I would still recommend this game as everything leading up to the endgame grind is utterly fantastic. Most people probably won't reach that grind until they are 20-40hrs in and you may find yourself willing to overlook the bad gacha. As of this review, there are no true microtransactions, everything minus a few colors are free, and the devs plan on adding more content. However, if you are the type of person who truly hates gacha style loot the end game will drive you away.

A "simple Monster Hunter-like game" where you beat up monsters and upgrade equipment.

I say its good because its simple. I don't need to sharpen my weapons, eat food, manage stamina gauge, etc. Perfect for semi fans(?) of the MH-like genre who like beating monsters but hate micromanagement of resources midfight. Just go in, beat things up, get out.

It is an aggressively ok game.

-Combat is very satisfying and a lot of fun. Each character feels unique, each with their own strengths and weaknesses. Not much to say outside of that, I don't personally have any issue with any of its mechanics its just a lot of fun to smack enemies and will probably keep returning to the game in the future because of it.

-Story is ok and roughly 20-30 hours long, generic enough jrpg plot but that's not really a negative. Not knowing any of the story of Granblue to begin with and the story expecting you to already know all the characters makes it really hard to follow along. And locking HP and attack power behind individual character lore/stories is kinda messed up but whatever lol.

-Voice acting is alright, Siegfried is a bit rough but its the cut in voice lines characters make in the levels so horrendously bad I had to mute the dialogue. I never hated a character more than I did Io.

-Graphics and Performance was stellar. Gorgeous game that ran wonderfully. Never had frames drops or any noticeable bugs despite how busy the screen gets.

My feelings on this game are mixed. What I did experience was really good, but I feel there was not really enough good to justify the price.

I got drawn in by the gorgeous artwork, grand and beautiful music, and the admittedly very fun gameplay . The story though is short. I spent just a little over 20 hours in-game to beat it, and I only had to do side quests twice to buff up my party a little bit. The story is not great, but not awful either. It's fairly generic fare, and the characters don't really get a whole lot of development.

Each recruitable party member has their own unique combat style. If you're the kind of person who loves to try all sorts of different things, you won't be bored. 

I have heard it said that the real game starts after the story. I suppose that is true in a sense. After the main quest, the game gives you a lot more side quests. You can grind for XP and mastery points to level up your characters and gear. It's like it's trying to be like Monster Hunter, except I feel there is nowhere near enough variety and depth to justify hours of grinding when the story has long ended.

tl;dr: Game is worth it for the gameplay, art, and music, but in my opinion does not offer a great deal of long term value. Grab on a sale.

I really wanted to like this game but I just can't. The combat is fun enough and the progression is pretty nice but the endgame is not very fun (and the story is horrible but I imagine most people aren't playing for the story). It seems like they gave many of the difficult fights very tight damage checks that if failed would end the quest immediately which was very annoying to do solo (with AI companions). It required me to run very specific builds and not let me build the characters the way I wanted to (there are so many interesting skills that just aren't viable), which made my experience much less fun.  I'm sure its better when doing multiplayer but as for someone who loves solo play, after having beat Proto Bahamut in proud difficulty, I can definitely say this game is not for me.

A decent ARPG, the story is kinda of generic anime story. The characters all feel unique and fun to play. The endgame grind and suedo gacha stuff is off putting. Solid 7/10

review from someone who wholeheartedly loves plot-heavy rpgs. (ff, skyrim, persona) and action-packed gameplay (dynasty warriors, lost ark)

it's a hard recommend from me.

[b]story: 5/10[/b]

the only disappointing part of the game imo. as someone who has step foot in the gbf universe before, i really wasn't expecting too much in terms of plot depth and complexity or any overarching themes. really is just your cookie-cutter fantasy story: lacking in true tension and substance and really doesn't engage me enough. characters are just thrown in without any real consideration or gravitas and half-explored: which does slightly hurt the immersion, but not by too much.

however the story isn't catastrophic, and serves as decent stepping stones and gives enough context and world building for the true endgame later on.


p.s IF YOU'RE LOOKING FOR A STORY-FOCUSED GAME DO NOT COP THIS.

[b]production: 10/10[/b]

phenomenal. a very fucking well-polished game; probably one of the best ones in the industry atm. 

the visuals are stunning and perfectly encapsulates the fantasy in granblue: towns are intricately designed with attention to detail. no choppy character models and well thought-out levels. nothing much else to be said here: gbf relink is vibrant, colorful and filled with passion.

the cast of voice actors (i play with jp dub/eng sub) have done an excellent job in portraying their respective characters and brimming them with life. a few familiar ones too. (for those who enjoy anime)

the soundtrack is insane. almost all the boss osts gave me goosebumps on my playthrough. it really kept me captivated and my experience elevated.

[b]gameplay: 9/10[/b]

having played quite a bit of action rpgs and mmos before, i'm a big fan of the raiding system and it's elements. gbf relink has a fluid and well-crafted action system that leaves the player satisfied after every fight. personally i really dig the full-burst attack as it really emphasises on a collaborative effort.

variety is great, like how in monhun gameplay varies by weapon, in gbf relink it varies by character. characters are very in-depth in their individual mechanics and personally it's really fun discovering a new character's kit for the first time.

have to state that multiplayer runs very smoothly as well for the few times i've tried it so far.

[b]replayability: 9.5/10[/b]

with these games, i often adopt a very completionist mindset where i want to collect every achievement, max every weapon/characters, etc. 

with how the game is stylised similar to monhun, completing quests and killing bosses repeatedly is something i really enjoy. additionally, nothing is timegated so it really does appeal to people who occasionally may not have the time to log on (me too sometimes) and allows you to progress at your own pace.

despite probably not being a live-service game, i'm sure cygames will pump out significant updates in the future; so hopefully we'll enjoy more content down the road.

[b]final thoughts[/b]

the game's great and is a must-cop for any action-rpg fan: i can definitely foresee myself dumping hundreds of hours into completing the game in the future.

It is a great Action-RPG. Cool moves, no frame drops and fluid gameplay.

BUT

This game was easy to beat even before awakening the first weapon. After getting a Terminus Weapon...man with a decent team even the last boss with power level 17500 is so easy, you beat him by skipping 2 of his phases with stuns, dmg and the 2+2 burst strat.

Hardest fight is maglie and gallanza at power level 16000. Your character reaches that level even before awakening a weapon. And with terminus weapon you are 22000+ power level. There are no fights in this game where you need insane gear like that.

Just one new "very hard" raid they promised us won´t cut it...

And btw, having only 1 boss fight to farm terminus weapons (best weapon for all of the 20 characters) is also not good...gets a bit boring to rinse and repeat 1 boss only.

Also getting 1 char to max is pretty nice from the game pacing perspective, but if you want to do more, then it is not worth your time...ppl even startet to AFK farm because of this issue. just check youtube.
Balance the damn loot table and difficulties (or add one above proud with new boss moves at least)

Summary:
x If the devs dont give us content that is hard to beat...why should we farm stronger gear? Just to kill the bosses even faster than 2mins? Pls...harder bosses/difficulty.
x If we get so many playable characters, it should be more accessable to get multiple chars up to max weapon level without afk farm. (again, higher difficulty with higher %drop chance could fix that if done right)

Without spoiling too much, the story goes like:
Day 1: kill some goblins
Day 2: princess got kidnapped by cultists
Day 3: You attempt rescue, the cultists stomped you and sh*t on your face.
Day 4: You attempt rescue, the cultists stomped you and sh*t on your face.
Day 5: You attempt rescue, the cultists stomped you and sh*t on your face.
(no, these have nothing to do with you actual skill,  just scripted fights which you lose.)
Day 6: With the power of friendship you finally get the rescue, but the cultist boss already got the what they need to screw the entire world. 
Day 6.5: You try to stop them by beat the sh*t out of the super badass demigod-monster-creature summoned by the baddie in an epic battle (before which you again get stomped by scripted fight).
Day 6.75: Nevermind, baddie summons another super badass demigod-monster-creature, and all of your efforts went futile. F*ck you I guess?
Day 7: idk didn't play, I'm currently looking for a mod that skips the entire campaign.

So yeah no would not recommend, unless you love being the stereotypical JRPG hero or you love seeing all of your effort goes to waste.
One might argue that the gameplay is pretty neat and I agree. You get many options to choose from, and the bosses are generally quite fun to play against. But, I'm paying for the whole game so I wish to enjoy the whole game. Would you order a pizza just to find out that 1/3 of it is spoiled, and yet still give it a 5 star rating? Probably not.

Absolutely smitten with this game. Anime? Not my scene, typically sends me running for the hills. But Granblue Fantasy Relink? It's like discovering the anime universe rolled out the red carpet just for me. The visuals? Chef's kiss. Pure magic.

Combos and I usually mix like oil and water—I'm the one floundering while everyone else swims. Yet, here I am, diving headfirst, eager to get my combo game on point.

The battles? Epic doesn't even start to cover it. And the character roster? A smorgasbord of fun waiting to be unleashed.

EDIT: But hold up—after clocking in over 100 hours, it's time for a reality check. My thrill-o-meter hits a slump unless I'm duking it out with dragons or those mega crocs. Why the dip? Because every other boss feels like a marathon of cutscenes or a crash course in gimmickry. Let me pummel those bosses with style, not with a side of eye-roll-worthy tricks or cinematic fluff that drags on forever. And I mean, forever. The more you beat the crud out of 'em, the more cutscenes there are!

And let's talk about the sigil mess. Echoing players before me, the whole dance of transmuting sigils or tossing the rejects feels like a black hole for my precious gaming hours.
 
I've lost that loving feeling and Dragon's Dogma 2 can't arrive soon enuff.

The camera randomly re-positions (with all adjustments turned OFF of course), and is extremely clumsy to use. Suddenly dips down to the ground for no reason. I've never actually dropped a game because of poor camera control and this would be the very first. Will revert rating once devs fix this completely gamebreaking issue making this one unplayable.

Really wanted to like this game. Got through the main campaign and to the prologue, was hoping issues with combat would get better, but so far they havent. The lock-on is both too hard of a lock on and too soft. Unlike the souls-like I've played, it doesnt track very well, so bosses/targets will often be off screen or at the very edge (and some of the larger bosses, you cant see your character). Additionally, when locked on, it doesnt allow for changing the camera, so you have to unlock do do mechanics. So it just feels like you are fighting the camera more then then the bosses themselves. Some of the character side stories have you fight bosses that are anti the character you are forced to play, and without a party, which makes some of the side stories unnecessarily tedious. Fighting ranged mobs is just a pain, since multiple of them will target you at once and attack at different times, without constant stagger resistance, you'll either be stun locked or constantly dodging and unable to kill the mobs. It might just be age making me slower, but IMO the combat of early Vindictus (pre-season 2) was better.

After 35 hours and finishing Chapter 0, I would to like stand myself corrected with my previous review.

The game actually offers destructible parts in the boss. And what's more is that the player will also be able to use and control Bahamut. [SPOILER ALERT] The Bahamut against Bahamut Versa is so satisfying. It reminds me of the dot hack GU.

As to the difficulty, the more you unlock, like the Maniac and Proud, the game actually offers a lot of challenging gameplay, which is contrary to the difficulty I earlier stated in my previous review. Yes. The game is actually hard at some point.

The only thing I have reservation with, is the full auto assist mode, which allows you to farm afk for materials. It's just a Quality of Life option but it becomes a necessity at the end of the game if you want to Min-Max the game. Thus, making one player leave the game on even in their sleep, if they intend to maximize the efficiency in farming for the materials they would need.

This game really surprised me with how good it is. Combat, boss fights, the music, the art style and visuals are all fantastic. The game is very well optimized and runs well with no framerate drops or problems even with all the chaos of a big fight going on

The only downside to this game is the story, which really just feels like it gets in the way for the first 15 hours or so. When you complete the main story, it feels like you can finally just play the game and enjoy everything that's great about it

The bosses are what impressed me most and I'm not usually into games that are so focused on boss fights. But the boss designs, the music choices, the brief cinematics that play and presentation of the fights as a whole are so good, and every new boss you face just seems to outdo the last

This is just a great fun game with amazing gameplay and is definitely worth the price. Again, I typically don't like boss fight games or JRPGs but this game just did so many things so well.

Honestly, a pretty amazing action JRPG. I've never played GBF before but I was very impressed.

JRPG equivalent of Mad Max: Fury Road. After brief introductions, this game is nothing but pure adrenaline. Between short breathers, you are back into absolutely ludicrous action. Combat is fast and damn fun. It's a very fun game to play and there is no time to get bored.

The story is very cliche and unoriginal. But the raw gameplay easily makes up for what the story lacks.

Combat is the main focus of the game and it feels damn good, no matter what class of characters you pick. All 17 characters feel good in their own way, though some are, of course, better than others. Overall, the combat is fluid and responsive. The end-game loop revolves around min-maxing your characters to complete harder and harder content. This process is kind of grindy, but not as grindy as an MMO and is also not time-gated, which is a big plus for me.

One complaint I have about the game is the "padding" of play-time by leaving one of the best stats in the game down to RNG (0.06% chance of getting what you need). But that aside, the game is still very fun and a 9/10 for me personally.

I never played the original Granblue so I cannot say with certainty how many of these mechanics are granblue originals or not, but essentially, the game comes across as a high-octane and much easier and forgiving monster hunter style game with many other elements from different titles. The combat feels similar to a tales-esk game but pushed to the maximum in terms of how over-the-top it is.

Unfortunately, this game is also plagued with similar problems as modern monster hunter 5, but worse. It lacks a sufficient end game of any kind, does not provide any sort of "endless" or randomly generated missions to grind, and no obvious account ranking system. Despite this, the game still manages to bar your ability to build and max out your team of four characters through rng systems and the requirement of many many low drop chance items. Additionally, virtually every character is funneled through basically the same end game build: stack damage cap gems as high as possible. If Granblue Fantasy was going for a much more casual style of game that you beat and then move on from, then why require such a grind?

This game would be greatly improved with the addition of:
1) A random matchmaking lobby to accelerate matchmaking speed
2) The ability to move around towns while waiting in queue
3) Additional rewards for completing random hunts with strangers online
4) Copy monster hunter and add "investigations", "anomaly hunts", or missions that randomly generate a combination of enemies you have to beat in waves, instead of all at once, as well as more mission structures that aren't centered around just killing a boss
5) After maxing a weapon to level 150, make every subsequent weapon easier and cheaper to upgrade or craft; Same for character levels. The game forces you to hard commit to one main character for too long before you farm out enough materials to play other characters comfortably.
6) remove damage cap entirely, it is a bad system and forces you into always using gems to upcap it, making more versatile builds impossible. 
7) Rushing through the story feels sort of bad. Advancing the story isn't barred behind an account level system, so you can ignore every side mission, put the game on journalist difficulty, and speed run through the whole game in about 6 hours or less. Makes the game feel empty.
8) Having chests, slimes, and crabs really only farmable by replaying story missions after finishing the game is a drag. Make more game modes that are open world, where you go to an overworld, explore it as your own pace, and hunt monsters that spawn there, then leave when you feel like it. That, or just dont have collection systems in a game like this, it doesn't work that well in my opinion. 

Overall, the game feels pretty light weight. Its fun, sure, but I completed every single mission in the game from easy to proud difficulty in 30 hours and really dont feel much of an incentive as a player to continue on. Its a good starting point and framework as a start to a potential franchise, but needs a lot more work on content, endgame, pacing, systems, and scope to feel like a fully realized game.

"Granblue Fantasy: Relink" emerges as a polished action RPG that strikes a harmonious balance between engaging gameplay, compelling character diversity, and an expansive world rooted in the rich lore of the Granblue Fantasy universe. It delivers a seamless experience across platforms, performing admirably on both PC and the Steam Deck, with minor hiccups such as an unplayable cutscene on the latter device only slightly marring an otherwise smooth presentation.

The game, while accessible to newcomers of the Granblue Fantasy series, offers depth and complexity that will satisfy veterans. Its combat system, favorably compared to Platinum Games' offerings, blends strategic depth with accessible mechanics, ensuring a rewarding experience for players of all skill levels. Characters are distinct and versatile, allowing for a range of playstyles and strategic experimentation, further enriched by a system of mastery points, weapons, and levels that encourages players to delve into post-story content.

Despite its strengths, "Granblue Fantasy: Relink" is not without its flaws. Some players have noted the generic nature of its story, critiquing it as a conventional tale of good versus evil that fails to innovate within the genre. The voice acting and localization have also drawn criticism, with a strong recommendation to switch to the Japanese voice acting for a superior auditory experience. Additionally, the game's approach to multiplayer and difficulty balancing has been a point of contention, with disparities in challenge between solo and co-op play and an overreliance on DPS checks in boss fights.

The game's visual and audio presentation has been universally praised, with stunning environments, character designs, and a soundtrack that elevates the overall experience. The attention to detail in the game's art direction and the quality of life features stand out as highlights, providing a visually cohesive and user-friendly experience.

"Granblue Fantasy: Relink" positions itself as a must-play for fans of the action RPG genre, offering a satisfying blend of combat, exploration, and character progression. Its gameplay loop is addictive, drawing players into its world with the promise of new challenges and rewards. The planned updates and expansions indicate a commitment to the game's longevity, promising to address some of the current criticisms and expand on its already rich foundation.

In conclusion, "Granblue Fantasy: Relink" is a testament to the potential of the Granblue Fantasy franchise in the realm of action RPGs. Despite its imperfections, the game offers a compelling experience that rewards player investment with deep gameplay, a diverse cast of characters, and a world that begs to be explored. It stands as a beacon for what the genre can offer, inviting both newcomers and seasoned players to partake in its grand adventure.

I'm a big fan of all the games I'm about to compare this game to, and know that those comparisons are compliments. 

Granblue Fantasy: Relink is my new go-to proof that people obsessing over the concept of originality, who are scared to make music/art/books etc. because they're worried they'll be 'derivative', who edit the soul out of what they make because it's too close to something that already exists, are [i]missing the point.[/i]

This game draws heavily from Monster Hunter and from Final Fantasy XIV, and does what it does in many ways better than those games do. Excellent! Perfect! That's exactly what I would want! Who doesn't want more of something they like that's better?

I have no interest in gacha and will never play one, so it was a huge surprise to me to learn that this setting is actually REALLY COOL and the narrative, while not innovative in any way, is a fun exploration of an offshoot of this setting that goes out of its way to illustrate just how WILD it can be.

I am convinced that Monster Hunter: Rise, a game I very much love, would be about as good as this game if it didn't have the ability to draw from past Monster Hunter titles. Yes, Relink does not have as many enemies or as much enemy variety as a series that has been building up a monster catalog since the PS2. Yes, Relink does not have as many boss fights or as in-depth a story as FFXIV (which is over 10 years old). What it does have is an EXCELLENT base with plenty to do.

I'm 63 hours in and find some of the complaints I've seen to be extremely amusing. I've heard the game described as "grindy". This is not grindy. Doing things that you enjoy doing to Make Number Get Bigger is not really a [i]grind[/i], it's playing a game?

Moreover, it's far easier and more consistent to get materials that you want from doing late-game fights in this game than in any of its peers. I'm currently working on maxing out weapons and characters, and I have thus far found exactly one material that is "difficult" to farm, and what that actually means is that sometimes when I do the mission to get it I don't get it.

Meanwhile, this game is competing with Monster Hunter, where wyvern gems are the bane of my existence. It has a built-in pity system for most resources, too, which is very nice!

I cannot emphasize enough how much, gameplay-wise, this is Monster Hunter Final Fantasy XIV. The characters control like Monster Hunter and many have really fascinating and awesome tech that makes them have way more depth than they initially seem (as two big examples: Percival can dodge cancel his offensive skills to rapidly charge his heavy attack for BIG damage, and Katalina can cancel the end of her Ares combo into any damaging skill and right back into Ares for HUGE sustained damage. There's plenty of this kind of thing.)

My biggest complaint is that even though the game explains a LOT (and has a LOT to explain to a brand new player to this series) it could still stand to explain a lot of the more advanced gameplay concepts better than it does. There are tutorials, but they're fairly short and come very quickly early on. I also find it odd that the journal is a completely separate loading screen and can make it feel a bit clunky to look things up. Also if the game DOES tell you to go to the trophies menu so you can claim rewards that you get from getting trophies, I sure didn't see that until I went to the menu 60 hours into playing and had a huge pile of rewards to claim. (Thankfully, you can get them all in a single button press.)

My only other complaint is that I feel like the difficulty curve is a cliff. Easy, normal, hard, and extreme missions are all fairly straightforward and easy. Then you hit Maniac and suddenly boss fights ROCK YOUR ASS and you had BETTER have learned how to survive the now much more complicated and aggressive boss patterns. One in particular has been kicking my ass (not that that's a bad thing; I appreciate the challenge!) and I really think the game could stand to have made Hard and Extreme more difficult so there was more of a curve there, because it definitely felt like hitting a brick wall.

I also wish that Quick Mission would check your character's stats before deciding what mission to send you on; I may have accidentally gone into a mission once with a character at /half/ the recommended strength because I wasn't thinking (the previous four had all been low level!)

In short: Character progression is straightforward, pretty much every character is fun (Charlotta hurts my hands to play, too much mash </3), unlocking characters isn't obnoxious or RNG based, and the only real RNG I'm running into is basically just Decorations from Monster Hunter World, with the caveat being that it's pretty straightforward and easy to get GOOD sigils, it's just RNG heavy to get THE BEST sigils. So you don't have that feeling of being useless that World gives you if you dare to fail to at acquiring multiple Attack gems when the acquisition rate is something absurd like 1%.

Some people have complained that there's a damage cap mechanic here in Granblue. I think it's brilliant. If you think about it, EVERY game has a damage cap, the game just doesn't tell you you've hit it - and the 'meta' is to tailor your entire build around meeting it. At the end of the day, you've hit "damage cap" in Monster Hunter when you've fully minmaxed your offensive stats, right?

Granblue finally solves the issue that is at the heart of Monster Hunter: the divide between "people using maxed out glass cannon high skill builds" VS "people that want some comfiness in their build". Here in Granblue, when you're at the end of the game and have a completely turbomax meta endgame perfect super special build, you're going to STILL have slots open you can put into any utility or QoL you want. That's AWESOME. This is a brilliant way to enable and encourage build creativity that every game in this genre should steal.

(Key to it is that the damage caps are rather high, and easy to raise a significant amount with your build)

This game RULES. I highly recommend it to anyone who likes Monster Hunter and/or wants to experience a pretty damn cool setting with VERY GOOD gameplay.

Gameplay is amazing if you're not looking for Devil May Cry depth, but is ridiculously easy, even when fighting the last boss.

Story is...Monster Hunter levels of engaging. Serviceable, but only as a vehicle to get you to kill things. The game does nothing to get you invested in the characters or story, save for putting walls of text onto a static png, which you unfortunately can't ignore if you want to increase your characters' stats. The questionable localization doesn't help either. If you understand Japanese but play with English subtitles, be prepared to be very distracted by how different the dialogue is. Fortunately, mashing the A button is a thing that exists. But if you're in it only for the action anime gameplay, then you'll have a pretty fun time.

Grinding is a huge pain, expect to spend gatcha game level of hours grinding and grinding if you want to max out a single character. On the other hand, if you like grinding endlessly on the same content over and over, then this is the game for you. Just be aware that, if you think Monster Hunter grinding is long, then this game is even more so.

However, if you're someone who likes arcade-y action games who honestly doesn't care about the story and doesn't mind the limited amount of bosses, then this game will be a pretty fun time.

Yes, this game is censored. I'm not going to tell you what to feel about it, if this is something preventing you from buying it, then all the power to you. It's a fun game and all, However, the end game is boring and match-making with random sucks. If you're a solo player and expecting fun times at random, I would not recommend this game. If you have friends that play, heck yeah, this is the game for you. That said, the end game grinds solo is rough, you have 4 characters to max out, and each one takes a good 10–15 hours depending on how efficient you are. But when you have those initial 4 characters maxed out, you have another end game grind to your character and that is where the game falls off. You're stuck doing the same quest over and over. Matchmaking has no intensive other than daily tickets you can spend on special items. There is a chance you will lose a match at random, and they won't restart, or you, join a match, and you can't hold your own and die pretty much instantly.

Again, as a solo player, this game is fun till the end of the game and match-making is horrible because most people beat the game, so good luck matching with, random people. I'm about half way, heck not even halfway through the end game and I'm stuck and bored with the repetitive nature of the end game. If match making was better, I'd have a lot more fun, but there just aren't enough players to make it fun. 

Solo game is fun, but it just doesn't compare with playing with real people. The CPU AI is good and all, but like I said, you can't beat a human.

The game interface is pretty neat and visually there isn't anything wrong, but the game fails a lot in terms of story progress and content balance.
The game story is something you can play throught in about a single day if you don't focus on grinding items to get stronger, since even on hard mode, you can easily finish it even if you're underleveled as long as you're skilled in dodging and blocking.
On hard mode I easily defeated a challenge lvl 60 when my group was all lvl 30's.

The biggest issue the game has, would probably be called a feature by the developer team... basically after you play through the story, there is a lot of "content", doing quests on the guild/hub or having a new start with a new unlocked difficulty.
Why is that an issue?
Well, when the main story is completed, we consider the game finished, done, finito.
Besides starting a new game difficulty, why would I care to go back, grind more and finish side quests then?
Making it an option to play certain chapters again to find stuff you missed instead of having an open explorable map that isn't limited to finishing the story first... is a huge mistake.

Something else worth mentioning, would be the ship you travel around with.
There could've been so much potential on adding all kinds of mechanics and character development, but no, you just have a single layered platform in form of a ship were everyone is on top of.
It hurts so bad, not being able to enter the doors, interact with the crew when you feel like it or even have something casual there. Instead it's working as a kind of a passage to go to the mission only.

Now something that makes me actually grind my teeth or slap my own face, is the fact that during the story the group meets an enemy and instead of jumping on them to start a fight, they just start having a long speech. 
The main antagonist, keeps repeating herself to no end after each encounter, so much that I can't hear her talking anymore.
This besides mentioning, that it's a bit of sad that the female voices of the playable characters in English Dub, are shocking to hear, since you would expect something more... japanese kind of cute and not... woman with a deeper voice.

The combat system is quite irritating, to the point someone could break the keyboard if you play as "Io".
The camera focus is a pain sometimes, and the worst of all are the boss fights.
I'm not so good with close combat, I do like to play as siegfried though, but after hearing him say all the time, "This is power" I decided to just play as "Io".
"Io" is a character that channels a lot during combat. While fighting bosses, her channel gets canceled a lot because of transformations or "cinematic moments", this is specially painful during quests you want to kill the boss in less than 2 minutes to get the highest ranking.
This could be considered a game breaking bug for people that mainly play as "Io" since the impact of it on her is so big.

Overall, the game does also have a fair amount of good aspects.
But sometimes it just feels a bit like "copy paste" because of the lack of polish.
And the main issue that the game gives the players the best part of what they want, when it's already finished and it doesn't really matter anymore to some players.

To put it short, the game was a potential gem, but it ended up as it is, because there was some lack of consideration towards players and for some reason everything was made in a rush???
This game as been a lot of fun. I don't have constant game time like I did in the past, so being able to play with the AI has been great.

You should honestly just play this game. Endgame grind with your friends and become an absolute monster, plus the story while a bit cliché was super hype and fun and honestly not that long compared to other J ARPGS!

However, the English translation is pretty weird. I do understand the context of what they're going for but it feels mostly unnecessary for what they're trying to achieve, creating weird characterizations with certain characters and even makes some events feel odd. I'm not asking for a direct Japanese-English translation but it could've been way better than what we have right now. Usually things like this don't bother me but this one is very noticeable and is so far the only thing that I've been concerned with throughout my current playtime.

Overall, still a good game. I really enjoy the grind and the game itself for how it looks and plays, looking forward to future expansions and DLCs. Hoping to keep playing this in the long term.

TLDR; A good JRPG hindered by its story's pacing and bland cast. Incredible visual art style, smooth animations, responsive and snappy combat, epic combat scenarios and a good endgame loop. 

I have not played any Granblue game but I do know that this franchise exists. Having said that, I have not found the story of this game overwhelming. It eases you into knowing the cast, their history, and the world they live in. While that is a good thing, as someone new to this franchise, the story fails to keep me interested with these individuals. Additional info per character IS available through reading a wall of text, unlike some JRPGs where they take time introducing you to the cast. Another problem with the story is how it is paced. Characters introduced throughout the main scenario aren't given enough screen time for character development. The crew jumps from one battle to another with not enough downtime in between to help you digest what has happened. My last gripe with the story is the dialog. Yes, JRPGs are notorious for corny and cringey dialog, but in my opinion, this one takes the cake. With the lack of proper pacing plus the lack of historical knowledge of these characters and their bond with each other, it feels cornier than usual when they say their corny lines. While the story lacks individual character arcs, proper pacing, and better dialog. It is still digestible since the game only has 10 chapters and the story can be finished in 10-15 hours, maybe less. 

If you can treat the story as background noise, then you will be treated with artistic visuals, responsive combat, epic boss fights and combat scenarios, and an endgame loop that will make you want to keep playing long after the story is over. 

Oh yeah, there is also online co-op. So participate in Jolly Cooperation!

Bought this game at day 1, took me 126 hours to complete the side quest and the beat final bosses (proud proto bahamut), the game are split into 2 mode which are story mode (single player) and quest mode(coop). Here are the pros and cons:

✔ Good optimization at day 1 with no stutter or fps drop at 1080p ultra (Ryzen 5 5600, RX6700XT, 32GB RAM, SSD)
✔ Engaging boss battle (like monster hunter/god eater)
✔ No micro-transaction or P2W element
✔ Japanese VA
✔ Smooth and fluid animation during combat mechanic (doing combo+skill+link+break+art+burst)

✖ No side activity or mini game (side quest are too simple and not engaging)
✖ Not open world or at least explorable world like monster hunter world when doing boss quest
✖ Not so many bosses *maybe added in the future update or DLC

Background: After 200+ hours so far, I have managed to fully awaken 6 (Percival, Lancelot, Vane, Charlotta, Io, and Eugen) weapons. I am intending to awaken the rest of the characters in due time. Fully farmed all content in the game both with online matchmaking and AI companions. Let me give a quick review for this game.

PROS:
* Excellent combat engine with fast paced and deep mechanics and high ceiling on some characters.
* Fluid, lifelike, and gorgeous art and animations. The Cygames team have an excellent engine on their hands.
* None of the characters that I've tried and learned play similarly to each other. Each character have their own strength, weakness, and key mechanics.
* Characters are very endearing and there are unique banters within special set of characters.
* For your first character, very few grind is required even to fully awaken your terminus weapon.
* Some of the bosses have great and interesting mechanics.

CONS:
* Currently (February 2024) none of the endgame bosses require high damage or mechanical mastery.
* Sigils which are a big part of power progression are mainly received from a menu that requires too many clicks. Highly recommend setting up your Steam Controls with a way to turbo the Sigil opening with vendor.
* When you want to make your other characters stronger, you will have to grind for many materials and sometimes due to efficiency you end up farming lower level contents instead of the Proud (highest difficulty) contents. Probably need to tweak Proud fight rewards.
* Story is very weak but serviceable.

A very interesting part of this game is also the possibility to farm materials and fights with your AI. Your AI companions will always have AI control, but your player character can only use AI up until Extreme difficulty. For Maniac and Proud difficulty, your character cannot be controlled by AI however if your other 3 companions are strong enough it is possible to farm Proud content fully AFK with AI.

One important point about AI farming is that it will only do it for 10 times before a prompt will show up on your screen asking you if you want to continue. This means AI farming can be done in the day while you are doing your daily errands and work but it cannot farm by itself while you sleep. I think it's an important disctinction.

Overall, I find the game to be truly refreshing for not using any Gamepass or FOMO tactics to make people keep playing. People keep playing due to its gameplay and all we're missing are harder bosses and various contents. Looking at other Granblue franchise history, they seem to have enough things cooking to be able to do this similar to Monster Hunter. Give some time limited collaborations, add harder bosses overtime, and drop a full-fledged DLC after a year or two.

Performance: Not a single issue if all playtime (no crashes, stutters or fps drops). Though that may not apply to everyone.
The game is really fun when you play with other online. Story was...kind of "meh" but you breeze through it easily. Characters are very fun to play and you unlock more of them, with more variety in playstyle.
Eng game weapons are a grind for drops, but all it took is a few hours and all my characters got theirs so its not as bad as some make it out to be.
If you liked monster hunter games, you will like this one. Though I have to say even the hardest difficulty missions are easy, so tha game as a whole is easy and not to challenging. You can play it solo with AI party or with people online.
