[h1]Gran Blue Fantasy: Relink Review [/h1]
[hr][/hr]
[h3][i] Overview [/i][/h3]
[i] If you're a fan of immersive, action-packed gameplay experiences akin to Monster Hunter or the expansive worlds and diverse character options found in Final Fantasy XIV, then Granblue Fantasy Relink is an absolute must-play. Its robust endgame content ensures that the adventure doesn't end with the main story, providing ample opportunities for continued excitement and challenge. With a vast array of characters boasting unique playstyles, abilities, and backgrounds, there's something to suit every taste and preference, whether you prefer to dive into the fray with a heavy-hitting warrior, support your allies with powerful magic, or outmaneuver foes with swift and agile tactics. Granblue Fantasy Relink offers a breadth of gameplay possibilities that will undoubtedly capture your imagination and keep you coming back for more.[/i]

[h3]Story[/h3]
[hr][/hr]
Embark on an epic journey through the vast skies and mystical realms of the Granblue Fantasy universe. Set in a world where islands float among the clouds and ancient civilizations thrive, the story follows a young hero who teams up with a diverse cast of companions, including skyfarers, magical beings, and powerful warriors. Together, they must uncover the secrets of the Astrals, formidable beings threatening the balance of the world, while unraveling the mysteries of their own pasts and forging bonds that will shape the fate of the skies. As they battle formidable foes, explore breathtaking landscapes, and encounter a myriad of colorful characters, players will immerse themselves in a captivating tale of adventure, friendship, and destiny. This all sounds incredible right? If you strip out the gameplay, and fantastic visuals, the story itself feels a bit phoned in. I found myself losing interest far before the credits rolled. All the characters are interesting in their own right, but the Story doesn't build on these connections in any meaningful way. You can do Fate missions, which are separate from the story, and delve deeper into the characters. But for the most part these become a slog as they gate stats for each of the characters and feel very low effort. As a whole, if you are buying Gran Blue Fantasy: Relink for the story alone, I fear you may walk away disappointed. 

[h3]Gameplay[/h3]
[hr][/hr]
Granblue Fantasy Relink bears the unmistakable imprint of Platinum Games, evident in its fluid movement mechanics and meticulously crafted character abilities. Each character boasts a diverse skill set that resonates with a global appeal, reminiscent of the intricate combat dynamics found in titles like Final Fantasy XIV. The game seamlessly incorporates elements like animation cancels and combo chains, lending depth and dynamism to every encounter. What sets it apart is its flexible character roles, mirroring the versatility seen in multiplayer online battle arenas (MOBAs). Whether players prefer to tank incoming damage, provide crucial support, or unleash devastating damage, every character can adeptly fulfill multiple roles, albeit with varying degrees of proficiency, ensuring a diverse and engaging gameplay experience for all.

[h3]Visuals[/h3]
[hr][/hr]
The cel-shaded art style in Granblue Fantasy Relink reaches new heights of visual splendor, surpassing even the notable achievements of titles like Borderlands. While Borderlands may have introduced cel shading to widespread acclaim, GBF: Relink elevates it to an art form all its own. Reminiscent of the enchanting visuals of Ni No Kuni, the hand-drawn aesthetic captivates players from cutscenes to gameplay, maintaining a harmonious balance that prevents screen clutter even during the most intense boss battles. This seamless integration of artistic design is a testament to the meticulous attention to detail exhibited by Cygames, showcasing a level of craftsmanship rarely seen in modern gaming. Every aspect of the game exudes a sense of care and dedication, solidifying Granblue Fantasy Relink as a visual masterpiece deserving of commendation.

[h3]Port / Bugs[/h3]
[hr][/hr]
From a port perspective, its easy to tell this game was made for the Playstation 5 and then ported over. No ultrawide support is a big miss in my opinion.For a game that was ported from Playstation to PC, its strange that Playstation inputs are not available but Xbox inputs are. As bugs go, I have had no issues, everything has run smoothly since release.
Endgame & The Grind
[hr][/hr]
The journey doesn't end with the credits in Granblue Fantasy Relink; in fact, that's just the beginning of the thrilling endgame experience that awaits players. After approximately 20 hours trenching through the main story mission,, adventurers will find themselves diving headfirst into a challenging grind, taking on progressively tougher bosses until they face the formidable foe, [spoiler]Proto-Bahamut[/spoiler]. The grind intensifies as players strive to level up their characters, acquire powerful sigils, and enhance their arsenal of weapons, immersing themselves in a cycle of resource farming that, while repetitive at times, is undeniably addictive. Despite the grind, the game's engaging gameplay mechanics and captivating world make it easy to invest countless hours, ensuring that players will find themselves eagerly sinking more and more time into the rich and rewarding experience that Granblue Fantasy Relink offers.

[h3][i] Thanks [/i][/h3]
[i] If you spent the time reading this review, thank you! I hope it helps you make the right decision in buying (or not buying) Gran Blue Fantasy: Relink [/i]

Granblue Fantasy Relink is a bit of an anomaly. It's main story is pretty short with most people beating it in around 15 hours of exploring areas with set piece story and boss fights, while the bigger post game portion is more Phantasy Star Online/Monster Hunter style quests against standalone bosses and the like. It's a game that switched developers midway though and is related to a browser/phone game that's English version is almost an unkempt secret. So with all of these things seemingly going against it... why is this game still an absolute joy to play?

The plot is approachable for newcomers to the series (like me when I started), as it is more it's own thing like an anime license game story. It's not something I would call great, but it has fun bits and great set pieces and fun characters with great designs.

Speaking of character design and the visuals, this game is absolutely gorgeous. Technically it is a bit behind, but the art design and the colorful aesthetic are just something I love. The music is also fantastic, with a fairly varied soundtrack, going from typical fantasy tracks to things like rock with certain bosses.

Gameplaywise, it's an action RPG with a bunch of characters that all have their own quirks so there is absolutely someone for anyone to love using (I personally really like Racham's mad daka-daka and Percival's charge focus) and the gameplay itself is fast paced, exciting and my god we have an action game like this were blocking is not a waste of time!

Major recommendation for fans of action RPGs and games with a lot heart in them.

This is a good game, if you were one of those keeping an eye on it waiting for its release then go ahead and get it. Its a very safe buy. A few notes though for a heads up.


 :Story: 

-Plot; It's not really bad or anything, just generic and meh

-Characters; Decent

-Mission Structure; Very good

-Set Pieces; Definitely epic, reminds me of Final Fantasy 16 and that's not just because both games have Bahamut. Story boss fight's are better than they have any right being (this could also fall into gameplay below).


 :Gameplay (why you buy it):

-Combat; It's awesome, flashy and feels amazing

-Classes/playstyles; Great variety, even the same "class" can fill different playstyles

-Content; Plentiful, you will fight the same bosses multiple times though but it hasn't felt repetitive yet. Also helps if you play other classes/characters


:Misc:

-Not really any exploration but has similar structure to Monster Hunter without feeling like Monster Hunter (this is not a bad thing either). If you're wondering about any paid cosmetics or pay for characters then worry not, what is on the steam dlc page is all there is (a few skin colors I believe is all?). No "premium" currency or anything. This is not a live service game even if it easily could have been one.

-Issues; Had a few at launch that were genuinely frustrating but they seem to have been fixed now. 

-Performance; Seems pretty good but your hardware may vary. It's always smooth in my experience though. 

-No Ultra-wide support (yet) but there is easy to use mods for that available.

Enjoy

Only been playing for a couple of weeks and it's already one of my most-played games on Steam. I've put time into three different characters now, and look forward to trying more.

I wish there was a little more build variety between characters, you can pretty reliably copy over all but like two or three sigils from one character to another and have a functional build. But the uniqueness in playstyles between each character makes up for that.

Many people complain about the endgame grind, but I think it's only a problem if you're just wanting to beeline it to an optimal damage build. I'm focusing on playing different characters, leveling up their weapons, and I'll sprinkle in a few final boss fights here and there. I'll get what I get and make the best use of what I have. You can more than comfortably play and complete all content right now without the strongest weapon which is a rare drop. At this point I haven't really missed out on anything and I'm lacking some of the stronger coveted gear.

My only real complaint is that the full story is a prerequisite to the majority of the multiplayer content. I'm real tired of forced single player in great co-op games. I wish the story was completely optional. They have the "Chapter Select" feature which lets you play the story again whenever you want, if it was completely relegated to that I would love it. A 10-15 hour story is huge hurdle to convincing people to play with me who don't have investment in Granblue.

BANGER of a game

Granblue Fantasy: Relink takes a well-established IP and brings it to a whole new audience in a wonderfully executed presentation that balances both the Action and the RPG side of this Monster Hunter-like action RPG.

Pros:
* The main story is fun, engaging, and epic, and does a great job teaching you about the cast and setting without ever condescending to the player. At about 4-8 hours total, it also doesn't overstay its welcome either, wrapping up and letting players free to engage with end-game content or not as they see fit.
* The story fights are all epic as heck, each topping the last to the point where just when you think you beat the last boss, another one appears.
* The towns and settings are breathtakingly gorgeous and are some of the most detailed I've seen in a game of this type before. They are full of NPCs that quietly tell more about the setting through dress and mannerism and never feel strangely small or depopulated.
* The combat system is snappy and responsive. 
* Top-end (Proud difficulty) content is at a good level, being fun and challenging without being frustrating or unfair. It is entirely possible that you will lose some encounters in co-op multiplayer, but most players doing that content are skilled enough that it rarely happens.
* While the jumps can feel a bit "floaty," the platforming elements don't overstay their welcome and are completely optional.
* There is a wide roster of characters with very different playstyles. Each character dramatically changes the feel of the game. You can try many characters to keep the game fresh, or go deep on a single character to master their moveset.
* All except the very highest difficulty is relatively forgiving and easy to power through for players who just want a cinematic experience.
* There are many options for building your character to match your play style. *

Cons:
* The main story is entirely single-player and cannot be done with friends. It is possible to engage with friends in side missions at any point in the game, but the main story must be done with 3 AI-controlled characters.
* There are only two cities currently. While both of the cities, especially Seedhollow, are gorgeous and expansive, it would be nice to get new cities to explore in future downloadable content.
* When doing co-op with vastly outgeared players, unless matched using quick quest (random matchmaking), the numerical difference leads to one player contributing nothing while the other one-shots the enemies. I haven't found a way to force the game to scale stats down to match the difficulty of the quest being posted.
* The very end-game turns into a pretty heavy grind, getting 100% mastery on all four mastery paths, unlocking and leveling all of the characters' weapons, farming for a terminus weapon, going through two very arduous awakening phases for ascension and terminus weapons, and leveling an endless parade of randomly generated slightly-better sigils to level 14-15. Most steps require large amounts of a rare item drop called Silver Centrum that proves to be the bottleneck when all other bottlenecks (boss drops, money) cease being a barrier.
* The sheer amount of grinding it takes to max out a single character makes it unreasonable to play multiple characters in end-game content without committing to an equally long and arduous grind for each new character. While you can do most of the content with a character that isn't completely stat-maxed, it feels like the game more rewards extremely deep investment in a single character than branching out.
* Your character quite quickly hits the "damage cap," thus making "damage cap+" the most important skill in the game. It invalidates a lot of more interesting builds that focus on situational damage increases, as it becomes almost trivial to hit the damage cap with a small handful of damage-boosting sigils, rending all other damage-boosting sigils useless. 
* The maximum damage cap increase (65 levels from weapon and sigils + 100% from terminus weapon) becomes the baseline for all builds, making building individual character sigil builds feel only modestly different from one another.
* Through most of the game, your choice of weapon is a strong reflection of your personal playstyle, but the ascension weapon and then the terminus weapon outclass them to the point where most end-game builds are pretty prescriptive and every player is visually using the same weapon, taking out one of the few avenues for personal customization.
* The alternate color palettes, including the ones that are DLC, are all pretty mediocre or actively bad, and generally look worse than the characters' default palettes.

Overall, I feel like the game is a great experience and certainly worth the 10 hours or so it takes to play through the story campaign and enjoy the side content. For those who want to stick around and enjoy a nice good grind, it can be very rewarding. For those who don't find that exciting, the story provides several good stopping points where you can put it down, satisfied in a well-executed and polished experience, satisfied that you got your money's worth.

10/10

An absolutely superb game. It has fun and engaging combat, a great cast of characters with clear influences from past videogame greats and anime alike, and a brisk story that doesn't outstay its welcome. It has tons of content after the story is done to sink your teeth into. All of this without any MTX, gacha mechanics, or other bullshit that's infested the gaming industry despite its mobile game roots.

Good:
* Graphics are absolutely wonderful and the game runs smooth as silk. 
* Sound and music are high quality. 
* Voice acting is solid - maybe not the best ever but still very good. 
* Tons of stuff to do without being too much to do. 
* A solid variety of encounters, ranging from hordes of enemies to giant bosses. 
* Characters all feel viable, unique, and fun with a wide variety of archetypes. You'll find at least one character you love.
* No MTX. No cash shop. No paid cosmetics. No battlepass. 

Bad:
* Story is serviceable but isn't going to wow you. You'll likely predict every twist and turn ahead of time. 
* Game is really easy until the endgame. 
* Wasn't a big fan of the main character in this one. She/he is really outshined by the rest of the stellar cast. 

Ugly:
* A few 'mobile game isms' exist, such as certain resources being hard to farm. As I understand some of these things were available in the mobile version's cash shop. 
* Missing S++ by a single enemy and being robbed of needed items sucks.
* Buff Vyrn fanart.

The game is fun, the story is your typical anime story, a bit enjoyable at times, where this game shines is gameplay wise, the combat is very good, you have a lot of characters to try, and every character has it's own mechanics, so you will never get bored.

The Dualsense ruble and haptics are very good, they already fixed a bug where the controller would disconnect randomly, and that's a big plus for me, but the game doesn't have Dualsense or any kind of PlayStation button prompts, why on earth a game released only for PS5 and PC doesn't have this icons?

This can be fixed with mods, but why is always the modders fixing this kind of issues?

The missions are fun to play, they compare this game to monster hunter, and they are right, but this game is more friendly, there are some interesting missions, like the one you can control a cannon (this is my favorite one because the Dualsense haptics, you need to try it for yourself),

Enemies have a good AI and bosses are fun to fight.

Also the graphics configurations are too simple, it is missing the most basic settings, let me change the anti-aliasing, shadows quality, effects, textures and models quality individually, also it would be great if they add upscaling like DLSS and FSR 2.

Besides this, the game is fun to play, if you like anime ARPGs or JRPGs, this game is for you.

Overall good game, just hope they add more content later on to keep the multiplayer alive.

Hi, I have now finished everything in the base game content-wise, and even though when I initially made a review for this game after 9 hours I severely believed I didn't even need to, it turned out I was right and the gameplay loop for this game is indeed way too good. 

I went into Relink thinking it'd maybe be a decent multiplayer experience at best, but what I ended up finding was an incredibly fun game with so many great intricate systems. The best way to explain the gameplay is to say, "what if your turn based rpg was an ACTION RPG", AND IT ENDED UP WORKING REALLY WELL?

Gameplay is fluid throughout multiplayer and single player, the bots that control your party members do the best they can, for the most part, with the characters they're given to control, and the same can be said about randoms or even your friends.
I say 'for the most part' because there are a very few amount of characters, like Ghandagoza and Vaseraga (the two massive beefcakes) that the AI doesn't make the best use of, in the sense they don't execute Ghandy's perfect timing hits or Vas's charge attacks.

As of the time I'm editing this review, there are 19 playable characters with 2 coming in the extremely near future, all with extremely varied playstyles. You're given access to unlocking them pretty easily as you follow the main questline, the only time you'd really have to "grind" for one is to unlock whichever final character you choose.
My initial impression was a low level of disappointment in how some character's had shared mechanics, but after delving into every single one I now realize I couldn't be more incorrect.
On top of each character having a fully unique design, they're each given a passive that HEAVILY impacts their gameplay, and definitely require you to use the customizable skills that come with each character to use them to their full potential. So much of the customization in skills comes in the form of how you want to output damage, how you'd like to support your team, or how you'd like to support yourself, giving you a decently varied playstyle just for a single character. I'm fully min-maxing my 7th character right now and I cannot express the amount of joy each one gave me.

Also in case it needs to be mentioned because we live in a world where the gaming landscape is controlled by the idea of "viability", yes, every character is viable. Some will do more damage, some will have more utility, and others will do a bit TOO much damage, it seriously barely matters. The ONLY TIME IT MATTERS is when you get to bosses with damage checks, but this is more like the game is gating you off from content until you're actually SERIOUSLY ready for it.
Every character is designed to have a specific role and be able to play for the team in the form of buffs or debuffing the enemy if you don't feel comfortable in being the main damage dealer, and you'll more than likely be doing your part as long as you play the game and try not to die! Healing, debuffing, and buffing is also NOT REQUIRED IN ANY PART OF THE GAME, I have played the entirety of this game solely super-armoring through every piece of content with Vaseraga as I let my starving, piss-stained AI companions grapple onto me like my children as I do all the damage. 
ALSO, YOU DO NOT NEED TO PLAY THIS GAME HYPER MECHANICALLY IN ENDGAME CONTENT, ANYONE WHO TELLS YOU TO DO THIS IS A GARBAGE DELVING RACCOON ON A KEYBOARD, but you can definitely play mechanically if you'd like. :)

The game also allows for even deeper customization in the form of Sigils. Sigils are stat amplifiers that can support everything from your damage, crit chance, percentage based damage based on certain qualifications, lower cooldown times, decreasing cooldowns every time you do damage, and the list goes on. Every time a game has stat amplifiers like this it seriously makes me so happy, and I constantly spend hours theory-building and testing to get the perfect build for how I can get the highest damage while also catering to my playstyle.

The mechanics of this game, separate from characters, are mostly in the form of guard breaks, blocks, dodges, and your Super Burst Gauge. Dodge rolling and blocking can both be perfectly timed and give you an amazing buff if you do so in the form of making you invulnerable to damage for a few seconds (which can by the way be buffed with the aforementioned sigils!!), letting you get off some more of that sweet sweet dps as long as you can stick to the enemy. 
The Super Burst Gauge is this game's form of giving each character a cinematic chargeable ultimate, that is actually able to be combo'd with any of your teammates. The purpose of this mechanic is seemingly to put it together for a massive elemental combination burst after combining each one, but a tip for players going into the endgame, you can actually use your SBA to stall out damage windows for you and your team, and more than likely get more damage than you would have otherwise.

As for the story itself, I can't say I care for it! It has moments where it has a lot of fun with itself, but for the most part it takes itself very seriously, and what it takes very seriously is SERIOUSLY campy. This is for the most part an intensely cookie-cutter anime turn based rpg storyline. But I seriously don't care! I appreciate the amount of effort put into the game and it's story as a whole, but I also really appreciate the amount of effort put into allowing me to skip every cutscene I'm not in the mood to sit through! There are some seriously flashy and cinematic parts to the main story that do make it pretty entertaining when you're actually PLAYING THE GAME though, so i'ts definitely not an entire snooze.

Problems though! Only 2 that I can FORCE, but they do exist. I understand the need for a damage cap, and even though the game itself actually gives you a certain amount of ways to INCREASE the damage cap, when it comes down to it there's an actual concrete damage cap eventually. I wish I could say it would be somewhat difficult to get to, but if you play this game to the degree of maxing out multiple characters, it does ultimately come to chance, but for the most part you will be hitting the damage cap on a few characters you put effort into building. Granted though, a damage cap for this style of game is pretty important, and does balance out multiple characters that otherwise could very feasibly beat endgame content in seconds, which is already possible.
Probably the only other actual issue I have with the game right now is that there aren't enough bosses for the EXTREMELY LATE endgame content in this game! Farming in the EXTREMELY LATE endgame has you fighting around 9 of the same bosses multiple times, and that doesn't even include the final boss that for the most part is grinded out separately for other reasons I don't want to spoil! These boss fights get pretty repetitive, especially if you're doing what I'm doing by building multiple characters to appreciate more of the content put into this game.

There is more content post-release that does appease one of my more fair complaints, but the only form of said content that's been actually shown is in the form of a new endgame boss coming out a month after the game's release date. There are some nice bonuses with the arrival of two new characters and some sort of paid dlc in the next couple months, but past that I have to just hope the developers see how much people love this game and desperately wish it gets even more extended content.

If you're a fan of games like Monster Hunter (but hate how long hunts can take), or crave something akin to Genshin's party system in a fully fledged multiplayer system, maybe interested in the fantasy anime RPG elements, or even love the chaos but synergistic gameplay of DMC or Bayonetta, seriously type into your little Youtube search bar and look into the game, because I definitely can assure that this game would be worth your time and money, ESPECIALLY at full price.

10/10 I really enjoyed the game. The story can be kinda cliche at times but the boss fights are awesome.

I wonder how many thousands of hours went into the development of the assets for the game. Imagine every item in the game every floor every wall had to be developed and have a texture put onto it.  The characters are unique and have their own backgrounds an stories to follow through the fate system. The main bosses the BIG bads are really unique fights. I recommend the game if you like combat like monster hunter and Geshin impact. This games combat reminds me of Tera back when it was the prime action MMO RPG. I dont know if I'll do another run of the story but its going to be one I remember for a very long time. Its kinda got a kiddish feel to the plot. However, I think the story was fun with reading all the fates and glossary entries. This is a massive world of fantasy if you look around and start looking into things. It reminds me of all kinds of fun games.

i went in to this game with little to no expectations after a friend showed me a few of the characters and talking about it a bit and i was very impressed with just about everything the game has to offer. a fun story that didn't overstay its welcome with some really fun boss fights, satisfying combat loops and a GORGEOUS art style bring it all together for a memorable experience.

CyGames has made one of the best anime RPG's of the decade. I believe this game deserves all the praise it has very much earned. 

BUGS: Unlike many games that have come out over the past couple years, I have yet to experience a single bug or issue in my first 24 hours of gameplay. Not only were there no bugs, but i have yet to see a screen tear, long loading times, or poor connection issues in online matches. There's nothing. I have seen absolutely nothing negative, and it is actually appalling. (in a good way)

GAMEPLAY: for people wondering about the core aspect of the game, do not worry, you will not be disappointed. For anyone who has played Honkai Impact 3rd on PC, You will absolutely love the playstyles that each character has along with their bursts and combo's. Not only this, but the endgame is very much worht the grin with the  different combo's you can do with the in-game weapon and sigil system.

Character/Environment Design: Peak design and animations as well as overall look of the world. Runs and looks amazing even on my 2060

Nostalgia: For someone who has played the original games of GranBlue Fantasy, it is oh so refreshing to see all my favorite Skyfarers back in action. (Love you Zeta)

ROADMAP: after realizing that not only is the game not stopping after this one launch, but is getting updates to the story and the amount of characters being added to the game every month, I basically folded. I would be willing to spend XXX amount of money to get the DLC's for this game as they released.

Conclusions: there is honestly so much more about the game I can say, but I believe you can tell  by all the positive reviews. If you're a fan of GranBlue Fantasy? Love JRPG's? Love CO-OP? Love Anime? Love Endgame and Min-Maxing? You said yes to any one of those? Buy it.

Upd: Devs please, remove "Dmg Cap" mechanic and "War Elemental" sigil. Those two absolutely kills any endgame builds. 

== TLDR ==
Game is good, combat is fun. 
Enough playable characters to spent a lot of time with each of them. Hundreds of great animations. 
A lot of content to grind in post-game.
Great English voice acting. Probably the one and only case when I prefer DUB over original. 
GREAT OST. Almost each boss have boss theme which you expect to hear in LAST FIGHT of another game.

That's how Action JRPG should look like, not a mobile casino trash.

== Detailed == 

Story: It's boring Just another generic anime story about friendship, etc.
At least it's not too long and it's not a total cringe as some other games with anime stylistics (Tales of Berseria, etc.)

Locations: Invisible walls are more then I would like to see, but less than I was afraid to see. Big and interesting locations are not string point of this one, since it use "hub" structure for all content apart from Story quests.

Music: I've found that I did not care about music during story at all ("Managarmr Part 2" is a rare exception).

Probably combat system is too intense for me, so I literally did not care about everything else before finally start doing quests in "Maniac" difficulty, being accustomed to gameplay and starting to paying more attention to surroundings.

Music is GREAT.

Gameplay: Battle system is good. Not a super casual, which is pleasant to see nowadays.

AI party members: Good. While they definitely cheating in a lot of situations, it's still pleasant to see useful AI party members which behaviour is interesting to watch.

Localization: I've seen a plenty of reviews which says localization is bad. Maybe - I honestly don't know. But the one thing I know - English DUB is definitely great - it's not worse than original, and maybe (!) event better than original.
(from the person who prefer to watch anime with English subtitles)

Technical: I've seen a lot negative reviews about game crash, freeze, etc. But personally I've experienced 0 problems with game. 
Being installed on SSD it's also has VERY FAST loading times.

Quality of Life: I'l write it as separate option, since game just filled with QoL features. Which is always good to see, especially in game which is a few days old.

Let me start by saying:

[h1]Granblue Fantasy: Relink is an amazing game. [/h1]

As an action RPG/JRPG fan, I really love how Cygames delivered this game and the attention to detail they have given to make this game fun and enjoyable. From the amazing combat to beautiful art style and amazing soundtrack, I am happy to say that this game tickles every itch that I have in an RPG/JRPG game.

[h2 ]The Story  [/h2]

Although the story very short, it is adequate enough and is fully jam-packed with fun and amazing storytelling and battles. You can think of this as the introduction of the main chunk of the game. 

My only complain in the story though is some of the English translation to its Japanese audio is poorly translated.

[h2]The Gameplay Loop [/h2]

This is where probably the majority of your playtime will be, and where the game really starts. Granblue Fantasy is well known for having cool and lovable characters in its franchise, and this game you get to play some of them! As of writing this review there are currently around 20 playable characters, and each of them has unique and fun combat mechanics.

You take on different quests from exploration to boss fights, either solo or with other players to grind character exp, materials, and sigils to make your character strong to further take on difficult quests. Very much similar to games like monster hunter, which I am a big fan of.

The combat is very fluid, fast-paced and fun. Since each character plays differently, they can have a wide variety of builds that you can try to match your favorite playstyle.

[h2]Visuals and Audio Design [/h2]

Even though the gameplay is entertaining, I just can't ignore the art direction the game went to from its environment to enemy designs. Everything very much an eye candy and is gorgeous. 

Same goes with the game's audio design and OSTs. I am the type of person that appreciates a game's music and sound design, and Granblue Fantasy: Relink delivers well on this part.

[h2]My Closing Thoughts [/h2]

[b]Yes[/b], the gameplay loop is compelling. [b]Yes[/b], the game is amazing. [b]Yes[/b], the game is fun.

As a player that loves grinding in video games, I really love what Cygames cooked with Granblue Fantasy: Relink. From the game's announcement since 2016, I think that it deserves all the love it's been having, and it's a game that was worth the wait.

I highly recommend this game to all players that love a fast paced action RPG/JRPG and to fans that love the franchise. Give it more love as the game really deserves it! ♥

New to the Granblue franchise. Went into the game from past reviews saying its like Monster Hunter in a way. Off the bat, even though I haven't finished the main story yet, i'd rate this game a 9/10

[u] Gameplay [/u]

The whole reason you'd get this game in the first place. There's no other way to describe the boss fights other than its 100% anime. Not in a bad way, in fact the presentation of the fights are spectacular. Feels like you're actually facing off against something genuinely threatening. 

Combat is fluid and has some thought put into it. Can't just forever spam dodge or block and become completely immune throughout boss fights. But, the game does reward perfect dodges and blocks and it feels great to do every single time

Each character is unique in their own right, different systems, different combat styles, the like. Large, linear skill trees that don't force you into a specific line for the character. Usually just amounting to minute stat increases that adds up as you go through it.

Main story is played with up to three AI companions, but you can go at it solo with the main character on your first playthrough. At least from what i've heard in the multiple New Game Plus difficulties afterwards where you can omit the main character. The AI is actually very competent. Heals you when you're low, books it to you to revive, avoids boss mechanics generally. At no point will the AI ever feel like a hindrance

[u] Main Story [/u]

Typical JRPG, damsel-in-distress plot. Haven't finished the main game fully(Only on Chapter 6), but that's not what you'd play the game for

[u] Side Story [/u]

There's not much character building present thus far in the main story. So, there's this thing called "Fate Episodes" that delve into some decent nuance for the playable characters. Voice-over from the character in question and most of the time its lengthy dialogue boxes

[u] General Cons [/u]

Unlike Monster Hunter, combat doesn't have a weight and satisfaction to it. It's a hack-and-slash moreso than methodical and calculated. Nothing against it, but with how both the playable characters and boss fights are presented. Would've loved a weightier combat. As such, when the playable character you're controlling becomes incapable of movement through status effects or using block/dodge too much. It feels too much like control is taken away

The large, linear skill tree that is mostly just stat increases that add up over time. While simplistic, would've liked it if it was more game changing. Once you gain a new ability, that's it. Nothing in the skill tree will change how its used or comes out. Once you unlock a character, they'll pretty much play like that the entire time. With a few skill nodes increasing their individual systems in some way or another. The approach is more of getting the biggest number possible on the screen than anything.

The amount of time that I unexpectedly sank into this game.
Nice straight forward story, beautiful soundtrack, amazing characters and chemistry.
The developer put tons of effort into making the game feel immersive, with each character having
lines with any party member you assign.This game is full of so much personality which you feel during the combat.
There are so many ways to approach combat in this game, with each character having 
a different control scheme. You can even apply autoplay features to play the game without really playing the game if you want. They really made this game for ANYONE to enjoy. 

I absolutely love building my characters in so many different ways.
Building your character in different ways means they can be played in different ways.
You can turn a DPS into an absolute tank unit. You can play the game entirely away from your enemy
by playing ranged characters.

I normally don't enjoy farming in gaming, but in this game, farming is so rewarding as you recieve 
rewards that can be used for so many things. There are so many things to do, so much so that 
when you have an objective, you are easily distracted by another. 
The bosses in this game are where the game truly shines, especially end game. 
Fighting a lot of the bosses over and over may get a bit repetitive at times, but the versatile ways you can approach them and the many different things you can do with the rewards is what keeps it fresh.

My only issue is the lack of cross platform play. Unfortunately the story mode is NOT co-op, but there are a plethera of missions to play co-op. Another gripe i have primarily pertain to the visuals, which are amazing, but at times so flashy and overwhelming that you can't see what small enemies are doing. The aiming system also needs adjustment as it's linked to the right joystick, which results in you accidentally locking onto a different enemy, making your attacks go nowhere sometimes.

Great game overall:

Story is kinda mid, but I appreciate it doesn't waffle around too much. It's also the arguably least important part of the game.

Once your past the story, the real game kind of opens up. From there, the difficulty climb and diverse gameplay of each character makes for a kind of loop that Monster Hunter excels at.

4/5 out of game; Has good grind, free content updates incoming, and phenomenal OST.

S A L V A T I O N
The combat is very fluid, all of the characters have their own playstyles. Very well done indeed.

The story is the worst part of the game. It's not that it is terrible, it is mediocre at best, but it's just not this game's cup of tea. The graphics and the musics are pretty good though. There is also english voices.

The combat is the main selling point of this game and is probably the best out of any other anime games out there. The gameplay is smooth. It is very responsive and you can cancel out of any actions with block or dodge. It is also forgiving, but not to the point of making the game too easy. End game is just fighting bosses, which feels a bit like Monster Hunter, but without the running and carving aspect. Additionally, the gameplay mechanics of all characters are unique to them, meaning that you won't feel like any characters are simply a different flavoured of a copy pasta.

The progression systems feels pretty good in general. My only concern would be at end game, where things getting a bit inconvenient. Farming sigils feels terrible. One of the main way of getting them is through Transmutations and Transmarvels, but trade-ins are 1 by 1, meaning you will need to click a lot. Then, getting one 2-lines Sigils is hard, because so many sigils are just not worth considering because of the Damage Cap system, to the point that all characters will be using 90% of the same build. There's also the end game weapon, which you can't even guarantee a selector and are left to the mercy of randomness to get the one for the character you play.

Regarding multiplayer, I've mostly done solo queueing through matchmaking. The only issues I've met is mostly regarding the times where steam went down(ie: weekly maintenance on tuesdays), but otherwise, I've not met many issues. One of my favorite thing is that even if you get disconnected, you get thrown into an offline instances with AIs of whatever player characters there was. I'd like to see matchmaking for multiple missions at once and maybe buffed benefits to Quick Battle, but otherwise, it's still a solid multiplayer system.

The AIs in this game are incredible. Not incredible in term of performing character mechanics, they are crap at that, but their survivability is actually better than most players you would encounter in multiplayer. It's not uncommon for AIs to not die during fights, provided you haven't neglected them anyway.

Overall, the game is incredibly fun, and I'd even go as far to say that it is one of the few anime games where full price is justified, as it is a high quality game, something rare these days.

OG Granblue Vet reporting in:

This game from a longtime fan is that it's beautiful, runs well, plays great, and is honestly the most I could probably ask for in a mainstream Granblue game that's close to capturing the beautiful insanity of the original browser RPG. (Which you can still play, real easily - I only recommend if your gambling addiction is low).

Cygames has been for most of it's history incredibly fair to it's players, and there's a part of me that is genuinely proud of a game company that has such love for it's community to be able to branch out like this. Take this from someone who's been playing Granblue for eight out of the TEN years of it's running - they do deliver, and they will take care of you. This game will see future content.

Now for potential downsides - the story in this game will be kinda confusing if you haven't played, oh....300ish chapters of the browser RPG. That being said, you can also entirely ignore that jump since characters will reference events as "being similar to X" and they're pretty much right. This story follows a similar tread of the first 20 or so chapters of the original with some utterly new characters and stakes. That being said, I do hope some classics like Sturm and Drang, Zooey, Orchid, Noa etc do make their way onto the roster.  If you're looking for an easy entry to Granblue this will work, but if you ever wanna go back to the OG make sure to temper your expectations. And don't run from Guild Wars.

TL;DR - Really lovely game, and for a mainstream entry to a storied series you could definitely do worse. Wait for a sale if on the fence, but I really think anyone can have fun here. Ignore early downvotes tbh - a lot of grognards were mad that Zeta wasn't wearing "tactical panties" like in her art from literally a decade ago. She has since had like fifteen versions with pants and skirts alike. They don't know squat.

i think its finally time for me to talk about this game. First off I LOVE THIS GAME TO BITS I ADORE IT i had been literally living in this game for the past week and i dont think i regretted it. 

This game feels like one of the higher quality gacha game with its good gameplay loops WITHOUT ANY GACHA. Its basically everything genshin wishes to be and more. But i dont want to make that comparison in anycase since its a whole different game, obviously.

Start with the story. I've seen many people in the reviews complaining how simple the story was and yes, it was a straight forward, short, and mostly predictable. The story start off feeling "mid" then it turned into "not bad" and then finally turned into "thats pretty good ngl" Its not a top-anime level of a story, but it does it job great. The writers and dev knows exactly what story and how they want to tell and did that almost flawlessly in my opinion. This is because most of the time, the visuals and the maps are nothingless than stunning. I find myself just stop and look around to see how  cool the worldbuilding and the maps are made. But not only that, it is PACKED with content. Yes, the story is relatively short, but every chapter feels packed to the brim with content and is very VERY memorable. A lot of times a new boss is reveal it just makes me go "HOLY FUCK." And when the story seems to be over the game tolds you NO ITS NOT OVER then throw you more epic fights, then they do that again and again until its actually over with the MOST FUCKING EPIC FIGHT EVER i had goosebumps and then it ends. It was enough for me to give me that feeling of emptiness when its over and all of these combine made me focus on enjoying the story more and lowkey immersing in it than trying to predict things or pick things out. I love everything about it.

But the thing is, the game is barely over at this point and YOU"RE IN THE ENDGAME right? Now, many have said the endgame of this game is great, and I totally agree with them. But I'll just lay what its like right now for you. In the endgame your goal is to basically grind better and better gears for your characters, find the perfect sigil, upgrade weapons, etc. And for this, you have to play the same quests over and over again. If you're like me and you love the combat then that wouldn't be much of a problem either. On top of this, compared to other games, the game is very generous on what it gives you in each quests. Yes, theres a lot of grinding, but the chances and the amount of loot you get is also fair. Its prevalent that the game respects your time. Some quests you can just semi-AFK over it too. The quests unlocks like how monster hunter does and the progression feels pretty natural. If you want to know if you needs friends to play with or not my answer would be not until the lates of late game when you're AI team arn't enough for the mission and you're basically forced to go into online. But people are mostly nice there and the matchmaking is relatively quick. Although there might be some server problem here and there that could get a little annoying. 

But heres come another problem with this and its that, the boss designs and how it plays in end game. Its not really a big complain but some bosses just feels like it was design to be played once. It did a very good job at giving you a sense of epicness and awe when you first encountered it. But when you have to play it multiple times, it gets a bit annoying for some. [spoiler]Like Excavalllion and Vulcan Bolla for example[/spoiler]. 

But other than that, i feel like the game is great and is absolutely worth the price! If you like the game, the play time could EASILY reach a 100hrs. 8.5/10

Very fun game to play. The combat is fast and exciting, the graphics are great, the music can go from relaxing to extremely exciting, and the level of challenge is just right. 

Don't be intimidated by the fact that there are multiple upgrade systems, the game is very forgiving and you can't really do anything wrong. From my experience, there's no wrong way to play the game and you can definitely beat the story quests (so don't worry about switching characters even if you've dumped all your resources into upgrading a different one already)

There's a lot of extra content besides the story mode, but in my opinion it's best to view it as stuff you can do after beating the story mode. Don't approach it with a completionist mindset, just leave it as stuff to do if you have already beaten the story but don't want to leave the game behind yet.

If you like Ys games, I think you'll really enjoy this game.

After the main story (which took me 15 hours), this game becomes like monster hunter, a 4 player coop game where you are taking down increasingly hard boss fights for, what looks like will be, 100's of hours. 

There are some big differences though. This game is a lot more casual in a lot of ways, the combat feels better than any action game i've played, its fast, chaotic, requires quick reaction time for fast dodges, positioning, and utilizing the skills that you built on your character in ways that work well for the fight. It is incredibly rewarding. 

One of the coolest things about this game is the characters, there are around 15 characters in the game right now each offering unique skills, skill trees, weapons and play-styles. They plan to add more content and characters often like a live service so more characters and content is going to be added frequently apparently. This is like a nice blend of monster hunter and genshin (without the gacha). 

Thank you Granblue team I will be putting a lot of hours in this one.

Is the best action jrpg that I have played. The combat, music and visuals are great. Each crew member you play has a unique play style. Main story is fun to play through. The endgame is quite enjoyable with it's monster hunter style boss encounters. There is also no gacha involved in the game or in game store, which is a big plus. 

Cons: 
English voice acting for some characters is absolutely terrible. The English dub is lacking as well. Lastly, the amount of grind to level one character at endgame is a little much.

i like it, coming from other character action games like pso2 and mh. however, saying it's like monster hunter is like saying that titanfall 2 is similar to team fortress 2 - the nuances are completely different. the character models look good, attacks are fast and things feel punchy.

that being said, here are some critiques:
- game balance feels terrible in the endgame. presumably this is to lay the groundwork for future fights. as it currently stands right now, as soon as you reach the final difficulty, you can clear any fight. as soon as you get all of your mastery nodes maxed, you become super overtuned for basically any fight and the only way you can lose is if you don't understand how the game works or if a party member is throwing. the final fight in the game can be beaten in under 1 minute and 30 seconds in-game time (roughly 6 minutes actual time) with a specific party composition and can be comfortably beaten near-bis with a random party assortment of competent online players in under 5 minutes IGT. enemies are way too squishy and the damage cap makes some skills completely worthless. you can also achieve near optimal damage while having defensive utility, which doesn't make sense to me and kills most illusion of choice for buildcrafting. the endgame pivots from action game to grinder once you are bis aside from Supp V+s and the hellgrind that is the perfect weapon imbue - for no meaningful ingame benefit. a lot of this stems from the best stuff being put behind the easiest fights and difficulty not scaling rewards well.
-- additionally, several attacks can be animation cancelled to do more damage, which is cool. however, a small subset of those attacks are skills that can be dodge cancelled [b]AT NO COST[/b] and fully refunds the skill, giving you whatever benefit you would have for casting that skill (e.g. vane going into his finisher, percival having faster charge on his Y, vaseraga going into his charge attacks faster than normal, katalina getting gauge, etc) and completely breaks the expected damage output on that character and kills their skill depth by turning them into one-tricks. hopefully the costless cancels get patched.
- the game is anime as hell, for the good and the bad. both ally and enemy cutscene attacks are not skippable, meaning a significant amount of the game becomes waiting for cutscenes or waiting for trivial attacks to end so you can play the game. it also makes some characters significantly better than others since you can skip certain attacks with hard CC and SBA chaining. at least in the gacha game, you can f5 the page and skip the animations. you can't do that here. in versus/rising, cutscenes are only for SBA and they are way shorter in comparison.
- bloodthirst, a buff that makes it so the enemy takes what feels like only 5% of normal damage, is the only buff that can't be dispelled. this compounds with the cutscene stuff to force the player to play a minigame while the enemy tries to beat over the player. some fights are significantly less interactive than others during bloodthirst/OD mechanics, which hurts the moment-to-moment gameplay. extremely questionable design choice.
- a lot of the minmaxing in the endgame is either cheating, botting or mostly AFK playing to farm resources to try to win a 1/5k roll for a marginal power boost, with getting a single curio roll every couple of minutes. doing the fun things will slow down your grind to a halt. additionally, the game is vulnerable to [spoiler]savescumming for masteries and transmutations, both of these seeds are stored in the game save[/spoiler] and will save you hundreds of hours of grinding by using this to your advantage. the game does not autosave after rolling.
- the camera is pretty bad. the consequences of this are: big enemies are unpleasant to fight (maybe the game really is monster hunter???? :^) ), perfect defending attacks is inherently wonky, blocking is encouraged and is sleeper overpowered when compounded with oneshot attacks.
- fighting aerial enemies feels like shit unless you have an explicit out (e.g. you're playing charlotta, rackam, eugen, and others to a lesser extent)
- the game's communication to the player is bad - just like the gacha game. very few people know that you can mash/spin sticks to leave critical state faster. the game doesn't make it obvious that OD (not Bloodthirst, but enemies entering Overdrive) reduces their damage taken. defense values are not displayed anywhere. damage cap is obtuse - only visual indicator is a yellow stroke around text which can be lost in the damage number noise. some traits stack multiplicatively and others stack additively - the game does not tell you directly, you must experiment.
- the solo story missions cause an odd problem where you're incentivized to gear your entire party, but then as soon as you get access to multiplayer, that gearing on your party is no longer relevant so you're put into a dichotomy where you either gear your entire party or you make your main character snowball into a death machine. this is further complicated by that if you want to do the [spoiler]ultimate difficulty campaign, you need to gear up id and gran/dj as they have sections where you are forced to play as them[/spoiler] and that the AI companions are really underperformant compared to a person, even without abusing cancels.
- why is the ultimate fight in the game a [spoiler]mediocre turret fight where the boss is slow as hell when compared to every other fight on proud difficulty excluding versa?[/spoiler]

This game is actually really good -- I enjoyed playing it, even though it frequently crashes. I could look past that, because the game was really enjoyable.

All the way up until for zero reason, it randomly corrupted my save file and I lost my ENTIRE playthrough. Just fired it up to play and BOOM, nope, cannot load saved game. Since you can't save in additional slots for some reason, this becomes utterly gamebreaking. The expectation seems to be that you will religiously manually backup your save files in the Windows directory. How is that a developer expectation in 2024?!

There is no point in playing this game as long as it's so buggy that it will literally corrupt your save for no apparent reason. It's just begging for massive frustration. I can't even bring myself to start another playthrough, after reading about other people's stories of this happening two or three times. Who has time to just have their game progress evaporate and start from scratch constantly?

I love the GBF franchise, but it is hugely disappointing and completely unacceptable that they released the game in this state.

It looks amazing.  It sounds amazing.  It plays great.  Its story is terrible.  Honestly, it's a really fun kind of terrible until captain bandage sword starts sucking the air out of the room.  There's also some genuinely interesting stories in visual novel style interludes called Fate Episodes.

There ARE genuine problems.  I know there's a healthy player base for this game, but I consistently can't get into a quick match with my buddy.  You gain power too slow to use two characters, but too fast for just one.  So, if you beeline it through every required mission you'll constantly over power yourself and end up with check lists of trivial boss fights.

However, this is the best way to bring up new characters as level matters very, very little.  Gear and unlockable skill trees are everything.  So a powerful character can farm for everyone.  This discourages experimentation with their varied and gigantic roster, but I would still stop and do it.  The most fun I've ever had in this game is right after the credits when I had multiple crew mates with 50% of their skill trees and a decent weapon.

Otherwise, the main story is 10-15 hours and it's a BLAST.  The narrative isn't good, so if you find the cutscenes annoying, skip them and move on to the next awesome action set piece!  It's a great game, and whatever faults it may have it's just really fun on the whole.

Granblue Fantasy soars high with its renowned Japanese voice cast, bringing each character to life. But at a daunting $90 price tag, be prepared for a grind. While boasting an impressive amount of content - individual fate quests, weapons, and mastery trees for each crewmate - many feel like filler due to their minimal story roles. Customization also feels limited, with mastery trees lacking focus and the real variety coming from expensive sigils and a handful of skill slots.

The story itself takes a nosedive into linearity and predictability, with the true challenge waiting post-game in a grind reminiscent of Monster Hunter: World. Be warned, the base game already demands a hefty time investment, and Hard mode just extends fights with stingier resource drops.

Ultimately, Granblue Fantasy's charm lies in its stellar voice acting and vast content, but the hefty price and soul-crushing grind might leave you grounded. Consider waiting for a sale if the captivating voices and extensive content outweigh the potential for burnout.

Pros
+Good gameplay
+Many different characters to master which each plays differently

Cons
-Limited boss variety
-Sigil transmutation and transmarvel has to be made one by one which wastes A LOT of time

Other points
Full stack of potions are provided free at the start of each quest makes going from quest to quest more convenient 

In combat, hyper armor, invulnerability, lenient i-frames for dodges and parries allows for a much more aggressive gameplay

If you enjoy MHW but find the combat too committed, you will likely like the gameplay here much more since almost all moves can be dodge cancelled.

The main story line is actually kinda trashy. Power of Friendship yadda yadda. The voice acting is either really good for some characters, or really poor and hammy for the others. You'll know which ones I mean. 

The REALLY good parts of the game are the actual gameplay, and the graphics/art design. I'd recommend this game if you don't mind the cheesy anime tropes.

Ah... Granblue Fantasy: Relink...!
What a joy, a diamond in the rough with all the great bases covered.
If you are a JRPG fan, you will immerse yourself in this world.
If you are a Mission Board enjoyer, you will have plenty on offer here.
If you are an FFXIV telegraphed mechanics enjoyer, you will feel at home.
There are few caveats though, and its that, for all Granblue offers, its never the best at it.
I see this first PC/Console game as a jack of all trade, master of none.
And that's okay in my book.

[h3]TIME[/h3]
There are 3 structures on hand that the game offers.
The Story, which is basically your tutorial that will take around 10-ish hours to finish.
Then, the Mission Board will open and you will enter the Road to Endgame content. It's based on Ranks, ala Monster Hunter ranks of difficulties to go through. From Easy (Story, 1st difficulty type) to Proud (the 7th difficulty and hardest content). 
Then, once Proud is unlocked, you will enter the End Game; where monsters get high levels than yours (up to 40 levels above you) and will become an average FFXIV Savage Trial. There is a lot on offer here, and getting to proud might take you around 30-40 hours or so. Then you will have to play... 200h afterwards if you wish to platinum. There a lot of bang for your bucks, but a lot of repetitive content to grind too.


[h3]LORE / STORY[/h3]
The story is probably the weakest part of the game. Not by its very nice graphics, moments, artistic moments and set pieces, no, this game suffers from the generic mobile game plot and one-sided villain archetypes. There is very few innovative or even efforts to tell an original story out of the VERY generic shounen tropes.
But there are set pieces that will remind you of Armored Core 6 and Final Fantasy 14, and just for these, this story sold me on how innovative they wanted gameplay to be. And I highly welcome that in our current gaming landscape.

[h3]GAMEPLAY[/h3]
This is an action-adventure based role playing game. 
It's close to a Tales of or Genshin Impact (without the gacha and not with an open world) as it's instanced based instead. This allows the game to have more "money shots" and "time based action set pieces" to sprinkle the adventure and create new interesting transitions in-between arenas of gameplay and combat. Not everything always meshes together though, as the arenas feel very flat and hold very few interactions with the monsters overall. And just like FFXIV, the game relies heavily coloured telegraphs that are VERY messy and difficult to read.
Also you have total of 20 characters on hand to play  (once they are all unlocked) which will open 20 different sets of gameplay and game-feel. Along those sets of skills, you have skills trees (masteries), uniques weapons (6 per character) and 15 accessory slots to create unique builds and synergies. 
The gameplay is very addictive and deep to indulge into.


[h3]ART DIRECTION[/h3]
The developer talked in interviews the "watercolour-like" art and, to be fair, other than clouds and the world map you see in the story, the watercolour effect is probably the worst of it all. It's more a hand-painted marvel to look at, yes, but watercolour specifically? No. That doesn't keep the game to being beautifully lit, textured, vibrant and has very clean biomes sets. Characters are nicely animated and have clear defined animation sets that makes them likeable and enjoyable to attach yourself to. I'm sad we don't have more unique Armor skins unlocks for achieving masteries and hard achievements per heroes.

[h3]REPLAYABILITY[/h3]
OK. Replayability is very good, but it will highly depend on your tolerance on repetitiveness. 
Once the story is done you can fully replay it per chapter, take you time to finish and acquire every collectibles and even choose higher difficulties to clear it (you should as its tied to an achievement). Then there's the Lyria's Journal achievement, which require to unlock and do everything with everyone, which might take you 200 hours to get or so. It's replayable, but the ceiling of Platinum-ing here is very insane.
The grind required to clear the game is too egregious to me.

[h3]SOUND/MUSIC[/h3]
EXCELLENT original soundtrack made by Octopath Traveler Yasunori Nishiki and Tsutomu Narita. Because you will replay many missions and come back to many of the two main cities, most of this soundtrack will stay engrained in your mind: from soothing tracks to action-filled combat themes; there's aorund 70-80 original tracks at least to eargasm to.

[h3]PERFORMANCE[/h3]
On a good rig here:
4K 43" Monitor
GEFORCE 4090
AMD RYZEN 5950X
128GB DDR4 3600Mhz
980Pro Samsung 2tb NVME Drive

Had excellent FPS at fixed 144fps at native 4K constantly. 
There was no DLSS options when I played.

[h3]CONCLUSION[/h3]
It's an excellent first original experience that Granblue has on offer here.
I am looking into it and wishing for an equivalent to an "Iceborne-expansion"; this game is so ripe and fit for it. This first instalment really shows to everyone how a mobile game can create a real immersive world on PC and console to show they can do better. I just think they should find 2-3 more writers to make less trope-ish and pre-pubescent remarks and dialog.

If it's on sale just grab it and encourage this game you just won't regret it!

Its like the game does everything in its power to make you hate the antagonists and then it just brushes everything aside and allows the antagonist to escape justice. Outside of that, I am enjoying the game so far. Its just fun to play and although i have issues with certain aspects of the story its decent enough that it makes me want to continue playing it.

Game is straight awesome! One of the most fun action RPGs I've played in a while! There are however some issues that I want to point out.

1st, graphics are great, but optimization is poor in areas with a lot of traffic. With an NVIDIA 3080 FE, I can get 120 fps regularly at 1440P EXCEPT, when I'm in the town hub area. For whatever reason, the FPS always dips a tremendous margin in those areas, and that's even after turning on RBAR and other performance enhancing options in Nvidia profile inspector.

2nd, you are basically forced to main 1 or 2 characters as there is tremendous grind to max out even one character. Maybe include a repeatable quick quest farming option that requires some type of ticket to do. This would significantly reduce the amount of redundancy, while still forcing players to be strategic in how they use their farming tickets.

3rd and probably the largest issue is the lack of image scaling, and DLSS support. Implementing these features would help tremendously in overall game performance.

4th besides the 5 free color palettes available, there aren't a lot of customization options to differentiate yourself from other players, especially if you play on a team who all play the same character. Maybe add additional character costumes?

Also the damage cap thing is a little weird, but that's a personal opinion

Good game, just don't be an idiot like me and try to use AI teammates for everything. They are super useful until the very end, then they just died so many times I would fail missions without dying. That's on me, not the game.

This is a quest based aRPG with a hub system in lieu of old Phantasy Star Online 1/2 and monster hunter games but also with a story that actually goes beyond that type of gameplay. So the game can be divided into two distinct ways of enjoying it - the story, that has actual (small, corridor like) locations to explore and go through and the quest mode, which usually throws u into a cut off boss arena or some small fragment of the story mode setpiece repurposed into a quick mission.

The story is great. It's pretty much anime tropes but IMO they were executed well. The game is FULL of crazy moments, right from the start, you wont get bored. It's a nonstop assault of explosive action with incredible visuals/audio and bosses/locales that push some crazy epic BS at you. The game feels like a bullet hell at times. Bosses in this game are insane, the first major one you encounter is such a spectacle that it could work as a final boss. But no, its just the first one. And ones after him are just as (if not more) spectacular. It feels like a blockbuster movie but its actually playable. Mechanics correlated to these crazy moments in these fights are great in the context of the story. It feels like a lot of effort got put into these battles, the campaign also has exclusive gameplay interactions that u wont see in the quest mode (like new combat mechanics when u get to control... some stuff that u will encounter in the story mode). The ending was great. I love the antagonist and chemistry between the chars. Story just felt like a great journey full of action and with colorful cast of characters. English voices are great imo. I didnt mind the writing/translation and it was funny sometimes.

After you complete the core story (which, in my view, should take around 12-20hrs to beat if u dont rush it)  you will start unlocking the access to meatiest parts of the quest mode. You thought the game ended when the credits rolled? Well, you can drop it here and now if u want to but if u want to grind (or just see more of the game) then... there is absolutely shit to grind AND ACTUAL NEW CONTENT to unlock. Quest mode actually has a new kind of story progression that continues from where the core story mode ended. At this point main gameplay loop becomes the Monster Hunter like loop of: beat the "key" quests, complete the "urgent quest" (a boss battle) and unlock a new difficulty tier/quest rank and repeat till you see everything. There are new bosses to see and lots, LOTS of potential to hyperoptimize your builds and grinding. There is a lot of progression systems - getting perfect rolls on the overmastery skill tree, gridning the best sigils (think of decorations in monster hunter), getting the ultimate weapons and ascending/upgrading them as high as you can... And theres like more than 15 characters. Maxing one takes a long time, if u want to do that for everyone then we are possibly looking at hundreds of hours of playing. Beating all the quest mode content took me around 54 hours, at that point i have seen every quest so far present in the game and every "secret" boss there is. I still didnt "max" any character, i got 2 ultimate weapons (none of which i managed to level up to max) out of like 19. Is there much of a reason to get perfect builds? For now, from the perspective of hard challenges to overcome - not much. You can beat the hardest boss with just semi-optimized character builds and that, as i said, will probably take around 50 (more depending on how fast/slow u learn how to buildcraft) hours in this game if you arent tryharding and IF u are playing multiplayer. Because for multiplayer u only need to have only one semi-well built character that can stand their ground. If you want to beat the last few bosses solo then its gonna take considerably longer because u will need to have the whole 4 (you and your AI companions) person team kitted out. Last tier of quest difficulty is actually hard if u dont think about your builds and survivability. So far i have 2 characters that maybeee stand a chance for these hardest quests, i need to build my team more. I beat the final boss with randoms in multiplayer and i want to be able to solo it just for fun. 

So - the replay value of this game comes from the pure fun of combat and getting higher numbers for the sake of higher numbers (and again, theres lots of numbers to optimize). The combat itself is really great, character movesets are very varied and lots of them have their own, often simple but very fun, gimmicks. Dodging has bit of a nier automata feel, perfect dodges give u a hefty iframe reward. Swinging weapons is fast and feels good, you can cancel most of animations. Its a bit button mashy, combos arent complicated but they do require some thought. Like for example, a character named Siegfried requires you to swing his greatsword rhythmically so his attacks get buffed when u get the perfect timing on each swing and it is cool. While a character named Narmaya capitalizes on switching between her two combat stances seamlessly through her combos to buff her active abilities. There are even gunner characters and they have their own gimmicks too.

What can be annoying about otherwise amazing boss battles is that they have like a sort of unskippable, mini cutscenes baked in when they do their ultimate (mmo raids vibe) attacks. Its fine in the story but can get old while grinding. U cant move your characters during these animations. And overall, bosses at times have invicibility phases so these things combined can throw the pace off a bit.

Music and visuals are great. Game runs in 60fps on my laptop gtx1650ti but i did need to downscale the resolution in settings. Sadly, graphical settings are lacking. You dont have much of a finer control.

UI and quality of life thingies are great, this game has features that monster hunter failed to implement (like wishlist that actually shows which quests drop what items and instantly redirects u to said quests). There are still problems tho, like for example the mastery skill tree navigation is too slow when u want to spend your mastery points all at once. The mastery view is just too slow. And then there is the post-quest results screen which weirdly requires every player to accept the end screen to progress further. It has like a 40 seconds timer so if someone doesnt click "next" you will have to wait it out which is weird and can halt the pace of a gaming session a bit.

Another nitpick would be the camera: theres some sort of a soft auto lock on going on in the combat, you cant turn it off. Usually you dont mind it much but sometimes it will fuck you up. It makes some of the boss phases hard to comprehend, both visually and gameplay wise cuz your attacks will be locked to what the camera deems as your goal. Tho that only applies to specific cases.

Feels like game was made with a lot of love, theres a lot of cute character interactions and cool voicelines, small details, fate episodes, cute emotes, so on and so forth.

Overall: I think that the game is well worth the asking price. 50hrs to clear all quests might not seem to be that much when compared to behemoth like monster hunter but keep in mind that this is a totally new game, first attempt from this studio at a game like that and the game doesnt feel padded at all (there is content recycling but it felt fine to me). These 50 hours, IMO were just chock full of fun. And then you can continue to grind it or drop it, whatever u want.

Anddd there will be content updates, possibly more of a reason to grind. We dont know how many updates we will get but at least one big one is certain.
