Kinda early for a proper review, but I have to. 

Haven't been an active Granblue player for long, been mostly playing it seriously since around August/September last year? Anyway, all the months I played it before picking this up made this an absolutely enjoyable experience. This game is an absolute treat to fans of the series.

For those who aren't fans of the series, you still have a pretty damn accesible experience, the Fate Episodes do an alright-ish job of introducing you to the chars and give you a slight recap of everything that went before this game's story happens (not like it matters, this is basically the playable equivalent to a non-canon Shonen movie lmao)

As for the story itself:  it's alright, very fun but nothing you would say groundbreaking. Some of the bosses are absolutely cinematic masterpieces, though. 

In the gameplay side of things, you've got what's basically a crossbreed between Monster Hunter and FFXIV, with gacha-like progression (fear not, no microtransactions are present... just fearful GRINDING), so don't go expecting a proper ARPG. 

Most of the time you'll be fighting instanced fights against bosses with 4 goblins that may or may not know how to protect and may get instakilled because they stood right next to the boss [strike]no I am not talking by experience I perfectly know how to block I swear I haven't wiped myself out like 5 times during my first Very Hard quests in multiplayer[/strike]

Music wise it's a Granblue game. No need to say anything more. 

All in all, this game is INCREDIBLE. I still have to dive deep into the rabbit hole of Maniac and Proud quests, and from my experience in the gacha, that will be a treat. Now if you excuse me I'll go listen to End of Ragnarok on loop for 50 hours straight while working in the rice fields for our lord and savior FKHR
AWOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOGA

It was worth the 7-years wait, is how I would sum up this game. For a first entry into the "classic" PC/Console RPG genre, Cygames absolutely nailed it. There's a lot to love and little to hate in my opinion.

[h2]The good :[/h2]

- Granblue builds up on a gigantic lore from its original gacha game, and Cygames gave us a run for our money here. Literally everything but a couple characters are straight from the original game, from the NPCs to the playable characters. Some locations are original to the game. Top it off with gorgeous graphics & sceneries, as well as an amazing soundtrack faithful to its origins, and you have something to show for it.

- 19 playable characters all with their own gimmicks and personalities. It really makes you want to try all of them, and it's hard to select the 4 to keep in your party.

- The flow of combat feels [i]really[/i] good. I was scared when I heard Platinum Games was pulling out of the project, but they still managed to work it out. It's tight, dynamic, flashy but not too much, and most of all, satisfying. Nothing better than a 4-way charge attack on a boss resulting in a massive blow and stun to get your blood pumping.

- The AI is NOT dumb. They actually went to great lengths to make the AI really smart in combat: It's actually really good at dodging, using skills, supporting you, and so on. Cygames told us you could do "all content" with bots, and this looks to be true. Other companies should take notes. Like, seriously.

- Fully fleshed-out upgrade system, with upgradeable weapons, "sigils" to give yourself passives in combat, as well as skill trees. maxing out a character requires quite a bit of work, but you'll enjoy the results.

- The end-game content is where it's at. It kinda plays like Monster Hunter where you collect loot from missions to reach your ultimate build. While there are a lot of reused monsters from the campaign (albeit with many variations), it's surprisingly not a bother at all because everything else is amazing and you're just craving for more combat and better upgrades. Truly a bold move from Cygames, and they made it work. I got over a hundred hours in this game, 75% of it was post-game, and I'm still not bored (experience may vary per individual).

- Lots of convenient options such as fast-travel to NPCs for quick quest turn-in, or fast-travel to merchants or locations is also available, and that's the little things that really add up to increase your enjoyment of the game.

- Super-fast loading times (at least on NVMe, but I'm guessing even a classic SSD is fast), it's honestly "wow" how fast your can travel between locations, especially the towns where there are a ton of assets. It's super optimized and is really enjoyable.

- While the campaign is short (about 20h~ish), and not with the most elaborate plot ever, it's very Granblue-esque with lots of epic fight sequences that makes it an enjoyable experience nonetheless.

- Achievement hunters will be pleased with this game, as nothing is missable because even story chapters can be replayed after you finish the game.

- Rock-solid online coop netcode. I've had no problem finding other people to play with (for most stuff), and I NEVER had any lag issues that impaired my combat (which require precise timings). And if there is a network issue, the game automatically falls back to offline mode and players get controlled by bots so you can finish the fight. It's a super smart implementation by Cygames and, like I said above, other companies should take note : This is how you do it. Not sure what kind of magic they use for the netcode, but it works damn well.

- Last but not least, I want to add a special mention for the towns in this game. There are ABSOLUTELY GORGEOUS, brimming with life and personality. When I first visited Seedhollow, my jaw literally dropped. If I were to be reincarnated in a fantasy world, that's the kind of city I'd want to live in. And I've seen my fair share of towns in RPGs.

[h2]The bad :[/h2]

Nitpicking at this point, because there's not a lot of bad things to say, but if I were to list some:

- Campaign could've been a bit longer. the narrative & pacing was perfect for a 20h~ campaign, but I would've liked something in the 25-30h. But the end-game content makes up for it. Playing on max difficulty (Hard) was not that hard either.

- Quests feel very uninspired (get X mats, kill X monsters), I had hoped for something with more narrative like in the recent Legend of Heroes series.

- Would've liked more variety in the post-game monster missions. The combat makes up for it, but it would still have been a great plus. But I can't find it in me to blame the devs when you see everything else.

[h2]Conclusion :[/h2]

A fantastic first entry in the classic PC/Console JRPG series by Cygames. It's almost frightening how much stuff they got right, and often even better, than other studios. You can really tell they sat at the meeting table and said "OK, what are all the little things that players find annoying when playing RPGs? Let's fix those". And they freaking did. All those QoL (quality of life) things are noticeable for RPG connoisseurs, and they really enhance your experience.
I personally can't wait (and hope) for their next game. With all the experience they got building this one up, and seeing how good this one is, the next one could be a true masterpiece. They already sold 1M copies, so there is hope. They did say more content was planned for this game, too.

[b]Verdict :[/b] If you're a JRPG fan, this one is a must-buy in my opinion.
DLCs are completely optional and not really needed, just so you know. I think now's the best time to buy it because there are lots of players doing the end-game content, and I don't know how long this'll last. But, like I said, you can clear all content with bots, tho it's gonna be considerably slower because you have to gear your bots on top of your main (you should definitely invest only in 1 chara first, is my advice). And a lot of fun comes with playing with others in coop, too. I personally think the game is worth the full price, but maybe I'm biased, given my long history with the Granblue lore. But hey, you tell me.

I caved in and bought this despite the $60 USD price tag due to the great reviews this game is getting, and I'm so glad I did.  You do not need to have any context whatsoever going into this to enjoy it.  I had never heard of GranBlue before this, and I honestly had really low expectations the second I heard this came from a mobile franchise.  

However, this game started proving me wrong the moment I turned it on, and it hasn't stopped.  It blends a few different games' styles (Monster Hunter, Tales, Warframe, FFXIV) into one for a uniquely blended awesome cocktail of action w/ boss fights that are honestly probably what FFXVI was shooting for.  It's a great game.  Pick it up if you're a fan of any of the stuff I just mentioned.  You'll be pleasantly surprised.  I can't believe I'm saying that this game is worth the price tag, but it is.  Also, they got Nobuo so you know already know the OST slaps.

As someone who has played, invested way too much time, and way too much money into Gensht, I got to say this game is far superior than Gensht in every way with the game devs and the game itself respecting our time as a gamer and our wallets as a consumer. Everything you could want from Gensht can be found in this game without additional cost after the initial one time fee purchase. You'd get the same replayability+more while being able to have access to new additional characters apart from the main starting 5 characters with all of the characters having unique unlockable free weapons and unique combo style while having a multitude of play style between each character going from full dps, full tank, full support or to a mix of the 3 playstyles per each character even though some may be suited more towards one style that can be UNLOCKED FOR FREE THROUGH GAMEPLAY WITHOUT ADDITIONAL COST vs the scummy gacha mechanics in Gensht for both characters and weapons. 

Apart from those few comparisons between Gensht and Granblue Fantasy Relink, game visuals are like constant gorgeous art work as well as EXCELLENT music throughout the entire game. World exploration is more than adequate as it's a semi open world with exploration in each zone like with a Monster Hunter game. The combat and movement during combat is 100x better than Gensht. Online gameplay is quite similar to the Monster Hunter quest lobby where you talk to an NPC to access online mode as well which works extremely well since you DON'T NEED TO ALWAYS BE ONLINE WITH ONLINE BEING AN OPTIONAL FEATURE. Boss fights are VERY SIMILAR to FF14 where the boss attacks are properly telegraphed with key visuals which works extremely well with the perfect dodge and perfect block mechanics.

WE NEED MORE GAMES LIKE THIS, THUMBS UP FOR CYGAMES ON TRANSITIONING AWAY FROM GACHA GAMES TO A PROPER GAME WITH AN EXCELLENT GAMING EXPERIENCE.

It's a Final Fantasy rip-off with a generic anime story and fast, fun combat and some impressive boss fights. 

The combat is where the game shines, which I assume is largely thanks to Platinum Games' contributions during development. Tons of characters with varied, stylish playstyles. When you press a button in the game, your character does a thing.

The game also utilizes Final Fantasy tropes really well. Summons, limit breaks, materia, etc. are all here with different names and used well. Throw it all in a blender with co-op boss fights and a Monster Hunter-esque endgame and gearing system, and it just kinda works. I didn't expect to enjoy or get as much mileage out of this game as I did.

Basically, like Palworld and other derivative games, makes you realize how much the owners of some of these IPs are squandering the potential of their franchises.

The game is kinda shit until you reach the later part of the story(which is the most generic trash) and you get a good grip on the mechanics. From there on it gets better and better until you reach Proud difficulty.

I simply can't believe they made something that bad: Insanely bloated HP, one shots even with defensive builds, sigil RNG so bad you'll feel like you're playing the gacha, visual effects everywhere hiding bosses' attacks and dubious S++ rank requirements. Oh and who could forget the classic "Let's put 3 bosses at the same time!"

The quality of the experience drops so sharply past that point that i simply do not recommend it since it's built around the endgame.

tldr: Monster Hunter + gambling gear progression + spam one mission for character/weapon levelling "currency". To get to the actual game, you have to complete a single-player-only story mode (not very long). Many different playable characters with somewhat different playstyles.

Granblue Fantasy: Relink is a good, Monster Hunter-ish type of game. There are many unique characters and a grind loop in the endgame. Almost everything can be done in singleplayer with three CPUs helping you, or you can play multiplayer with randoms or friends. Be aware that if you plan on playing with friends, you'll have to spend a day or two completing the campaign first, because it can only be done in singleplayer. I haven't seen or played any previous titles in this series, and it wasn't a problem. You can read a quick recap of how you met each character if you are interested. And if you are like me, tired of watching cutscenes and dialogues, you can skip everything, and there will be a few-sentence recap of what you skipped. The gameplay itself seems pretty easy so far because you can revive yourself too many times before a "game over" screen. But doing so will earn you fewer rewards for missions and take more time to complete them.

In the endgame, on top of classic MH parts crafting and upgrading, you get a gacha-like gear acquisition. Early endgame gear is more than enough for everything in the game for now, so completely maxing your character is not required unless you want to. Most people spam a few META missions, so you will have hard times matching with anyone for something else, unless maybe peak online hours. At some point, you will have to spam one of those missions to improve your characters. Character building isn't very diverse, as you can use basically the same build on everyone (with a few tweaks). But the characters themselves have different playstyles and combos, plus you can still make some fun builds if you don't care about damage.

There are DLCs with new bosses and playable characters announced already, so the game will probably get even better.

I'm so tired of the forced loss trope.

It's like an entire generation of developers watched a video essay on Sans and thought "oh so I just make the player lose. that'll make my villain look super duper fuckin mighty"

Please, if you're a developer making a game, and you're going to employ this trope, just don't do it 4 times in 8 hours of gameplay. I'm begging you.

The game is... alright? Characters are very flashy to use, but feel mechanically very one-note. You're Siegfried? Press the button at the right time. You're Yodarha? Make sure you're stacking finishers before using skills. Rosette's the only one that feels dynamic to me. The game gets away with this fairly well on account of satisfying animations, and a wide enough variety of options that you're not *just* mashing attack, but Relink fails to inspire in me the feeling of "wow, there's actually a lot more to this charcter than it seems" like weapons in say, Monster Hunter.

Boss Design has flashes of brilliance and flashes of big dumb. Maglielle(?) is a boss who feels like a pretty wonderful fusion of MMO, bullet hell, and traditional ARPG style boss design. Thoroughly fun to fight. She's followed by two gimmick fights against super giant enemies that are a lot more running around than actually fighting, and gee willickers it's another forced loss (I think this is #3 in less than 8hrs gameplay?). This all happens at a point when it felt like the game was building momentum in a good way, then proceeded to shoot itself in the foot.

Higher difficulty options are needed from the outset. If you pay attention to the basic mechanics and bother to keep one or two characters up to date for the point you're at in the story, you will not face a real challenge until 25+ hours if then. The game doesn't have the kind of story that'll keep players new to Granblue interested, so having the ability to kick up the challenge early game would go a long way.

The story is what you expect from something that traces it's lineage to Gacha. Very flat, tropey, heavily depends on the quality of its character designs to get by. The setting seems pretty neat but I just don't find myself caring for the plot even as I started out wanting to.

[b]REVISION AFTER REACHING ENDGAME[/b]

The endgame almost fixes some of my problems, but introduces a bunch of new ones.

For one, it's virtually 100% recycled content. Unlike monster hunter, you aren't grinding familiar fights to see new ones, you're grinding to see the same ones with a few new tricks. For a game that was developed for 7 years and has beaucoup gacha bucks behind it, I'm really sour on how limited the boss roster is. 

Many maniac and more egregiously proud difficulty quests involve fighting multiple generic bosses at once, which clearly weren't designed to be together. What a tragedy, I finally found the challenge and it comes from having to manage the terrible lock on system and pay attention to three bosses at once such that I'm still guarding/dodging while putting out damage. I don't normally bust out the L word but this is straight up lazy design. 

Lastly, the endgame is horrendously starved for essential QoL features, compounded by the bad UI design. You will regularly spend 5-10+ minutes going through your inventory, option by option, individually selecting everything you need to recycle. You must transmute sigils one by one, which adds more pointless menuing. Given how short fights can be and how long menuing, selling, transmuting and making adjustments can be, you may genuinely spend half your time in the endgame in menus.

Ultimately if you need a new grinding game, Relink might do it for you on sale. It's a game that does well on spectacle, runs well and isn't buggy but seems to fall short in most every other department, Wide but not deep, long but not varied, and full of issues that realistically should have been addressed in its 7 long years of development.

Pros:
-Great entry for gamers into this hunting action genre  (imo it's in this genre since post game 90% of the quests drops u into an arena to fight 1 boss . Or very rarely 2/3 boss jammed together with no sense of coherence)
-graphics, sound, music, designs (while based on the original franchise) are beautiful
-Main story Boss fights are choreographed rather nicely
-Some oddly good QoL for an RPG (teleporting to side quest giver, Wishlist; Repeat quest immediately) 

Cons:
-Main story quest is only 20 hours
-only 20 bosses at end game . a few of them have reskinned versions , notably one Ancient Dragon which has a grand total of 7 skins. Quite a turn off
-Characters, while very easy to pick up, have rather low skill ceiling. Your character gets stronger mostly from equipment and sigils, which are all from grinding. Few aspects that let the player feel good for making skillful plays
-Almost no sense of achievement when even has highest Maniac Difficulty, with a group of players at that power level, the quests end is 5 min. 10 mins tops, except for the final 2 bosses
-Outside of Main story, most maps are just 1 round arena. 
-Some VERY QUESTIONABLE DECISIONS e.g. no minimap , or even a basic map for the any of the towns; no  batch gacha at Siero's; no skip function for Fate Episodes; very long Mastery tree which you have to scroll down manually; no options to turn off damage numbers; NOT ABLE TO REMAP CONTROLS

Absolutely stellar action RPG that doesn't fall into the pits that a typical JRPG does, (being way too fucking long) but has a ton of content for the players who actually enjoy the super long games more in the vein of the Tales Of series.

The story of the game is pretty standard fare, but makes up for it by not dragging you its feet and getting right to the point. The bulk of the story can be completed in around 10-15 hours, which is where the rest of the game picks up. The end game consists of quests in the style of a Monster Hunter title, where you go out and fights enemies/bosses to collect *things* with which to become more powerful through a nebulous but nonetheless easy to understand game-play loop.

The sole complaint I have with this system is the endgame devolving into mindless grinding for a set of weapons that drop exclusively from one mission, but they're rare drops, so you end up repeating the mission endlessly, and it just fucking sucks.

Amazing game.
I'm usually not a big fan of action games (couldn't get into Elden Ring and DMC series), yet this game managed to make it's fast paced action very easy to pick up, but have a lot of depth and very high skill ceiling. Even if one character doesn't click, there is a huge roster with vastly different play styles to try which prevent you from getting bored. 

The fantastic looking art style is just the cherry-on-top. It's similar to Tales and Arise and I absolutely love it.

However, this game is not perfect. The main story is just servicable. Voice acting is pretty good, but the story is too short and not very engaging. The side character's stories "Fate Episodes" are a real missed opportunity. They could have at least went with Tales of Arise's comic book style without spending too much effort on it, but it feels like they really run out of budget at this point and just give up ...

In short:

Beautiful game, very little issues on launch easy to pick up and has a high skill ceiling with animation canceling. Perfectly parrying/dodging attacks and weaving your attacks feel great. You feel like a boss when you're maintaining DPS because you perfectly dodged while everybody else running for their lives, dodging mechanics.

Endgame gameplay loop is like doing mini FF14 raids with a MonsterHunter Rise style partying system. This is a good base for a game that hopefully will become like Monster Hunter Rise Sunbreak with more solid updates coming in that would create more play styles and harder content as the end game is pretty easy and isn't much prestige. There's no achievements for soloing bosses and camera lock on is dogshit, turn off all the auto options for camera.

Pros:
[list]
[*] Fun gameplay that feels smooth and responsive.Also has a high skill ceiling with animation canceling that can vary per character. Although there are some brain dead characters too.
[*] Abundance of different characters with different playstyles
[*] Has light auto farm capabilities to make the grind easier and you can save scum. I appreciate ways that can lessen any sort of grinding as I value my time.
[*] Looks great very animu, much weeb
[*] Good QoL features that let you teleport around NPCs and quest finishing. Also Wish listing item drops. Although it is missing the option to roll multiple times when you have an abundance of resources to gamble.
[*] You can somewhat tune your difficulty by playing solo without a party or with a party or with randoms.
[/list]

Cons / Nitpicks
[list]
[*] The lock on camera is god awful. Half the fight is you against the camera some times. If there's more than 2 enemies on the screen, the lock on will drive you insane. Learning how to play without it is a must.
[*] Endgame builds are the same for every character due to the damage cap system. Builds only open up when playing without a party darksouls style vs bosses, but due to this bosses with DPS checks seem to be undoable solo.
[*] No option to dial down effects of other players like in Monster hunter or FF14 so there is a huge lack of clarity in fights, this is especially bad when you can die in 1-2 hits.
[*] Boring variety of bosses. You just fight multiple bosses or reskinned boss models.
[/list]
O_O

Granblue Fantasy Relink offers an expansive and rewarding experience that extends far beyond the main story. With a plethora of content awaiting discovery, including the pursuit of level 150 weapons and legendary sigils, completionists will find themselves immersed in a world brimming with challenges and secrets.

One of the game's strengths lies in its replayability, allowing players to engage in quests repeatedly to enhance their characters and skills, whether they have just a few minutes or several hours to spare. The flexibility in playtime caters to a variety of gaming preferences and schedules.

For those seeking a true test of skill, the Maniac and Proud difficulty levels deliver a formidable challenge that demands strategic thinking and precise execution. Success hinges on careful preparation, including the selection and utilization of sigils tailored to each boss encounter.

Granblue Fantasy Relink stands as a testament to its worth, offering a rich and enduring adventure that justifies both its price and the investment of time. Whether delving into its depths for the first time or embarking on subsequent playthroughs, players are sure to find ample enjoyment and satisfaction in this remarkable title.
Overall, Granblue is way worth the price and time.

[h1] Highly addictive multiplayer beat-em-up [/h1]
I have seen people likening this game to an anime Monster Hunter, which I only partially agree with. As opposed to the slow and methodical gameplay found in the Monster Hunter franchise, Granblue Fantasy Relink opts for an arguably simpler, and beginner-friendly combat loop. The game, however, does offer its own unique strengths in the form of extensive build varieties.
[b] The Goodies: [/b]
My only experience with the Granblue franchise was some brief experimentations with the main browser game and the spin-off fighting game. Nevertheless, according to my limited understanding of the lore, you don’t really need to play any of the other games to jump right into this one. The game features a typical anime storyline with a protagonist and their fellows beating monsters to save the world. What I do enjoy about most games in this franchise is their stories’ sypnosis system and detailed encyclopedia about the franchise, which can help new and returning players catch up to speed.
The main gameplay consists of you taking on quests (mainly beating monsters up) in different biomes, which is similar to a Monster Hunter game, albeit with a lack of an expedition or meal system. Finishing these quests nets you goodies to upgrade your characters and weapons. The game currently features a cast of 18 playable characters, each with their own unique playstyle and set of skills, which consequently leads to quite a bit of build potentials.
[b] The Not-so-Goodies: [/b]
The game can get quite grindy towards the end, especially when there is RNG involved; which is not surprising considering the original browser game relies heavily on a Gacha system. Regardless, the game is plenty of fun without tackling the endgame contents, and you will most likely burnout trying out all of the playable characters long before.
[b] Conclusion: [/b]
The game is great if you’re interested in getting into the franchise, or if you’re looking for a more laxed version of Monster Hunter.

Completed the main story within 17H on Action difficulty, which I assume to be the normal. For the most part, the game is not hard, the story however is the standard granblue fantasy mobage story where it emphasize on the power of nakama. Only got stuck on the final chapter boss where it requires some damage check and I think I am under level. You could just change the difficulty to story and clear the final boss.
Then the 2nd part of the game begins, where you would need to grind to get more powerful weapons and higher level with higher difficulty quests. The good thing is, you can invite ppl to join your game to help you. I think this would add another 5 - 10 hours to the game depending on what is your objective (if you are perfectionist, most likely getting more hours due to grind). 
Overall, I think this is a good game. But if you  want to have the best bang for your buck, hoping this could burn your hundreds of hours like monster hunter, this might not be the game for you.

I love the character designs and Franchise BUT the game was a huge false advertisement for me. Sure within the latest CBT or Reviews it could have been clear what it is and what not BUT I got overly hyped for so many ears and with all that was mentioned and shown before I thought I had no need to discover something I thought is not the case. What I mean is. I hoped for a fast open world game with deep story telling. But in the end it is a Monster Hunter clone with small or medium areas you get teleported to and grind monsters. Which is tedious to say at least. It takes forever and the waves sometimes seems kinda endless. It sadly hits the current agenda people like to play: End game hard mode. But I hate that. I wanna have a chill time and enjoy a good story and not a bunch of characters constantly talking story related paragraphs in the middle of a fight. But in the end the story is sadly something you can ignore anyway. I got a refund and bought Persona 3 Reload. A much better choice. All the waiting for this game was for nothing.

Honestly, I wouldn't play the game unless you A) play Granblue Fantasy and want a giggle at seeing some of the gacha characters brought to 3D, or B) you enjoy mindless grinding with questionable at best gameplay on a screen full of visual gibberish.

Yes, the artwork and the OST are amazing - as is known of Granblue as a general rule. But even as a fan of the setting, all this game presented me with was the fact it is a clearly unfinished project they shipped off as a stitched together, salvaged zombie of what they hoped it could be. 
Cygames will be drip feeding some of the missing content for the next few years at a crawling pace to keep it alive, but that won't do much to you unless you can live off of the "ah! I know that guy/fight/boss/event!" feeling stemming from other Granblue material. 
Unfortunately and in my personal opinion, the game has a very big "meh" plastered on it on a fundamental level, and the only reason I've played through it is my previous investment in the characters. Were I to rely only on its actual content/storyline, I would have given up around the ten hour mark if not earlier.

To its credit, all technical parts work. No bugs, perfect performance, online services smoothly working, the UI is pretty and well done for the most part and the translation to English is... well, it's alright.
But if you read any review that says you don't need previous knowledge of the series to enjoy this game, know that is entirely false. Everything pans out under the assumption you play the gacha, know all the characters involved and previous events, and essentially are there for the insider knowledge.

Granblue Fantasy: Relink
It's great when a game just works.

The graphics?
Stunning. A unified, clean series of designs for every aspect of the world.
Everything is done in engine. No crunched up FMV's to be seen until the credits roll.
Player and boss super attacks are well choreographed, sending graphic effects flowing across the screen to contrast with the more grounded normal combat.

The plotline?
Pure, undiluted, A+ anime tropes. I knew absolutely nothing about Granblue lore and it brought me up to speed, then proceeded to deliver anime climax after climax after climax. Each of the main story episodes is about an hour long. Each with some sort of amazingly choreographed boss fight at the end, starting with the wind god. I did like ~1 episode a day and side quests and the pacing was pretty good.
None of the major boss fights are wasted, each letting one of your supporting characters shine or letting one of the villains chew the scenery. Even the few re-fights in the end game boss rush are paced correctly, lower hp, their attack patterns altered and different methods of support. 
And when you think you're done? More bosses, bigger stakes.

The gameplay?
Very nice. Each character is like a musou character, with some sort of semi unique mechanic and a list of skills to choose four from.
You get 6 characters to choose from to start, then you can choose to unlock more as the story progresses. The extra characters don't seem to have a story role though, so I left them aside.
You lead a party of four characters, where you play as only one of them while the others are played by AI.
The AI isn't braindead and took care of keeping healing in reserve (though having multiple healers will cause them to overlap their heals) or starting a super attack chain at the appropriate moments. They also are aware how enemy bosses super attacks work and can mostly avoid the glowing circles without cheating.

The grinding?
The main story with all the side quests took, 10 hours? Going though the multiplayer mode with npcs took me to 32 hours. So the grinding really increases in the post story.
The post story grinding is pretty bad, since it involves you running a mission on repeat to get [whatever you need right now]. Repeating a single 5 minute mission to get resources is boring.

Unique mechanics to encourage cooperation.
Link attacks that can be performed when you exhaust the enemies stun bar. If you are within a generous distance to the stunned enemy, anyone can press the interact button to fly to the enemy and attack, this builds up a meter that activates 'bullet time' when the team all does a link attack.
Super attack chains. Chaining together your characters supers attacks adds a bonus super attack on at the end based on how many players chained their attacks together. It's also cool when the characters shout out the extra attack name in unison.
Team based failure. The team shares a failure timer that drains while one or more characters are down on zero HP. Each player can self revive by mashing but having an ally interact with you revives you faster.

The bosses are great. They shift between a normal or warm up attack pattern, but can also enter an enrage mode where they have harder attack patterns that drains over time. But it also drains quicker if you hit them, encouraging your to keep the offence up. Also, when you break their enrage mode they enter a down phase for free hits.
Bosses also have limited use spectacular attacks where they turn virtually invulnerable and force the players to be on the back foot temporarily.
The constant shifting of boss tempos between the normal, enrage phase, invincible phase and stuns keeps each boss fight varied.

The multiplayer?
I don't know. The main storyline doesn't allow for co-op play. The multiplayer capable missions are very short and mindless. So I would label this game as singleplayer first, with a bonus multiplayer mode added onto the end.
I tried to queue for a multiplayer side mission early in the game, and the game queue timed out and told me to switch back to single player mode. There probably isn't a mid mission join feature. I'd like to run side missions with AI and leave my game open for humans to join in if they wanted.
Apparently players are scaled down to the lowest level player, so having friends at different levels might work out alright, instead of the overleveeled friend stomping everything.

There is a quick play mode that unlocks after the main story, but I haven't been able to find anyone. Maybe there is region locking or something.
Since quick play just spins the wheel and drops you into a random mission, it would be great if the 'repeat mission' button would just take you to another random mission while in quick play mode. Anything that encourages repeating the same mission over and over is a surefire way to burn players out.

[h1]This game has no right to be this good[/h1]
First, let me open the windows real quick:
Downsides are criminally bad EN voice acting (for the love of god switch to the godtier JP VA) and localization, some stability jank and hub CPU overhead despite the good perfs and instant loading times, badly thought-out co-op downscaling that makes playing with underleveled friends a sad experience, underwhelming rewards for quick-questing, no PC<->PS crossplay, no GBF codes on PC, and multitarget attack magnetism hating you.
Okay, we can breathe now.

[b]We are only in February and it's already my [i]mercilessly[/i] uncontested GOTY.[/b]

Immediately buy it now if you like any of those: Character-action combat (Platinum games), MMORPG raidboss mechanics, Final Fantasy aesthetics, Monster Hunter beast slaying and game loop, Tales of JRPG comfort food, Skies of Arcadia or floating islands in general, or huge angry lizards.
Worth at a discount if you just want to enjoy the short and generic, but explosively spectacular tutorial that is the main story.

[b]Gameplay, presentation, visuals, and soundtrack [i]are at the top[/i] of the J-ARPG genre.[/b]
Count 60-ish hours to complete the game up to the current Proud difficulty last boss. 8-16 intense hours if you only want to play the main story. Hundreds if you want to be that one guy with every character maxed to high heaven. Post-game is very challenging and has some cheesable grind.

[h1]Unexpectedly blue skies[/h1]
Granblue Versus first introduced me to the franchise with a stellar fighting game, and made me fall in love with its world -as a huge fan of anything celestial fantasy- and its characters, from my goofy main bro Lowain to the ever so popular Narmaya. After a while, I made the mistake of touching the browser game and got hooked by its progression, story, grid system, Narita's music ( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zPjsv056BXE ) and Minaba's pretty draph pictures ( https://gbf.wiki/Character_Tier_List pick your poison).
While every love story has its honeymoon, what follows is often a bitter marathon. [b]And good lord if Cygames isn't a company that masters the monkey paw like no other...[/b]
Every great addition was punctuated by terrible management decisions and very strong disconnections with their games' identities and playerbases. After years of going through nonsensical balancing in VS (and still going, hello 66L), and debacles like GBF's infamous summer fortune, revans weapons BS and simply inhumane grinds, I got used to the ways of that company... Or so I thought.

After 7 tumultuous years of development, what we thought was basically vaporware, came back from development hell to slap our collective behinds, into a now million-selling release on PC alone. And... just wow.

[h1]A game that knows exactly what it wants to do[/h1]
The identity crisis most JRPGs and ARPGs face generally takes the form of a thick layer of bland-tasting fat, with stories that try being impactful but fall flat, convoluted and broken systems, endless padded sidequests and oh my god the pacing! Here, most of it is trimmed, with some remnants to remind you that this is a Granblue game, and to lure you in with some sweet suspension of disbelief. And by the time you realize it, [b]you're enjoying the gameplay so much you just forget about everything else[/b]. You know the story is McDonalds JRPG slop. Relink knows the story is McDonalds JRPG slop. You look at each other and nod, then cut to the chase.

There's the hubs, the main story and the co-op monster hunter-like gameloop. Everything else is treated like the aforementioned fat and aggressively cut. Forget long character intro monologue cutscenes. Here you have a few gists in voiced text blocks in the form of fate episodes. Collectables? There's just a few barely hidden chests in your way. Side-quests? It's just auto-complete stuff you automatically hit as you progress through co-op with some handy repeatables for that endgame grind. Character banter? Percival orders Vane to bark for him as you chain skybound arts together, no need for a dedicated cutscene that cuts your gameplay for 5 minutes.
Dialogues and cutscenes exist to put the fights in context and that's it, and they are all skippable and handily summed up if need be. Hub area, dialogue, short cutscene, repeat. [b]The momentum never stops[/b] and you surprise yourself binge-eating the game at 2 AM, wanting for more every chapter...

...And that's only the tutorial.

All of it is presented in a polished package with one of the most beautiful and tightly executed art directions this techart nerd has ever seen. It's [b]Hideo Minaba's illustrations coming alive[/b], with jaw-dropping vistas and hub areas that brim with life and personality from Folca's retired draph soldiers teaching swordfighting to a bunch of kids to Ghandagoza getting lost in Seedhollow's backstreets.
The visual effects are omnipresent and bursting with energy while staying perfectly readable in some Proud fights' bullet hell situations. I very much know how difficult these things are to pull off and this simply leaves me in admiration.

[b]The game keeps raising the bar on every chapter in every form[/b]. And one I haven't talked about yet is the soundtrack. In short, you are not ready.
As always, Tsutomu Narita + Nobuo Uematsu + Stella Magna is a very deadly combination.
While it sometimes re-uses tracks from good ol' GBF, it has many original tracks that are among Narita's very best works. If you don't mind me spoiling you the battle track for the base antagonist in the game's cover art, Id, here's a sample of what you can expect from this game: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RDq5_PZ57xg

[h1]And now, the meat[/h1]
[b]This is the best-feeling action combat I have ever touched[/b]. It's heavy and observant like Monster Hunter, fast and deep like a bayonetta, over-the-top flashy like a Metal Gear Rising, strategic and demanding like an MMO raidboss, bullet hell-y like a Nier Automata, and has big number soup that goes brrr with insanely complex itemization theorycrafting like.... Granblue Fantasy.
You control one character in a Xenoblade-y party of four, starting with 6 base playable skyfarers and a pool of 12 you progressively choose and unlock as you progress through the game.
They are all incredibly varied, ranging from Lancelot's mash & dodge gorilla gameplay to Rosetta's buff and rose turret uptime rotation, Zeta's pogo stick loops with gradually tighter timings, Narmaya's super technical and fun stance dancing, Eugen's third person shooter mode, Io's cast-for-hours nukes... Every character is like playing a different game, and not a single one of them is boring, with multiple possible builds each. Fantastic kit design.
Teammates can be players or CPU, which are, surprisingly, [i]really[/i] good, like, better than the average player!
You hit, hit harder with another button, do character-specific combo routes, manage character mechanics and stacks/bars/etc, block, dodge, jump, attack in the air, use one of four skills of your choice, break enemy "parts", do linked attacks, chain ultimate moves into each other, use a variety of potions, revive teammates, become a doormat, spam silly stickers when the big dragon boss fires a huge laser so that all your teammates can see on their screen is a dumb obscure old man GBF meme bathed in blinding, lethal light.
Your equipment consists of your levellable weapon (customizable stat stick) and slots for sigils which contain traits that conditionally modify your stats or build you a certain way. This is pretty much GBF's grid and weapon mod system, and if there's one thing GBF vets will always say good things about aside from the pretty JPEGs, it's the grid.

Starting off let me just clarify that I don't really play JRPG's so I was going into this one with an open mind! I do find this game more of a Hybrid JRPG/Monster Hunter game  rather then a full JRPG experience , The main story itself being the JRPG and the After-story being the Monster Hunter side.

The Art :
The game itself is visually amazing , the views you get and stylised backgrounds are wonderful to look at even while fighting/exploring and whatever else you get upto! There are plenty of different area's and unique things to discover , The animations are flashy and the game provides a very nice cinematic experiance overall. Not much to complain about here , only praise from me.

The Controls/Camera :
I played with a Game pad and found a typically easier experiance , only thing that is a real bother is the camera in certain fights pan's upwards and makes it a tad hard to see the telegraphed floor markers , With this in mind , I have also found the Locking-on to be . . . Meh , as there are times when your doing a DPS phase and while being locked onto the part you can hit as a Melee , it will instead lock-on to a part you are unable to hit , but you will attack it all the same, so you waste time trying to reset yourself which is a massive annoyance

The Campaign :

Its around 10 - 15 hrs long I would say depending on skill level and whatnot regardless I did enjoy it very much and very invested through-out the story , With Chapters leading upto a boss fight in each act , it sets you up to experience what you will be doing in the after-story , as a bonus there are Character specific mini-stories you can do to explore their story and gain small side bonuses for doing so with each story being about 20 mins total

The Monster Hunting Part :

So now you beat the story , you will pretty much be levelling and grinding out various systems to increase your power to complete progressively harder fights , nothing untoward really , This does involve a ton of farming which can be very monotonous because you will need to farm A LOT. You will be using  multiple Gacha style systems to increase your PWR rating with some pieces of gear being gained from blind luck , well . . . a good few pieces of gear , It also doesn't really give you an idea of how important certain skills are and just kind of expects you to know when your at your DMG CAP  for example

Overall :

This game is pretty nice , I was worried about the price but so far at 100hrs I feel I have my money's worth and I think with some QoL improvements it will be really nice for sure , even better with friends if you have those

Over-all, it's what I was looking for out of this game, has a monster hunter hub-feel, and play with upgrading weapons, and the mid maxing of stats through gem items as well as being able to slot in a gem to you're weapon. Multiple different characters, who all have there unique play styles. Adding to engaging and fun fights against different bosses, with just as different elemental properties, and characters with there own countering elements. 

A simple but impact stat/mastery system. End game looks like trying to get better rolls on gems as well as. . . gems to put into you're weapon that best compliments you're favorite character with you're favorite way to play them. All characters are great to play but hard to master, and the flexibility on how you build them makes for useful and fun ways to play them (characters) depending on if you want to use them to farm a certain mission or mid max for a hard boss-battle. 

There are slots to save different builds to use as the developers thought of this since it definitely looks like they play-tested the game with all the creature comforts they have in the game AT LAUNCH and not to patch in later... you know who you are games... looking at you darktide.

So let's start with the cons:

-Very short campaign. If you ignored sidequests you could probably finish it in maybe 10 hours.
-VERY EASY campaign. Not a hard negative, but even with just a smidge of grinding every fight felt like a breeze, even on the hardest difficulty
-Not all the characters are balanced. Poor Gandaghoza.
-Monster designs are almost too stereotypically fantasy. Griffins, goblins and dragons? You can have fun with those, but please get even a little creative with them!

And now the pros:

-VERY good post-game. I don't know why they waited until after the main story to start the Monster Hunter style gameplay loop, but once it hits it hits!
-A very pretty game in every way. The location design and music are all top-notch, and it has some truly impressive set pieces. Excavalion boss fight, anyone?
-Very fun and intuitive combat- for the most part. Once again, poor Gandagoza.
-The writing and voice acting is very good. Controversial take, but the English VA is extremely well done.

And this is where I confess that for me the big draw, the thing that finally got me to buy the game, the ONE THING that drew me in:

HOLY SHIT IT'S AN ANIME GAME WHERE I CAN MAKE A TEAM OF BURLY MIDDLE AGED MEN and one Yoda knockoff ~I guess~ BUT HOLY SHIT ITS NOT ALL WAIFUS AND ANIME TWINKS HECK YEAH EUGEN VASERAGA AND GHANDAGOZA the only way it could be better is if we added Soriz

As far as this game goes it's alot of fun and even though the grind is made insanely grindy just to squeeze replayability out of the game, with the decent gameplay, nice visuals and co-op you can overlook this. The soundtrack as usual with Cy, is really nice. That aside, with GBVS being out and most of this cast being in that game, I would have liked more of the player SBAs from that game to be featured here as well as Primals as summons would have been nice just to add variety to characters Kits and players options. (Zeta's kit is...pretty freaking lame and quickly repetitive. You could have did her better justice Cy...). Ares, Tiamat, Noa, Colossus, Leviathan, Yggdrasil and even Bahamut are all relegated to the background and/or not even used when you could have had a summoning system in the game...

Outfits - Color palettes for outfits?! REALLY? Big Sis Narmaya has at least 5-6 different variants in the mobile (most others have the same thing), you could have brought those over into your first major AAA release... Heck, you don't even allow people to pick the classic Djeeta/Gran outfit in favor of the new outfit if they wanted to....lame.

Combat - Chaining combos is awesome, to the point of learning out to use a character to maximize your output is pretty rewarding. Most characters kits are engaging and unique (Zeta was again, pretty robbed...). The only problem becomes the same typical problem you deal with in RPGs. Every.Single.Goon in the game has next to no hit stun and can just outright steam roll you whenever they want to, right down to basic goblins and wolves...so all those practiced combos go to waste because you're forced to dodge and block on a constant basis by enemies that are seemingly spamming X and Skills more than you are. This can be fixed with things like increased dodge immunity after perfect dodge, Stout heart, or even an increase to stun power. But this is so ridiculous to have to go this far just so an enemy will act like they're being hit. It's nonsense. Games doing this is getting old....

Story - The story is fine. A bit cheesy and at points is laughable in how little sense something makes or a character action is. I do like that Djeeta/Gran aren't silent and will say the dialogue option you pick, that's really cool. I think you could have utilized more QTE here and there to kick up the scenes and engage players for having them watch, but it's fine. The big poo-poo is that none of the story is co-op which is just a head-scratchingly stupid decision. There is plenty of juicy aspects that would have been fun to do in the story scenario with a friend and I was looking forward to that only to find it was gone. It makes even less sense since when you join another player you talk about story spoilers and toggling it when you can't even do story...so why the useless disclaimer? Just because you can fight a boss? That's not spoiling anything...

Targeting - This whole system can be a bit wonky just because the natural lockon of skills is so good that I often drop it. Additionally, the camera often can lose track of you and worse of it, is that bosses have so many target options, that sometimes you get locked onto a spot that's not reachable and you're just blindly swinging at something you can't hit. Thus, I mostly don't even use this system unless I pick up throwable items and want to chuck them from deep. This system needs a touch up.

Quick Quests - Freaking Quick Quests....I get that you have mobile game roots. It vomits ALL OVER GBR with Dalia Badges and Knickknack vouchers (Both are utterly stupid and useless currency that exists to bloat replayability). Again, artificial replayability by putting in gacha and an overinflated grind to max out and build characters. Fair. But Quick Quest....the 'underleveling' for Quick Quest has got to be the dumbest thing this game offers aside from the fact you can't play any of the story in co-op. Why are you nullifying player progression in Quick Quest by scaling players down to match the quest? False advertising. It outright states you'll get a quest in range of Easy - Very Hard+. They are NEVER on Easy because you dumb down players characters to match the stage. I fought Vulkan Bolla in Undertake Quest and beat him in less than a minute. Legit got the SAME quest right after that in Quick Quest only for it to take nearly 6 mins+ because you scaled me down to match it JUST so you could make the quest difficult. This makes no sense when you already HAVE quests you can just match to my power level and it doubly makes no sense because you don't underlevel people in regular quests and you don't do it in story chapter select to the point players can beat Id in the first encounter because they're so overpowered yet...yet...you underlevel players for quick quest? Idiotic. The underleveling for Quick Quests should be freaking patched out, it's dumb.

All these things aside, the game is fine and would love to see more content drop, namely characters, quests, and ACTUAL costumes. This game is psudo live service, so these new additions would be nice and I know there are already plans. Playing the story co-op would equally be nice, but I guess that's a pipe dream now. Oh well, cheers, thanks for the game Cy~!

I have been waiting for this game for a while and wasn't sure what to expect out the gate... Fast-forward a week and it has become one of my favorite passtimes. 

Grandblue Fantasy: Relink manages to captivate the player with its immersive play style, build crafting, and expansive universe at every turn. You will find yourself spending hours trying to obtain that one weapon or sigil that completes your build.

While the game had a rocky launch on Steam, the game itself was still too good to dismiss. With the popularity of "review bombing" earlier on, I am always hesitant to dismiss games on Steam reviews alone. Hence why I spent an ample amount of time playing this game thus far before I decided to put my thoughts out there. 

If you want to know where I am at in the game...
I have beaten every fight with an S++ rating, 100% of all collectibles, and even have 100% completed 4 characters (Rackam, Ferry, Lancelot, Io). Yes, this includes siglis+'s and [redacted] weapons. The game just makes you want to go for it when it comes to building out your characters. 

The game plays kind of like the God Eater games, mixed with a little bit of Monster Hunter, and the fantasy elements of the Final Fantasy series. Yet, it still stands out as its unique IP. The story may not be for everyone, but the world surrounding it is beautifully crafted. I found myself looking to find out more info on each of the characters and references that were hidden throughout the game. 

The game presents a fairly linear storyline to end game loop progression that takes into consideration teaching the player things as they become applicable. There were a few misses where some things could have been explained earlier (curio RNG, Knickknack vouchers, Sigil + versions, and crewmate card usage). There are now plenty of us past this point that would have benefited from knowing more, but that is part of learning in a new game. Make sure to check out many of the guides out there explaining the system before you commit to spending those resources super early on.

Regarding the multiplayer end game aspect... The loop feels great. I find myself WANTING to grind out more things for my favorite characters. There are a few things I would like to see change (repeat quest when more than 2 people select it and improvements on where to find items per quest), but for the most part it is just really enjoyable. The progression from 'Easy' to 'Proud' feels fantastic, too. They took into consideration the type of task you need to do as you advanced which I thought was neat. Felt like a real guild was assigning you quests based on your rank and skill. Because of this, I always found myself adjusting my sigils + playstyle as I progressed. 

In closing, I have enjoyed the game and am so looking forward to the updates to come. Give the game a try! You might just end up enjoying it!

Longtime Granblue player here. It's great to see that Cygames was finally able to release after a series of unfortunate delays as well as a global pandemic. As someone who has been waiting for this game for over 6 years, I can happily say that it was worth the wait. 

To start, it looks fantastic and the approach that Cygames took with the art style both maintains the Granblue Fantasy style while also giving it a fresh coat of 3-Dimensional HD paint that the series deserves. Every character model oozes personality and does justice by their gacha game counterparts. Their models are well-detailed and their animations, both in and out of combat, ooze personality. 

The soundtrack is great as well. Classic tunes get new versions that help set the mood of the more idyllic setting of the base game (Sierokarte's shop theme being a softer acoustic guitar instead of being a high-speed folk violin solo). Bosses, which will comprise most of your playtime, will have a variety of themes from pretty par-for-the-course RPG boss themes, to chiptune(?), to full-on power ballads as you take on some of the game's toughest fights. 

If I could describe the gameplay, I would compare it to the controls of a "Tales of" game with gameplay loop that presents itself as more of an arcade-y Monster Hunter, except instead of picking out a weapon to define your playstyle, you're picking up one of Granblue Fantasy's iconic, or not-so-iconic characters. This game was worked on by Platinum Games, the studio responsible for games such as Bayonetta or Nier Automata, and as such the combat is fast-paced and sleek. For veterans of character-action games this game will be relatively easy early on, but the difficulty ramps up nicely towards the end with fights that demand deeper character knowledge to meet DPS checks as well as avoiding AoEs that are vaguely reminiscent of Final Fantasy XIV raids. 

For those who are not are used to games such as this, there are a variety of accessibility options that can make it easier for you such as the "Story" difficulty that will make fights easier for you as well as the Assist settings that streamline gameplay for you. While these options will make a fair bit of the content easier for players who need them, you will need to learn how to interact with the game's systems in order to conquer the high-end challenges. 

In regards to story, this game gives you a self-contained story that is connected to the lore and world-building of the original Granblue Fantasy, but can be enjoyed without knowledge of previous works. Additionally, all playable characters also have additional story beats that give players additional insight into who they are and is fully-voiced. My biggest complaint about this game is in regards to its story. The game's main story, while having some fantastic peaks, is ultimately your standard shounen adventure. It's not bad by any means, but coming from a company that has shown its playerbase that it can put out excellent narrative in the mobile game such as Home Sweet Moon, And You, and the What Makes the Sky Blue trilogy it's a shame how safe Relink's story can be. 

All said, this is an excellent game that I would wholeheartedly recommend even at full price to Granblue newcomers and especially fans of the original. Cygames has already planned content to be released for at least the next three months including an endgame super boss and two new characters, however given the positive reception I wouldn't be surprised if they went even further.

List of itches this game scratches for me:

Badass big boss battles (Ex: Final Fantasy, Monster Hunter, etc.)? ✓
Fluid combat & mechanics (Feels like FFXIV raid mechanics, and certain characters, like Io, can feel similarly (black mage?)) ✓
Grindy yet impactful gearing/skill system (Feels like Genshin Artifact farming without the horrid RNG and time gating) ✓
Endgame co-op with actual difficulty? (Feels like Remnant & Remnant 2 on Proud difficulty) ✓
Anime aesthetic that doesn't look cheap/uninspired (Feels like the Tales series & Genshin) ✓
Gacha-feel unlock system without ANY micro-transactions (You farm character unlock tickets and choose)? ✓
Diverse play styles & characters (19+ very unique characters, more announced for future DLC)? ✓
Actually GOOD NPC AI (CPU-controlled units can be used through any stage of the game to very good success)? ✓

List of issues for me:

Not a massively talkative player base (most communication is via stickers, like MHW).
Relatively short, semi-generic story (took me around ~12-13 hours; including minor exploration & some side quests).
Most rewarding co-op content locked behind completion of story mode (matchmaking pre-Proud difficulty is very hard).

Overall, I give this game a solid 8.5-9/10. Definitely a fantastic game joining the 2024 GOTY contenders (with Palworld, Enshrouded, Etc.).

A derivative game that excels in its execution. Elements of Phantasy Star Online, Trials of Mana (Remake), and Kingdom Hearts blend together to form a satisfying JRPG with enjoyable boss battles and snappy action.

The story is predictable and cliche, but ultimately inoffensive and buoyed by its fast pace, phenomenal setpieces, and well-directed and animated cutscenes. The narrative won't surprise you, but possesses the comfort and joy of a Saturday morning cartoon.

The mission-based game structure and boss design are much closer to Phantasy Star Online than Monster Hunter—special moves, constant cut-ins, and telegraphed bullet hells await. Relink does an excellent job teaching you the many different fights as you progress through the tiered difficulties—when you finally arrive at Proud you should feel prepared for what's to come.

There's a LOT of grinding to be done—grinding for sigils, grinding for weapons, grinding for materials to upgrade your sigils and weapons. But like all good grinding games, the grind in Relink is an optional task—you can clear every fight in the game with suboptimal loadouts. But Relink knows that it's fun to min/max and reach your character's peak potential.

Granblue Fantasy's artstyle has translated beautifully to Relink and the game is a joy to watch in motion.

tl;dr great game, well worth the price

Get the game if you enjoyed RPGs like Dragons Dogma, Nier, Monster Hunter, Final Fantasy, etc.

Really polished Action RPG with Monster Hunter-like quest structure. The main story doesn't overstay its welcome & quest system keeps things refreshingly focused compared to your typical big budget ARPG. I think this game could be god tier depending on the quality of challenging endgame content added post-release.
As it is it has all the makings of one but the 'optional' content is very easy and takes a long time to build up (especially if you touch multiplayer) while player side mechanics are really strong.

Combat definitely feels very platinum games-like. A bit simple but each character is very unique from the other. The skill ceiling is still higher than you might think and some characters are more technical than others.
The amount of quality of life features is kind of incredible, from training modes to wishlists etc. As a comparison both of those features are pulled off better than monster hunter. The downtime / busywork you need to do between quests is extremely minimal.
Enemy attacks & AoEs have the cleanest visual indicators i've seen in a 3D action game like this from memory. They can definitely up the difficulty without visibility being an issue.

Misc. gripes:
The disparity between multiplayer and single player difficulty is too big. It's not good if multiplayer feels like an easy/cheat mode. This is a bit like if monhun didn't scale quests to be harder based on player count.

Guard seems nonsensically strong. Many bosses have attack patterns where you can't do anything but dodge until it times out. But guess what. You can just stand in place and hold the guard button. If you got hit it's because you assumed you need to do something. There are very few fights with unblockable attacks, and it's usually some mid-tier monster instead of an endgame boss.

There are many bosses where the only challenging part of the fight is a DPS check. This is pretty cringe & even if the rest of fight was fun in a challenge run (say playing 1 character only) that limitation might make the dps check part impossible. Struggling through a difficult fight with a lowish power party isn't rewarded, rather you kinda get punished for good gameplay through the rest of the fight.

Lock-on and targeting behavior is strange with your character very likely trying to hit something on the other side of the map, if the movement direction matches more.
The auto tracking on your moves is really strong even without locking. If manual aim could be more of its own thing ala monster hunter this could make some characters with slower attacks more fun to play.

Launch version specific:
The endgame quests aren't very interesting for multiplayer play. Only 1-2 quests are challenging for survival if played with random people (main one having multiple bosses at once, one with many unblockables). For others if you are playing multiplayer you can assume there's no chance of quest failure and it's just a speedrun to get to your loot drop gacha. Getting hit also barely costs you time or resources unless it kills you, unlike monhun. Tanking hits is the way to go if you are specced above the quest level. The 'final' farmable quest is more of a setpiece & dps check fest than actual combat which is pretty meh.

An engaging party-based action RPG with fluid, responsive controls and systems. Granblue Fantasy veterans will find it more than worth the wait, while newcomers will still be able to sink their teeth into a very impressive game.

The game isn't the optimized the best, though FPS will thankfully only dip during cutscenes and in towns. Even so, the visuals are amazing, from the art style to the VFX and animations.

I finished the MSQ on Hard Mode in about 20 hours, a pretty modest length. However, the game is actually part of the monster hunting genre of action games, so its true appeal lies in the combat itself as you delve deeper and deeper into post-game encounters and raids with other players (or your own party).

Each playable character plays completely differently than each other, along with skill trees and gear allowing you to create loadouts for a character that can emphasize different roles in a party. One character might excel in tanking or be built to be a damage dealer, or another character may specialize in a buffing support role or as a healer. This flexibility and freedom of choice makes the combat even more appealing, being able to tailor characters to your preferred playstyle.

The story was fairly generic but it was filled with many big spectacle moments that were cool to watch and fun to play. The story is only a small part of this game though, once the story is complete there are many more bosses and activities to take part in during the post game. I took my time and completed the story in 20 hours and have spent 40 hours so far in post game and there is still more for me to unlock. The combat in this game is incredibly fun and it's biggest selling point, there are a bunch of characters to play many with different play styles to make them unique. I'm hooked on the build crafting for this game chasing bigger and bigger numbers. As you level up you get a large amount of control of your characters stats in the form of Sigils that you will spend at lot of time chasing the good rolls some missions will have set Sigils you can farm from them while there are others you will need to use you resources to test your luck on an RNG loot pool.

Only big downside I've experienced is the matchmaking has been setup in cumbersome way that tends to get in the way of itself. For example if three of four people toggle to repeat a quest but one person does not then it disbans the whole group rather than look for someone to fill an empty slot. Also the online for the game is region locked so player activity will swing wildly based on time of day making is near impossible to matchmake into groups for less popular quest depending on time. Even with those points however I still have fun playing with randoms and farming endgame activities.

If I could make a small request to the devs it would be to not lockout the chat/stickers during phase transitions and end of mission screens when they would be most beneficial to have.

This game is one of the best action JRPGs ive ever played, dethroning Tales Of Arise for my top spot. The combat is fluid and fun the 8 skills per person makes a very fun and diverse setup with varying level of complexity and depth. The fate episodes are nice and give fun insights into the people themselves. The MP is why i love this game so much, theres a insane amount of depth and fun playing with random players with the 5 different Online game modes you really get to pick what you wanna do and have fun doing it. The main campaign has been fun and the combat is flashy, bright & over the top in all the right ways.

The only downside i have is the gear, am disappointed they missed the chance to do helemts, armor, boots, gloves, etc to provide and further enhance the build you wanna do with a certain person. Even no visual change would of been fine with me to add another layer of depth to the game.


But overall if you havn't played a JRPG this is a great one to start off with!

Story is God Awful; Uninspired, boring. If you've seen any fantasy anime, ever, it's just that.
Rush through the dialogue, because the combat is FANTASTIC. 
It's like Monster Hunter had a baby with Final Fantasy and was raised by Wolves.
Worth buying for the gameplay alone.

The game is beautiful and extremely polished. A wide array of playable characters and, even though the combat is fairly simple, each character is a different kind of joy to play. The voice acting is pretty good, story is decent (nothing groundbreaking), but seeing as I knew nothing about Granblue characters, and that this is the first breakout title away into this genre of games, I am definitely invested in future adventures.

In 69 hours, I have not crashed once. Only issue I have is sometimes the matchmaking gives me a "Network Error," but it immediately allows me to re-queue (most of the time) so it's no love lost.

This scratches the itch of an MMO that doesn't include microtransactions and has reasonable farming methods. Co-op is kind of tied to the story, so you will have to generally beat the game in order to fully unlock all of the co-op, but it opens up the other 80% of the game once you do beat it. But at each story-step of the game, it does provide you with some missions that are available to play in co-op.

Willl recommend this to anyone who is on the fence. I was waiting for this game for a long time and it didn't disappoint, I love it!

7/10. Would recommend, with big caveats.

The gameplay is good, music is great, story is pretty good too. The actual playing of the game is great.

Personally, I do not feel I got my money's worth.

I enjoy ARPGs, I enjoy character raising games. The problem I have is that there isn't any endgame content/replayability. ***There is no content for you to do with a maxed out character that you haven't ALREADY done with a weaker version of that same character.*** Fights that seemed hard the first time through become easy - you essentially stat check the bosses even BEFORE you even get your truly max level stuff (Terminus weapon, all sigils at 15 etc).

Not only do previous fights get stat checked - but the amount of grind that you will have to do to get a fully upgraded sigil set and weapon will leave you wondering "Why am I here still? The fights are not hard, and there's nothing left for me to do with this gear" so uh....

Game is super fun. Until you beat it. On the one hand, wow big surprise the game has an end oh no - but on the other, this game was marketed as having end game content. It does not - it has "post main story content". For what it is, the game is great. But don't make the mistake of thinking there is much actual end game to experience. There is going to be one more boss fight released in March(?) but after that, given comments from the devs, I don't expect that this game will have much more to offer.

Let me start with the following quick info:

- I hate the fact that steam players are more or less seen as "secondary" with PS5 getting all the benefits. If they just didn't do that, there wouldn't be any drama around that.

---------------
Well then, oh boy. This game got me real good. 127.5 hours in 2 weeks ... (holidays/days off)

Story: 8/10 
- took me around 13-14 hours to see credits
- took me around 20-23 hours to see the "actual ending"
- It's a bit short if you ask me, they could've introduced the other characters in a better way

Gameplay: 9/10
- You can feel the platinum games dna here
- The characters actually play different enough
- Super amazing boss fights with raid mechanics
- Hype Boss fights in endgame that can be quite difficult early on
- Great progression system with Mastery (skilltree), Weapon upgrades and sigils (sockets/accessories type equipment)
- Great endgame with decent methods of obtaining good sigils and decent weapon upgrade in (current) late endgame.

Soundtrack: 10/10
- It's simply amazing and I'm not surprised, if they got the FF1-10 composer on board
- The themes with lyrics are straight up bangers
- Some bossfights got the best themes in gaming for me personally (managarmr)

Graphics: 10/10
- They absolutely nailed the artstyle/design
- The characters look amazing
- The visual effects, especially during boss fights is astonishingly good

PC Port: 8/10 (my personal experience)
- You can't play the game with a PS5 Dualsense controller (frequent disconnects and cutouts for inputs during gameplay
- One freeze during a cutscene quite late in the story (had to alt+F4)
- few disconnects during multiplayer sessions
- Great performance with stable fps, no matter what happens on screen (3080)
- No stutter
- very short loading times (SSD)

Overall: 9/10
Absolutely worth the 60€ (or 80€ with 2 color packs and some other okayish goodies)

Not sure if I can recommend it to everyone... if you're looking solely for a MH game, then you'll have to wait through the JRPG and if you're looking for a JRPG, the JRPG section is fairly short.

But I enjoyed my time with the game.

I walked away from the final fight thinking "I should build Eugen so I can farm this fight" You know when was the only time I had the very same thought? The Slime mansion. (a mission which the mobs dont even fight back and only exists for farming catch up currency)
