As someone who was looking forward to be playing co-op with friends on this game, I'm afraid I am in the same situation as many others before me. To be specific, I am unable to play the game. The game crashes after starting a new game. I've contacted Cygames support and they've given me a template reply that I should wait for their official announcement. Well, v1.0.4 patch announcement came for the day 1 patch. Unfortunately, the patch did not resolve my issue. After near two weeks of waiting for a patch that would resolve my issue, I am inclined to leave this review here.

[h1]The problem with the PC version[/h1]

Reading through the issues in the Steam forums, there are couple of notable issues that keep popping up.

[h2]Can't start the game[/h2]

First, is the inability to start the game. We're living in the age where computers can be really complex and have many various features and instruction sets that general average PC consumers don't really pay attention to. The minimum system requirements simply do not convey enough information. Intel Core i3-9100 was launched 2018, sporting 6M Cache and up to 4.20 GHz of clock speed. Where as Intel Core i7-10510Y was launched 2019, sporting 8M Cache and up to 4.50 GHz of clock speed (base 1.20 GHz though). Other than the clock speed, there is one key difference between the two. The newer one lacks AVX2 instruction set, which the game apparently needs. It is largely thanks to the community that figured this out. Second is a sudden guaranteed crash when the game is started after creating a save. Unfortunately, community has not yet manage to figure out the reason.

I find it is not reasonable to expect all PC gamers to know about the ins and outs of PC components. I would've given the developers a pass if there was a clear message on what's causing the players from unable to play the game. If an error like "Game requires AVX2 instruction set to play", "Need more memory" or "DirectX version X is required to play" is clearly conveyed somehow, then I believe it would've been harder to attribute the developers for "bad port" and it would give the players a clue to figure out the next steps to make the game playable. People didn't give Todd Howard's vagueness of "upgrade your PC" a slack for Starfield, I don't see a reason why anyone else should either for Granblue Fantasy Relink.

[h2]Controller stops working[/h2]

I witnessed this happening on a live stream. Controller suddenly stopped working and that requires a streamer to restart the game. The only time I've seen a controller to stop working suddenly was when I was messing around with Remote Play Together in another game, and that too happened intentionally. In normal gameplay, there is no reason for any connected functional controllers to suddenly stop working.

[h2]Random crashes during gameplay[/h2]

Based on the reports on Steam forums, crashes can happen unexpectedly. Can happen after the end of battle, from alt tabbing, during cutscenes, during Discord voice chat and etc. This forces the player to treat the game carefully and change their normal PC habit to accommodate the game. I've read case where someone's external application (Discord) crashed, because of this game. I believe this already speaks the quality of the software (not good).

[h2]Save corruption[/h2]

People have been reporting save corruption. I haven't found a thread to confirm does the same happen to PS4/PS5. There are some that have claimed that PS4/PS5 can experience the same save corruption. Due to the game design, you're only ever playing on one single save. On PC, I see no reason why games should be tied to one single save. Divinity: Original Sin 2, Trails into Reverie, Neptunia: Virtual Stars and even Tales of Arise provides more than just single save. Not only does it let players to go back in time for certain point of the game, but it also provides a convenient way to setup a backup save in case something goes wrong with their main save file. If the game has to operate on single save-design, there has to be measures to ensure the integrity of the save file. It was brutal for me to read how people were spending over 50 hours only to have all their efforts wiped clean.

[h1]Wrapping it up[/h1]

All in all, I wasn't able to play the game so I can't really comment on the core game itself. At first I wasn't planning to leave any review, but reading how the random crashes and save corruption was happening to other people, I felt I should at the very least write my thoughts on the quality of the software. It's a shame as I was looking forward to playing this game. In the unlikely case I ever come back to this in the future, I may update this review.

This game is worth the money, And I just love it so much, what're you waiting for skyfarer? The Grandcypher is about to sail!

[h2] TLDR: 6/10 There is a lot to like, but quickly became tedious, uninteresting, and frustrating. [/h2]

While I haven't completed Proud Mode yet (stuck trying to get myself motivated to kill all those tedious duo fights), but I feel like I've seen everything the game has to offer.

[h3]The Start and the Story:[/h3]

It starts off really nice, then quickly shows that it's story is very run-of-the-mill "Power of Friendship", and more of the bosses just really hated you for playing a melee character. You start with a handful of characters, but can unlock more as you go, Unfortunately you can't test them out, so you are pretty committed. If you don't like their gamefeel, not really much you can do about it.

The Japanese Voice Acting is really solid with some recognisable names popping up here and there, but unfortunately the English Voice Acting lacks direction, and feels like there isn't much emotion. The subtitles are also an issue. This game uses a ton of tropes, and to hear them and not have the subtitles match is fairly jarring. It's one of those "close but important context is lost" situations.

[h3]Combat and Issues:[/h3]

Whether it was things flying around above you where you can only hit with a terrible air "combo", or bosses that cleaved around themselves in melee range while not interacting with any ranged at all outside of one attack, Some fights generate pockets of wind that push or pull you, once again making melee a nightmare where ranged aren't affect to nearly the same degree. This is an issue as a lot of characters have combo's that need to be done in order to access a lot of their power. After a while this just becomes massively frustrating, while ranged is so easy that it's boring.

Unfortunately this compounds into the "post-story" which technically is still the story mode exists for a good while as you are introduced to Very Hard, Extreme, and Maniac difficulty quests. These put you against the same bosses and enemies you have already faced just with more stats and occasionally a new attack. The same issues still apply and are often compounded. And it only gets worse when two bosses show up at the same time.

Additionally, some bosses have DPS checks, and these are absolutely insane compared to what you are asked of in general. If you can make these DPS checks, then the "Clear within X minutes" goal is completely meaningless as clearing the DPS check will mean that you are capable of clearing the fight well before that time. It's a very, very, weird feeling to easily be able to clear the fight within the "challenge" time, but not make the DPS check.

Fortunately your AI companions can pull their own for a large portion of the game, given they are properly equipped and levelled. Do not neglect them. They fall off later on in Proud Mode, but that's a mode reserved for just pure suffering. Also, you can't really control what they do when, so if you want to save your abilities for a big burst phase....not much you can do. This will only apply in Proud Mode though. Again, Proud isn't fun, it's just pain.

[h3]Postgame[/h3]

The endgame very much consists of very little but endless grinding for items to make other items that will be replaced by other items to make big numbers go bigger. It's like Monster Hunter, if you were only hunting the same monster you were fighting at the start of the game. Fighting eventually becomes very dull, and using other characters for variety is really hard as you then have to level them as well, which means more grinding.

It is a MASSIVE time investment, for something that at the moment doesn't stand to do much. Builds are fairly set with only a few places for deviation, unfortunately these builds rely on a pure RNG nightmare. You will grind countless hours for a chance to maybe get an upgrade. It's....a lot of time to invest. You are going to want to get these if you are any form of serious about endgame as it's a VERY large increase is potency. From where I started in Proud Mode to where I currently am, my output has more than doubled, and I am no where close to that end point. 

[h3]Concerns Going Forward[/h3]

My biggest concern is what comes in future. As new content is added I am left with a question. Wiil the devs balance for the endgame players that can melt things and leave the majority to feel like they have to do that insane grind, or will they balance it around a logical "next step", and have the encounter just get melted?

The difference in potency is extreme.  

[h3]Conclusion[/h3]

This game is beautiful, but it's also a mess. It's great for pure grinders and people that like gacha mechanics without the micro-transaction, but if you aren't interested in doing the same thing, fighting the same fights, doing transmutations thousands of times one transmute at a time only to turn it back into tickets to buy more transmutes to turn back into tickets over and over, there isn't much to offer past the final story bit. Maybe in April this will change, and will be the only reason that I will still keep playing.

People say the game is like Monster Hunter, but that's really only in regards to the gameplay loop for the Quests. The actual gameplay itself is [i]really[/i] more akin to the more party-based style of modern Ys games. Fast, fluid action combat with four skills you can use with the face buttons? Perfect dodging and perfect guarding? You can find all that kind of stuff in the modern Ys games too. With the fact that there are over a dozen characters to play and level up individually and make them all powerful as heck, you're probably gonna be sinking some heavy hours into this game if you want to work on all of them. Most likely all of the hours in the game will come from the end game content grind for sure.

The story's pretty basic, and it's short (took me around 30 hours to complete), but it's there. And honestly, it's pretty nice for what it is. Nothing too emotionally nor philosophically deep but it's a wholesome game at the end of the day and it makes you feel good. However the game does look pretty nice and if you have a medium-tier rig, you should be fine running it pretty smoothly; the game's going to still look great regardless of the (very limited) quality settings.

The game's great and you'll definitely get your money's worth if you're looking for a good action JRPG, that also has an online co-op mode, albeit for Questing only, nothing story related. If you're not interested in any of the quest related things, and are just here for the story, I would suggest waiting for a sale as the story content isn't as plentiful as the end game grind.

Multiplayer sucks. I was under the impression that this was gonna be a full story co-op campaign. Instead you get instance quests via quest board which are used to grind and farm items for leveling characters, weapons, and money..

The single player story mode is good, but had I known the multiplayer operated via quest boards for instance quests, I wouldn't have bought it. Now it's too late to refund it.

I had been looking forward to this game since it was announced, but even with my original expectations I didn't expect to like it quite this much. It has quickly skyrocketed to my all time favorite game. The gameplay in this game is extremely well made. It can be really tight or it can be really casual depending on which character you choose and how you build your character, there's a ton of customization and a lot of characters to choose from. The story in this game doesn't do anything unique, but it's presented incredibly well. It's well paced and has amazing cinematics along with an outstanding soundtrack(Which by the way, you can listen to the entire soundtrack in the in-game journal) that brings it all together. The graphics are also pretty in this game and while the art style of the characters may not be for everyone, I greatly enjoy them. There's a ton of post game content to explore once you've finished the game as well which continues to become harder and harder as you progress, but in no way does it ever feel cheap. The only complaint I have about this game is the online matchmaking can be really spotty at times and if and when that's ever fixed I would go so far as to call this game perfect.

Dabbled in the mobile gacha game prior, and enjoyed it's anime too. So having played/watched those, I already knew I'd enjoy this games setting. I originally played this games demo on PS5, then debated between PC and PS5 for my purchase. I saw the "jank" comments about it on PC which made me hesitate, but I really didn't like PS5 being 4k @ 30fps when I knew my PC could do better. There are cons on PC, but it doesn't apply to everyone! Setup is 3440x1440 monitor, RTX 3080, R7 5800x, 32GB RAM

This game absolutely reeks of Final Fantasy aesthetic and for good reason - it's the same art director who did FF6 and FF9! It has airships, and summons, and materia (sigils), and anime tropes, etc. so if you're an FF fan, this game is definitely something you need to check out.

[h3]Pros:[/h3]
- Smooth 120fps @ 1440p ultra settings. Haven't seen any dips. Makes the combat feel much better.
- Gameplay is addicting and responsive. The combat is simple enough for anyone to enjoy but it has decent RPG building aspects with materia/sigils.
- Boss battles feel like they came from FFXIV due to the ground markers. Hell, I've already encounted divebomb mechanics from one primal beast fight.
- Lots of characters to choose from that you can play as, all with different fighting styles.
- Story is okay and feels campy. I enjoy the camp, but I can understand some people cringing at it.
- Voice acting in JP and EN is excellent. Normally I play JRPG in JP, but I'm enjoying this one in EN.
- Animation is beautifully cel-shaded but 3D with no weird stretchiness that some of these games get. Textures are all high quality.

[h3]Cons:[/h3]
- Forced resolutions. I'm on an ultrawide 3440x1440p, and have black bars on the sides. I've been on this aspect ratio for a long time so I'm used to it, but that doesn't make it okay. Mods can fix it, but wish the devs would officially support 21:9.
- DualSense/PS5 controller support is bad. Very bad. Going into the menu at a Hollowed Ground will ALWAYS make the PS5 controller stop working. Sometimes it happens between other menus or loading screens. Luckily, this is fixable:
------> Disable PS5 Controller support in Steam completely and enable Xbox support. Use DS4Windows+HidHide and emulate it as Xbox controller. Fixed every controller problem I had.

If you don't have an ultrawide monitor, and don't plan to play on a PS5 controller, these cons don't exist for you. :)

A mashup of Tales of Arise and Monster Hunter.

+ Combat is great (better than ToA and FF remake for example, with great character depth - much closer to Monster Hunter or DMC etc.), and the boss fights are exciting and well done. Game looks great, especially in motion. Developers are to be congratulated for delivering a game that actually works at launch and sustains high framerates etc.

- Characters, designs, plot, music extremely formulaic. Lots of people moaned about the VA but it's actually fine, if a little annoying (damn these guys like to chat during combat). Some finicky technical issues (no ultrawide, HDR or auto HDR, although fixable with mods/third party programs)

Overall good if you're in the market for a solid "action" JRPG

This Game is Worth the Wait for 4 Years+ in Development... 

Its Granblue Fantasy but its Action RPG

Firstly, although this review is negative, consider it as a recommendation review. I decided to leave it negative for now, because I believe that like me, no one reads positive reviews. I will leave this positive review in the future.

I want to start by saying that this game is worth it simply because of the combat gameplay, there's not much to say, it's almost perfect. I say almost perfect because there are certain mechanics in this game that make it... disheartening.

Before continuing, I want to clarify that I have 116 hours of play at the time of writing this review, I have almost all the rare sigils of the game and at the moment I'm farming the last boss in order to get all the weapons in the game.

Build characters / Damage mechanics cap
If you played a good part of the game, you know that this game has damage caps assigned to different characters.
It's difficult to choose the words to describe what I feel about this mechanic, theoretically it's a good idea, as it tries to bring the balance in the game but it was simply poorly implemented.

If you don't know what I'm talking about, imagine that your favorite character's damage cap is 100,000, there will come a time in the game when you will have to farm sigils that allow you to increase your damage cap limit, making it reach 200,000 , 250,000 for example. Understand that it's not difficult to increase your limit, it's just very annoying.

Understand that, in the end game, every character of yours will reach the damage cap easily, making many of the sigils that should be interesting to build useless, such as Break Assassin, Overdrive Assassin.

The damage cap affects "slow hard hit" characters like Io/siegfried/ghandagoza/vaseraga much more than others. In addition, this mechanic makes characters damage buffs useless.

Boss loop:
Don't get me wrong, I like farming bosses in RPG games, the problem is when I have to do it more than 100 times, especially in a game that has more or less 15 bosses (some of which have elemental variations, but in general they are the same). I don't understand why Japanese games do so many re-skins.

Party roles:
Don't build tank, it's useless, many of the bosses hit a wide area, although it's focused on the tank, it will hit your team members.
Do not build support. It's useless, attack buffs are useless (blame the damage cap).

Anyway, there are many other minor problems that it is not worth mentioning each one.

is it worth playing? yes of course, go ahead.

A gorgeous and beautifully presented action game made by a gacha company that hates action games and has no idea how to make one.  Relink was delayed by 8 years and CyGames still couldn't get it right in all that time.

The graphics are gorgeous and Granblue's fantastic character design, music, and art are all present in full force.  However, it utterly fails at being a capable standalone action game.  Much like its mobile browser game origins, it values weapon and character stats over any kind of skill or execution on the player's part, and enemies are designed with spectacle in mind rather than being fun for a player to fight.  Every single boss has a 15 to 45 second long super attack sequence in which the player can do nothing but wait for it to finish, and they will all do this multiple times per fight if given the chance.  Visual effects, both from the player characters and enemies, are so pervasive that it can be difficult to even tell what's going on.  The camera will constantly try to wrest control from the player to force you to look at what it wants, and the lock on is clunky and disruptive.

The story is bland at best, and annoying at worst, and the English localization does it no favors.  Having played the Granblue mobile game for a few years, Relink's English dialogue is wildly out of touch with the setting's established tone, featuring a lot of punched up, quippy writing that is simply not present in Japanese.  A whole lot of "He/She/They would not fucking say that" listening to the English voice acting.

Perhaps most frustratingly, Relink expects you to grind purely for the sake of grinding.  The main story and character sidestories can all be completed by level 60 or so, but character and weapon levels cap at 150.  The game's prolonged and repetitive post-game exists solely to make you do the same content you've already done but with massively inflated stat requirements with no real incentive to do so.  Character progression is agonizingly slow as the costs for even marginal stat improvements grows exponentially as levels get higher, and in some cases require randomized stat rolls costing massive amounts of in-game resources per attempt.

If you like tedious soul numbing grinds with no actual reward or incentive, maybe Relink will scratch the itch.  Otherwise wait for a heavy discount and put it away once the main story is done.

Probably the best Action RPG game released this year. Absolutely a must buy game with dozens of hours can spend on this game upgrading your character, seeking the best stats, and also work together with other player on taking down the challenge provided. Don't wait, buy now!

Combat: After almost 40 hours this is an easy recommend if you're looking for flashy combat that's just engaging enough to keep it fun, while not so deep that it's overwhelming. Plenty of upgrades to chase post-game, and plenty of missions to grind (akin to Monster Hunter).

Story: Don't expect anything groundbreaking here - you may be a little lost when it comes to certain character references if you're new to the Granblue universe, but it won't hinder your ability to enjoy the story really at all. Some elements were somewhat predictable, but overall it's just a fun, Anime-esque story.

Graphics: Real good. No complaints here.

Music: SUPER charming music for almost every area of the game. They didn't really have to go this hard but they did. The town BGM's are almost always stuck in my head after playing for a bit.

Overall: 8.5/10. Plenty of content, combat and gameplay are great. It REWARDS EXPLORATION (huge plus for me in any game) and it doesn't take itself too seriously. Definitely worth at least $45 on sale if not more.

Grind-Blue Fantasy Relink -

There's nothing really wrong with the story(other than being an 'C' average story turned up to 10 in a good way) and the music is great for like a grand total of 3-4 fights however;

20 hour mandatory SOLO-ONLY story with about another 5-12 hours of more pointless missions with the worst matchmaking that can take anywhere between 2-10 minutes to match with people that will be cleared under 2 minutes. It took almost 40 hours to get to the final mission of proud and by then there's no real challenge at any point except for maybe 2-3 fights.

You will battle the camera / targeting system twice as much as the actual bosses they throw at you because it's a completely non-functioning system that makes the game more difficult for no reason.

Endgame is an absurd and pointless RNG grind with arbitrary damage caps per character, with RNG Terminus weapon drops on the final boss that unlocks your damage cap even further. Because the devs can't actually balance endgame DPS #s, they lock your damage potential behind MANDATORY sigils that limit your builds as much as 8-9 out of your 12 total slots. Build diversity is a completely limited by (4x)Damage Cap V , War elemental , class sigil+, (2x)Supplementary damage V, Crit Chance V, EVERY SINGLE CHARACTER WILL BUILD ALL OF THESE with several minor exceptions.

To top all this nonsense off there's actually optimal strats for you to literally turn on assisted mode and full afk your game for 20 hours farming materials like Silver Centrum so you can max out equipment.

So you're actually incentivised to not even play the game and to treat it like an idle game and get all your materials that way too.

No wonder this game was stuck in development hell for so long. Every endgame mechanic is simply a bad choice.

8.5 / 10

GBF Relink is a solid Anime ARPG/JRPG that seems to feels like MHW mixed with Genshin while bearing some influences from others like FFXVI and Nier Automata. Despite it's flaws, it offers is a good and tight, if a bit predictable, ~15h of main story along with a somewhat solid end-game content and replayability, playing Cygames's other games and watching the GBF anime def help gives proper context and insight on parts of the story and references, but overall, it is still quite friendly for a newcomer as well (I'm being one of them)

The game has:
+ One of the best graphic for an anime games IMO (IDK why anime games seems to love sticking with low res textures and low poly models... considering how far hardware has progressed)
+ smooth performance, it even runs on steam deck
+ Good story and amazing characters, though it is to be expected considering the franchise
+ Fun and solid gameplay, imagine fighting MHW bosses with characters that can move and attack at the pace of Genshin Characters
+ Each character comes with a somewhat unique weapon, and therefore gameplay, which gives you more variety in how you approach your game
+ improving ideas that they "took" from other franchises, for example: all the characters that you've met / in your roster can spawn in the actual game world (staring at you hard, GENSHIN, TF you mean characters only shows up on events/quests), there's also [spoiler] the primal battles which are basically ikon battles from FFXVI [/spoiler]
+ Good AI companions that are actually useful and doesn't hinder your missions, even toward the end-game contents

But it is by no means flawless:
- UI and menu control are obviously very controller-centric, this game is just a straight port from the console version, a good and stable one, but not a full PC port
- Some of the mechanic that they pulled straight from their mobile games doesn't really fit people that would play on PC (Fate episodes anyone?)
- A lot of reused assets, was expecting more variations and unique stuffs considering how big the company/franchise that's behind it and how much the game cost
- The camera has a mind of its own at times, which is annoying
- Very rigid world design with plenty of use of invisible borders, as an avid open world game enjoyer, I really don't like the fact that they used so much invisible barriers to block your progression instead of clever world designs, though this is also nothing new in anime games...
- Despite having a variety of characters, the story seems to only revolve around the main party, which does break immersion abit (it's like -talking to zhongli in Genshin, as zhongli- kind of immersion breaking)

Overall though, despite all the flaws that I've listed, they don't really affect the overall satisfying experience that I had with the game, but rather mostly minor complaints, nitpicks, and constructive criticism, I think that the game delivers a great base experience that can certainly be expanded down the line with Expansions, DLCs, seasonal events and updates, just like MHW did, which I hope the company would do!

[spoiler] Review is made after finally beating that sonnuvabich Versa in Proud difficulty [/spoiler]

You have no idea how many hours of sleep I lost because of this game.
How many times I told myself, "1 more run." "1 more roll." "1 more quest."
How many days I went to work half-asleep or sick.
It's rare for me to find a game where "grinding" for something is "fun and addicting." Borderline unhealthy.

While this game's story is as generic as any anime adventure plot can be, the battles are flashy, fast-paced, exciting, and enjoyable. It encourages cooperation between each characters and it rewards you for it with cinematic moves and thousands of damage numbers flooding your screen. Let's not forget the AI here are often smarter than most human players as they know how each boss mechanic works and will do what they need to do to not die.

I've spent almost 30-40 hrs in story alone, mainly because I didn't want to miss out on loots, lore, and levels. And only then did I get to "play the actual game" when I unlocked all the difficulty levels and started playing online coop. The online community is also quite nice, but most of all, efficient as to this day I have yet to play with anyone who was intentionally a burden or has caused our mission to fail.

You get the full game experience as you should for its price tag. But even then I've enjoyed this so much I'm willing to spend more for mere cosmetics if ever they plan to release some in the future. The only downside I see in this game as of the moment is it's rather demanding requirement as it crashes or lags heavily on mid to low end PCs, which prevents some of my friends from joining us. I will edit this part in the future should this get patched.

I haven't had this much fun in an RPG since Monster Hunter: World. And at 100+ hrs in, I barely scratched the surface on how many things I need to do in this game. The community calls this "Grindblue Fantasy" for a reason.

JRPG with elements of Monster Hunter

10 hours of Main Story Quests
40 hours of post-game Progression
The rest is a mix of AFK and manual farming until BiS. Repeat with other characters.

If you like the grindfest experience of any Cygames IP, you will love this.

It's a fun game. The story has been pretty good for the most part. I'm not an absolutely huge Granblue fan and I don't have the free time or mental energy to get bent out of shape over subpar-but-passable translations (though highschool or college past me would have thrown a fit). I found the voice acting and script mostly enjoyable, though there were definitely some spots where it was obvious the English script writers took some liberties they definitely should not have (mainly bad puns). If modern day slang in fantasy settings bugs you, you probably won't like the translations here. Another downside about the writing is that the unlockable characters, because of their absence from cutscenes, feel kind of out of place when they interact with the crew during dungeons. Like "Uh... Have you been here this whole time?"

The characters all seem well designed and have their own gimmicks so they all feel satisfyingly different from each other. Bosses are well designed and most of them feel just right; not too long, not too short, not too hard, not too easy. However, one downside is that you basically have to commit to a single character. You don't really get the resources to level more than one (though I guess this may change in post game with adequate grinding). The reasonable ability to build up enough characters to round out a 4 man party would have been nice.

Performance-wise, I'm running a build WAY under the recommended settings and its running on high settings at 60fps with slight occasional slowdowns in cities. The graphics are absolutely gorgeous and everything looks fantastic. Outside of the one cutscene crash in chapter 1 that I had to change to Windowed mode to get past, I haven't encountered any bugs or issues.

In short, visuals and OST were beautiful. The game runs smoothly under minimum requirements. The gameplay is fun. The story is good but not quite great. The voice acting and dialogue are hit or miss depending on how much of a translation purist you are. Being pigeonholed into committing to a single character from early in the game kind of sucked. Overall, I think I'd give the PC version a 7.5/10. When crashes get fixed, I'd see to giving it an 8.0/10.

its a JRPG game. its also online multiplayer/coop, it gave me Monster Hunter vibes cause you get sigils that are kinda like Monster Hunter World's jewel system, there's weapon crafting (for all characters), and weapon ascension but for the main character Gran I do not know if you can ascend any of the other characters weapons yet. There are 10 chapters to Relink, and 1 character that stood out to me was Bahamut. I thought at first it was gonna be a Final Fantasy rip off till I got to the other primeval beasts and they are all different and unique. I thoroughly enjoyed the surprise of finding out the first primeval wasnt going to be Garuda. The online potion is a quest board mission system with short missions basically to farm for sigils and materials but they are fun, they got different modes like bosses, survival, hoards, ect. Each mission feels unique enough and the rewards are something to look forward too. If you guy's are wondering there is a battlepass system I sadly don't agree with not every game needs one but since the devs made mention they will not be adding any micro transactions they do need to monetize in some way I suppose. All in all this game is 100% worth the buy and play I would recommend it after beating it myself. I hope you guy's enjoy it as much as I have!

They have all these characters, but there's really only 4 playstyles (skill based, timing based, charged attacks, and ranged). Some characters are more defensive than others, but due to the atrocious balancing, that's rarely notable. You are either clearing a story boss in two minutes, or there's three bosses clearing out your team in two minutes. Couple that with abysmal drop rates for rare items, and I find myself unable to really enjoy the end game grind. It's a shame because I had followed this game for years, only to get something that ended up disappointing.

Cool game so far, I can see what they were going for with the coop but it's a little confusing/disappointing you can't play the singleplayer together when it's required to unlock more coop missions. Even Monster Hunter, the game this game's progression is based on, lets you play the story missions together. Seems like a massive missed opportunity.

The combat is fun, runs fine, looks pretty standard. Will have to do a deeper dive to see if it's worth the money really. On the surface after finishing all the Normal level quests, it seems like it has potential to have a very interesting coop endgame.

Edit : Made it to endgame with Siegfried. It's pretty good, it has a long way to go as far as matching Monster Hunter, which is really what it feels like it's trying to capture via the sigil system and emphasis on replaying missions. I would like to see more missions, the end of Proud mode felt very rushed. A good example is one of the monsters you fight near the end, who has just one fight and no variations or alternate buffed version. For now, there isn't much to do after you max out your last weapon -- it left me feeling very powerful with not much to do with that power, if that makes sense. It's great groundwork for a game, and just a few content updates could completely change my take on this game. I hope they ride the wave of popularity into a game with a solid playerbase.

Fantastic combat system and OK-ish everything else that doesn't get in the way of the fun part of killing stuff and progressing in power. Massive variety of playstyles across all the characters. Story that bounces from one big set-piece to another without overstaying its welcome. Really beautiful presentation & great music cap it off nicely.

I can't vouch for the story but I can't really hate on it either because the foundation for this is based off the gacha game story which was already not the best for me. In this case it's already at a disadvantage. The character banter on the other hand is quite good. I expected to be annoyed by some of the characters but I was only really annoyed by Katalina because of she wouldn't stop talking about Lyria, also Lyria was annoying to me. Moving on to gameplay. What can I say? This game is so much fun. Attacks are satisfying, the characters are unique, multiplayer is a joy. The town hubs is great to move around in, it really gives off the fantasy town vibe. I'm just having such a blast. Every chapter is just hitting highs all the time. The game keeps dropping banger combat segments and it never stops after a certain point in the story. I have a few minor gripes on repeat bosses, especially one near the end where you have to fight a different version of it 3 times, but it's not a deal breaker. Overall, this game is a straight up 9/10, 10/10 if we add my bias.

As a Granblue Fantasy Browser player of 6-7 years, I can confidently say, they were cooking when they made this game.

The graphics are good for the most part, there is allot of hectic clutter from damage numbers and skill effects, but just enough to view the boss attacks/mechanics.

Considering they showed the content map with [REDACTED] and more to come, one can only hope they cater toward Browser no-lifer nostalgia factors.

Id rate the game a solid 9/10, but it could get some work in terms of utility in the endgame, for example, why need Defense Down when you're hitting cap anyways, other than that, I feel as though the game is going in a solid direction, some buffs or gameplay changes could be in order, but other than that, after sinking 100hrs in the first week, its just a gem that I had been waiting for ever since the first trailer.

If I had to sum it up: Tales of Arise combat meets the Monster Hunter formula.

This is so... unexpectedly fun to play! I'm new to Granblue and I only know the characters because of Granblue Fantasy Versus: Rising having a free edition.

In a year that's already stacked from the beginning for JRPG's (Persona 3 Reload, Like a Dragon 8), and with upcoming games like Dragon's Dogma 2, my wallet is already crying. And don't get me started with how good Tekken 8 and Granblue Fantasy Versus: Rising ended up being. 

So I decided to check this game out, because I like the combat from games like "Tales of..." and Ys 8. I'm still at the start, and while the story is just there for things to get rolling, the combat system is satisfying and flashy. The scenery is gorgeous, the music mesmerizing, and the combat simple but fun! 

Edit: 15 hours later retrospective: The most fun action RPG I've played since Ys 8 and Tales of Arise. Story is akin to a "One Piece/Dragon Ball movie", but it just exists so you can fight epic bosses, and visit a variety of locations. 

Last but not least, in true "Monster Hunter" fashion, the good stuff start after the story. I'll be playing this game for a good while!

The game is all-around fantastic, just not optimized for higher-end systems imo. I have a ryzen 9 7900x and a 7900xtx, and in order to play the game without it crashing I have to set it to 1080p windowed mode. Hopefully a fix comes for this, because the gameplay itself is genuinely great and I have enjoyed the time I've managed to put into it so far.

edit: What is currently an apparent fix for me was to undervolt my gpu to around 85%. I am assuming transient power spikes were the culprit.

Except it doesn't have gacha, mtx and time-gated garbage that relies on player FOMO for retention and plays like a complete game from start to finish, with some great endgame content to uncover. 19 characters at launch, all of them are fun to play.

The game is divided into a story mode that takes place in "semi" open areas (mostly linear though), much like an adventure game and quests that play like Monster Hunter games. It's a very grindy game, so if the combat and characters are not your thing, then don't bother.

Not much to write anything more about other than this is some of the most addicting, grindy fun I've had in a videogame in years. It's a VERY solid game overall and it delivered exactly what I expected (it even exceeded at the combat department) Let's see how the upcoming content fares.

You always liked these types of dynamic action games that focuses on character growth but are filled with gacha to r*** your wallet? Granblue Fantasy Relink covers all of this. And also, no, you can't kill Genshin or the Hoyoverse, the fandom is just too toxic and will defend it at any cost. Let Genshin and Honkai kill themselves, they seem to be doing a great job in that regard with their sheer incompetency.

I'm immersed in a captivating world that scores an 8 in my book, with the potential to hit a solid 10 for anime and manga enthusiasts who invest in the storyline. The concise yet engaging plot propels me on a quest to save the world alongside a diverse cast of characters, each with their own compelling journey.

The game-play earns a perfect 10, offering an astonishing variety of ways to play that I find simply unbelievable. The dynamic real-time combat, exploration, and puzzle-solving keep every moment exhilarating, making it a truly immersive experience.

Progression gets an 8 from me, with a heads-up for those planning to dive into the late game. While the system is well-structured, there's some grind involved for those aiming for extreme levels of mastery. But, if you're ready to invest the time, the payoff is worth it.

The cinematic experience is an absolute standout, earning a perfect 10 in my rating. The game's cut-scenes and cinematic sequences are breathtaking, seamlessly blending with the narrative to create an immersive and visually stunning adventure. Every moment feels like a carefully crafted masterpiece, enhancing the overall enjoyment and making the storytelling truly memorable. 

Granblue Fantasy Relink is a game where the story's potential for anime and manga enthusiasts, diverse gameplay options, and the challenge of late-game progression combine to create a thoroughly enjoyable and rewarding experience.

Story  -----------------> 8 ( if you like anime and manga and invest in the story it will be a solid 10 )
Game-play  -----------------> 10 ( You have so many ways to play the game is unbelievable )
Progression  -----------------> 8 ( if you are planning to go to  extreme and dive in late game you will have some grind )
Cinematisc ---------------------> 10

UPDATE: 2/12/24
Last update addressing some of the known issues was 2/3/24. Those issues remain, and have not been fixed if you go to the comments section. The issue with controllers randomly disconnecting in the UI menus have not been addressed or fixed yet. You have to navigate menus with keyboard/mouse, and play with controller. No game I have ever played in my life has had this problem. Also, I'd like to add that anytime this happens you're forced to shutdown steam through task manager. The game will remain open and running even after you return to desktop via in game menu. FIX the game! I want to add the good things with the game, but Cygames isn't getting a free pass from me for failing to do their job and make sure the PC version is fully functional. 


Original:
“The developers recommend playing this game with a controller.” Well, funny enough that’s what I attempted to do. Worked perfectly fine until I reached the main hub to accept quests. Now, opening any menus in town causes the controller to lose functionality, and will occasionally send those inputs repeated if you are patient enough to watch paint dry. Just for that I’m leaving a thumbs down for bad functionality. It’s unacceptable even if it is launch day. Fix the issue, and I’ll fix my review. No sense in listing the positives if it all ends less than a few hours in.

Extremely fun for a game I didn't expect much from. My biggest complaint is the insane level of grinding required at end game. Gearing up becomes a matter of running the same bosses hundreds of times to get a *chance* at getting useful sigils. That said, you definitely don't need to perfectly min/max to get plenty of enjoyment out of this game. It's just something that would have kept me playing longer if the slot machine odds were a bit more reasonable for what is essentially a single player game with an optional "for fun" multiplayer.

Overall, this a very strong recommend! The issues I mentioned aren't even something you'll care much about until you're 50-60+ hours into this and at that point you've more than got your money's worth.

I knew nothing about Granblue Fantasy prior to playing this game, and I wasn't expecting to still be playing it after 138 hours. I'm writing this review immediately after collecting all of the achievements— but I haven't nearly exhausted all of the content and fun to be had in this game.

Relink is a triumph. A game that moves players between impressive setpieces while slowly unfurling the breadth of its mechanics and systems and telling a tropey, but ultimately compelling and sincere story. And after you've spent 10-15 hours playing through that story, the game opens up like a bottomless pit, threatening to swallow certain types of gamers whole. I am, fortunately, one of those types, and Relink's post-game content has been a wonderful climb through a shocking amount of vertical and horizontal progression, new bossfights not featured in the story, and good challenges with equally good rewards. 

The easiest comparison is Monster Hunter; hunt stuff to get parts to make a better sword to use to hunt stronger stuff. But the systems in place go deeper than that, feeling similar to those you'd find in a gacha game, but balanced for a full-price title. And the progression does feel fair and expeditious; despite spending almost 140 hours already, I don't feel that my time has been wasted with pointless tedium. As the phrase goes, this game is firing on all cylinders, brimming with intelligent and considerate design, even long after the credits have rolled. I love this game to death, and I think anyone that enjoys action games will too. It's not perfect, no game is, but so far the flaws have not ruined my enjoyment of this game that apparently took eight years to make. Worth the wait, I'd say!

TLDR = JRPG Monster hunter-esque with fluid combat. One of the Best 3D Action JRPG I've played so far gameplay-wise
Solid Game for the price.

Pros:
- Gameplay system is polished (From Fighting systems to Character systems), 
  (Only gripe is the quick quest system design and DMG cap design)
- Great boss encounters, attack patterns and mechanics
- Multiplayer working well (Good netcode with client side calculation for dmg)
- Support for variety of playstyles via different characters with unique mechanics with their techs
Example of playstyles: Mage Dps , Range Dps , Support Dps, Fast Attackers, Slow Attackers, Stunners
- AI Companions if you wish to tackle content solo
- No performance issues encountered
- Majority of the game is voice acted
- Nice Osts and Sound Design (Other than the Sierokarte repeated lines during transmuting..)

Neutral:
- Story Content
- Skill Tree  (I do prefer specialization tree rather than just a grab all skill tree. Feels pointless other than just linear progression)
- Grindy gameplay Loop (Alleviated with AFK farming i guess but definitely not my thing)

Cons:
- Camera Controls can be wonky even with everything disabled (Quite annoying in Duo/Triple Boss fights)
- Lack of builds variety since everyone is optimally just pushing for DPS in the endgame.
- No crossplatform

Looking forward to see what the postgame updates will be like.

The selling point of this game is its combat and the progression which allows every single character in the game to become a complete powerhouse. This, combined with very fast loading screens makes for an addictive gameplay loop which had me not wanting to put the controller down.

Graphics and Art Style:
From the moment you step into the world of Granblue Fantasy: Relink, you're greeted with stunning visuals and vibrant art direction that bring the fantastical world to life. Character designs are beautifully crafted, environments are rich in detail, and spellbinding special effects add to the immersive experience.

Gameplay Mechanics:
The heart of Relink lies in its exhilarating gameplay mechanics. The combat system seamlessly blends fast-paced action with strategic depth, allowing players to unleash devastating combos and powerful abilities while mastering the intricacies of each character's playstyle. Whether you're engaging in epic boss battles or exploring sprawling dungeons, the gameplay remains consistently engaging and rewarding.

Story and Narrative:
Set against the backdrop of a captivating narrative, Relink delivers a compelling storyline filled with memorable characters, intriguing plot twists, and epic moments that keep you invested from start to finish. The journey is enhanced by well-written dialogue, dynamic cutscenes, and meaningful character interactions that deepen the connection to the world of Granblue.

Content and Replay Value:
With a wealth of content to explore, including a sprawling main campaign, challenging side quests, and engaging multiplayer modes, Relink offers countless hours of entertainment for players seeking adventure. The game's replay value is further bolstered by character progression systems, loot customization options, and ongoing updates from the developers, ensuring that there's always something new to discover.

Performance and Technical Aspects:
On the technical front, Relink impresses with smooth performance, stable frame rates, and minimal loading times, delivering a seamless gaming experience across different platforms. While occasional minor glitches may occur, they are overshadowed by the overall polish and attention to detail present throughout the game.

Final Thoughts:
Granblue Fantasy: Relink is a testament to Cygames' dedication to crafting unforgettable gaming experiences. With its captivating visuals, engaging gameplay, and immersive storytelling, it stands as a must-play title for fans of action RPGs and newcomers alike. Whether soaring through the skies or battling fearsome foes, Relink invites players on an unforgettable journey that will leave a lasting impression.

Great game, but the end game feels artificially difficult. I understand that this is Granblue and this is supposed to be expected, but the amount of grinding you'll have to do here to get your Terminus weapon is disgusting. 

Once unlocking Proud missions, the last difficulty setting of the game at the moment, you'll be tasked with clearing all of them, all while attempting to ascend your weapons.

Ascending your weapons not only will take a considerable amount of grinding for materials, you will also need to complete character specific achievements to be able to ascend it higher. For example, one of those gates is performing 30 Skybound Arts playing AS the character. So if you're trying to get a full party up in power, you'll be here for a while. The most optimal way of progression would be finding parties online as it will help you focus on just one character.

While you are TIRELESSLY farming to maxing out your ascension weapon, at one point you will face the very last mission of the game, home of the Terminus weapons. But you might be thinking: "Wow! I beat it! I can get my weapon!"

Clearing this mission gives you a CHANCE to drop A weapon according to your current available character roster. A CHANCE.

Fast forward - you've now upgraded your Terminus weapon to 150. You've +99 mirage munitioned it. You've ascended it once. TWICE. +5! +10! YOU DID IT! YOU HAVE THE BEST WEAPON IN THE GAME!
What's the reward? An achievement? Nah. A new skin?! Nahhh. 

YOU GET A GLITTER EFFECT ON THE WEAPON! CONFETTI! WOW! Here's the kicker! It doesn't even show online!

Don't get me wrong not a bad game, I just don't like JARPGS and I don't enjoy the simple story it has so far, and the combat lacks depth. This game has so much potential in how you CAN make it cool but just doesn't.

Lemme just address some of the ways I find this game to be inadequate. I do play with a mouse and keyboard so I will be referencing controls with that.

Combat
Game has the left button for your basic combo and your right to finish a combo. Really could have changed it to light and heavy and had different combos based on it. Game just doesn't and it feels lacking. Could have had more combos and variety in attacks. Dodging and Guarding might as well be the same thing as there is never an incentive to choose one over the other. Game could have solved this by having undodgeable attacks and unguardable attacks. I know some bosses have like a AOE to make you guard but how they design it is that you shouldn't be needing to do that if you were behind the blocks of ice we placed. It's also usually death if that does happen. Dying is too generous, I don't like the critical bar you have, it incentives more recklessness than observation "eh I still have 10 more lives I'll be fine if I just die here". And along with this the party AI is way to competent at prioritising you to heal but that's not a negative just feels like it caters too much to you.

Now I did go back to relink in the middle of writing this review to see if playing without party members was fun. It's not. Bosses aren't scaled to members in a party but just to a max party. And why can I just not play as the Captain or have her in my party. I don't like her move set and I don't want her in my party. I am just talking about the Story quests. So far I have no incentive to play the hub quests unless it's for a crewmate ticket which I will hoard until I finish the game because I don't want to farm for all that MP (mastery points). They unlock crewmates based on progress (which is good) and there's no reason for me to unlock more crewmates unless I want to suffer later grinding (which I don't link).

Why is Bahamut here, why can I not just use him as a summon for battle like FF7 or a poundmate from Yakuza. If you're going to make him destroy 3 wyverns in the beginning surely I can use him to destroy a couple of goblins right?

Can't tell what happens in a battle half the time. Can I like, just turn off the flashy effects, I like being able to see and not be blind. Why does it say I can break parts off monsters on Eugen (or was it Rakham) but never actually works. Do weakpoints even exist, I can't tell because my damage doesn't change color.

Story
It's boring. I understand this is meant to be accessible to a wide audience but at the same time a story written by adults should definitely have more depth than "oh shit evil people from nowhere, now my princess is gone, time to go rescue her, ah fuck man I keep losing to these people time to keep chasing them because they literally cannot kill me, etc". Not going to go more indepth because for those who haven't played the game it's very surface level, lacks tension and makes me question my sanity, confronted with these things they call Skyfarers (And from what I understand, aren't they suppose to be big shot adventurers who can fight primeval beasts). Also Lyria, WHY THE FUCK DID YOU SUMMON BAHAMUT TO FUCKING DECIMATE 3 WYVERNS, NO SERIOUSLY WHY-. I'm still mad about that. Also why are we trying to find a way to sever the life link, she is suppose to be our waifu... right? It's feels like I'm finding divorce papers. And Id literally went, she's first woman who was nice to me besides mom and now I must knight her, bro you are like the strongest knight here why are you like this. But either way, I just hate a very simple story. The fact that this takes 10 or 20 hours shouldn't be the case. This is just a giant goose chase.

Crafting
Why the fuck is this so barebones. What's even the point of making weapons if the only thing you are going to do is change stats and add a different unique effect like "does more stun damage" and tell me that I can collect 6 weapons only. 
Could have made this into a bucket system with randomised stats for weapons with more different cosmetics. Why does Siero just give me items can I not just make it myself? Why does Siero only stock three categories in her shop? Why can't I have two of the same weapon with different augmentations (wrightstones). I wouldn't do that because that's a pain but maybe others would like that. 

World
Why do you just have several locked chests in the beginning of the game in the hub that I can't unlock until much later? Like it's not because you're not skilled enough or you haven't been able to get a key from a mob drop but just a "no come back later when you've done enough story and open them all".

I actually wanted to learn more of the life of the people and ecology in the Ice lands (not because I saw a hot animal eared mommy) but that's just not a thing. Like what crackhead decided to live next to Furycane shrine. But it's all just, yep they exists. 

Overall, despite it being a game that actually works and isn't filled with bugs (aside from the people not being able to launch the game and crashing) it sucks. Cannot recommend it just due to a lack of depth.
Opinion subjected to change based on comments (would appreciate constructive criticism and not just "stupid")

Edit: The localisation is horrible, deviate from the original japanese lines to emulate more teenager American language (Not sure how to put this in better terms).

[Mild Spoilers]
The games story starts you off at the mid-point of the mc's overall story, your crew mates have already joined you and there is already a bond between them, so for you there is no attachment to the mc or any of the crew mates [except for 1 but he joins late], you can unlock more crew members with a crew card but these crew members have also already joined you in the past before we join the story so there is no real attachment to them either.

The story itself is ''been there done that'' if you have played other jrpg types then this storyline is something you have experienced before..just more lazily done [the only cutscenes you will ever see are to do with msq and nothing else].

The gameplay is good, it has a monster hunter vibe to it in which you go to a quest counter, choose one then press ready when you are ready, the game is not open world or anything you can only explore within the mission area [some missions areas are large]. the combat is also good, there is no mana or stamina, you just hack and slash until your arms fall off, which i found to be fun.

TDLR: if you are looking for a story rich experience where you laugh and cry with the mc, this is not it.
if you are looking to just hunt bosses and monsters then this is fun.

**Read Important Note below**
I will say, this game is my favorite game yet in 2023-2024. As a player who specializes on FPS Shooters, I will say I enjoy the game a lot. The grinding is a lot and have some cute anime girls in it, my fav is Cagliostro... don't judge me. As a person who got extremely disappointed with Gensh*t, this game is definitely leagues better than that game. Definitely requires way more skill to play compared to Gensh*t. 

The best part of this game that it is not a gacha game, so not much "immoral" practices of draining your wallets out for a chance to get a character. Definitely a money worth  and I am willing to spend money on DLC where you are guaranteed to get certain characters, and doesn't require you to slave everyday (but you can do so, because I did). I am hoping that they plan to add more characters from CyGames universe (Please Kasumi Kirihara... please come home...), and hoping this game will last years to come by them adding DLCs.

For context, I play very limited amount of RPG games. The RPG games I have played and enjoyed are Monster Hunter World & Rise and Pokemon (already stopped playing). I played a couple of gacha games (Gensh*t & Arknights) and was fan of Princess Connect from CyGames. Just a big fan of their character designs over most other franchises so far.

For me, it is worth to get the full price tag (it is cheaper at my place because regional pricing). But if you do not want to dish out as much money, wait for it to go on sale (I doubt it will come any time soon though). I am planning to support game companies that support good practices like selling premium games and having DLCs to add more extra stuff like cosmetics and more story/game modes.

[b] IMPORTANT!!! [/b]
I do want to give a word of warning. I would [b] RECOMMEND [/b] turning off Steam Cloud Save and turn off auto save. The reason is if you are somehow saving and a blackout happens that causes your PC to turn off... or just a BSOD, your save file [b] WILL GET CORRUPTED [/b] and lose your save. This will cause you to start from beginning or find out another solution (using saves). 
Ask me how I find this out...

Your save file will be located in AppData\Local\GBFR\Saved\SaveGames
The easiest way to access this is to type "%AppData%" in the directory. Then go to Local after clicking AppData in the directory.

This game is fantastic.  Looks great, sounds great and plays great.  I've been waiting for this game for a LONG time and I would say Cygames has delivered on all counts.  Thank you for taking the time to get everything right.

Gameplay-wise I would say this game sits somewhere between PSO2 and Monster Hunter.  The game feels less rigid and more forgiving than Monster Hunter as you are free to use the dodge or guard button to cancel out of a lot of attacks.  You also have dedicated buttons for your character's skills rather than the MH approach of making them combo based.  A lot of characters also have parry or counter moves that reward skillful play in various ways.  The game also employs a stagger system where you can create your own openings by staggering bosses and eventually stunning them for about 10 seconds or so.  When you counter a boss into a stagger and then knock them into a stun?   It feels SO goooood!   The hit feedback in this game is so CRUNCHY.  I love it SO much!

I found the story, while short (roughly 10-15 hours), to be very enjoyable thanks to the excellent, highly entertaining, very cinematic boss fights.  The game doesn't end after you beat the story though.  There's an additional post game story chapter with more bosses and more difficult versions of what you fought during the story and there's even harder stuff after you're done with that.  All the while collecting stronger equipment and materials to upgrade your characters.

That's the other neat thing this game does.  It gives you a roster of around 20 characters and lets you make a party of any 4 you want.  They're also all playable, fully featured characters each with their own gimmicks and distinct playstyle.  It was hard to choose what 4 characters to build first because every single one of them seems cool and interesting.  The AI itself for your party members is also very good.  I find myself getting outscored by the AI when I play badly.  Coop and matchmaking is also available for non-story quests too if you'd rather run with other players instead.

There is also a complete lack of live service features, and micro-transactions.  You pay once and get the whole game with no restrictions.

I fully believe this will go on to be one of the most fun ARPGs released this year.  I hope Relink gets a big expansion because I am 100% willing to pay for more of this game.

10 hours game, 5 hours me running around trying to find treasures, 20 hours farming after credits to unlock the true ending, 5 hours of me finally trying out each character. If you don't mind the 20 hours farming, you can actually find some fun. I hate how they baited me into doing some grinding quests, making it look like it's only a couple of quests, but then they add more and more with no end in sight. This turned into a full time job and a hate / love relationship with the game. It could be so much fun, but no, they had to artificially increase the game length.

The cities in this game look amazing (composition, detail) and they are filled with so much life. Spells (or VFX in general) look incredible, too. Comes at a cost though. Framerate is all over the place (RTX 3060, 2560x1440 , 28 - 120  fps (120 locked, no vsync), mostly averaging 60 fps. In fights, you might die, because there is just too much stuff happening.

Outside the cities, the level design is completely trash.
The first level is okay.
But then you get a level that is timed traversal with multiple paths that can lead to treasures, but there is no way to tell which one will lead to the treasure. It's a coin flip and if you are wrong, you have to suicide.
The next level has a "challenge" that would take 20 minutes to beat a certain enemy, because your stats are not good enough. This ruined the game, because since that moment, I never tried a challenge again, even though some of the later challenges were easier.
The level after that is just one huge area with a bunch of treasures etc., have fun running around aimlessly collecting treasures. I tried finding everything, but still had to look up a guide later.

The combat is smooth and looks incredible, too. With parry and dodge at the same time, I rarely lose health. However, most of the time you play your character and go into auto-pilot mode. Without knowing boss patterns, it's easy to get greedy and keep hitting, until you get 1 shot. Hard to judge if the game forces you into grind mode and rarely wants you to actually block / dodge. Most of the time you can keep attacking until a cutscene plays, then you have to run and wait.

(I played the main character who is okay with all the buffs. I then switched to Yodarha and he is fun. Then tried Io, was fun, too. Rackam got stale pretty fast. This was my main party. After the credit screen, I put some effort to upgrading Eugen. He was quite boring, but all my points were spend on him already. In the end, a waste of time. To play with another character, I would need to do like 3 boring grind fests to play another character. Which is a big letdown)

Upgrading everything is hell. It takes at least 10 minutes, to read some background stuff about your character (which gives you stat boosts like 15% or something, hard to pass), buy new weapons, upgrade weapons, check sigils, upgrade masteries (offense, defense, x). And now all this again for the other characters.
The mastery tree is a waste of time, there is no variety, you will skill everything anyway, so what's the point? You could as well get these stats when leveling up your character.
Also, why did the game never tell me that the weapons I don't equip can still give me their mastery upgrades? That's massive if you look at the 3k HP weapons that everybody seems to have and that comes from just 1 weapon.

Story is meh, I screamed at my screen when certain characters acted questionable.

I'm playing with a PS5 controller and it works when I disable Steam Input and use DualSenseX.
This game is addictive but I give it 6.5. Would be 8.5 if they fixed the camera.. No joke "Proud Difficulty Boss" can kill you in 1-2 hits. So the camera becomes your main enemy..

Story is cheesy and endearing, often reminiscent of the 2000-2010's JRPG era. Characters are also quite charming and all play very differently. Endgame is the real game, though. Tons of stuff to grind, but can become repetitive for those who aren't into fighting similar enemies again and again.

The true fun comes with learning the characters and their unique play styles. Combat is fast, flashy, and fun, and playing with others is incredibly satisfying.

That said, Leveling one character up can take an extremely long time due to the number of things to grind for (their specific weapons, leveling and uncapping said weapons, character abilities, and stat boosters called sigils). 

Would definitely recommend to those who love a good grind with simple, yet satisfying combat. Not recommended for those who are just in it for the story as it mainly serves as a tutorial.

This is a really fun game with a very responsive combat system. The main story is fairly short (10-20 hours depending on familiarity with the rpg mechanics) but in that time the game pins you against tons of monsters that will kill your whole team if you are too careless with both your decisions in a fight and neglect to upgrade your skills/weapons. Even if you fail, if you like spectacle, this game's story has that in spades.

If you are as hungry as I was by the end, there is even more post-game content that continues the main story a little further with chapter 0 and even past that, there are even more new bosses for you to discover through a Monster Hunter: World like mission system. These missions will ramp up in difficulty to the point where you will be fighting multiple bosses at the same time.

I have finally reached the end of the game and completed all missions and I am still obsessed with this and plan on coming back to try out more of the 20+ characters currently in the game. I also am looking forward to the promised future updates that will be releasing throughout this year.

Cygames knocked this one out of the park!

The game is fun. You can see the elements of Mobile  Gacha RPG in it, from the listing pictures of items, their short descriptions, the star ranking system. It's all there. But there is no "Champion Collector" store mechanics. Neither is there a Stamina Bar to stop anyone from just repeating a grind into infinite. 

There is still the suggestion of researching the First Ark of Grandblue Fantasy, as this is not a remake or retelling. There is some story in the Fate Chapters but not all of it is there. So if you are interested into more story; pick up the original game to go over what happened before hand and learn of the deeper connections and trials that your crew has gone through.

Relink kind of feels like two separate games. If you're here for a grind, you can blast through the story and stay for the postgame stuff, which encourages you to fight bosses and enemies over and over in Monster Hunter-esque fashion to grind up gear and characters in order to MAKE NUMBER BIG.

If you're just here for a satisfying singeplayer experience, you'll find the main story is a 15-20 hour affair packed with fun fights, plenty of spectacle, and great music backing it all up. For some people, 15 hours of enjoyable action RPG might not sound worth the money, but after playing through Relink's story, I can say with some confidence that I would rather have what it offers than 60+ hours of tedium occasionally broken up by long and pointless dialogues that so many JRPGs have delivered in the past. It's meat vs. fat, and Relink's campaign is mostly meat, which I appreciate.

That stuff aside, I have to comment on how much care obviously went into this game--I'm talking animation work, voice work, music, pretty much anything you can think of. Each area in the main campaign has an adaptive soundtrack that smoothly increases in intensity when you enter a fight. Some characters have little animation flairs like fixing their hair after landing from a jump. Seemingly every combination of playable characters has unique, voiced battle interactions that show off their (sometimes clashing) personalities. The characters will react in combat when you do something cool, like performing a perfect dodge. There's a huge amount of detail that didn't have to be put into the game, but was put in anyway.

Is it perfect? Hell nah. There are problems. The story is passable, but basically standard JRPG fare; start by fighting goblins, somehow end up fightings gods and saving the world with the power of friendship. Some people like that kind of thing; to me, it's old and tired and bleh. A lot of bosses in the postgame are recycled to stretch the content further; their moves are remixed each time to make them challenging in a meaningful way, but if you don't like seeing the same models, you might be disappointed. You can't apply scaling to yourself when selecting specific quests online, so if you want to play with a much lower level friend, you're just going to curbstomp all the content available to them in five seconds. Also the postgame grind can get pretty nutty. You will never have enough resources, and you will repeat quests many, many times, even raising just one character. I cannot imagine the time it would take to max out every character in the roster.

Yet despite all this, I recommend the game. Bottom line: it's fun, and it's fun practically right out of the gate. You don't have to play for 70 hours before Relink "gets good." The game wants to show you the best it has to offer as soon as it feasibly can. More games should try to be this way.

I would absolutely recommend this game to anybody who likes boss-fighting action games. The characters are numerous and they all feel different to play, the online stuff works well, and almost all of the fights are fun and unique.

If you're worried about there being gacha pulls for the characters, don't be. You get awarded crew tickets throughout the story (and a couple of other ways later on) and you just exchange one of those for a character of your choice instead of rolling for them or whatever. You get enough tickets to buy every character, so there's no missing out on anything.

This game is an absolute blast, and well worth the full price.

Good leveling system, better end game grind than Monster Hunter titles, characters are well balanced, the combat is good in terms of both character kits and boss AI patterns. For downsides, it does take a lot of resources to level up one unit to their max potential, let alone 4. The game does get easier for leveling up in the endgame if you opt for co-op over solo play. There are a few weird bugs that can be resolved with a restart, but they shouldn't be present. The story can be a bit campy/cliche, but it's a good introduction to the GBF series. Overall, 9/10 game. Would recommend, especially if you want an "anime monster hunter".

Overall: 8/10. Mainly because of the boss fights

Good stuff:
- Boss fights. Each and every boss is unique in their own way in terms of mechanics. Very engaging and even replaying it doesn't feel super bad.
- Character design is good. Every character have their own play-style and look very different from each other.

Mid stuff:
- Some of the soundtracks for boss fights are good. The best is probably Excavallion boss fight. The others are straight up forgettable/mid. Pretty bad for a "Japanese-theme" RPG where there's usually quite a few memorable soundtracks.
- No crafting system. Sigils are straight-up random from gacha or targetted farming from bosses

Bad stuff:

- Bad console port. Console controls + console UI + console graphics + random FPS drops in some random places. This has to be super lazy of them. The only good thing about that is the FPS are at least stable during boss fights.
- Horrendous storyline. Feels like it was written by a 13 years old. Super ResidentSleeper. Just skip everything. Don't bother with the story, massive waste of my time. Main character basically has no personality, good for self inserting.
- Damage cap mechanic. This has got to be the most terrible, lazy and straight up worst mechanic I've ever seen. Yes, some RPG(s) has some "damage-cap" where it is usually capped at "99999" or something but this one that they have is dependent on the skill/attack you use. It doesn't even tell you when your damage is capped, you've just gotta look at it and notice whether you are able to crit. This thing also takes up so many sigil slots in the late game. Please, for the love of god, remove this.

This is a beautifully executed action RPG/anime. I really like the monster hunter format games and this is an excellent example of how fun those sorts of games can be. 

The graphics and sound design are exceptional, the game play is fun and fast. There is a lot to learn but it's easy to pick up. There are great accessibility toggles for players that want to get a little penalty-free help. 

The voice acting is excellent, the cutscenes are excellent, and it really hits a lot of the old Squaresoft notes without being a direct cribbing from older Final Fantasy games. 

I'm going into the harder difficulty settings now, and I'm excited to see how the game pushes back against the power of the player characters.
Worth the full price, especially if you have friends to play with.
