Fun game and is as Cygames advertised, not as curators marketed. It's an action RPG title that plays soundly enough like one. This isn't Genshin Impact with character switching nor is it methodical like Monster Hunter, it's an anime action game that leans closer to titles like Nights of Azure. For all of its polish, it does lack some depth when it comes to upgrading and diversity between builds and weapon variety. Progression is very much linear with alt builds functionally being regulated to counter strategies for endgame grinds or multiplayer speedruns/safety nets exclusively. This isn't God Eater nor Monster Hunter so don't come in with that expectation. Meet the game on its own terms and you'll likely have a good time with it.

The story is fine for what it is and I can't speak for much when it comes to how serviceable the fanservice and content is for a glorified GBF fan as I'm only really familiar with bits and pieces thanks to Shadowverse, Rage of Bahamut, and the anime. You don't need to know much about GBF at all to get into this game and like the characters and honestly it probably encourages you to try the source material if you find any of their stories interesting. At the end of the day however, the story is decently short (which is why it's more of an ARPG than a JRPG) but the majority of your gametime will probably be spent on endgame progression and unlocking difficult challenges to take on.

I'm pretty good at action games so I can't really speak on the difficulty but the general perception tends to be that this game is on the easier side, so it's definitely something you can do with friends for fun or during downtime and not be stressed out about constantly wiping to a wall or learning specific mechanics for several attempts on end like say a Dark Souls or Ninja Gaiden title would have you doing. The player is rather powerful in this game and the tools at their disposal definitely makes the majority of encounters laughable when take advantage of so! I strongly recommend that you play as much of this game as you can blind to make sure you're getting enjoyment out of it while it still poses a challenge as eventually it does reach a point where it's a pretty systematic grind. You can do well with the AI companions, as a solo player, or even with self-imposed challenges. Multiplayer does make the game significantly easier with faster encounters just because players tend to be much better at dealing (and taking) damage than CPUs; however, there is no wrong approach to anything in this game. I think from my experiences however, after completing the story I would likely just recommend taking on the newly unlocked difficulty tier(s) with a friend who is at a similar progression point or gear level as you, just so the experiences feel closer to Monster Hunter and God Eater rather than having an incidental teammate 1shotting everything for you on your first encounters- could DEFINITELY ruin some of the more interesting things you'll run into later down the line.

And on the top of grind- that's basically the entire endgame. If you've played MHW, think of Investigation spamming for Decoration farming; however, you'll need to do that for missions without any variation or enhanced drop rates in addition to having to roll on several different F2P (there are no P2W aspects of this game) gacha systems for your best-in-slot or even just passable substats and gearing. There is a substantial amount of content in this game to take on so I'd definitely recommend taking it at a slower pace and not being frustrated with having to catch up on gear progression or anything silly like that. I beat most of the encounters in the game with a Lv 75 weapon until upgrading it to 125 which is 25 levels lower than the maximum- and wasn't even best-in-slot using a team entirely of characters who I just liked having around in the party. You'll be fine to play anything and everything you want and you shouldn't be expected to be punished for it--- barring some flying enemies at times but you know how it is with ARPGs.

The formulas in place and current roadmap for the game at the time of writing this does have me more interested in what may come in the future with updates, especially when compared to how I felt about MH Rise so while you're still on the fence about picking this title up, just know that Cy doesn't plan on dropping it at least for a good chunk of time. It's a complete package + more to come.

I'm not granble fantasy fan, but action part is very good.

The story and writing is really bad and the focus was clearly not there. It's cliché, save the innocent girl just so she can be kidnap more and defeat ennemies with power of friendship + end with a sh*tty moral at the end. Even if I didn't play the game for the story, I was expecting a minimum of effort. The story was unbearable to me as a fan of the yakuza series and visual novels in general. Also they drag the end too much. Probably because they know their story is not long. So they try to prolonge that, but longer story doesn't mean better, and I would rather have a game with no story at all and just quests rather than what they give me here.

Just offering some color swap as DLC is sc*mmy at best and is an open insult to the player base, it's even worst at their price. Real cosmetics should not cost more than 5 € at worst so a color swap for 8€ ? Please don't buy that.

The multiplayer is dead because the matchmaking takes too long to find a group. Maybe due to a regional matchmaking so the number of player on steam is misleading. Depending on where you are you could end up solo and the fun come in end game multiplayer. I am not American therefor I am mostly solo. 5+ minutes of waiting for a quest that last for an average of 2 minutes is just infuriating and it's when I'm lucky to find a group. I am in France if it can help you.

The gameplay is however really good but they really lack bosses. On top of not having a lot of them, some are really awful to fight like the one in lava. I also didn't like how the numbers are show. You just see a bunch of unreadable number stacking on each other. Clearly it was just put there to make the gameplay feel good rather tham giving informations. They could have replace the damage numbers by "Boom ! Splash ! Vlam !" like in comics and it would be the same...

So despite the gameplay being good, the problem of the matchmaking plus the bad story really prevent the game from shining and it becomes an average experience. I hope they will do a sequel and improve all of that because it can clearly be a really good game and kind of an alternative of a monster hunter. I am happy of what they tried to do and just hope they will improve their formula for a potential next game.

The game is crazy fun, stable and well optimized.

Right now there are alot of player because of launch, but I worry about the future.

I recommend you get it only if you are happy playing solo.

Edit: Matchmaking is better now, but still far from perfect.

A well-rounded game: plays nice, works fine, looks awesome. It greatly exceeded my expectations.

The main campaign is about 15 hours long even on hard difficulty and it's a faceroll on any difficulty lower than hard. Main plot sucks, the antagonists be like "you're too weak" or "that didn't count" or "ur mom" and move a goal post a chapter away. However, it doesn't really matter since it's just a tutorial before the end game and it's *the* real game. Also you really want to progress as fast as possible to unlock and try new characters: the story offers you 3 unlocks at different moments of the campaign and the rest can be acquired in another 15 hours.

Characters have rather unique fighting styles even if some of them share the basic mechanics but there's a lot of them. And more are coming with their own customizable set of skills. The animation is smooth, the voice acting (JP at least) is outstanding, It's probably hard to find the similar game with the characters' appeal this high, especially if we exclude the obvious gacha mentions as ironic as it may seem. When I think about it, the designs are just too lovely for an action-RPG but my opinion is probably biased. However as the main plot line is short the unlockable characters don't get much of story coverage besides 2 personal missions and some static but fully voiced VN-panels.

Where the characters shine bright is at the battle. Game has a huge focus on the boss and horde fights. While well- and rather too obviously telegraphed the attacks are intense and deadly. All the boss fights feel meticulously crafted with the different phases, desperate aggression periods and ultimate attacks. The game is coop-focused and sometimes NPCs can't keep up with the pace of a battle but still you will probably die much more often than them and they will take care of you just fine. As the only irritating detail I can mention the weird working lock-on, and since the game allows you to lock on different parts of the boss the additional targets can distract you and cause confusion.

A game runs surprisingly well even on the highest graphic settings on my modest (R5 5600X & 1070) setup and while some locations are just nice to look at, one of them is marvelous in terms of architecture and style. I can't stop myself from examining it every time I enter, seems like a lot of work was put into. And no stutters whatsoever. Dear God, I don't remember the graphics and style being so balanced and polished.

UPD: Yeah, I forgot to mention but the sound design is also splendid. Both music and sounds ain't lacking in any sense, quantity or quality.

This is probably the most complete package of a game release in at least 5 years even now staring down the final ultimate encounter, I still want more.

Granblue Fantasy: Relink is everything I wanted in a AAA Granblue game.
I am someone who has been a casual fan of the mobile game's story, characters, and world for several years, and followed the anime when it released.
So you could say I was already very invested in Granblue before playing Relink, and had been anticipating the game's release ever since it's announcement years ago.

Needless to say, Relink did not disappoint.
This game has some of the most enjoyable real-time character-action combat I've ever played.
Every character is super diverse, controls are intuitive and responsive, and the combat visuals are that perfect balance of flashy, and informative.

As for story and setting, the game takes place in a different province of the Granblue world from the mobile game, so players unfamiliar with the series can jump in and play along mostly fine.
All that's really required is watching season 1 of the anime to get up to speed with the etymology of the world, but if you're not interested in that and are only here for the gameplay, it can be safely ignored.

The soundtrack is absolutely superb, I genuinely wish the soundtrack could be purchased, on Steam or anywhere else, because its all so beautiful and theatrical, especially the major boss fight tracks.
There are some very minor sound issues that do annoy me a little, like the overall game volume being pretty low, and there are a few character's who's voicelines sound a little weird quality-wise.

The campaign took me 40 hours to finish including the Epilogue chapter, and I'm really looking forward to the many more hours ahead of playing though the extensive endgame content with online matchmaking.

If you love Granblue, or are at least fond of it's world or characters - even if you have no previous experience with this franchise - I strongly recommend playing Granblue Fantasy: Relink.
It may very well be my game of the year.

It took me 100 hours to stop playing the game and make the comments, and I'm making this comment while i'm grinding silver centrum while dodging all the coolest boss moves. Just kidding here's the honest review:

+ A vast cast of excellent Japanese voice actors and unmatched visuals for its art style make for an outstanding presentation that culminates in a powerful cinematic experience during the main plot. (I guess i didn't waste 7 years for this)

+ Gameplay alike Monster Hunter series but some of the aspects got the better improvements, fights are pretty insane indeed come along with new and old awesome soundtracks. However, it's kinda sad for them that they don't also add the old BGM (6 Dragons, Diaspora Theme) into the archive. (Fr, please add in so i can stay in Lyria's Journal forever listening to Burning Out The Blue xd). The enviroment sound when in towns (Folca, Seedhollow) are astounding where all NPCs are fully voice to the perfect bit (Stop it i am not crying, you are crying).

+ Cracked A.I, actually doing better job than players and called them giga skill issues, man they literally dodge everything in 0.001s frame wtf. This opens a lot of opportunities for players since they can just solo questing without waiting 7749 hours trying to queue up for mediocre quests.

+ The main story is really nice, but kinda bit rushy at the end. In addition, the dialogue references LOTS of Granblue Fantasy Gacha Mobile Game version. Personally, i would find it a very smart way to promote the gacha version for themselves, which is again, very clever. However, somewhat backfire if the person really hate gacha and want to know the whole fantasy of Granblue (Ngl the gacha version is kinda f2p friendly i g-guess? so might as well give it a try, it has old interfaces but also really addicted when you get to know what you are doing).

+ They did fucking wonderful job in keeping the original material from the gacha version of the character's skillset (Rackam's Collateral Damage + Duration, MC's Base Skill, etc.). Morever, all weapons are familiar too (Vintage Weapons, Illutrious Weapon, etc.). Idk what are people thinking about this but i personally think this small detail is pretty dang wholesome (Why only Zosimos and Ereshkigal make it into the End-game weapon why Kimura ? :whysnapped:) 

+ Builds and Weapon Choices: Introducing new concept of 'Dmg Cap' for non-grubble enjoyers. However, this make really fun to theorycrafting a specific for build for a specific character. You can just literally build a Support-centric character to character-who-carry-your-ass-run.

+ Same issue to Monster Hunter, the game act pretty bad toward modifying number tools, which is so called hacking/cheating. Personally I am considered cheating is pretty unethical in this game because you basically missing most of the fun in grinding but it makes understandable for who those might not have time for this kind of hell grind and basically just enjoy the story. This means I'm not agree on cheating is fine, No, cheating is pretty gayass, but if you know what you are doing then im fine with that just don't ruined others players' experience (a.k.a Airplane Mode) (fr i have spent 80 hours just to grinding Silver Centrum mom pls help me i'm despacito).

+ The game has some connecting/booting issues but immediately solved the short moment after so this headpoint is made for fun frfr hehe xd

+ Regarding the running issues of Localization/Censored/Regional Pricing:

Localization: i have to admit that for the new players who have not known to original Grubble storyline. This is troublesome cause it might affect the way people looking toward the contents and such others thing. Personally I running on JP Dub/EN Sub, its pretty much not similar, but if you by any chance looks like a weeb, you kinda alr understand the context of the dialouge, no big deal.

Censored: Dude, I'm paying 50$ for the gameplay after 7 years waiting, who's gonna give the damn thing that if Zeta pansies is being censored, stop being a coomer and literally just buy some erotic stuffs with less than 50$ lmfao. The game gonna make you look what the boss gonna doing instead looking at pansies you can't never eat 24/7.

Regional Pricing: Just crack it my dude, i don't see the problem :cluelesstyping:

TL;DR: 
- It's Illusion of Freedom, if you are a Grubble player also, you know what i'm talking about
- It's 12/10 for JRPG. Shut up and take my money Cygames (Once again)
- Definitely worth it

An extremely fun Action RPG. All the characters have very unique playstyles and are fun in their own ways. Story is relatively short, only about 10ish hours give or take, but is well paced and has some great boss fights. The real meat of the game is the Postgame, which is more quest oriented. Most comparable to Monster Hunter in a sense, though only in the fact you go out on missions to kill stuff to get materials to get upgrades. It's satisfying. A fun co-op game with a good amount of content, with more free content coming in the future. Would recommend.

So I have never played or even heard of this game series before. I was very skeptical at first being that I don't really play JRPG's and the game seemed very limited. While I wish there was more customization, I LOVE THE CHARACTERS and their dynamics. I really hope the devs continue to develop the characters, their relationships/interactions, and add more story! Will update the review once I actually finish the game, but I am absolutely loving it so far. Easily some of the best visuals I've ever seen in a game, and the gameplay is immediately fun.  
  
Follow up:  
  
After nearly 100 hours, I can say that I definitely love this game, and recommend you pick it up if you love flashy, fast-paced action combat. I'll start with the negatives because there are only a few.  
  
First off is the story. It's super straightforward, there's barely any filler, and it's pretty short. It's not bad, but it's definitely not great. For a game that's mostly about multiplayer, I think this is the "best" issue you can have.  
  
Secondly, there's a lot of small QoL stuff that leaves much to be desired. It's a Playstation game that completely lacks Playstation icons when you have a dualsense plugged in. There's no button remapping as of this writing this review so you have to work around it by using steam controller input. Matchmaking is restricted to your download region which is such a weird thing to do in 2024. You can easily swap your download region but come on, just make the servers worldwide and let players adjust their ping limits themselves.  
  
Thirdly, the endgame is kind of repetitive. Everything leading up to it was fun and amazing, but at endgame there is basically only about 12 missions to do, one of them you will be repeating at least 100+ times trying to get a weapon to drop. It's kind of a spoiler but I won't get into it, but basically a "Monster Hunter"-like game shouldn't have you continuously hunting only a handful of bosses of endgame. In this sense, the game desperately need a variety mode where it can truly feel endlessly grindy and not repetitive.   
  
Finally, Build variety is kinda limited. At endgame everyone is forced to build their character a certain way which sucks.
  
With those out of the way, I will say everything else is perfect. This is without a doubt one of the most visually stunning games you will play. There's a lot of hand-painted backgrounds that feels like it had so much love and care put into it, every little detail feels like it had dozens of hours dedicated to it before the stroke was made. The UI feels very vibrant and cool. The characters are visually distinct. Things just look pretty and cool to look at. There was without a doubt a lot of love and care put into this game's art style. Same goes for music, sound design and everything else art related.

The gameplay is really great,  there are 18 characters to choose from, each with their own distinct mechanics. I will say that there's some overlap between characters in that their gameplay tries to achieve a similar goal. For example, Lancelot is all about spaming attacks. and dodges out of the way, and Charlotta is a character who spams attacks and parries instead. They have different skills so those will be different, but their moment to moment is pretty similar. This isn't a common occurance though and is only limited to a few different characters. 
  
The meta game is really good too, it's very similar to monster hunter in that you have a lobby where you craft your gear, gather materials from missions, craft better gear, gather more materials....etc. If you love that gameplay progression loop, it's right here in this game too.  
  
In conclusion, this game is a must-play if you like fast-paced action games with a monster hunter gameplay loop, that is visually the best thing to look at.

Altough the story is nothing otherwordly, i loved it even if short. The soundtrack is superb and the visuals magnificent i was impressed on everything blends perfectly. The star of this show  is the gameplay that will provide an incredible fun experience.

It's an amazing entry, in wich at the endgame it becomes more of a boss rush in where you can play with friends or strangers, but trust me when i tell you it's a blast.

If you are coming to this game like I did because of the Monster Hunter recommendation, let me be transparent on some elements that I haven't seen any reviews talk about.

First: The story is terrible, lazy, rehashed anime tropes left and right. I couldn't stomach it all, and started skipping the cut scenes about 75% of the way through.
Second: You know all those bosses you fought on your way up to the conclusion of the campaign? Yeah, get ready to fight those same bosses, and only those bosses, not just once, not twice, not even 3 times, but at least 4 more times with a progressively bigger and bigger health pool. This only slightly changes when you're on the final difficulty tier, which is a real shame.
Third: The game is way, WAY too easy. Yeah, this comes up in every review out there, but I couldn't believe how easy it *still* is knocking on the door of the hardest difficulty in the game.

With all this negativity out of the way, here's why I still give the game a recommendation:
The characters are fun. While they are no where near the depth or complexity of MonHun weapons, they still do have their own level of mastery to be attained, and it's just complex enough that the moment to moment game play can be enjoyed near endlessly. If you get tired of playing that character, you can very easily swap to a different one in your party of 4, and have just as much fun as the first character all over again.

It's a solid, fun game, just don't come looking for variants of bosses, or complex weapon systems.

Since Steam treats the review system as a score they may manipulate, I shall do the same.

GB Relink is one of the best games in recent memory hands down, an excellent ARPG that's as much character action as it is MonHun.

But it gets a thumbs down in Steam's score system because of the utterly awful translation. Almost every single incidental line has been "punched up" into glorified fanfic. If Granblue is a throwback to classic JRPGs in setting and style, this "translation" is a throwback to "you spoony bard" tier complete nonsense localization efforts. Frankly, for a game 10 years in the making, we deserve better.

9/10 this game is absolutely amazing for what the boring standard for its genre usually is.

Now for the game itself...

The good:
+Game looks better and much cleaner than its predecessors, even though the fighting games look pretty good.
+Loading screens are extremely short, it's splendidly optimized which is rare on new releases nowadays. It runs smoothly on my 2060 with all graphic options on high.
+Gameplay is not as repetitive as other similar RPGs, as bosses actually have a good repertoir of skills and many of them are actually quite complex. You can equip 4 skills at the same time aside from each character's basic combos, and one ultimate skill for each character which you can combine with other people in coop to make a ''all out attack''.
+Skill/stats trees are HUGE and that's always a good thing
+The protagonist is voiced and actually speaks. Dialogue options are pretty irrelevant though, but it's a nice touch.
+When you have to do mini-games that require platforming and running around, the game automatically teleports you back to the starting point whether you succeeded or failed, this lets me know that they actually kept the player in mind, as it makes me look forward to the reward rather than imagine beforehand the tedious task of running around all the way back every time.

The bad:
-The story is quite cheesy, but if you like these kinds of games you're probably kinda ready for that. Character individual stories are pretty interesting though, and give them good development.
-The roster is quite short in comparison to the fighting games and I was disappointed that many characters were not included, although it is possible that they will add them as DLC content later on (maybe it's already confirmed that they will or they won't, I haven't read about it so I do not know).
-The censorship. While in the fighting games there is the option to play the censored or uncensored version of the game, in this one you have no option but to play the censored one. Now whether you like pantyshots and underboob views or not that is completely up to you, but censorship is bad in all its forms and I will never support it, hence why I'm not putting a 10 on this game, but I still recommend it because it's not as invasive as in other games. I will update this review if the option ever gets added to the game.
-Localization is terrible, as it usually is in Japanese games.

One thing to mention is that while the story is rather short (around 20 hours to complete with some secondary quests in between) this is more like Monster Hunter in the sense that you complete the story mostly in order to unlock the game itself rather than play the game for the story. 
The ''unlocking'' part meaning the second half of the game, which includes 3 new difficulties for new quests and evolved versions of the original bosses which are much harder but give new materials for new weapons. 

Overall, the game runs good and is fun, and that's what matters the most.
Way better than Monster Hunter. Sorry Capcom.

This is the game that makes me upgrade my a decade old gaming rig. The combat system is great and there are lots of content (story + endgame) and grinding as typical of JRPG. Comes with many playable characters, which can be unlocked by obtaining crewmate cards through through and story. It has a mastery system which spends MSP points to advance your character stats. Reading character stories also improves stats like Princess Connect. It comes with online coop with friends though not cross platform (only for PS4 and PS5). From my past experience and the exposure of the story and content so far, this would take triple digits hours to 100%.

Graphics wise is not on par with FF series and more towards Atelier. Whichever is better is subjective. Coming from Hyperdimension, this is a huge upgrade.

My only problem with the game is the translation. The tone of the translation is not on par with the original JP. I'd rather have a close to direct translation not an interpretation of the original work. If you are familiar with Japanese, might as well don't read the English translated text as they are not accurate.

Knowing Cygames, I hope they can continue keeping their longevity support for their work and have plenty DLCs for this in the future.

Its difficult to give this game unified score out of 10, so in brief review I will separate it into categories. Keep in mind, im shortly after finishing the main story and currently doing epilogue quests to reach true "endgame" by unlocking the highest difficulty levels.

Story 6/10- While I didn't hate it, It wasn't anything amazing. Just typical, "save the princess" story. The bad guys nearly winning, hero saves the day in the last moment. It would have been higher, but the game is technically a sequel to a franchise, some people recommended watching anime to get the idea of how the crew gathered together. I wish they spend a bit more time on it in game. There are "Fate episodes" quests that somewhat explain it ... but they are just walls of texts, without any animation or even gameplay (with few exceptions). So in short, watch anime, it might give you a better introduction

Secondly, the pacing is terrible. While at the start its decent. Later on there is no breathing room for a player, as if they were rushing to finish the story. There is no hype up to a final boss fight or rather its never ending. At certain point you will be going from boss fight to boss fight thinking its the last one. Just for them to drop "ohh noo, now we have to save this person", because the bad guy, despite losing is still pulling "haha, see you later, teleports away with friend" card 3x. Just really annoying.

Lastly... there is no explained character growth. Yes we as players, see lvl ups. distribute points etc. However, story doesn't reflect that. At the start we get our ass absolutely destroyed. Immediately get up for rescue mission. Get our ass beaten yet again, in the same spectacular fashion, just to find enemy yet again and now with the power of "friends we gathered during our journey" being directly delivered to us, we have a chance to fight. Even tho the enemy also gathered 10x more power. No training, no secret power we found. Just believe in yourself and strangers that you now call friends.

Gameplay 9/10- While story is slighly better than okay. Gameplay is for sure the dominating aspect of the game. I really enjoyed all the fights, the combat system is working well. Each character has their own unique play style. The AI team, is actually smart and supporting. There is a lot of endgame content and a lot of characters to be unlocked. If you want to max it out, you will spend hundreds of hours playing the game.  And the only two minor issues I have, are : 

1. Annoying camera lock- as if they tried to show you more during fights, but it actually does the opposite. with locking usually picking furthest enemy... instead the ont closest to you.

2. 1 or 2 boss mechanics... - it  could be me or not. But there are some that I simply could not predict. Like laser beam going absolutely all over the place and you had to hope it won't hit you, because it would cover like 80% of the map. I would mostly die and wait for AI team to pick me up. There is probably a way to avoid it, I might just be blind to it right now.

Visuals 9/10- I really liked the visuals, they are very anime like. The enviroment looks absolutely gorgeous and perfectly fit the anime style of the characters. Honeslty, if they made anime the same way they doing those 3D rendered cutscenes. It would be the first 3D anime that I would accept with open hands. The game to cutscene transitions are also really smooth.


So in the end. In my opinion story is its weakest part. Interesting world, but not enough explored inside the game and a bit rushed, to call it amazing. I hope for future projects they will put a bit more love to story, than they did here. I will definitely play more to see the endgame content and how much it tests player's skill. Lastly I really recommend this game, purely for visuals and gameplay as its really fun.

Imagine a gacha game with none of the bad but all of the good: numerous characters with mechanics to master, tons of upgrade paths to grind out, and REALLY fun bosses to challenge.

Granblue Fantasy: Relink is like if Monster Hunter had a love child with Dragalia Lost (rest in peace). It’s so beautiful.

[hr][/hr]
[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
In many aspects, Relink resembles a gacha game—except with all the brainwashing and anti-player systems taken away.

Loads of characters with different mechanics to learn? Check—but without having to open your wallet just to gamble a coinflip of getting 1/7th of a proper character.

Quests that allow you to farm for specific materials or resources? Check—but without having to wait 3 hours just to play a single stage.

Challenging end game content requiring really built-up characters to clear? Check—but where you need to learn mechanics instead of just roflstomping.

Incoming updates adding new characters and fights? Check—but where you’re actually excited for the content instead of worrying if the next banner is gonna fuck you up the ass.

Hell, there are even hundreds of little in-game achievements, tons of currency types, an auto mode, and character episodes. It’s like this was designed with a gacha game blueprint but somehow ended up as an actual game.

[b][u]The Bosses[/u][/b]
Oh man. The bosses.

If you’ve ever played Dragalia Lost, you’ll find the style of attacks very familiar—especially those of the end game bosses.

Tornadoes, flamethrowers, meteors, blade showers, lasers, earth explosions, movement restrictions, dimension shifting, and so many more mechanics make boss fights more than just “hit boss, dodge boss”.

Now, Relink’s end game isn’t as mechanics-intensive as Dragalia Lost’s (just phase 1 of Volk was more complex than anything in Relink). Skill expression here is more focused on comboing and dodging/guarding.

Still, we’re getting new content soon, so maybe there’s hope for some really complex bosses in Relink.

[b][u]Criticisms[/u][/b]
A few areas for improvement and minor gripes.

You can’t change controller keybindings, and the camera is very slow and feels slippery to control. Lock-on logic is also very weird, which makes it hard to target what I want to. They seem to be planning to fix some of these issues.

It would be nice if I could see damage details, durations, and cooldowns on skills—especially Damage Cap. We also need a “Detailed Stats” screen. The availability of vital information in-game is currently very limited, and trying to search for it online has Google trying to shove the useless cancer that is Fextralife down your throat.

Ultra end game min-maxing of builds requires you to get UNBELIEVABLY lucky in 3 separate gacha systems. I like grinding, and it’s nice that maxed players have something to aim for, but tens of thousands of hours of lootbox grinding for perfect Overmasteries/Wrightstones or Supplementary Damage V+ Sigils involves brainlessly farming easy stages instead of interacting with the fun content (i.e. the bosses).

Still, future updates would likely make acquiring some of these less time-consuming, as is oft the case with these types of games.

[h1]Performance[/h1]
Relink runs excellently on aged hardware. Even on my old-ass GTX 1080, I’m capable of playing on Ultra on 1080p at a consistent 60FPS in quests.

Frames only drop in the towns, which is resolved if I switch to lower settings. The game still looks fantastic nevertheless.

Load times are really quick even on an HDD.

I’ve crashed only once in 120+ hours of gameplay.

[h1]Story[/h1]
The main story is pretty standard for a JRPG. There are loads of callbacks to events from Granblue Fantasy.

For someone who hasn’t played Granblue Fantasy, I feel like the Fate Episodes did a great job at catching players up with what happened in the original game, along with providing insight into their personalities. Story-wise, I think this was the high point of the game.

A quick shoutout to Hanazawa Kana, by the way. The range of emotions she conveyed in Zeta’s Fate Episodes shows just why she is regarded as a top tier voice actress.

[h1]Localisation[/h1]
So, I’ve seen people complaining about the localisation being awful, with some focusing on how the game supposedly panders to virtue-signalling gaming “journalists” by censoring or changing things to be more PG.

As someone who actually understands Japanese, I don’t believe this to be the case. (At least the pandering part.)

The thing about anime-style Japanese dialogue is that it uses nuance, context, and expressiveness to give emotional weight to even the simplest of words.

What many English localisers do is, instead of following this principle of “simple is best”, they either go full /r/FellowKids cringe (e.g. most gacha games) or spam flowery language in disastrous attempts to imitate GRRM (e.g. Triangle Strategy), along with vomiting out a torrent of stupid mistranslations (e.g. the Octopath Traveler games).

Fortunately, Relink’s localisation rarely outright mistranslates things—rather, it randomly adds and changes things to be different from what is said in Japanese. It’s like a high school assignment of having to quote a passage “in your own words” turned up to 11.

Like, they changed “Seedholm” to “Seedhollow”, “Zega・Grande” to Zegagrande”, and “Divine Protection” to “Wrightstone”.

Here’s an example from the opening lines of Vane’s Prologue Fate Episode:

[hr][/hr]
Original JP:「みんなを守れるようなカッコいいヒーローになる！それが俺の夢だ。」

My translation: “To become an awesome hero capable of protecting everyone! That’s my dream.”

The localisation: “My dream is to become a hero. I know, I know. Kind of stupid, right?”

[hr][/hr]
If any supposed pandering occurred, it would have been an unintended side effect of this “style” of localisation. It’s mostly a vibes-based localisation that violates “if it ain’t broke, don’t fix it”.

That said, as far as I can see, there aren’t any majorly mistranslated combat skills (like in the Octopath Traveler games) or any stupid pandering (like in Triangle Strategy) going on.

Overall, although I find the localisation kinda awful on an absolute scale, if we’re grading on a curve, they’re doing above industry average. The localisation didn’t trigger me as hard as Octapath Traveler 2, most gacha games, or the English subtitles of basically any anime on Netflix, so there’s that.

[h1]Final Words[/h1]
Relink has already given me over a hundred hours of fun on just a single character and will continue giving me more as I develop and learn the other ones. More content is coming very soon, and I’m super hyped for it.

P.S. Cygames, please, for the love of God, give us a Dragalia Lost game made like Relink.

Personal main story and personal side quests are single player only but you have 3 reliable AIs (sometimes more) in your party. Each playable character's fate episodes (aka character's view of their story) are also solo only.

Quest counter (eg. Bounties and commissions in other games) will be unlocked as you play through the story. These quests can be either played solo, mutiplayer with friends only or multiplayer with public. More of these quests/bounties will be unlocked as you play through the game with new stages and different difficulties. (Similar to Monster Hunter style)

All playable characters in game so far are unlockable for free, A good amount of character cosmetic colour and weapon skins are also free as long as you play through the story and craft your weapons.

60usd is easily worth it in my opinion. Hope this is enough information for someone to decide on getting the game.

Extra Info: If you are worried about unstable internet connection during matchmaking with other players, as you disconnect and reconnect into another instance their characters will remain in your party as AI to help you fight till you finish the current quest.

TLDR: Really fun and addicting action game albeit with some enemy variety issues. There is enough enemy variety during the story (about 10-15hrs long, quicker if you're a story skipper), the post-story gameplay does not have any new enemies until the last difficulty, "Proud". Proud is where the game actually starts to get difficult to the point of having to dodge properly and gear up your character. The story is overall pretty meh. Post-story content is about 35-50 hours long so you're looking at about 55-75 hours for the full game with a bit of grinding time in there too. More hours if you want to get a perfect build on a character as there is RNG for important gear drops.

More indepth review:

Positives:

The graphics are great. The face and clothes quality are especially good. The mouths are well done and are very expressive (I wish Genshin had mouths this good). The lip sync is actually really good (I play on EN voices and subs), never saw mouths close when talking or talking when no voice is happening. The general environments are pretty good too.

The monster designs are pretty good. Though a lot of things are so obviously Final Fantasy inspired (not a bad thing).

The gameplay is pretty much perfect outside of a few issues such as AoE circles hitting you even though you aren't even close to them. Will go into further detail on that in the negatives part. The hitting feels satisfying and each playable character is somewhat like a different weapon in Monster Hunter. I play Io so I do big aoe blasts like a Black Mage from Final Fantasy would, but then I can swap to Lancelot and do lots of small hits which add up to a lot of damage. Lots of build variety to choose from with the sigil system (similar to decorations from Monster Hunter).

Neutral:

There is a system called "Transmuting" where you can make sigils with tokens and the chance of you getting a character specific sigil (late game only) is pretty low and when you do get one it's probably not for the character you want. It does add something to keep grinding for after you finish everything but... meh... Maybe a bit too much RNG. No pity system on it either.

Negatives:

I get that it's a grindy kind of game but 3/4 of the post-story gameplay is just such a waste of time because you fight the same monsters over and over again just to get to Proud difficulty where there's actually new content to experience. Perhaps it's this way because they wanted to bloat the gameplay hours??

Some of the hitboxes on the AoE circles are really bad. For example, on the final fight in Proud difficulty there are meteors that come down around crystals you are supposed to break, I can be standing completely out of it but will still get hit. I'm assuming this is because the meteors that come down are projectiles and hit your character from the side they are coming down from... rather than just blasting the floor where they are aimed and telegraphed for. Knowing this, if you aren't aiming for a perfect dodge you have to walk extra distance outwards... Feels bad.

Enemy variety is pretty low for post-story content. From off the top of my head there's probably about 15~ boss enemies minus reskin versions. There are a lot of reskinned enemies which to be fair do have quite a difference in their movesets but it still doesn't really feel great to fight a fire dragon.. then an ice dragon.. then an earth dragon... then a black dragon etc. I know there are more fights planned for the game but I hope a lot more do get added. The game really needs more enemy types.

This is a Granblue Fantasy Game that everyone should actually try.

Pros:
1, The story is not the best but it is actually not atypical of a JRPG. The action pieces are great and imo that is what makes the story feel engaging till the end.
2. All the playable characters in the game are viable and fulfill different playstyles. 
3. Difficulty Curve and progression is one of the best in almost all games I have played. You don't ever feel like you are suddenly thrown into deep water even all the way till the highest difficulty of the game. That being said it is expected for newer players in the genre to struggle in the harder content due to not having access to assists. This is intended and you will eventually be skilled enough to get past that barrier.
4. Fights are fast-paced.
5. Both online and offline play are good options to enjoy the game. Although I would like to point a caveat that you will be progressing slower offline because you need to raise multiple characters instead of just one to get to harder stages.

Cons:
1. Not all the characters shown in the story are playable. To be honest I wish they added them into the game. Will obviously not name for spoilers
2. Super lategame farming is truly brings out the reality that this game is not granblue fantasy relink but grindblue fantasy relink. Of course, you don't need super high-end items to beat the game or even put bosses on farm. But yes there is the grind.
3. End game builds are unfortunately a lot more cookie cutter than I would like to imagine it to be. There will still be some variation but many core sigils are obvious picks when trying to build your character.

All in all, a solid recommend even with these cons. Any casual player should try it. Any dedicated player should also try it.

I was worried when the demo (and the game) initially released and the vast, vast majority of comments on the game I saw were along the lines of "lackluster/mediocre action RPG" and similar gripes, but I was very pleasantly surprised once I picked up the game myself. It's just really freaking good and well polished. I personally never had performance issues or any glitches/bugs at all.

Fast paced and enjoyable combat, a simple but fulfilling fantasy story, very pleasant visual design + effects, fun endgame, very solid music, excellent sound design (those goddamn perfect parry/block sounds are to die for).
Endgame is somewhat similar to Monster Hunter where you pick up quests and take down a big boss or groups of enemies, so if you're a fan of that kind of game I highly recommend trying this out.

One thing to note is that the main story is NOT co-op. If you're looking to play this game with friends, just keep in mind you won't have many options for co-op quests until you've finished the story.

There's nothing truly groundbreaking here, other than Granblue Fantasy finally escaping outdated-gacha hell, but by god does it do everything incredibly well.

This game is very fun especially when played online however right now my biggest issue with this game is the online matchmaking system is lacking.

If you don't find a group in about 30 seconds it will give up or requests you to retry rather than just leave you in one queue until ready which can make it annoying to queue for bosses.

They also give you no time to interact with people you queued with after a battle, and while the option is there to stay with people it's not explained and noone uses it from my experience.

I feel if they allowed you to stay in the instance for a few minutes and allowed players to leave at their own pace it would allow people to use the interaction and typing features and encourage staying as a group, 

It would also be nice if the stay as a group feature got streamlined in a future updates, as well as the ability to allow for longer queue times instead of cancelling the queue after 30 seconds.

I have yet to try the online session matchmaking which I'm sure is better and would work fine but my opinion still stands for open quest queing 

Other than that while the story is short and fairly forgettable plotwise, every boss feels like a massive setpiece and this is easily one of my favourite action RPGs in years with plenty of post game content, and if properly supported it could definitely become even better.

As a fan of Monster Hunter World, Final Fantasy XVI, Xenoblade Chronicles (all of them), and the original gacha game, this game feels like it was made for me, though I'll try to be as objective as possible. As of the time of this review, I've played everything in the base game, including the final challenge. I'll also not acknowledge the Assist Mode, as I never used it and it cannot be used in the end-game anyways.


Granblue Fantasy: Relink is an attempt to take the world of Granblue Fantasy and put it into an action setting, which I believe it succeeds at marvelously. Characters are represented beautifully and faithfully from their gacha counterpart, right down to a lot of NPCs looking very similar yet also immediately recognizable from the gacha. Many mechanics from the original gacha game are here in ways that make sense, such as every character having four skill slots that have cooldowns after uses, weapons having level caps that need treasure drops from quests to uncap further, and a wishlist that players can add treasures to so they can easily find which quests they can farm them from. But there's NO ACTUAL gacha here, this is not a pay-to-win game you can whale at, this is a full-fledged game.

And I want to emphasize that you DO NOT need to know Granblue Fantasy to enjoy this game, the whole point of this game was to introduce the IP to more people. I have friends that know very little about it, only what they've heard from me over the years, and they enjoy Granblue Fantasy: Relink just as much as I do. Every character has Fate Episodes you can go through, which most are just still-images with text on a screen voiced by that character. The first 2-3 Fate episodes per character are their backstories, so you can learn what you need to know in-game. In fact doing Fate Episodes grants stat increases for that character, so you're encouraged to do just that. Some Fate Episodes do have quests attached to them, these also have important unlocks you will want.

Aside from the visuals, the first thing that will stick out is the story, and this aspect of the game can be polarizing. The story is only okay, and yet I think that's okay. As a fan of the original gacha game, it just feels like another side story event. It's not bad and not great, just with a much higher budget and visuals. But the core of this game is the multiplayer aspect, which doesn't fully unlock until the story is completed, which can hold people back. As with the original gacha game, nearly all cutscenes can be skipped, which are accompanied by a short blurb detailing what happens in the scene you're about to skip, so players wanting to jump into multiplayer ASAP can do that and still have a basic idea of what's going on. The story can take somewhere from 5-20 hours depending on just how much of the cutscenes you actually watch and how through you are in scouring the story quests for collectibles.

The game is a mixture of character action like you'd expect from Platinum+ (who actually assisted in the initial development), raid mechanics like you'd see in Final Fantasy XIV, and 4-player co-op like from Monster Hunter. This doesn't sound like it should work, but it does spectacularly. There's over a dozen characters, starting at six with others unlocked over time, with each having a very different playstyle from one another and granting every player to find their own way to play and express themselves. Each character has their own unique traits and combo system, and unique skills they can pick from. While they can only bring up to four into battle, they each have a handful of unique skills to pick from. You're encouraged to try them all out and find what works for you, or more importantly what works for the quest you're tackling. While some characters are a little more complicated and difficult to pick up than others, the ease of controlling and attacking with them makes jumping into Granblue Fantasy: Relink an immediately responsive experience. There's also a training area where you can practice using a character without worry or failing a quest; you're highly encouraged to utilize this. As you unlock more skills and sigils, you'll need to figure out what works well together.

The meat of the game is the post-story multiplayer. While playing the story, you'll gradually unlock Easy and Normal level quests, and they can be played in multiplayer, but they're so easy it's not worth the time. After completing the story, you'll unlock Hard level quests, and the Monster Hunter-style progression will begin. Clearing select quests will unlock more and harder quests, granting access to more bosses, materials, and more to strengthen your characters for the next challenge to come. While there is a variety of quests such as surviving an onslaught of weaker enemies, the ones you'll spend the most time doing are boss battles. They start out with simple mechanics like finding a way to deal with a goblin with a massive shield or avoiding a giant rock monster as it tries to roll you over, but slowly get more in-depth and eventually introduce breaking boss parts to either gain rewards or stun/disable them. As you advance to Very Hard, Extreme, and higher, the boss battles get harder, add new mechanics, and do everything in their power to put you down. The final level of challenges get especially brutal, making it all the more satisfying when you finally overcome them.

The music is incredible! In the early years of the original gacha game it was composed by Nobuo Uematsu, legendary composer for Final Fantasy, and those compositions are rearranged as well as new compositions by the current composer Tsutomu Narita. I'm not really good at explaining how and why music is good, but as with the original gacha game there's quite a variety of thematic styles. Seriously, just go online and listen to some of the boss themes for this game. I recommend Managarmr's theme.


Granblue Fantasy: Relink is incredibly fun and gorgeous, with a vibrant and colorful art style that can make you feel like the world is alive and gameplay that's very satisfying to play, though it takes a while to get to the really fun part. Depending on your skill level and ability to learn MMO-style raid mechanics, you may find the game challenging right away, or take a long time to reach that challenge, but I assure you the challenge is here and waiting for you to find it. And with post content on the way like Lucilius's Dark Rapture, I promise the challenge will only intensify.

This game was a surprise.  It looked like it would neat in the trailers, but I had no idea how good it would actually end up being.  

This is basically Anime Monster Hunter, and if you like that style of game... you will love this one.  It however, is much easier to get into than Monster Hunter and I would say the combat itself is not as complicated either.  This doesn't mean that combat is a lesser tier in this game however.  In many ways, in can be more difficult since many of the characters (think of them as the different MH  weapons) require precise button timings to pull off their combos and button mashing absolutely does not work here.

The fights themselves are a much much flashier and fast paced affair than MH as well.  Some of these boss fights are truly a sight to behold!

Character progression is also very deep and varied and is just as satisfying as any MH game is as well.  

The story is actually not bad either.. at least I found it a lot more entertaining than any MH games main campaign.  The music, voice acting and visuals are amazing as well.  

The only real gripe I have is that we could use more bosses, even though the ones that are here are very fun and have variants etc...

Also... No Ultrawide support..... major bummer... but it oh well.

TLDR;  If you buy this game.. you will not be disappointed.

The story is short and sweet. The game starts after the MSQ, when you start fighting different variations of the bosses you fought so far. They get harder and harder and it's a fun challenge to get to the endgame. You spend a lot of time grinding for specific items to level up your character, weapon and finding sigils to accommodate your playstyle.

The controls are simple, and they respond very well.

There are 18 different characters that allow you to play in many ways. The 12 Sigil slots also allow you to customize your playstyle.

The graphics are very good, it'd be better if the characters had fewer clothes, but they still look nice. Ascended weapons are really pretty. The color variations add a nice touch.

-- Things I wish were better ----------
The game camera is complete trash and it needs to be fixed.

A couple of things I think could be improved is that there are too many DPS checks, not allowing your group to play tanker/healer, the last boss of the game is extremely punishing if you don't do enough DPS and it's last attack kills your entire party no matter what and you fail the mission if you don't do enough DPS. The power you can get with items etc is much greater than the difficulty of the game, so once you have 18k+ power score even the last boss becomes trivial.

It'd be great if there were more bosses on the level of the final one (or stronger).

It'd be great if there were more items to chase, currently there's 1 weapon and 1 sigil you might want to farm, and both of them you get from the final boss. There should be more weapon variations and different bosses dropping them.

Bosses should be harder, or actually what I think I want is players to be weaker. Players can get like 21k power and the final boss requires 17500, I think if the numbers were reversed the fight would be way more interesting.

JRPG Monster Hunter

if you dont know what monster hunter is then ill give a basic rundown of the gameplay loop. you pick a mission (most of which involves fighting a boss) you get resources from said mission to upgrade characters and you repeat. there is a LARGE variety of characters and although there are levels its not hard to reach max levels. rather most of the strength increases for each character involves the resources you grind for and the resources needed to max a single character is a lot between weapons, masteries, and sigils. 

there are a TON of characters each with at least 8 different skills (you can only bring 4 with you) so even playing the same character has some diversity to it. 

game is amazing honestly I really only have two issues. the game is popular but it also separates people by region and theres no crossplay between console and pc so the wait times for content that isnt late game gets real rough but if you are at the late game (at least currently) there is little to no wait time.

my other gripe is the story sucks. like it is genuinely the most mediocre hard to follow jrpg stuff that feels very uninspiring. it is a visually stunning game but I wouldnt be surprised if there was a single dude who was given a week to make the whole story because it is short and also SO MUCH content is behind the story so you feel incentivized to get it over with asap to get to the "real" game.

all in all I give it 9/10 the content in the game more than makes up for the weak story but if youre the kind of person who primarily plays a game for the story rather than gameplay this wont be your cup of tea

At first glance, this game seems like a quaint, breezy Action RPG with lots of grandiose set piece segments. And I love it for that. But once you finish all of that, get through the story, see all the locations, etc... that's when the game sinks its claws into you. Surprise! It's a Monster Hunter-style never ending buffet of boss fights! It doesn't really get difficult until you're in the endgame of the endgame, but by then you should have the resources to gear up and get the job done.

I've really enjoyed playing this game with friends, and there's a surprising amount of strategy around clearing bosses as quickly and efficiently as possible. And before I forget, each of the characters feels distinct and mechanically interesting to play, which is amazing, because they outnumber the weapon classes of Monster Hunter as of the time of writing.

All-in-all an amazing game. Easy recommendation.

The game is really fun, characters feel different, story is simple but interesting and questing is fun, but the matchmaking is not that great before you reach Maniac difficulty, and sometimes it will load indefinitely and crash, forcing you to restart the research or even close your game in the worst cases.

Thankfully AIs are fine, so playing solo is not that horrible, but AIs are not enough in endgame content, some bosses can be really challenging.

On an other note, the game looks wonderful, especially in the cities (game's hubs) which are just gorgeous, the Granblue Fantasy artstyle is perfectly brought to life in 3D and finally being able to visit the skies is really refreshing.

Now, let's hope the content will keep flowing so the playerbase stay interested, I'm hoping for the obvious new characters and new quests and bosses (Edit: it's already been announced YAY!), but new main story would be really cool too!

Insanely goated action JRPG with flashy combat, great music, and an enjoyable post game. It's story is short and sweet, but but doesn't feel like a chore to complete! A game's combat has not felt this good for me in a long time. Blocking, dodging, and using the game's combo strings/character skills all flow nicely into other. At no point did the combat feel clunky or difficult to work with. Each of the 18 characters have it's unique gimmick while in combat, giving players tons of ways of tackling the story and endgame quests. Music is another highlight. For me, it doesn't quite hit the heights of Nobuo's earlier works but are still certified bangers. Especially the boss battles. Just getting started with end game shenanigans and feels very reminiscent of the Monster Hunter games in it's progression, which I love! The visuals are also top tier, especially if you love the classic anime aesthetic. Looking forward to all the new content in the upcoming months!

If you like mundane and generic anime plots and amazingly two-dimensional characters, this game will definitely check every box on the list. It has an annoying mascot with a shrill voice, a mysterious damsel in distress with Plot McGuffin powers, a melodramatic villain more concerned with theatrics than anything else, a completely forgettable protagonist, and a really unforgivingly bland introductory sequence which probably only makes sense if you've played some ten-year-old gacha game. 

The gameplay itself is acceptable for an ARPG, but nothing groundbreaking and a bit more on the spammy button mashing type with twitch dodge/guard mechanics and stay-out-of-the-giant-ground-markers gameplay. It's definitely alright, but you may not want to pay full price for this game since there's better ARPGs out there and Dragon's Dogma 2 is around the corner anyway.

Update: Granblue Fantasy Relink is kind of difficult to review because I want to like it, but feels like the game developers have never made a computer game before.  The Steam release is plagued with technical issues, such as the DualSense controller support being terrible (my directional buttons don't work at all and I need to use the keyboard for items despite them being completely functional in other games), and other issues like being the only game in the last 5 years I have bought which cannot get screen resolutions correct. Anything other than default 16:9 resolution isn't supported and god forbid you try running the game on borderless with multiple monitors, because it will assume your primary display is 16:9 and split the screen across both monitors. I have never ever spent so much time fighting with game configurations and worse yet, losing.

Despite that, a lot of effort went into the combat, which can be enjoyable. There's a lot of content to grind, but the game feels soulless and shallow because of how amazingly linear it is. I wish Cygames had showed similar care when it comes to their characters, half of which have no impact on the story whatsoever outside a Visual-Novel-esque questline which is basically a voiced-over narrative. I don't really think this game was what I was expecting when I saw the trailer four years ago and I do feel a bit let down, but the game isn't bad, it's just amazingly unpolished.

More than 100 hours in and I'm still really enjoying this game.

Many people will compare this to stuff like Phantasy Star, Monster Hunter, or other such games.
This is its own unique game I feel. There are so many different characters each with their own game play style to enjoy, and the curve to master each of them is fun and rewarding.

I'll keep this short by saying the thing I love most: THE ENDGAME. 

Though it's absolutely unnecessary, I love how, if you grind enough, you can absolutely overpower yourself to the point where you can completely destroy all of the bosses on the hardest difficulty. 

Do you need to do it to beat everything in the game? Absolutely not. Not at all, and yet it feels so rewarding when you fully awaken your best weapons, fully gear and optimize your characters. It feels so rewarding to go in and smack fights that you once had to struggle to learn and progress through once upon a time.

My final verdict: Very rewarding and fun. Can't wait for future updates!

One of my favorite games to play right now. Pretty easy and quick to hit end game, but you'll need to grind a ton to fully max out 1 character. 
Current cast of characters are diverse and fully viable once built. World is beautiful, music is beautiful. Highly recommend if you've been looking for an ARPG to play with friends or solo.

Finished the game and all bosses after about 50 hours then did grinding for some sigils and Terminus weapons (BiS weapons) for about another 30-40 hours. Putting the game on the shelf now and might come back for the upcoming Luci boss/raid but unsure. Would overall recommend the game regardless.

Pros:
- Amazing battle soundtracks and music, the specific boss to unlock Proud difficulty is probably the best soundtrack IMO.
- Very fun and flashy combat, never got old or boring for me to use skills and attack.
- Animations are very smooth. Everything feels good to do, feels good to play. Dodges, blocks, moves and all that are very satisfying.
- Polished game in general. Did not personally experience any bugs or performance issues. UI was clean and felt like an actual finished game.

Cons:
- Forgettable, generic story. I didn't really get the game for the story so it doesn't matter to me but honestly if you're looking for a good JRPG story and only that, I couldn't recommend this game.
- Endgame grinding lacks variety - The dungeons/instances where you grind for your endgame curios/gold/Terminus will pretty much be the same with no variety. Terminus weapon boss isn't mechanically intensive and just effectively a big meat sponge. As someone who loves endgame grinding, honestly felt like the journey in this game was more fun than the destination.
- No anti-cheat. Subjective in some ways since you can beat the whole game solo and there's no competitive aspect (e.g. leaderboards, PvP, etc.) but I'm still of the opinion that any game that can be played multiplayer should have anti-cheat. It's lame when you queue up for a boss and someone just one-shots it in a single second. People will for sure cheat for future content.

Several issues with online matchmaking, such as:

1. Stuck on "Connecting..." loop.
2. Doing more than 1 "Quick Quest" in succession can soft lock your game, requiring you to restart it. 
3. Random ass error messages such as "Another player has cancelled the match" or "A network error has occurred". None of these messages mean anything to the player and the game needs to do a better job of articulating actual useful information. Bring the player back to matchmaking or produce an error message that is helpful as to show the player why they weren't able to be brought back into matchmaking. 

Despite the flaws above, it's still a good game for co-op (when it works); recommend getting it with a group of friends once the issues have been ironed out. Random matchmaking is good too but you'd want the goofs and gaffs of playing with friends in a game like this that can otherwise take itself too seriously in the endgame.

This game has exceeded my expectations of what it is. Initially thought it would be a standard JRPG but turned out to be a very in-depth one with lots of upgrading and monster hunter-like game play loop that is so much fun to level up and get better stats and equipment.

Simply put, this is a Devil May Tales of Monster Final Fantasy Hunter Cry kind of game

The campaign is like Devil May Cry series, in which you run through several main missions, and as you progress, you unlock more and more moves, skills, characters and difficulty. Which by at the end of the game - if the gameplay clicks with you - you'll want to do more of it with higher difficulty with the build you thought of.
The grind is quite similar to Monster Hunter and Warframe, in the sense that you re-run some missions to farm exp, skill points and materials, then you go fight the big boss to farm rarest material and weapon drops.

If all of the above piqued your interest, I can wholeheartedly recommend it for you. Yes, the main story campaign is quite short (~15 hours with extra 5 hours for the epilogue) but that's quite on par for action games, and the bulk of your game time would be grinding the post game missions, which could easily go way beyond 50 hours in my rough estimates. My only complain is just that I want more of the story, since it's very good imo and reminds me of ye olde classic JRPG stories, and it also feels like one of the many adventures that Granblue Fantasy could have, which I hope Cygames will add more stories for the game, as new characters are coming as DLCs. 

So yes, I recommend this game wholeheartedly, just for the JRPG story and the action gameplay.

So is the campaign bad? No, but if you spend 60€ for the story only I'd wager you'll be a bit disappointed. 

I had a great time just breezing through the campaign and enjoying the world and vistas. The game reminded me of how freaking long ago it was since I enjoyed a game, and world, as much as I enjoyed Ocarina of Time  (which was not exactly yesterday...)

So, now... 
- if you don't mind a ~15ish hour campaign with a very goodie good anime protagonist
- if you like the fast paced Monster Hunter-ish combat and a similar-ish mission system that takes over after the campaign. 
- if you like gearing up, leveling characters, figuring out which set of gear give you the best versatility and dps potential, and watching the characters stats break all the limits of the universe

This might be for you.

It's a classic JRPG story conveyed through the polish of a developer that clearly has the budget and the passion. I never played the old mobile games, but didn't feel too left out of the story on this one. The story is reminiscent of the golden age of the Tales Franchise (actually reminded me a lot of Tales of Eternia for those lucky enough to play that on the PSP back in the day), and is a really nice mix between the good parts of Genshin Impact, Final Fantasy, the Tales franchise, and the Mana franchise. A lot of JRPGs seem to be quite derivative of each other, but this one at least has enough of an idiosyncratic style to make it a refreshing experience. The visuals are gorgeous, the combat is live action and feels very fluid, the mechanics are intuitive and just feel good, and the character development is surprisingly robust. Fully voiced dialogue, unique character interactions based on your party composition, and despite the disappointment of not being able to do co-op for the main story, the co-op is quite fun. It reminds me a lot of Monster Hunter World in that regard. I haven't finished the game yet, but it seems like the post-game content is quite extensive. The only disappointment is that, while you can play as other characters, you can't switch which characters you control unless you're in a resting zone. Would have been nice to switch through the party mid-combat. The best part about this game is that it's the sequel to a mobile game, and there isn't a single micro-transaction that I've found. I'm normally not a big fan of anime games, because I find the english VA's and dialogue translations a bit cringe, and while there is some of that (I think it's just unavoidable for the genre, but it's just my personal opinion either way), I found the dialogue to be well-written, and the VAs did an excellent job. The characters have a lot of personality, which is cool for a game of this nature.

It's a lot of fun

Main story was generic JRPG stuff, fate episodes(characters' personal stories) kinda redeemed the story content in the game, but their presentation is bland - prob my biggest gripe with the game as a granblue enjoyer; There were some flashy moments and cool minigames in the main story tho so + for that

Core gameplay is a mix between MH/Tales/FF14, feels very responsive and all the chars I've played are distinct and a blast to play with, the link system combined with everyone using their special attacks consecutively for a big combo explosion feels very rewarding to pull off even though it's not hard at all - it just feels satisfying

Voice acting to me is a big part of this game as all characters interact with every other character mid-fight, because of that the fights feel a lot more teamwork-oriented and all the lines fit every char's personality perfectly, that being said I think this is only applicable for the JP version of the game as it's just stacked with insanely good VAs - if you feel like you can understand some JP or want to play in JP then this will be a + for you, if you choose the EN dub I think this will detract from your experience

Progression is smooth and upgrades don't really take more than a few runs until the final parts of the endgame, boss variety is slightly short of where it should be, but most of the bosses offer a good challenge or are at least fun to fight, with some having special interactions that make the fight easier

Overall I'm having a great time with the game and I think it is solid, well polished, looks really good with its unique artstyle despite having lower fidelity graphics, plays smooth as butter and I can weeb out all I want when I listen to my fav chars from the franchise completely pop off in a proper 3D environment

Great game, reminds me of the Tales games in a lot of ways. It can be kind of grindy, but I like a certain degree of grind so that's not a bad thing. I'm not much of an anime fan, so I thought some of the characters would be overbearing and annoying, but they aren't really; they're nothing you haven't seen before, for the most part, but they're likable enough. There's 18 different characters to play, and it can be a bit tough to find the one that really fits exactly what you like... but the fun is in trying, and building up your characters to be stronger and stronger as you progress.    
    
No prior experience with the franchise necessary. I didn't even know it was a franchise until I'd already played it a bit, and I don't feel like I'm missing anything. There's an ultrawide fix on Github if you need it, I'm playing at 3440x1440 and it looks great and works perfectly (big thanks to Lyall for the work on the fix).

The game is good for what it offers, good solid RPG with mechanics found in KOEI TECMO Warriors games, except this one does not have the fodder enemies found in those games. 

If you have play any of the Warriors games before, you will feel right at home with this one. From the way missions start, to side quest, specific character quests related, is easy to see where they got their inspiration from. The advantage in this one so far, is that 4 characters can level up at the same time, since you can have a party, something I dont remember been able to do in the KOEI TECMO games. Also, like those games, you have tons of characters to play as and level up, and grind items for to keep you entertain for dozen of hours and features and online function which I have not try yet.

It also features gameplay mechanics similar to the last iterations of Ys games, where the you have a party of 4 and you learn skills that help you in battle, it has similar link attacks, ultimate attacks, and boss  can be stagger in a similar pattern as well.

Basically the game plays like if the Warriors games and Ys had a baby, it would be something like this.

I was hesitant in getting this game, as it was a bit out of the norm for games I typically play, but after playing the demo on PS5, I finally understood.

I have several hours in Monster Hunter-type games, and this definitely hit home for me. The main story is understandable for someone that isn't familiar with the series, and although there are some nods to events that have happened previously, the game does a good job of helping you understand what it's talking about.

The endgame loop is great - you have so many characters to level up and "perfect" and so many ways to get the items you need to do so (although some ways introduce a sprinkle of gacha elements to it, which makes sense, but didn't disrupt the flow for me). I'm not by any means done with the game, and hope that others give this game a chance to - it was very "over-the-top" and almost TOO anime at first glance, but I've really come to enjoy all the unique characters. Seeing that they already have a roadmap available of a raidboss and more playable characters coming out gives me hope for this game's growth.

Edit after 65 hours: The last difficulty, Proud, is challenging and fun. I'm not a big fan of fighting 3 bosses simultaneously; it feels a bit artificial, but later you'll be fighting one boss and these type of raid bosses feel difficult. The grind for the last weapon, Terminus, is just that - a grind. I wish this quest gave more materials for upgrading your characters, but I digress.

Excellent and fun game. It knows what it wants to be, and does not try to stray from that. Play this game if you want a fast paced and short but action packed RPG with fun and cinematic anime style boss battles thrown at you frequently. The online is also simple and easy to get into as well.

Main story is very action packed and well paced with great enemy variety, great combat/abilities, decent skill trees, great voice acting english or japanese, with a somewhat generic yet wholesomeish story. The characters, gameplay loop, multiplayer endgame, graphics, and world building lead to a light fun animeish boss battler.        (Do the fate episodes)             

No DRM and has offline mode so I appreciate them for this. So far only 2-3 hours into endgame but it seems the end game is where the enemy variety drops off slightly , giving you stronger variants of past enemies with different movesets, but this may lessen or worsen the more I play. The difficulty can constantly ramp by completing hard and harder quests to unlock new difficulties leading to more challenge.

Either way I enjoyed the story alot, the mutiplayer endgame might be a tiny bit repetitive sometimes but with how light and fun the gameplay is I can see easily playing a ton of this with friends.

(Also Dlc is not worth getting) ( And my friend played medium and got 22 hours of main story so depends on the person.)
