+Great voice acting (and lots of it)
+Fantastic music
+Story mode is a blast, very fun
+Plenty of after-story content to grind and improve your characters

Cons:
-No crossplay (as of the time of this review, could come later)
-Targeting is a little wonky but manageable

Overall very fun and enjoyable, if you enjoy games like MonHun. It feels like there's plenty of room to continue adding characters, weapons, locations, new quests, new storylines, etc. in the future.
pretty game combat kinda janky

After beating most of all of the content there is in the game, this is how I think of the game. Some mild spoilers.

What I liked
- The art style is incredible. The pixel count isn't the highest, but the lighting style they do with this game makes it look 10x better.
- The gameplay feels smooth. You click a button, it happens.
- Character diversity feels enough. Each character sufficiently feels different from each other in terms of gameplay.
- Despite low boss variety, it didn't really feel that repetitive. However, I could see how that's a con for others.
- Some fights are incredible. The first and last Proud level fight are very fun fights. Furycane during the beginning of the story is what really got me to go into the game.
- It's extremely approachable as a game. It feels easy to pick up.
- Very cinematic boss fights make the game much more fun.
- I think the only bugs I run into are camera angles during the story line, and all air attacks are incredibly buggy when you're fighting bosses like Vulcan or Bahamut. Very polished game.

It is what it is
- Full Auto Assist. Kinda interesting decision. You can't use it on later game modes, but it leads to a lot of people afk farming Extreme levels (but regardless you'd be able to do this with Maniac with enough investment w/ 3 AIs).
- Item caps on 999? Why? What's the point of this
- Matchmaking/COOP UI isn't really that great or intuitive.
- Kinda wished the story could be co-oped with your friends.
- The combat itself is not that complex, It's a little more complex than Kingdom hearts spam X, but it's also not as fleshed out like other games. For some reason the game insisted that all combos must start with X, and once they use Y, all remaining attacks must use Y. There's some characters, where I think would have greatly benefitted from a X Y alternating combo system. Regardless, they definitely added a lot of things to make "spam x" as interesting as possible.

What I dislike
- I don't understand the point of RNG drops that are "You get it or you don't" such as Dreaded Horn in offline games. Even though this has co-op, there is no centralized system in place to make "you get it or you don't" drops actually feel valuable and simply feel like a waste of time. RNG drops are ok, but it makes more sense to have something like "you can get a drop from a pool of items" and what item you get is random. They're fun the first time you get it, but once you realize you have to get it another 12 times, it stops being fun, and you start looking for non-gameplay strats like Autoplaying, Botting with a simple AHK script, or just hacking it. I will admit though, the last boss grind isn't as "unfun" as some of the other ones like doing Vulcan Bolla. Chasing Sigils aren't as boring because you do get sigils, its just a matter of what stats you get on them.
- I wish character builds were more interesting. Sigil system is alright, but I wish there were more interesting unique sigils. Some of the class sigils are cool, but others are kinda boring (Zeta is just 25% atk increase on a debuff she applies and the other one just makes you jump higher when you loop). 
- I wish some of the less useful sigils in the end game didn't have level caps to them so people could use them for specific scenarios or for fun - Stun Power, Throw, Fast Learner, Rupie Tycoon
- More clarity in some of the stats. Stun Power, unless I missed it, has 0 explanation as to what it actually does.
- UX/UI was clearly designed for console. It would've been nice to have at least some consideration for mouse like scrolling, selecting masteries when leveling them, zooming in and out. (I played mostly with controller).
- Story... is definitely a story. It feels very generic to me as someone who hasn't interacted with any previous granblue content. Even the character tropes and their backstories feel pretty generic with very little depth or care to them. It is presented very well though, which made it a lot more fun that it would have normally been.


Overall, I don't play singleplayer games that often, and I just kind of randomly decided to buy this game, and I'm glad I did.

This game shines in its combat, diverse playable characters all with unique fun playstyles, stunning locations, and epic bosses. It has a satisfying endgame grind, and very good performance that never faltered below 120fps. However, a few unpolished aspects hold it back from true greatness.

[b]Keyboard/Mouse Concerns:[/b]
While the controls are mostly functional, they lack keyboard/mouse-specific polish. Some key issues include:
[b]Mouse-unfriendly menus:[/b] Menus can not be controlled with the mouse. Navigating menus solely with a keyboard feels slightly clunky and controller-oriented.
[b]Excess mouse smoothing:[/b] Aggressive camera smoothing hinders aiming and responsiveness. Making some characters (especially Eugen) feel a bit cluckly when aiming.
[b]Tiny cooldown icons:[/b] The lack of a permanent "Show Skills" option makes monitoring cooldowns inconvenient. Wish there was a option to toggled that view all the time. Buffs icons are also really small and sometimes even worse as different skills use same icons it can be hard to tell which buffs you have active.

[strike]Also a wee pet peeve of mine, and 3% of Steam demographic: [b]No ultrawide support.[/b][/strike] nvm there is a mod now

Wanted to review this for the non-anime fan who is more into Souls and general action games.

First, this game is nothing like a Gacha game as it can be kind of comparable to, it's a more general JRPG with light anime tropes, but, a REALLY cool story (if not slightly friendship is magic-esque) but all that aside, the characters are really cool. 

You initially have to play as a very boring character but can eventually play as any of them.

I HIGHLY recommend doing some slight research on a character you like before unlocking as the crew cards at the start are very limited.

This game has some of the coolest boss fights I've seen as a Souls player and WoW Raider, it's a combo of those two, there are mechanics in some of them and I'm excited to try them in Co-op.

The games story is pretty short, my game time is extended from doing some side quests and stepping away, but the real meat of the game is the boss fights and side quests AFTER the main story to farm materials and XP to do stuff on harder difficulties. 

I played on hard and I only ever "failed" once, but never lost a boss encounter, it's very forgiving but I'm sure coop on harder quests will be more challenging, some of the characters are simply while others have crazy in depth aspects, none of them play the same at all and it's cool to find one you really synergize with.

I don't know how much of the farming aspect will make me dislike the game, but overall I really enjoyed the story, the art and characters are incredible, music as well, the set pieces and cut-scenes are nothing short of epic.

If you can look past the anime aspect and just enjoy it for a feel good fantasy, you will love this game.

The real question for this game is: Who is completing Lyria's Journal for her the entire main story since she's tutorial fodder for kidnapper noobies?

As someone who's followed this since its inception years ago, it's hard to recommend this game other than for someone who wants to play it for the thematic experience. Though, the game is paced well enough into small bite sized parts that it feels less of a hassle to play through and more of a lighthearted stroll along a breadcrumb trail, where the breadcrumbs are really hard to eat but you have to eat anyway. Just make sure to start upgrading weapons early. Levels don't play too much of a large role as much as the weapon levels. Masteries are also a great point to remember doing frequently as soon as you have more points.

In the 12 hours of completing the main story (Prologue, Ch 1-9, Epilogue and part of Chapter 0), the endgame content barely opens up all the upgrade possibilities, quest difficulties and real multiplayer opportunities. Which sounds good. But in hindsight, the scripted boss fights are damage sponges as you mash your way through the core of your controller or mouse, you get thrown off course and have to run back to the boss every minute (I started using ranged characters after a certain giant boss), and story-wise, it's one failure after another. Not only does it start with a frustrating turn of events that Lyria can't seem to shake off being #1 most easiest target in the world, it takes 10 hours of pointless boss fights for her to just be handed back over by a betrayal to become a reverse betrayal...to get taken back again in exchange for someone else...until the final chapters play out then you'll see an annoying pattern here. Point being, every chapter, albeit paced very well, ends in some sort of frustrating tragedy sugarcoated in a small victory. Some if not most boss fights are scripted so even if you get its HP to zero the event goes on until a scripted wipe or a scripted victory. Feels very on-wheels for the most part until you just start grinding quest content a la Monster Hunter or Phantasy Star 12 hours down the line. By this time, most players would stop playing already. And I think those who are looking for the endgame content might not be patient enough to stick around and enjoy the main story unfold for 12 hours. It's like having to watch Game of Thrones "play" scenes because they put some important dialog for story or lore while they were at it...heaving.

For something Platinum Games had a hand in at one point of its development cycle, you'd think that the combat would be combo based, but no. It's very Genshin Impact-esque in that sense where each character does a few things distinctly different from the other with two main buttons and a 4-button skill set, and the point of unlocking new characters is for coolness and a better play-style that fits yours. Most characters are fairly generic and their backgrounds speak for themselves, but some do make a difference. I did enjoy playing Ferry, Nermaya and Yodarha. Despite Gran/Djeeta being a great support class, playing them is quite boring.

It's a very beautiful but frustrating game. I love it, but I hate it at the same time. Honestly, I would prefer watching this as part of the anime more than playing through it, albeit the pacing in this (other than the extraneously long boss fights) is very good as a video game. The writing though, is too much for a game. Take me one long road to tragedy like FFXV or FFXVI but stop slapping me with mini tragedies in every chapter, please. I really hope that they continue from the mobile game cos the writing for Relink is downright frustrating af... The entire game is about failure after failure after failure. Like if I were Gran, I would have just offed myself to save the world at a point near the end... XD And even if the ending is bittersweet with the hopes that you'll meet a certain someone again, I don't want to hold my breath and grind the rest of the endgame content to find out it's not written into the game, so I will end my adventure grind at this point until more conclusive information comes around.

Great game. Very similar to Monster Hunter (I do wish it had more customization though). Tons of replayability and looks/plays great also.

A great action RPG with combat akin to Tales of Arise and stunning visuals to boot! Seeing the world of Granblue finally gets it's chance to shine in a full on game release as supposed to it's original gatcha format is a dream come true.

Playing through the main story and doing the accompanying side quests will land you around 20 hours of playtime, which has been a point of contempt for some, however, I feel it's a completely acceptable playtime for what is essentially a linear gameplay experience. The game does offer additional challenges with it's Monster Hunter-esque quests in "chapter 0", however, most of this is upscaled content you've previously experienced throughout the main chapters of the game.

That being said, the music and art direction for this game is great. Voice acting is also superb, however, the English translation gets a bit too loose at times. I'm not too fussed if some liberty is taken with translations so that a character comes off as more natural sounding in English, however, hearing Io directly reference "magical girl transformations" feels pretty inappropriate of the entire setting they are going for, and I can't imagine she said anything close to that in the original Japanese version. I don't find it incredibly intrusive, but other people have found the inaccuracies to be egregious.

Overall though, I've had a great time with the game and it's an easy recommend to anyone who's already into Granblue.

TLDR: Has bad translation if you play with JP voice using EN sub. But luckily the game is so good you can probably forgive the bad translation. 

Easily recommended

======================================================================
The Bad:

1. Pretty Horrible English Translation
It's really horrible, if you understand even a bit of Japanese, you will easily get confused because the localizer really like to tell their own story with their own wording instead of just translate it as it is. 
If you understand Japanese a little, often what you heard and what you read will be so different.
It's not just complex sentences, even basic ones got butchered. 

They also like to use unconventional English, modern gen-z English, and pretty out of date slang, which really out of place and ruin immersion.
This is important because some characters portrayed differently from the original because of localizer can't help to keep adding/changing stuff in translation.

Example of the worst yet so far:
(JP): Hmm
(EN): A wishful thinking
Somehow they managed to translated "Hmm" into a sentence...

(JP): Are you two a couple?
(JP): What!? No, we are just working together
(EN): Are you two an item?
(EN): An item!? Gross, no we are not...
wtf even....

Another examples:
(JP): Exactly
(EN): Exactamundo

(JP): Still talking about that?
(EN): You guys are such a dork

(JP): (dodged thrown spear) That is absurd!!
(EN): (dodged thrown spear) Well that is just happened...

(EN) Often Vryn talks in blabbering childish manner unrecognizable English, can't even understand most part. 

Even sometimes when characters speak formal and common Japanese, they altered it with some slang and impression which made the characters really looks out of place and time.

2. Censored/Altered
Yes, they censored/altered several characters outfit by giving them ugly short pants.

3. Possible cheaters in co-op mode because there is no anti cheat present at the moment.


The Good:

- The game itself run pretty good on RTX 2060, it's not a resource intensive game
- The graphic is beautiful
- Movement and combat almost feel fluid, but not the level of DMC or Bayoneta
- Good amount of playable characters and every one of them is unique
- Satisfying combat
- Good amount of side and end game content especially if you want 100%
- Combat is still fun even in higher difficulty
- Co-op

It's just so sad the translation is so bad and has unnecessary censorship ruining the original visual artistic otherwise a good game.
Japanese game companies really need to wake up fast, listen and make games for your the gamer not the localizer.
Such a good game, ruined by horrible localization and censorship.

If you can tolerate all the negatives especially the translation, then it's safe to buy.

Incredibly fun ARPG, along with some of the best art direction I've seen in a game.

Review in Progress:

Recommendation: neutral leaning positive for now based on good gameplay counterbalanced by some poor technical decisions (see below). 

I'm not very far into the game yet, so this review will be updated as I progress. If the game merits it, I will change the recommendation. I hear the endgame is where it's at, so we'll see how things go once I get there. 

Positives:
Granblue's art style has always been a positive, and that remains the case.
The music is engaging, though it may be time for Japanese games to shift away from the nostalgia piano/symphony style which seems ubiquitous in anime-inspired games. 
Combat is fun so far, though not particularly challenging, even on hard difficulty, even the bosses. 

Negatives:
The controls, the controls, the controls. 
Some of the choices the developers made here are baffling. 
Games have been offering the ability to remap buttons for so long this should be a standard feature in any game. You can remap the keyboard controls, yet GBFR does not let you remap the controller buttons. So, you're stuck dodging with RT and blocking with LB, weird choices in any game. 
Playing Eugen, when you aim his gun camera movement shifts from the right stick to the left stick, something I don't think any other game does. 
It's as if the developers didn't bother to play other successful games to see which control schemes work best and just reinvented the wheel. 
I hear a patch is in order to address button assignment, and it can't come soon enough.

Some settings choices are odd as well.
On the graphics side, you're locked into multiples of 16:9 resolution. If you have an ultrawide monitor, you can expect black bars.
Frame rate is capped at 30, 60, or 120fps. This makes me suspect the game uses frame data in multiples of 30fps for gameplay and move timing, another somewhat archaic system.

This game was a great surprise to me. the combat is very satisfying, its like a devil may cry. the endgame is really great and everything you do counts toward something. and the story is good and simple which thats a good thing for this game. easy 9 out of 10

The game was worth the wait.

For fans like myself it is a way to experience the world and characters we know and love like never before.
For new people, while there is some lore left out, through both the main story as well as the fate episodes you learn most of what you need to know in regards to both the world and characters, it is a good way to jump into this fantastic world overall.

In regards to localisation, while I understand it isn't for everyone, coming from the existing Granblue Fantasy games this isn't really any different from what we know and love, so I have no issue with it.

Gameplay is a lot of fun, a number of different characters can be played and upgraded, each having their own playstyle and can be switched out from your party which can give a different experience as well. Additionally each have their own set of weapons that can also be upgraded just like the character, during the main story this isn't too big of a focus, but that switches when you get to the end. The main story somewhat serves as a tutorial in this regard.

Performance wise I didn't experience many issues, maybe a lagspike here and there, but they would quickly disappear or be fixed with a simple pause unpause, and this was shortly after launch.

Artwise the game is phenomenal and a beautiful rendition of what we already saw in the other games. 
Music wise it doesn't disappoint, Narita and Uematsu have done a phenomenal job with it.

There are some issues I have, for example the target lock/target switching can be annoying at times, but the cons are heavily outweighed by this game's pros.

Overall I highly recommend trying out this game whether one is an existing fan or a newcomer to the series.

Also Cagliostro is best girl.

[b]TL;DR: [/b]Granblue Fantasy: Relink feels part DMC, part Monster Hunter and gets really interesting in it's endgame.

[b]Overall Impressions[/b]
While the game starts off with a mid campaign, (Albeit one with some unique moments that goes quite hard), even on it's hard difficulty, the campaign is largely a breeze to get through (Est. 10-20 hours depending on how thorough you are with side-content between main quests). The main cast of characters are decent although new players may be a bit confused given the canon ties in to the mobile gacha game this title is based on. My only gripe with the campaign is that none of the characters you unlock during it has no impact on the story and isn't even present in cutscenes even if they're in your party.

Where the game really shines is in it's endgame after you've finished the main campaign - Suddenly the decent action RPG becomes more of a Monster Hunter-esque experience with bosses to farm in order to upgrade your characters. As you progress through it you unlock higher difficulties with new bosses (or more difficult versions of previous bosses) New features, weapons and other gear to tweak and tinker your build.

Now your mileage in the endgame may wary depending on how invested you are into making a powerful build for your main, or if you want to dabble into more, or even all the characters (Of which there are many already, with another 2 confirmed for a later update.) The earlier difficulties are quite easy, though later bosses I'd liken to something akin to 'raid encounters' in other games with different phases and mechanics to be aware of. Another powerful looking boss is also planned for the game's first (Of hopefully many) updates.

More than anything else though, this game just feels like a complete package already, with seemingly little in the ways of mtx planned for it. It feels smooth on PC, I've experienced very little in terms of bugs and never had issues with performance, even on the more intense boss fights. There's no "Waiting for a season" or DLC or update that "Fixes the game". 

[b]Score:[/b]

Your controller will randomly disconnect (and will not reconnect) if you alt tab and if you try to use your keyboard sometimes it will work but then WASD won't, which means you can't navigate the menus. Then all of a sudden you've lost half an hour of progress because you couldn't save.

This game is the premier example of little to NO QA testing done from porting from the console.

good game but its funny how the Main Story feels like a tutorial and after you beat the game that's when the game actually picks up on different builds. The main characters name, gender/looks and difficulty mode can be changed at any time you wish in town easier or harder so you have no regret's when starting the game.

This game looks like the kind of game that has all flash but no real gameplay, but it actually manages to look good, play well, and be rather technically complex. Every character is unique enough to find something fitting your own playstyle in action games, as well as having their own unique dialogue lines. It feels like a 360/PS3 era titles where the story quests are just a bunch cool set pieces one after another, which can be good or bad depending on your perspective. It's a load of fun, and even more fun with a couple of buddies.

Problem is, I don't know where this game is going to be about 3 months down the line without those buddies. The game is set up in a way where it's highly dependent on having a multiplayer community, much like an MMO-lite/MO. I'm a week late to launch and the game is already to a point where, while trying to reach endgame, it's too tedious to solo, but too easy to get hard carried while queuing for multiplayer. The flash and effects of character skills look amazing, they can easily flood out the otherwise readable boss tells and AoE markers, making some fights much harder than they should be. 

While I was skeptical of this game since it seemed to be in development hell for the longest time, it ended up being a great one. Just fair warning though, if this game made you want to play the original Granblue Fantasy, well don't. The original GBF is a web browser based nightmare there the only players left are ones stuck in a sunk cost mentality.

"Excellent presentation, average in every other respect."


Specs:

Laptop: 2021 Asus Zephyrus G14 - Ryzen 9 5900HS, 16GB DDR4 3200 and a 6GB Nvidia GeForce RTX 3060

Performance (1080p/Ultra): 55 - 90 FPS Variable, typically runs between 55 - 72 FPS


Handheld: 512GB Steam Deck (Oct 2022) - CryoUtils, latest SteamOS updates, Proton Experimental

Performance (720p/Standard): 20 - 60 FPS Variable, typically runs between 30 - 40 FPS

Note: Do not use the game's built in V-Sync as frametime/pacing is very inconsistent. Either use your GPU's V-Sync or if you're on Steam Deck, lock the FPS to 40 via Steam OS. Leave the framerate at 120 FPS in-game. Performance remains smooth and feels responsive with no frame tearing to speak of.


Pros:

- Easy to play, even for someone who has never touched a Granblue Fantasy game before

- Visually stunning and full of great spectacle fights that are well designed, produced and executed

- Performs well enough for the quality of visuals


Cons:

- Easy to master. Every character has a gimmick to make them worth using, but none of the characters require dedicated practice to master. You should be able to understand them within 1-3 minutes of practicing at Sir Barrold.

- Difficulty is almost non-existent. I've been playing on Hard mode and have beaten every fight on the first try with minimal preparation. Mind you, I'm the kind of masochist that does naked low SL runs in Souls games for fun, so you'll probably have no issues with the difficulty if you're just the average player.

- The story, while it's serviceable and does a good enough job to incentivize the player to stay invested until the end, is not anything remotely close to the kinds of stories you would get from a game like Red Dead Redemption 2, Ghost of Tsushima or Witcher 3. It feels like a high production value, serialized anime on Netflix (e.g. Onimusha) as opposed to a grand odyssey with high drama, great dialogue with a satisfying climax. The story's sole purpose is to just give you an excuse to get to the next spectacle battle and well.. to be honest, that's perfectly fine for a game like this. I just put it under con because some people might go into this wanting an actually good anime story.

- Display options are extremely limited. You can adjust fps from 30 to 120, VSync is just On/Off, graphics options are just Standard/Ultra, you can adjust brightness and blur. No DLSS or FSR options. For Steam Deck, you cannot manually force a lower resolution in Steam OS to enable the use of native FSR 1, though you can likely edit an ini to force a lower res. I have not done this, so I cannot speak to whether or not it'll work or if it'll even look decent if it does. 

- Do not play this game in a dark room with the brightness even at 50%. Opening the menu screen is akin to having a flashbang go off, it's so damn bright! I would implore the devs to include background options for the menu screen so that we can change it to something darker.


Granblue Fantasy: Relink is a fun game with really cool spectacle battles and a well thought-out, though disappointingly easy action battle system. The controls are fluid and responsive, even in low fps situations on the Steam Deck and I keep having to pick up my jaw from the floor as the visual splendor of the game does not stop for even a minute. Unfortunately, even with online co-op, this truly is a "beat and uninstall" game as there are currently no incentives to replay the game, let alone master it. This is one of the few times I curse myself for being a massive Souls/Monster Hunter fan. Apparently four updates to the game are planned, including a raid boss designed for cooperative play and two new characters, but that honestly isn't enough for me to want to reinstall after I'm done with this. Unless you are a big fan of the series, I'd say wait until this game is on sale for at least $40 USD, it's worth at least that much.

Jokes aside, after having finished the main story and having gotten a taste of post-game content, I can confidently say that this game is a lot of fun. The gameplay is very flashy and fast-paced, yet it still manages to feel very fluid. Every character (at least the ones I played so far) feels very unique and the skill-tree (mastery) goes very deep. There's also a lot of variety in the form of different skills that give unique effects and can change gameplay dramatically. 

Aside from a few smaller things, the only thing that I think is a missed opportunity and in turn didn't really like, is the main story being singleplayer (even though I did enjoy it), meaning you can only do side-quests with friends.

Oh, and Vikala not being in the game is a major missed opportunity as well.

As Someone who's been waiting on this game for a while, i'm just glad its finally here.  And let me say it does not disappoint,  starting off into the fantasy world you wake up surrounded by friends, (if you want to get a feel for the characters you can watch the first two episodes of the anime) and you then choose who you want to main. (if you've played the gacha game then you'll already be familiar with these characters)  The story didn't take long to clear maybe 10-15 hours if you watch all the cut scenes and explore + whatever "current" difficulty you choose to clear it on from easy to hard.  Now regarding how good the story was I would give it a 7/10 even though i love the characters and the development it was predictable at times but also feel like this is a fair score.

After that's done then you can finally get into the meat and potatoes known as post game, MH fans should be familiar with this, you have to clear rows of quests to unlock the next difficulty to progress and get those materials you need to further upgrade.   in terms of building characters in this game though you have numerous options to build from sigils (perks) to weapon levels and masteries as well as choosing what skills you want to use. 

Now regarding the best part of the game, the combat is pretty good in all honestly it feels so fluid and each character plays differently which keeps things exciting.  You have a party of 4 and control one character even in early difficulties you can let the game play for you in assist mode or go full hands on you choose your experience. Anyways regarding the teamwork you can choose to do co op or the solo experience (let me say this AI is probably one of the most competent AI I've seen in gaming in a long time)   from linking skills to chaining ultimates, as well as dodging and coordinating who does what for the team and forming the best experience possible is whats keeping me and probably others HOOKED. 

Regarding the bosses, the difficulty for the story wasn't too bad for me personally (and will vary from player to player) starting on Hard but after beating that and going from Hard-Very Hard-Extreme-Maniac-Proud I noticed the spike in difficulty Very Very Quickly, But it was done tastefully as bosses didn't become HP Sponges but instead became more chaotic in a fun way.  

Regarding the endgame loop, its you min maxing characters to get ready for future raids and helping your friends out with quest, all in all I would put this game as a Buy Right Away if anything mentioned caught your attention and i say this game is a easy 4/5

This game is great.

+Complex combat system. Easy to get into, takes time to master.
+Fun boss encounters. Designed more like bosses in MMOs, but in a good way.

-Story is short and kinda whatever, generic anime mediocrity.
-Translation. As somebody who speaks both english and japanese, I can tell you that english translation is horrendous. At times characters are not just saying poorly phrased things, but outright entirely different sentences between languages.

Unlocking the final weapon for your character in Granblue Fantasy Relink can be a test of patience and luck. To obtain it, you must defeat the final boss and hope for a drop that grants you a random weapon for one of your unlocked characters. However, the drop rate for this coveted weapon varies greatly, ranging from 3-5 runs if you're fortunate to a staggering 20-30 runs for others. If you are a solo player like me. it takes about 10-15 mins on a random queue, and victory is not guaranteed. 

Luck was clearly not on my side. Having unlocked all the characters, which further increased the difficulty and the chances of getting the final weapon for IO, I found myself empty-handed after the first 20 victory runs. The prospect of potentially facing the boss 300 times or more, which easily translates to 60 hours of battling the same scenario, is daunting to say the least. 

If I saw that boss one more time, I am going to throw up :(

This game is seriously fun and looks incredible and runs just as good. Highly recommended for RPG fans.

Edit: I finished the main story at around 20hrs, I loved it and highly recommend the game, it was an absolute blast. If you're into end game stuff there is a shit load there also.

Really surprised how well this game turned out.  I never knew about the gatcha game and only roughly knew about the fighting game, but something about this gameplay really drew me in.

Note; hit Proud mode (end game) on PS5 and loved it so much that I bought it on PC just to rope my friends into playing this.  Killer combat, serviceable story, husbandos and waifus galore, and sped-up Monster Hunter anime fights.  Killer concept.

This is an excellent game with some minor issues with the combat system and a generic plot -- but I think if you come here for the gameplay and the spectacle then you'll get exactly what you wanted out of it. 

Other JRPGs really need to look a this game and learn from Granblue how to really bring the anime level of spectacle into the video game scene.

The only big criticism I have of the game is that it is far too easy, even on Proud. The difficulty of the storyline is OK although still easy on "Hard" mode -- but about what I would expect for a game that wants people to be able to get through the story. The post-game high difficulty content though? Not exactly high difficulty. The critical bar (how many times/how long you can be dead before the quest games over) is just far too generous, and potions too. Unless your whole team wipes multiple times you can get through things quite easily and anyone used to MMO raids should be able to handle the mechanics with almost zero difficulty.

Really hoping the future content will address that and give us a true difficult mode. I'll update this review then if that happens.

Overall I'd give it a 9/10 -- just give us a bit more meat to chew on in the hardest encounters!

Pretty good. Expected more combat wise for it to be something platinum games was involved in but it's still better than most anime games of this genre. Graphics are incredible as well only terrain I didn't like was the sand I always thought those scenarios are very empty and boring but it's good variety. 

Combos are okay. I've tried my best making stylish strings of moves but this combat is not entirely flexible for that and it is somewhat of a button masher. Some characters are miles better than others. Bosses were impressive at times. Even in the hardest mode this game is still relatively easy but boss patterns were a sight to behold at times with cool looking moves.

Story is pretty basic anime but it's enjoyable and something about this game which is underrated is that it actually makes sense. If I run a trail to get a chest I actually teleport in front of the chest at the end instead of having to run back. It doesn't make you do the same thing for too long and they switch up the gameplay often. Runs smooth everything on high. NPC's are not dying all the time and actually have a combat sense. 

I usually avoid buying games full price but this game deserves it in my opinion. It's a fresh new take and series and they're doing their own thing. Music is good and the scenes is genius looking. The combination of the both is a spectacle at times.

I love how cinematic all the fights are in this game. Everything feels like the big moment. Im so happy this game didn't disappoint after 7 years of development issues. I was tearing up the entire fight.. It was too epic.

Thats all I can say. But read further if you have either an older system or an ultrawide monitor or plan to play with a PS5 controller.

Its got some problems at the moment (launch week) most are addressed via mods or tweaks or developer updates.
The most critical issue was fixed a few days back with a patch from the dev team (the game would not launch on some systems or would freeze instantly and randomly crash on cutscenes).
The second most critical issue is Avx2 required, but this only affects people with older CPU's (2nd/3rd gen Intel). If you fall in this category: DO NOT BUY. You will not be able to play, period. It just simply won't launch for you.

Those two critical issues aside...
If you plan to play with a PS5 controller: You will need to install DS4 for Windows and then disable Steam Inputs under Properties > Controller. If you do not do this, your controller will time out randomly and often freeze your steam. Hopefully the devs fix this, but in the meantime, you have this option.
For PS5 icons, there is a mod that swaps the XBOX icons for PS5 ones.
If you have an ultrawide monitor: The game has no ultrawide support at all, but there is already a mod by Lyall that fixes almost everything. Be sure to read the read me file on how to adjust it for your specific monitor resolution/settings/fov, etc

Before I begin this review, I will say that when I enjoy something, I don't use that as the basis for whether or not I recommend something.  I think about WHY I like something or, rather, what compels me to do something like play a game repeatedly.  Video games, by admission of designers, can be flagrantly designed to be addictive.  I feel that this should be said before anything else.

Do I recommend Granblue Fantasy Relink?  No.  I don't.  I think there are a lot of cynics who feel like tradition only applies as, to them, it is seemingly being established.  Granblue Fantasy: Relink is a game that is the product of the work between Platinum Games, who for reasons that I have to say aren't fully known to me left partway through the game's development, and Cygames.

I will be upfront, I really like action games.  I am not a fan of Platinum Games so much as they are, or were, a source of designers and developers who formerly worked for Capcom.  It's a long, complicated history, but to keep it brief, they are a developer I keep my eyes on, even if I haven't bought a game from them in quite some time.  This one had me curious, because of Platinum Games leaving partway through development.  Cygames, in contrast, are a company that has developed a, as of today, successful profit extraction mobile game/PNG Dispenser RPG, Granblue Fantasy.  

In a move to broaden the appeal of the brand, love speaking like I'm greasy, Cygames commissioned two games based on Granblue Fantasy.  The fighting game, Granblue Fantasy: Versus and, this game I'm reviewing, the Action RPG Granblue Fantasy: Relink.

There are a lot of weirdos who don't realize that not everyone hangs onto every word or press release of a game.  I have not followed this game's marketing.  So, in that sense, I wasn't sure what this game was going to be.  Turns out, it is a game in the tradition or Monster Hunter.  This is where I can get to the point of where it applies to the reader of this review:

Do you like Action RPGs like Monster Hunter or games similar or adjacent to Monster Hunter?  Because that, ultimately, is what Granblue Fantasy: Relink is, and sadly it doesn't really do much to really break the mold of this tradition while, simultaneously, embodying all of the flaws of a Hunting game in terms of the things it tries to do.

There are people who like to dismiss the main scenario of these games.  These are individuals who I think are pretty stupid.  The game MAKES you play the story in order to get introduced to mechanics, the flavor of the game, and this is the tradition that I think Granblue Fantasy: Relink really fails to improve on or do anything of interest with other than to carry the torch of the flaws of this kind of game and what typically happens.

Instead of being able to play with your friends, you will have to make yourself play a game with a story aimed at adolescents and with, sadly, comparable mechanics and design.  Granblue Fantasy: Relink's story, if we're just comparing it to games that are aimed at a young audience, isn't interesting, but more importantly it isn't something that is interesting to experience save for these little glimmering moments that, I'd bet money frankly, are indicative of the fun that Platinum Games brings to their video games.  I wouldn't trust Cygames to design their way out of a paperbag when it comes to action, call me crazy but I just have a hunch who was bringing the meaningful experience to this project.

I enjoyed the segments that clearly are reminiscent of Devil May Cry and Bayonetta.  The game had long lost my attention, as I think the world of Granblue Fantasy embodies all the things that make Japanese cartoons based on shonen style fantasies so disposable and uninteresting.  So it would have been up to the game to really carry the brand, so to speak, and unfortunately I think Platinum's departure made for a much worse title.

Why?

Well, this game has one of the worst cameras I've ever experienced.  It poisons a lot of what you might get out of this game as just shameless junk food if you like action games.  If you like deck building and being mentally addled by shameless gambling, waiting for weapons or items or any number of things to drop or a number to go up, Granblue Fantasy: Relink is okay.  It is a mediocre game that has glimmers of greatness and even just fun missions.  But that camera needs to be able to frame the action, and the reason I've segue'd into talking about the game as junk food is because there are plenty of characters to use that are tantamount to the weapons that create different playstyles in Monster Hunter...

And this is where the problems start.  Unless you're playing as a character in the main cast, your character will never really be rendered in the main story.  The main scenario doesn't do a lot to really commit to having a dedicated cast of characters and instead of treating the additional characters of Granblue Fantasy as a bonus, Granblue Fantasy: Relink tries to have its cake and eat it too by just having throw away dialogue where you can imagine your character as "having been there" but their presence has no texture or real substance.  It's clear that the story is about certain characters and Granblue Fantasy: Relink isn't brave enough to work with that premise.

Why that should matter is that, your friends won't be able to play cooperatively with you, which is a problem with certain Monster Hunter games but to an even greater degree because now you have a story that you have to play by yourself.  I'd actually say this is more of an issue in Final Fantasy 14, which is a game I'd say probably has the actually worse version of this problem.  The game is very concerned with you, the player, experiencing a single player mode **by yourself**, yet weirdos/the supposed appeal of the game, is about the MULTIPLAYER part.  Crazy, right?  Wow, who would ever hold that against a game, crazy... just make yourself play the game, bro.  Don't get something that's actually treating that well or thoughtfully, just do what I say!

Your friends can't take the role of the principal characters of Granblue Fantasy and play the story with you.  This means the story mode is just something you want to "get over with."  It has no appeal of its own... it's in the tradition of mediocrity.  Some idiot would say "That's how these things go" and I'm just going to say, when you see some doofus burying the bar under the ground, I'm just gonna call it what it is: Bad, lazy... you name it. 

They didn't have to do that, but they did. 

So the camera and the lackluster scenario means that you have to have a predisposition to this type of game.  To me, if that is the case and the game has such a fundamental problem on top of having Cygames style gacha hooks and things that just kind of run part and parcel with this kind of Action RPG/Hunting game... I'd say that unless you REALLY, REALLY like this kind of game to a fault, I don't recommend it as it is.

It doesn't have any serious performance issues, I don't really care about the localization and I understand Japanese, I think it's up to taste, I like Japanese voices, mileage may vary... 

No, the reason I don't recommend this game is because it's just kind of okay while leaning on the side of irritating.  I'm doing the same stuff I've done in the past with other hunting games, rushing through quests, not seeing much reason to taste the food and lamenting the main scenario being so weakly presented.

It's not a bad game, but it could have been a good one.

Still very early into this game, but so far it is exactly the anime arpg I've been looking for for years. It hits hard in both style, and combat - one of which I've found lacking in just about every arpg I've tried. Code Vein was very stylish, but the combat felt weightless. Scarlet Nexus had great combat, but regularly looked like shit (straight up powerpoint cut scenes). Tales of Arise came close, but didn't grab my attention the way this game does. The new Hyrule Warriors was probably the closest as it had a great cast of characters, unique play styles for each character, and of course looked beautiful with the Breath of the Wild visual style. But Granblue just feels like it knows exactly what I want. The combat is crunchy as hell and I can feel every hit that lands, and even more so when you land timed attacks. Just about every characters attacks and skills are so over the top in just the right way, and so vibrant I just wanna stare at the animations and not the boss that's about to hit me. The monster hunter like structure also helps keeps rewards flowing, and enough stuff to do in between missions so that it doesn't get boring. I obviously don't know much about what more is to come, and this is a very personal take, but damn this might be the game I've been waiting for.

I've played action combat game with no lock on target in the past  so any target lock on just make me feel like i'm playing handcuffed.

It's good junk food style game.  Fun to play when you can't think to play anything else.  Story is meh, combat is pretty brainless.  I suppose it's not bad, just not worth the price of admission.  I see comments about how the English localization is bad, but, as someone who speaks English, I'm tired of weebs saying that "if the voice acting sounds bad in English, it's because bad localization."  No, everything is localized fine.  They're speaking well enough.  The issue is the way the story itself is written.  It's just typical anime cringe.  That's fine if you enjoy that, but making it Japanese doesn't fix it's over the top campy-ness.  It only makes it so I can't understand the cringe lines.  Frankly, Japanese in anime sounds much more campy and over acted than these English translations.  No, localization is not the issue.  The English language is not the issue.  It's just generically written.  And I mean, I can enjoy some over the top camp.  Reincarnated as a slime is bad, but lovable.  Persona 5 gets pretty campy, but it's still enjoyable.  This feel forced.  Maybe it's because they're throwing me into  the middle of an adventure.  Show me how these characters meet.  Don't expect me to play a shitty mobile game to get the full story.  You throw me into a flying boat with a bunch of people talking about how much they love adventuring together and how much they enjoy each other's company, it's not good writing.  I feel like I'm almost being pandered to.  If it was $30, I'd say "yeah go wild."  But, as much as I'll likely continue to play it, I can't recommend others purchase it, certainly not for $60.  Again, it's not bad, but that doesn't make it necessarily good, either.

Story: 3/10

Edit 60 hours after my early port impressions were posted:
If you only finish the story you miss out on a huge portion of the game. I speedran the story in about 10 hours and it took me another 50 to see everything, if youre not a godgamer like me youll need longer. Endgame has A LOT of recolours with vastly different mechanics ü a couple of completely new bosses and all of those get pretty damn hard near the end.

The game is very good if youre looking for monster hunter style endgame. The bosses have a bit more MMO ish mechanics with lots of AoE, Adds and similair stuff.

The combat feels phenomenal. The camera and lock on dont cooperate as much as id like to on occasion but besides that its absolutely amazing. there is a plethora of characters with a good variety of very different playstyles. The animations and repsonsiveness as well as the sound design just make the game feel really good to play.

Theres a pretty good chunk of gambling for gear (think monster hunter talismans) and im a little worried that this is mostly intended as an introductory game to the franchise to get people to play the full on pay2win gacha mobile game of granblue fantasy and get people used to the gambling mechanics.
However in the game itself there is currently absolutely no actual pay2win.

As such it gets a huge recommendation from me. Very cool gameplay, lots of cool bosses, lots of characters to play.

EARLY PC PORT IMPRESSIONS:
I had trouble finding info regarding the port so here are my 2 cents so far:

Controls:
Fully functional key remapping for M+K including setting actions to mousethumb. Button prompts show up ingame as you set them via keymapping. (e.g. it shows the keyboard input bound to "interact" when standing next to an item)
Mouselook feels distinctly like a Console game ported to PC - the mouse movement doesnt perfectly align with look speed but rather simulates stick input. Its serviceable - i.e. better than some other ports (looking at you release version of WO LONG) - but very noticeable. 

Graphics:
I ran the game at a smooth and very stable 60 fps using the ingame fps lock ("fps target" in settings). Maintained throughout the first major fight (the big Monsters are SPECTACULAR - full capslock). There is a reasonable number of customization options for graphics on PC considering its a port.
All settings on high/ultra @1080p 60fps.
3060 RTX, i5 12600K, WIN10 16 gigs of RAM, oldish SSD.

Loading is super fast so far. Hardly noticed any loading times.

tl;dr - good port so far with the sole exception of mouselook having the distinct console game port feel to it.

It's fun so far. Feels like a mix of Final Fantasy and Monster Hunter.  The story is pretty generic but still entertaining. I thought I'd hate the baby dragon sidekick but he actually turned out to be one of my favorite characters.

Now entering the "post-game" content after ~14 hours. Just like Monster Hunter a lot of the game's content seems to be located AFTER you clear the campaign. For comparison, my weapons are level 75 and they seem to go up to 150+. My heroes are level 50-55 while the max level is 100 (I think). Some gear traits go up to level 45 and the highest I have is 5.

Edit: Now beat the final final final real boss (final) after ~60 hours. The last difficulty is a real treat with many entirely new bosses. My only complaints so far are relatively low (but still decent) enemy variety and very aggressive downscaling if you do quickplay.

Certified banger. The combat is absolutely amazing, lots of characters, all of them unique with their own style of play. OST is also really good (its by the OG composer of the FF games unless I'm mistaken).

The story is its weak point imo. I understand that it has to do with already developed characters from past games/anime or whatever else but it still didnt feel that great. Its way too much of your stereotypical anime "power of friendship" type of stuff with characters that constantly feel the need to express how much they care about each other. I've watched anime and shows with the same themes but this story just drowns in it. The good things about it is that it has good setpieces, the voice acting is really good and its also short (around 10-15hours).

The progression systems are really good, at face value it looks like A LOT and while there is a lot of grinding (especially if you wanna have more than 1-2 mains)  its not as much as you might think, you get materials fairly fast and missions are by nature not that long.

The game is mission based, a bit like Monster Hunter. You have a hub where you upgrade, get side missions, story stuff etc (with some mild exploration elements)  and a quest counter that sends you out into an arena (most missions are bosses) or to do your next story quest. The number of bosses is average. Not too few but not many either. Theres a good amount but I'm hoping for more content in the future (which the devs have confirmed I believe).

My main complaint is that the game is a bit too easy as of right now. I just made it to Proud difficulty (highest difficulty in the game) and it is NOW that I'm even mildly tested. Everything else up until now, while extremely fun, has been a breeze, and I doubt Proud will be too hard since my main character isnt even close to maxed out yet.

EDIT: Another negative I forgot to mention is the fact that the game is region locked on PC for whatever reason (part of ports being bad because nobody cares about PC I guess). Thankfully it uses your steam download region to determine where you are so all you have to do is change that whenever you want to play Granblue Fantasy. It only requires a steam restart and the game launches super fast so for me that hasnt been a huge problem, but certainly annoying.

I want to write a positive review of the game, however, in it's current state I would stay away from wasting your money until they can make the game more stable.

I played the game through the campaign with I think one crash, which is acceptable. Then after the campaign I had about a day of questing with a couple crashes. Now I crash all the time. Sometimes it is during the loading of the quest, sometimes in the middle, and the worst part, sometimes after I have finished the quest while it is in the death animation. I can repeat a quest 10 times no crash and I can load into the same quest and it will crash 20 seconds in. 

I have been playing online games since the early 90's and I can't remember a game that crashed like this. Now mind you this is not early access this is full release.

It's a shame too, because the game play itself it quite fun.

I recommend the game. I am unfamiliar with the anime (hell, I only heard there was such a thing from a friend after I completed the story) and tend not to be fan of the multiplayer RPGs, but this game allows you to get by very well with Singleplayer only. 

The story was a bit brief for an RPG, but there is plenty of lore hidden in menu's, special quests and items to pick up, and so the game does a good job at rewarding exploration both in-game and in the menu's. 

The artstyle is lovely. I particularly like how the further-away parts were less anime artstyle and more paintbrush strokes. 

The combat is fun. it sort of reminds me of Dynasty warriors, but less 1v1000. Still, you do take on groups and the boss battles are spectacles and highlights. 

Hate the comic relief character though..... but I never like those anyway.

Very fun game. The story is linear for sure, but it's a good ride with a good quest variety. Combat is very fluid with a whole arsenal of ways to attack. Additionally, there's a whole plethora of characters to unlock and play. So there's a very good chance you'll find a character you really love to play and introduces an incredible variety and replayability to the game as a whole. For anyone that doesn't know, much of the end game content comes after the story concludes. From that point on, the game would be most comparable to something like Monster Hunter. You go and hunt big bad monsters. You can do it solo in a team like in the story, or go for online matchmaking, which is actually fairly smooth. I really enjoy this game and cant wait to keep playing it.

great game

First off, I'm able to play on a PC that barely meet the minimum system requirements and can do so on standard graphic settings with little to no lags. So performance wise, it is pretty impressive.

Since the last patch, I haven't experienced any crashes, even during cutscenes which did cause crashes beforehand. I finished the 10 main story chapters. The story was really nice and cinematic, but quite predictible and cliché from time to time. Overall I don't regret the buy solely for that alone.

I'm now at the beginning of the endgame and am slowly building up a team to challenge higher difficulty settings. Movesets of bosses don't seem to evolve much for the moment, but the damage they deal has skyrocketed for specific moves, making them nearly guaranteed one-shots. Depending on how you view it, that might be a negative or positive. I'm seeing it as a way to tell me to finally pay attention to what bosses do and how I might have to start to learn their patterns to be able to perfect dodge more consistently.

As I advance in the masteries of my main character, I can see that many additional quality of life masteries make the gameplay more smooth and make the triggering of the character's unique mechanic easier (in my case, Katalina's stand).

I haven't finished the final epilogue chapter, so other things will open up. Currently I'm not put off by the grind, but I can already see that there will be more grind awaiting that I won't be able to circumvent without steadily upgrading at least 4 characters, as coop outside of quick quest seems pretty barren.

I'll update my review when I'm further into the game.

The production values of this game are truly outstanding it really amazes me.
From the initial battle encounter with Bahamut through my first visit to the village of Folca, [b]Granblue Fantasy[/b]: [b]Relink[/b] gave me the impression that this was the anime action role-playing game I had been waiting for, and it certainly is.

*[i]The children having fun in the village—what an adorable scene![/i]
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DRAFtaGyo4w

What I really like the most of the game is the battle systems and skill mechanics, it's one of the best I have ever seen. There are a total of twenty playable characters, each with their own unique playstyle.

The overall story itself is great, I like it, and the best part is that the real fun actually began after completing the main plot. There are a ton of things to check out and unlock. For those who are seeking for challenging fights, battling Primal Beasts in Proud difficulties with other players in the online coop is one of them, and it's been a thrilling and exciting experience so far.

I heard about Granblue Fantasy, but because they are mostly gacha mobile games([i]?[/i]), I've never really played nor was I particularly interested in any of them.
After this though, they have caught my attention, and I look forward to more quality games from [i]Cygames[/i].
fun

Easily one of the best games I've ever played. Gorgeous graphics to look at, a banger of an OST, and the ultra-hype Campaign is literally a tutorial for the online stuff. Most of the game is just boss battling similar to something like Monster Hunter without the stalking, just straight up fights. Played the game half on the Steam Deck and half on my dedicated PC. Slight annoyance is that the game is locked 16:9 unless you use GBFRelinkFix, so the game has black boarders on Steam Deck and sits in the middle of my 32:9 monitor. Capped 120hz is below my monitors 240hz, but none of this was a detraction from the experience.

Insane amounts of character customization with 18 completely different characters to play and build up (with more coming). Buttery smooth action combat that is an absolute joy to learn and execute. There's grind, but it's a fun grind; with both loot for crafting and weapon unlocks and RNG rolls to min/max. Fights are fun, and the campaign is the most Call of Duty-esque non-stop setpiece action (that I can't talk about without spoilers) in between some decently sized exploration segments, and then you can hop online through the quest counter and play endlessly. My only, slight nitpick is the camera is kind of annoying at times; but it's still completely manageable.  

I paid $60 for this and I'd gladly pay more. Keep the content coming! I still have another 80 hours of content to go through, according to most reviews.

A surprising gem of game, with fast-paced and fluid gameplay, a ton of build and character/class variety, and a mountain of challenging and fun content to enjoy, with even MORE characters and content planned in future updates. You have so much to pick from to suit your play-style and so many ways to fine-tune characters the way you want them, and the amount of unique bosses with crazy animations and fun mechanics is insane. The endgame content is a ton of fun with friends, and I highly recommend the game for anyone that enjoys action RPGs and/or cooperative games.

If any of the above interests you, please support this game so that they can also continue supporting it!

It's an okay game at best 4/10. Here's why:

- The combat is hp sponges and it sucks (spam your kit until hp goes down).
- Bosses getting "second lives" is just the worst mechanic of all time.
- You are heavily advantaged if you play a ranged character over a melee.
- The late games fights are just recolors of the bosses you killed earlier in the story... straight up boring.
- Some mechanics are just never explained anywhere and are extremely idiotic.
- There's a full auto gameplay mode... they just couldn't be bothered at this point.
- The cinematics in combat cancels your abilities and whatever you're charging. 
- The dodge is absolute dog shit and is not an iframe unless you do it EXACLY when the attack hits you... like what? I really can't stress enough how freaking bad the dodge is... like really it is complete and utter trash.
- Some characters are just plain boring (to be honest Io's kit is trash and bosses move too much so you almost never land your lvl 4 charged ability).
- There's too much particles on everything (hinders visibility) like literally you can't see anything and it's even worse with the bad camera angle the lock gives you.
- The lock on camera sucks but you have to do it to hit your abilities.
- The story is extremely boring and the characters are all like 8 year olds playing with their imaginary friends (with how they talk and stuff).
- What ever you say has absolutely no impact on the story so why even put options in dialogues.
- The "puzzles" to get the chests are just boring and annoying why are they even in the game.
- Online play is dead (which is weird because I'm a few days after launch).
- You can't actually save and quit whenver you want even in a solo session because you have to wait for a check point... why is that even still in a game in 2024?
- Why is the menu and inventory and everything with a white background?
- Every character can actually do almost everything so there's no real concern about getting characters for certain roles (healers, tank and damage dealer)
- You can literally take anyone in any team and it will work so there's no real team building strategy so that sucks.
- The only real use of your allies when playing alone is to revive you when you're down because they do very little damage.
- You never actually kill any bosses or your enemies sooooo i mean that's boring. They're all alive or "controlled". 
- The characters are uninteresting and if you haven't played the first game, you don't get attached to any of them. 
- You get the defeated screen when you're still alive??? What the fk? 
- Angra manyu is the worst boss fight I've ever seen in any video game.

Over all it's an ok game but if I had the chance I would never pay more than 20$ for the small amount of fun you can get out of it. I would buy it if it's 75% off otherwise don't even bother trying it's just not worth the experience.

Went in expecting a gacha kind of game with mediocre gameplay, but its actually super fun and fleshed out.

Basically its Monster Hunter: Anime edition, with faster paced and flashy combat, very satisfying.
Attacks are very responsive even if you are butting mashing, providing great character control.

The story is not bad, and not great, just the generic "save the girl from the bad organisation" kind.
The characters are very charasteric, and have some good back stories, making them memorable, and they made a good antagonist that's easy to hate :)

The combat is with a party of 4, but you only control one character, so there is no swapping around during combat, nor having to remember combo's and skills of 4 different characters.

I use the Japanese voice acting setting, which is -as usual- top notch and definitely recommended in this anime-type games where the English voice acting can feel off.

GBF RELINK is a great game for newcomers and veterans of the franchise.

Art and Soundtracks are amazing, nothing much to say about that, just amazing.

Story was enjoyable, got better to the mid – end of the story. Overall, it could have been longer but not a massive deal.
Personally I think the story could have included some of the other characters within the game to appear or were mentioned to be around the place this also could have been a nice way make the story longer but get new players feel connected to other characters. While the game does have the Fate episodes quests for that it would have been more interesting and immersive if there was more connection to the main story. But that’s just my personal take.

My biggest issue for Story was the English localisation is terrible, which is a shame because there are some good English voice actors voicing some of characters in the game. Lot of the translations felt rushed or just made no sense whatsoever, it’s a fantasy game with characters saying some of the most out of place things.
If you are new or plan on buying the game honestly advise you to play in JP voicing acting.

Combat is fast-paced, flashy and very enjoyable with characters all having their own play style and skills and builds. Fighting the bosses is the great mix of MH style fights combining that with FFXIV or other mmorpg dungeon/raid mechanics.

Progression is simple and fun to understand. You have the character that you can level up and beyond to gain masteries and skills where you can choose multiple skills to use in content to suit your play style with a character.
You got Weapons where you can level up weapons to max level of 150 and sigils where you can really start focusing on your build that you want to make.
I do hope we see more weapons later on in future updates.

If you are familiar with the Monster Hunter games, then Content such as Quests will feel very familiar and just as fun. You have different types of quests modes from Defend, Survival, conquest, horde and the main one bosses fight which is the biggest draw to the game. There are different difficulty of quests from Easy, Normal, hard, Very Hard, Extreme, Maniac and Proud. The difficulty starts to show from Extreme and above. There will be a future difficulty I believe which will be Impossible difficulty when the Lucilius quest comes.

I can’t wait to see future quests, weapons, & characters to game, personally I would love to see Zooey, Athena be playable, as well as rest of the Society members: Beatrix, Ilsa, Eustace and Gwynne also be playable. But would be nice they used this game to introduce underrated characters as well. For boss raid like quests would be cool to see Primarchs make an appearance, maybe also Qilin & Huanglong.

[h2]Beautiful, Bountiful, But Slightly Too Breezy Skies[/h2]

Cygames loves Granblue Fantasy. While I've never played the gacha, the quality and presentation of their fighting games and Relink speak to how much that team adore this IP. They might even love it too much, as many of Relink's flaws could be argued to be devs smothering the game in unneeded mechanics and over-tuning. 

At some point, you too will fall head over heels in love with Relink, sparked by one of its extravagant set piece fights or a bewitching Skybound Art chain (unless you ruin it by being premature and not waiting for your partner. Nice Captains finish last).

[h3]Relink![/h3]
- Spectacular, high intensity combat. A feast for your eyes, ears and frantic fingers.
- Vibrant, colorful art style.
- Playable characters have distinct personalities, both aesthetically and mechanically.
- Sensational soundtrack. Excels in both gentle ambiance and fervent action.
- AI companions actually contribute!

[h3]ReThink[/h3]
- Too easy for first 20+ hours, even on hard difficulty without assist tools.
- Too many befuddling progression mechanics.
- Spotty localization. I only know a few scattered Japanese words and phrases from anime (or in other words, I speak fluent weebanese) and even I'm picking out jokes lost in translation.
- Tech limitations. Locked at 120 FPS. No widescreen support.
- Multiplayer only largely accessible after beating the 10-15 hour campaign.

[h3]Recommend To:[/h3]
- Any anime action RPG fan.
- Any Granblue Fantasy fan.
- Anyone who has ever audibly squeed when a character shouted out the name of their signature attack.
- "Dubs Over Subs" degenerates.

[h3]But Your Playgroup Might Prefer:[/h3]
[b]Monster Hunter Rise[/b] The multiplayer in Relink is wonderful, but it takes a while to get there. If your friends want a similar play experience and are in a hurry, MH:Rise delivers if you imagine each of its weapons as a Relink character. You might be thinking to yourself "There's no way some weapon can be as sexy as my Granblue waifu/husbando." If so, you are clearly not a Charge Blade main.

Relink is your messy romantic partner who fumbles their words around you and is a little too easy for your personal tastes, but is drop dead gorgeous and doesn't disguise their delight when you spend time with them (though they're a little standoffish with your friends at first). While the relationship will eventually cool off and Relink might one day catch you eye-balling that Blue Protocol hussy, you are missing out if you let their love pass you by today.

[hr][/hr]

I wish there was a "mixed" option because I hate that it's one or the other, but if I had to choose i'd lean more towards the negative. 

I can't in good conscience recommend this game because I genuinely feel like I would've traded the entire multiplayer experience for a more polished single player JRPG adventure game. As it stands, the game feels unfocused and (honestly) a bit too easy for my liking.

But let's give the quick run down of what the good and bad is:

The Good:

• Genuinely fantastic combat system.
• A cast of characters with a wide array of play styles
• Gorgeous visuals
• Amazing boss fights with mechanics similar to an MMO boss fight.


The Bad:

• The story is more or less a tutorial to the meat of the game.
• Aforementioned story is honestly not that great, and has an issue with resolving. There was far too many moments of: "Is it over? Nope, it's not over." and it felt like a slog.
• Aforementioned "meat of the game" is recycled content you've already experienced in the single player mode fed to you over and over without much variance.
• Character balance is genuinely not that great.
• Endgame is comprised of material farming for meaningless % gains when content (in my experience) was cleared incredibly easily just by being "competent" rather then really demanding micro stat management.
• Content gets stale quickly.


If you're a fan of Granblue, I could easily recommend this. You'll enjoy it enough, I warrant. If you're not and you've heard people tout it as "Monster Hunter Adjacent" then steer clear, because it lacks the long-term charm and longevity of it.

I'll probably return for DLC, but honestly it'd be a hard sell to me.

Best Final Fantasy game we have seen in years:

Cygames borrowed from the best when making this game, by which I mean hired away developers from other companies. The best elements of FF, Ys, Tales, White Knight and Altair are present in this game ... except for the plot: Cygames really needs to hire a real writing team is they want to move beyond being a mobile game developer. Not that the plot is bad (I have seen worse from bigger names) but the depth of it is pretty thin with how the characters go from A to B to C to D with without dwelling in the environments to let players explore the word, and the answer to obstacles is provided as soon as you hit it.

the game does make up for that by providing missions that can be played as either single player with NPC support or MP with online players (the menu for this looks like MH, but the in game application is closer to FF15's multiplayer expansion). The co-op system works and provides a lot of depth that the game otherwise would lack, but at the same time I think I would have preferred if Cygames leaned in on the single player plot and expanded that content, then followed it up with a stand alone MP game that went all in on the MP mission systems.

All in all, this is the first JRPG in a while that both felt fresh and worth paying full price for: you can really tell that Cygames cares about the Granblue franchise, and that is quite refreshing after the blatant disrespect we have seen directed at many of the other JRPG franchises in recent years.

P.S. that said, there is no way in hell I am spending $20 for those outfit packs that are nothing more than color pallet swaps.
