I played the Granblue Fantasy mobile game for 3 years. I was so excited to see a Granblue Fantasy RPG that could play off so much lore, with so many characters, playing as so many different classes... and this is what we get?

My main issue is that Cygames pulled a dirty trick here. A 10 hour campaign at full price with half the roster of characters not implemented in the story WHATSOEVER. That's right! Half the characters DO NOT appear in the game outside of combat! Not just with main story, the whole game. They're summoned out of the ether when you go into a battle map. Other than that, they do not exist in the game world. WHY!? WHO DECIDED TO SCREW IT UP THIS BAD!?

My second issue is the classes. Classes are another thing that didn't make it into Relink. You're the beginner class for Gran/Djeeta and that's it. Honestly my opinion is that Gran/Djeeta is the weakest character in the game. The only up side for a few people, maybe, is that you can freely switch between the two. Some of the swords you can get are very cool, but one of the best of them is literally sold as DLC from Day 1. Cut out of the game and sold to you separately. So our mediocre main character is incomplete unless you shell out even more money.

Which leads me into my third issue. With how little this game really offers the fact that they're already tossing out DLC like a Dynasty Warriors game really rubs me the wrong way. It tell me that this is just a cheap, poorly made cash grab. Prove me wrong, Cygames. If you can.

All in all, I expected so much more and I'm very disappointed. Expecially since their first DLC characters are also not recognizable from the mobile game.

I can only imagine how much they'll charge for two characters, given a SWORD and some mats is $11.99.

[b] Written Review & Video Review [/b]
[b] https://www.taptap.io/post/6973240 & https://www.taptap.io/post/6973013 [/b]


[h2]First time playing this series? Me too![/h2]
So let's get down to business. I've never played this series previously because I prefer [b]Bandai Namco's[/b] JRPGs, though I occasionally dabble in more niche titles like [b]Rogue Galaxy[/b], [b]White Knight Chronicles[/b], and my personal favourite [b]Trails in the Sky[/b] and [b]Cold Steel[/b] pick those bad boys up if you're into deep story! I used to be a huge fan of Bandai Namco's [b]Tales of Series[/b], but as they and many others grew as developers, they did what every series seems to think they should do. Overprice their games, increase the visual flare to 110% while sacrificing the actual game-play experience and story and throwing DLC inside the games or by just making the characters stiff and un-alive like they do in the recent Cold Steel series.

Granblue felt wonderful it felt like everything was alive including the characters and their expressions. It seemed like I was playing FF14, White Knight Chronicles 2 (a game that was discontinued with the release of FF14), Rogue Galaxy, and God Eater, all while incorporating their own mobile gameplay style into a PC JRPG. 


[h2]Localization[/h2]
There appears to be a group of folks who are enraged and upset because the game's localization falls short of their expectations. Essentially, they are talking about the English patch and censorship. I can definitely understand that having a character say something like "Hmm" and it comes out in the English version as "A wishful thinking" or something said in Japanese being emotional, while the English version is completely pragmatic at the situation that just happened. It's not as horrible as some make it out to be; the only issue I had was that the subtitles were way too small and not adequately seen when set against a bright background, and there were no settings to modify them. I can put up with certain basic things like that; I see character and personality, regardless of how it was in the Japanese version.

At the very least, they did not rename characters or change speech like you see in other games, manga and movies, such as [b]Atelier Rorona[/b], where [b]Esty Erhard[/b] was renamed "Esty Dee" because it was HAHA FUNNY. (It isn't), or Fist of the North Star being translated from "You're already dead" to "Your ass is grass!". 

The translations in this game are really minor and would only bug those who actually know how to read or hear keywords in Japanese that would alert them to the wrong translations. 

Moving on to the censorship issue. It's basically the minority; a few individuals are upset since all of the females are wearing shorts instead of their original panties and one characters outfit was modified a bit more (Narma) to show less skin, which is visable on I believe the console versions or in the official Japanese editions. While I can't confirm it, I believe other people are also arguing about Io and the main female character wearing shorts, but here's what I want you to know. Io is an 11-year-old anime girl and the female protagonist is a 15-year-old anime female. There is no reason for them to wear exposing clothing nor is there any real reason to be looking up their skirts to sneak a peak. I could understand Narma and other mature adults, who are equally covered up making it a much more tasteful JRPG in my opinion. I can't see this as a deal breaker. It's perfectly fine and doesn't effect gameplay. 

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]
It's fairly pricey, but here's the thing. It's pricey because you can tell they put a lot of time and work into all of the voicing (there are no reading parts, everything is voiced), the visuals are fantastic and well polished, and the models' attire and weapons do not clip. The gameplay is enjoyable and fascinating, keeping you going back for more. There are several quests, characters, builds, weapons, and skills with the online multiplayer. I could go on for several hours. 

If you're upset about not being able to search up young girls dresses and see panties or a lot of cleavage, someone will eventually mod the game. If you hate it when Japanese dialogue is adjusted and changed from the original in a minor sense, again it could be a deal breaker for you. But if you're interested in a fantastic adventure, awesome monster hunting challenges and playing with a friendly and helpful community, this would be your next stop for that adventure.

Stunned at how good + polished this ended up being. It will probably be among my personal GOTY candidates.
Pros:
[list]
[*] Friendly enough to be fun/casual for your less game savvy significant other/friend
[*] Slammed with skill-based tech to make excellent players stand out and feel great doing so. 
[*] Nicely balanced for both online co-op as well as solo players. The party system isn't great, but it's better than virtually every other monster hunter style game I've played in recent memory.
[*] Sorting, prioritizing, filtering on inventory and build related items is nice. It's not perfect, but was much appreciated late in the game as far as quality of life goes. 
[*] Really late game has some solid difficulty and really cool/unique fights - I will absolutely come back for new boss dlcs if they make them.
[*] You pay for what you get. No micro-transactions, tons of characters with significantly different play styles. You'll be impressed with what you get as a whole if you like the genre.
[/list]

Cons:
[list]
[*] The absolute best fights in the game require significant grind to reach. So much so - that I expect most players will miss out. 
[*] By the time you are in the zone grinding towards the highest difficulty fights, you'll have killed a lot of the same enemies which can make the ending portion a slog if you stick to 1 character all game.
[*] You can't technically co-op the main story. In between chapters, you unlock side-quests that you can group up for. More of a minor inconvenience than it sounds. 
[*] Each time you unlock a new difficulty (for most of the game) - you are given the resources needed to upgrade a weapon to the next tier. But this just ends up with your characters feeling too strong for the new difficulty. They should have made the weapon upgrades available at the end of a difficulty as opposed to the beginning.
[/list]

Mainly attracted to the game as it seems like a light JRPG tied to a monster hunter esque endgame, but with an anime aesthetic. Seems like a fun time. I can confirm the combat so far seems very fun and responsive with a lot of room for complexity, along with many distinct characters.

UPDATE:
After getting to endgame, lvl 100 and some of the grind, I can say I'm liking this game a lot. 

The main story is short and sweet. Fast paced. 10-20 hours. Not much downtime. Don't come in expecting a 40-80 hour JRPG. The bulk of time spent is in the combat and endgame.

The core gameplay loop is very satisfying. The game is super responsive, and has many different characters, all with completely unique combat and kits. 

The boss battles remind me of FFXIV bosses, but with faster paced action. In the hardest difficulty, you will actually need to have proper gear, and there are some DPS checks.

Endgame progression is very well paced. You always feel like you're getting stronger. Early to mid endgame does not feel grindy even. Of course, there are things to chase in the late endgame, but that's what you want in this genre. It feels around the right balance.

Overall a very solid game. The story is cool, but the main reason to play is the endgame, and it delivers exactly what it promises. It doesn't feel too grindy while at the same time giving you things to grind towards. It's pretty well balanced. 
Characters feel very impactful and each one has unique selling points, teambuilding is hella fun too. 
It's one of those games you can just spam play. Last time I had a game like this was Monster Hunter World, and surprisingly, you can compare both games since progression and skill system are roughly the same. GBR copied a lot from Monster Hunter and made it work for themselves, which is a very good thing in my book.
Just a great time, the multiplayer can be super rewarding!

I think this is actually one of the best combat based JRPG games ive played in ages, it shows really well the collab between the studios, also it runs and looks very good, but there are 2 fundamental problems

- The game is incredibly short, being around only ~10h to ~12h for main story and even with completing side missions don't add much meat and potatoes to the dish. There is endgame stuff but thats just repeating same bosses and dungeons over and over again
- The story is kinda abysmal, because it expects you are familiar with teh Granblue original game or the anime, which may not be case with many people. There isn't any flashbacks or recaps of what has happened to the prior events of Relink. 

If length and story isn't in high priority this is quite fun game to play and enjoyable hack and smash with multiple characters that bring nice variety when needed + you can team up with friends on side quests online.

From a gacha mobile game, to compelling RPG - I knew next to nothing about this IP, but I am now a solid fan. The main story is awesome and super fun (I am just about halfway there and it still feels fresh). The nuance for the different characters is just enough for experimentation, while still feeling familiar. 

The co-op (the main thing that drew me to the game) feels like a mix of mmo and monster hunter like. The only drawback is the lack of level sync with friends - of course this can be limited by plowing through the main story and just playing with friends after the fact - but I am saddened that the main story can't be completed with friends - so many parts would be AMAZING with actual other players - even if the host was forced to play the MC and your invitees got the play a party you put together. Really a missed opportunity. 

That being said, I can whole heatedly recommend this game. If you're feeling a need for anime power of friendship and ridiculous action - this is the game for you.

TL;DR: This is one of the greatest action RPGs of all time, 10/10.

I bought Granblue Fantasy: Relink while not knowing much about the universe. I was vaguely aware of a gacha game for mobile but had never played it myself, as well as a fighting game in the same franchise. I went into this knowing two things about this game, which immediately sold me on it:

1. This game features 20 characters, all with mastery trees independent of one another, with different skills and mechanics that differentiate each character's playstyle.

2. This game features a Monster Hunter-like gameplay endgame loop of completing quests for materials, and using those materials to improve your character in various ways.

The story ended up being quite charming, and the game features a feature that I would appreciate more games having - when you skip cutscenes, when the game asks to make sure you're okay with skipping, it provides you with a summary of the scene, so you can still follow the plot if you just want to skip ahead to gameplay. It follows a pretty standard JRPG story format, culminating in some very big boss fights with some incredible music.

The visuals are outstanding and style oozes out of every corner, especially the incredible watercolor portraits for each of the 20 characters. The animations are gorgeous, with each character having a completely unique moveset. The boss designs are pretty much all hits and enjoyable to look at over and over again, which you'll be doing over the course of this game, as its endgame is centered around doing quests for materials repeatedly.

The gameplay is the real winner here - 20 different characters each with different movesets to master and skill trees that give a real sense of empowerment, a sigil system similar to the charms or gems systems found in Monster Hunter games, and tense but fun boss fights.

This game is absolutely worth a purchase if you're looking for one of the best action RPGs of modern times, a very solid Granblue game, or you've already played your fill of Monster Hunter World and Rise and you're dying for more bosses to kill and materials to farm.

Literally everything I've ever wanted in a Granblue game, minus the gatcha grind.
Great combat akin to most Platinum games and FF16, with different playstyles for each character.
Quest system structure akin to Monster Hunter titles, with scoring systems and challenges, providing replayability
Story's pretty good but somewhat short for a JRPG, on average about 10-15 hours ([strike]haven't finished it myself yet as I'm writing this review[/strike] Edit: have finished it already, pretty good as I've stated, and doesn't feel rushed even though I've went through it in about 16 hours or so)
The art direction is beautiful and top notch, as expected from industry veterans such as Hideo Minaba.
The music is profound, as expected from the legend Nobuo Uematsu himself.
All in all probably one of my favorite JRPGs I've ever played in the last decade.

Long time fan of the franchise, this game takes some of their popular characters and brings then into 3D environment. They did and amazing job at translating their Medieval fantasy/Magic punk art into a world you can walk around in. The combat mechanics and character variety give way to many play styles, and it has some lateral progression systems that let you try out all of them. True to their reputation, the mid to late game contains repetitive grinding to progress your characters which might be a turn off to many people. Their over arching story is nebulous at best even for those entrenched in it and the character interactions are geared towards people like me who already know the characters and wanted more story which i think might alienate newcomers to the series. People usually play Cygames games for the art or the grind and this game delivers.
The game is just very good.

I've been anticipating the release of this game for years and it feels so good to finally play it. Co-op matchmaking with friends and randoms has been a blast. The story, while very short and simple, was still enjoyable. I love all the characters except it took me time to warm up to Vyrn as he reminded me of a certain specific emergency ration from another game. The monster hunter esque quest boards with FFXIV party matching for multiplayer content was a welcome surprise as I'm a huge fan of both. It feels so satisfying to have a great character progression model akin to some mobile games without any gacha involved. Combat feels smooth and consistent. Seriously one of the best action games to drop 2 months into this year.

I have very few cons such as the lock-on system/camera and a few matchmaking bugs. These weren't enough to detract the great experience I've had. However, my biggest issue was more related to my current location (at the time of this review). Matchmaking seems to have some sort of region locking but I was able to remedy it by changing my download region to a more suitable one. Luckily playing with friends had no issues for me. 

What I hope for is the introduction of more content to this game in the future. Whether it's new areas, enemies, playable characters, or an expanded story, I'm open to anything. This game definitely deserves it.

Not a bad game, not a bad game...
But I frigging hate the controls.

Let's use the context of a Nintendo Switch Controller.
I'm used to having Talk/Search/Normal Attack/Accept/Advance Text Window on the same button.
That would be A as someone that games in Japanese. Or B (X on ps) when I play American games...
If anything, most japanese action rpgs are like that.

Who was the frigging genius that decided to put talk on X, normal attack on Y, Search on A, Accept/Advance Text Window on B. Use one single button! At worst, I can forgive talk and search being split but not the rest...

And why is step/avoid on R2 but Guard on L1. put it on the frigging same level (both 1s or 2s).
The second I can still swap the buttons so it's borderline okay but the first, I find unforgivable...

Also, why the heck is the game auto-saving on my save slot, I skipped through a couple of events as a test to try something in the game and quit the game then the next time I loaded, i'm not at the point I manually saved, it was after the shop tutorials instead of right away entering the first town. WTF? The saving in this game is horrible.

Finally, give me the option to change the controller display in game.
I never used an Xbox Controller and seeing the Inputs based a Xbox Controller is really confusing. Xbox is the least popular machine and Switch the most popular and they are very confusing since X/Y and A/B are swapped. Should have bought the ps version...

Fortunately, they said on twitter that they will try to release an update to remap buttons, not continuing until that comes out. Last time I played Harvestella with a weird button mapping, I was suffering badly when I went to YS11 after and it took me hours to re-adapt, not doing it again...

As someone who is still pissed at how SEGA spat on the legacy of PSO2 and shoved the disgrace that is PSO2:NGS down everyone's throats, this game is something you want to check out. If someone told me that PSO2 devs moved here, I would believe them. The game even captured the essence of the annoying lock-on mechanics that has PSO2 has.

Jokes aside, the gameplay is pretty simple but it has enough mechanics for you to master to keep you engaged. It also offers a roster of characters that have varying playstyle. It's evident that the game is definitely designed as a console game. There are some minor annoyance that I encounter at times like:

-Wonky camera controls at times
-Locking on to things that are not in FOV because the target is closer
-Minimal graphics customization to help the game run smoother on lower spec devices
-No support for DLSS/FSR
-No Ultrawide support
-Keyboard shortcuts being unavailable at title screen but will be available after passing through a certain amount of tutorial
-Not being too clear with the quick access to skill activation on Keyboard. When playing on controller, you have to hold down a button in order to be able to use the skills you have equipped. In Keyboard, you still have a button you can hold but it is unnecessary as by default 1-4 quickly activates them without the need of holding down the button.

In terms of story, for someone not familiar with Granblue Fantasy itself, it will still be relatively easy to follow. For those familiar with the franchise, it definitely will be a treat. If in case someone wants to learn more about the characters, the game does offer things to expand about the individual character's backstory.

That being said, this truly is a gem of an action RPG game. The boss battles definitely were crafted masterfully to immerse you in the battle. It truly reminded me of how PSO2 was when it was lead by people with a vision as they created memorable Urgent Quests in that game. I look forward to seeing what CyGames does. I really do hope they expand on this game further. Even if they don't, the game will certainly still be playable by anyone who is interested as this is not a live service game.

If you're looking to play this on Deck, I was able to play it just fine but you will definitely be dropping down the 30fps side when there are a lot of things going on. Text is also a little bit hard to read at times since the scaling is not that good. Other than that, it plays well like you would on a proper console.

It might have been 8 years or so since this was announced, but I'm glad CyGames took their time in developing a good game rather than rushing it out.

Monster Hunter with the silky smooth combat experience you'd expect from Platinum Games (they co-developed this early on with Cygames), and the ability to auto-repeat some farming on lower difficulty stuff tat lets you just focus on the hard stuff. I'm terminally addicted to the game

This game reminds me what games used to be, you pay a price, get a full game, enjoy it, no battlepass, no adds, no gacha.

Progression is rewarding, you unlock characters, you get new weapons, classic RPG singleplayer stuff. 
Story is not amazing, not bad either, its something you can skip without missing out huge reveals or things that you cant quick watch on youtube.
The gameplay is where it shines, combat is fluid, rewarding, well animated. It might be a bit clustered at some fights but your character will always be highlighted.
As soon as you finish the story mode, you can remove CAPTAIN from the party, of course you can play your favorite character thru the story until the end even if sometimes you are forced to play as CAPTAIN because plot armor...
Its HUB based, if you played Monster Hunter you will feel at home. Also if you are MH fan you will like the boss fights as well. 
Combat is action packed, you can have nice combos with your party members, you can even ult together with a high damage unique finisher move.
You got the perfect dodge, block and hero-specific parries, jump, dash, leap while jumping, like Dark souls on steroids but with nice animations lol.
Worth every penny, as a gacha gamer, the price of this game is like 20 pulls and it already entertained me a lot and im at my first main.

Starts off as an annoying Tales of / Star Ocean rip off, but it quickly becomes an enticing MH-like with top-tier endgame experience. The story gets much better as you go too, and the many To/SO references leave place to a more "Final Fantasy vibe".

Combat feels great, many available characters to build up teams and test out gameplays, online coop in endgame content, lots of gears and skill trees... I've only just finished the main quest and I can tell that the game has only began.

Gameplay is generally fun, story suffers from Anime syndrome. Specifically, the main character is a white piece of paper that has no personality nor ever makes any decisions and the writers spread themselves too thin trying to write stories for 20 odd characters to have time to give them depth in the way they interact with eachother, or even the main character. Case in point, they all looove the main character so much, but it feels flat to an extreme because there is never any reason to love her other than she's cute and innocent. (In case you couldn't tell, I don't consider the character that you are forced to drag around everywhere as the main character because he/she is even more of a blank slate that makes no decisions at all than the little blue haired girl.)
If you like monster hunter or devil may cry, the gameplay is for you (I fall in this camp, hence my recommendation). If you like good stories and don't like harem animes, stay far away from this story; but even if you like the gameplay the story is a serious downer to my enjoyment of the gameplay.

[h2]Granblue Fantasy: Relink is a fantastic action RPG that masterfully combines fast-paced combat with stunning presentation and a strong postgame.[/h2]

[table]
[tr]
[th]🟩 Pros[/th]
[th]🟥 Cons[/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td] ✔️ Very capable party A.I. making progressing through even the postgame content viable for solo players. Likewise, this means developing characters you may not even play but who are part of your regular group feels rewarding.[/td]
[td] ❌Raising multiple characters is difficult to do. Throughout the roughly 30 hours it took me to progress into the final difficulty, I only managed to have one character up to the performance I would deem acceptable for those levels of quests.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td] ✔️ Fantastic presentation due to unrivaled visuals for its art style and a wide cast of accomplished Japanese voice actors, delivering an extremely cinematic experience during the main story.[/td]
[td] ❌ The English localization is infamously atrocious and ranges from awful voice acting on top of an already somewhat shaky script to outright mistranslations.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td] ✔️Strong replay value due to the large variety of unique characters and consistent unlocks even very late into the postgame, allowing for further difficulty modes in the campaign and a strong multiplayer component.[/td]
[td] ❌There are some balance issues. Originally, GBF was being called trivially easy, which in part is definitely true due to the Critical Gauge mechanic, but eventually begins outscaling the player during the postgame content.[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[table]
[tr]
	[th]🟨 Miscellaneous Thoughts[/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]The main story is somewhat short. If people merely focused on playing the campaign without side objectives for the credits, it would run between 12 and 14 hours. I, personally, got to the credits at 16 hours and then to the True Ending, another roughly 7 hours, which requires some decent progression into the harder postgame content.[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[h3]Technical Issues and Performance[/h3]
GBF:R ran without any issues. While there are some reports of people struggling to be able to boot the game shortly after launch, I have not encountered any such problems. The game never crashed, stuttered, or otherwise bugged out. The few hours of multiplayer I have played were stable, although the matchmaking is not exactly fantastic. 

[h3]Graphics and Sound[/h3]
Visually, GBF:R is utterly unrivaled for its art style. Both gameplay and cinematics look gorgeous, and there is an incredible amount of detail in just about every location.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3153437575

The sound design is not quite as impressive, with a soundtrack that is still generally good but not that memorable. The voice acting in the game’s original language is beyond fantastic, with a wide range of extremely talented and recognizable voice actors. The English dub, however, suffers from the aforementioned awful localization, at times changing the meaning of entire phrases, and likewise quite horrid voice acting.

[h3]Story and Setting[/h3]
You play as either Djeeta or Gran, depending on your gender preference for the main character, the Captain of a diverse cast of Skyfarers in a world entirely made up of floating sky islands. While in search of Estalucia, a fantastical utopia, you encounter a religious cult that takes interest in one of your friends who has the ability to seal and summon pseudo-godlike creatures like the dragon Bahamut.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3151952766

Needless to say, GBF is very much a JRPG with some interesting thematical parallels to specifically Final Fantasy, but it sets itself apart by its very unique setting. As a spin-off title to a gacha game, I was somewhat worried that the story may be an afterthought, but was generally surprised for that to not be the case, and as someone who has not played the gacha, I could follow the story fairly easily, though with a constant feeling of just lacking some context as to the interpersonal relationships of the different crew members.

There is a glossary that is just as boring to read as they always are, but it is nice that the game does give you an extensive interface through which you can browse anything from terms related to the world-building to the backstory of various characters and more. Characters also have mini-stories attached to them, which you unlock as you progress through the main story and level them up. Sadly, this seems to be a bit of a missed opportunity, as they are usually inconsequential enough to not provide significant character development and are also merely a few sentences short per episode.

Despite this, while I wouldn’t recommend GBF:R for the story alone, it is certainly on par with similar titles, such as the Tales of […] series, and may even be good enough to be recommended to fans of certain Final Fantasy titles due to the aforementioned thematic similarities.

[h3]Gameplay[/h3]
GBF:R can be broadly described as a hub-based and mission-centric action RPG. Campaign missions usually take place in a large, but fairly linear, level that encourages some exploration through collectibles and chests that consistently feel relevant and rewarding due to the different methods to progress your characters’ power level.

Side missions, and therefore the bulk of the postgame, take place in smaller segments of those aforementioned levels and range from mission types such as defending a static object to simple boss fights. Unlike other games in the genre, even later bossfights tend to be much faster, lasting typically between 2 and 8 minutes for the longer fights on anything above Maniac difficulty.

Fights are not just fast due to raw numbers, however, but combat tends to be very fast-paced in terms of how quickly attacks come out. To offset this, bigger attacks offer a telegraph a few moments before the attack actually fires. This is something that is very reminiscent of Final Fantasy 14, and I haven’t seen something like this used anywhere else. While this sort of MMO design, at first glance, feels a little odd, it actually does wonders for the game to be able to be as visually striking and responsive as it is, and I’m not sure combat would feel as good without this design decision.

As you progress through the story, you get to unlock more characters for the roster, each of which has a distinct weapon type and a unique gimmick; for example, Io, one of the immediately available characters, is a mage that augments her big spells through basic attacks, allowing for devastating combo-finishers. Each character also features multiple linear skill trees that eventually unlock further active abilities that can be freely slotted in to create unique builds. While this feels impactful, it never felt like I could augment a character towards a distinct role. Rather, the game is very centered around dealing as much damage as possible, even on the later, extremely lethal missions, since outlasting enemies through support just doesn’t feel very feasible.

[h3]Final Thoughts[/h3]
GBF:R is fast, flashy, and eventually scales to become extremely difficult in the late postgame. While this results in an awkward difficulty curve, it is an incredibly rewarding experience that still has a serviceable story on top of it all. Looking back at the game, while it probably will not end up breaking any new ground, I can’t really pinpoint any single aspect of the game that is outright bad and was a rare experience that I simply enjoyed going through from booting it up for the first time up until the very end.

After having taken just under 15 relaxed hours to play through the story, I can give this game probably the most enthusiastic, positive review I have ever given a video game. The combat feels clean and snappy, each character feels different, the graphics are stunningly charming at times, but I’m not experienced enough in this genre to comment appropriately and in greater detail on any of those things. 

However, what I can comment on is the story and the general atmosphere that is created here. In this review I will include very minimal spoilers about story structure. I am confident that nothing here actually classifies as a spoiler, but if you’re still worried then go buy the game now. 

The entire presentation is decidedly anime. You have your magical girls, your power of friendship, your spirits and monsters, your mysterious and edgy fighters, but it’s all delivered in an incredibly polished fashion. What this story gets right is the way it gets the player invested. Most JRPG’s include two different plot hooks, the personal hook for the character, and then a later hook where the end of the world lies ahead if the main character doesn’t stop it. The end of the world is always an easy way to motivate a character, however it is much harder to make that personal motivation stick. 

What this game does right is that it holds back that personal hook for just long enough that, when they decide to reveal it, the player is just as motivated as the characters they play to fix the issue. Going into greater detail about how this is achieved would result in a review that’s way too long for Steam, but it’s safe to say that the approach worked wonders. 

Looking at it objectively, the story is riddled with somewhat cliché moments, but with how they are delivered they never get annoying. Instead, Granblue Fantasy: Relink shows why some of these moments are such widely used clichés. It’s because they work. 

I rarely cry after finishing a videogame, but this was one where I could tell halfway through that I would. It takes you on a ride that is incredibly sweet, charming, sometimes just a tiny bit anime cringe, but worth every second. Let other people tell you more about the combat, the end-game systems, the multiplayer functionality, and whatever else this game still has to offer, but let me tell you that this story is an experience that has made me feel truly content, and every videogame that manages that is one worth cherishing in my book.

Combat is very good, with lots of characters to choose from that play very different from each other. Story is around 10~20h depending on how fast you do it, and although the plot is not amazing, it is dumb fun and there's a lot of spectacle.

Endgame has a lot of content similar to Monster Hunter games, beating different boss fights and quests in 4-people coop groups. Beat monster, get stuff to improve your character, beat harder monsters. There's different unlockable difficulty levels that I'm still working on.

Some people apparently have had problems with the servers and with crashes, but I didn't experience any at all.
I'm enjoying the game and I'd love it if they keep updating the game with new characters and content.

This game is peak combat experience. I personally wish there was more open-exploration gameplay besides the main story (like optional areas to explore), but the overall gameplay is absolutely incredible.

Alright beat the game made it to the end game can edit my review to give full impressions.

TL:DR: You like ARPG's about killing big bosses or hordes of grunts and pushing yourself and your friends to get the highest scores/lowest times possible on these kills? Do you like MMO raid bosses but wish the combat was more engaging? Do you like grinding to hit achievable and visible improvements in your characters? Sick of FOMO, MTX, Live Service, Time Gating, DRM, bullshit in your co-op games? Buy this game.

Story 8.5/10:
It's honestly paced incredibly well, it comes out the gate letting you know this game is gonna be crazy with a battle against a god on a flying ship in the skies. It takes a short break after that to let you explore the game systems while wailing on much smaller threats. You then immediately take on the primal god of vitality and the roller coaster never slows down from there. The overall premise is a tale as old as time save the princess, save the world. It's been done a million times but the spectacle on display for this more than makes up for the simplicity. The story is roughly 15-20 hours depending on if you do side content and the collectathon elements in the missions. You can probably blitz it in 10 if you skip all the cutscenes and play on the easiest difficulty. It gets an 8.5/10 because it does its simple premise well and while perfect length is a hard thing to achieve if I want more it means what I got was good.

Gameplay 10/10:
This is the best co-operative action combat I have ever played. Building off the backs of games like NieR: Automata, Genshin Impact, and other ability based action games Granblue takes all those elements and cranks them to eleven. Complimented by some of the best boss fights I had the pleasure to do. The action dances really well between these tense mechanic filled moments almost every character can be built to be pure damage, debuff/stun focused, or team support focused. Despite them all having varying ways to build them they all feel functionally unique and offer tons of longevity in just trying them all out. Percival and his mongrel Vane are my two go to characters but every single one I've played is fun in a unique way. When you're in co-op this game knows how to push your hype as a group to the edge especially in the harder fights, the final moments of hard bosses being capstoned by you and your friends cracking the last few percentages of health with the very cinematic ultimate moves in so satisfying. Hell even solo the AI are so smart they might beat you for MVP scores every once in a while they keep the fun just as well as human players.

Music 10/10:
Tsutomu Narita sores on this soundtrack elevating his and Nobuo Uematsu's original compositions for the mobile game to a whole new level and his new tracks for the game are all insanely good. Sequestrian Primal, Vow and Promise, End of Ragnarok, and other titles that have spoilers in them are all incredible. Narita has a talent not only for incredibly peaceful tracks but also tracks that really set your adrenaline pumping to match the chaos on screen.

Visuals 10/10:
It's been a long time since a triple A studio has brought so much work to stylized visuals. Cygames brought their A game to bring the style of Hideo Minaba and the rest of their art team to life here. Backgrounds and Skyboxes are beautifully rendered 2d water color paintings. Literal pieces of art paintings you could see in a museum or art gallery. Very clever use of 2d planes gives life to these paintings by putting moving elements like clouds and clusters of foliage in them. Then by layering it all it gives it a depth that is truly gorgeous to look at. The characters and their equipment are rendered out with such care as well with scoring and pencil marks on them that make them look like they've come right off a page. The black outlines around them are even scored as if made by a pencil. To top it off lighting has some global illumination and point lighting with great shadows but all these stylization efforts meant conventional lighting wouldn't look great so they hand painted tons of shadows, changed colors for shadowed elements to help accentuate them, hand painted BOUNCE LIGHTING EVERYWHERE. Seriously there are spots where lighting should only be possible with ray tracing but since the game lacks it and it wouldn't look great anyway because of all the 2d plane tricks they did they HAND PAINTED IT. All this love and care into the details creates this wonderful feeling of like walking through a play set or pop up book, it's fantastic, whimsical, and warm. I know people will just see typical anime visuals when they step into this game but the dedication Cygames put in cannot be understated this is the best this style of visuals has been done so far. Also as a HUGE plus NO SMUDGY TAA or dedication to upscalers the game renders at intended resolution targets natively. Animations are god tier can't even get into it.

Quality of Life 9/10:
The only reason this gets dinged a point is no native ultrawide support which is absolutely criminal for how beautiful the game can be, and no remapping of controller inputs on PC. Other than that the assist mode is smart and makes it so anyone can play through the entire story and 75% of the endgame. The menus are streamlined and easy to use. Lyria's Journal is probably one of the best game databases ever. Character, Enemy, and Weapon information AND a model viewer for all of them. A music player built in. Key Terms, World Info, and Lore bits. All in one place and it can even be pulled up mid conversation if terms are thrown around you don't remember and it'll bring up that term's page. 

Multiplayer 10/10:
This is where the game shines. The combat and gameplay overall come alive when playing with other people and Cygames made sure these system were polished to a luster. There is at least 100 hours of content here if you do everything. Multiplayer is also INCREDIBLY stream lined, repeat missions right from the end screen, a scoring system and time system to keep you pushing for the best possible clears. Crazy amount of social features you can communicate with people easily without ever typing a word let alone using a mic. Lobby Creation and lobby BROWSER as well as quick match built in day one of a multiplayer game in 2024?! Incredible. Not to mention no battle passes, arbitrary time gates, no FOMO mechanics, no pay to win mechanics, no intrusive anti-cheat for a co-op game, no DRM crap bogging the game down for no reason.

Overall 9.5/10:
This game is an absolute treat and a phenomenal way to start out 2024. Myself and many others were weary after a 8 year dev cycle, but this game payed off huge. It's stunning in every regard and deserves all the love it is getting. The only blips are the issues with launching people had which seems to be dying out and the no co-op for the story. More than anything else I hope Cygames sees the success of this title and keeps adding to it to push it forward. I want Monster Hunter style expansions and small content updates like what is already announced. After the eight year wait all I want is this game to keep going it's the most fun co-op experience I've had in years. Cygames delivers a full experience from start to finish with more than a fair share of additional content and quality of life features, nothing withheld, nothing locked for engagement metrics sake. We should treasure AAA developers who release games like this in this day and age.

Specs:
i9 10850k
Rtx 3080ti
64gb DDR4 3600mhz
Samsung 980 pro NVME

Settings:
3840x1600 using the ultrawide mod now.
Fullscreen
V-Sync off
All Ultra

Performance:
120fps almost locked some small dips here and there. 10-20 Frames at most.
Even in intense multiplayer moments it runs buttery smooth no visual hitches at all.
After putting the ultrawide fix in place I do get a drop when loading into Seedhollow at the docks where it dips to about 90fps.

[b]This game deserves the positive it is sitting at, but there are some issues:[/b]

- The localization is a bit off at times, I seriously hope that japanese devs step away from using out of country translators or work more directly with them (menacingly hovering over their shoulder). If you understand some japanese and I am not claiming to be a good at it but when even I can tell that the translation is completely off then we need to talk. Come on.
Havent checked the english dub yet but I hear its off as well, really bad choices made.

Found another example, thx to original uploader for capturing this: https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3155229515


+/- Some people have trouble with crashes, I am going to assume they did the reasonable thing and updated drivers (have not seen Nvidia, for example, drop a driver for this game specifically yet > works fine with older driver) and used Steam to check the files. Most of the times it is a file that is messed up that causes crashes at specific times, if its random then it is most likely a memory leak of some type. I hope a fix will drop if these issues continue even after measures have been taken by the customers. Also check system requirements.

+/- The region lock is weird, it checks for Steam region (can be changed in the Steam options) and it doesnt let you play with every person in europe for example it goes for smaller regions as you can set in Steam. This needs to be updated.

[u]About the game itself:[/u]
+ Game runs great and is visually very appealing, it looks like its own thing but still very similar to the anime and the mobile game (which I havent played, it is a gambling game / gacha), there is a fighting game as well which I am aware of.

+ Combat is amazing when you are playing a meleecharacter, I tried Io the mage and it didnt have that much ooomph (yet), maybe after unlocking more talents and abilities she will feel more fun. But if you like to stand back and do your thing with little worry you can just play ranged. There are plenty options to unlock.

+ Dont expect to much drama from the story or its depth, Gran Blue is not known for that. It is more a sweet story with fun characters.

+/- the passive skilltree is nothing special, you can get +20 HP here and standard unlocks, like perfect block there and some special attacks, but there is nothing to really write home about. That said:

+ There are unlockable passives that you can level that define your build the most and that is where the game shines, have fun hunting for some of the conditions! Need to find more weapons to tell more about those.

+ Every character feels different and you can choose who to play as (some missions need to done with certain people in the party fyi), have fun trying them out.

+/- Need to see a little more areas to get a full opinion on the design of the levels. So far there are plenty hidden areas and little secrets around. They are not that open and slightly linear so far.

+ Monsters and most importantly bosses are amazing, have fun beating those, there is endgame content as well and more planned (hear ye, hear ye)

Good JRPG with great gameplay experience. Storywise it's generic but hey, I'm not looking for something innovative. Just something that can be reasonably enjoyed.

What you can expect?
- Comfortable linear story progression and map exploration.
- Good combat gameplay with you being able to play 20 different characters. Each with their own unique playstyle. Seofon and Tweyen will be playable in April if not stalled. Unsure if it's free or paid dlc.
- Character building system is a mix of RPG and MonHun.
- The end game is all about counter quest if you're familiar with MonHun / PSO.
- Counter quests have pretty reasonable progression. You can't simply go for highest difficulty because if you do, you're simply being toxic with the party.
- Highest difficulty counter quest requires thinking before you go co-op. Don't simply fill your character equipment slots with damage increase. It's normal for team wipe to occur. Therefore, think of how to increase your chance of surviving and completing the quest. Aegis, Autorevive, Improved Dodge and Potion Hoarder. Remember these four.
- Upcoming Lucilius quest update in March if not stalled. Not sure if free or paid dlc.
- Upcoming update in May if not stalled. Not sure if it's story, more characters or quests. Free or paid dlc also unknown.

What you can pray for?
- Due to high replayability value, pray that Cygames release quest and character updates on frequent interval.
- Hope Cygames release full instance quest for co-op.
- Season pass dlc so that we can extend GBF Relink lifespan.

Granblue Fantasy: Relink had the potential to soar to new heights, but alas, it crashes harder than a wyvern with clipped wings. The game's freezing issues during cutscenes are not just occasional hiccups; they're like watching a slideshow in the middle of a cinematic masterpiece. The freezing is so consistent and disruptive that you might start thinking your PC has decided to embark on an unscheduled polar expedition.

Cutscenes, the bread, and butter of any RPG, are meant to draw players into the narrative, but in Granblue Fantasy: Relink, they're more like a cruel test of patience. Just as the story starts to unfold, the game decides to hit the pause button, leaving you staring at a frozen frame like a deer caught in headlights. It's as if the developers thought, "Why bother with a smooth storytelling experience when we can give players the joy of freeze-frame frustration?"

Navigating the lush environments and engaging in combat feels like trying to wade through molasses. The controls, which should be responsive and intuitive, instead feel sluggish and uncooperative. It's a disheartening experience, especially considering the potential this game had to be a visual and interactive delight.

In conclusion, Granblue Fantasy: Relink is a title that promises much but delivers little. The freezing cutscenes and lack of optimization for higher resolutions turn what could have been an immersive RPG adventure into a frustrating exercise in patience. Unless you have a deep-seated love for frozen frames, it might be wise to set your sights on a more polished and technically competent RPG experience.

Still i'd recommend this game once the devs apply fix for the said issues.

This is the best RPG I've played in a long time.

Lots of great characters with a lot of different abilities and builds. Has strong hack and slash as well as fun spell casters to play as, basically covers all play styles. Lots to grind and min max if you're into that, but it also has a fun main quest.

It's basically like a good Genshin Impact. Someone like Rosetta really shows how diverse the game can be as a mage that chooses where to summon plants after finishing a combo. 1 basic attacks and a heavy give a defense buff and can spawn a plant if you hold the heavy, 2 basics and a heavy gives a regen heal,  and  3 gives an attack dmg buff, 4 makes the already summoned plants attack more. Also all of these have her doing different animations and properties. She also has 4 other skills (out of a lot) from the plants taunting, to exploding, to summoning all of them, to mimicking a ton of attacks coming out from her, it's very awesome. Genshin felt really shallow to me, this is similar but has more depth and mechanics while maintaining an elemental system, if you want your depth in the extreme team synergies and character switching genshin is reliant on, this does not have that. It instead has all of the depth on the character you've chosen to play; which you can change your party and playable character whenever, just not on the fly for combat purposes like Genshin.

RECOMMENDATION:
If you like Genshin, or warframe, or Dragons Dogma (yeah), you'll probably like this game. The grind gives plenty of time to actually get good at the game, level other characters, and understand mechanics. IF you pick and only play someone like Gran the entire time you can still have fun but you won't be going into the real depth of the game (Gran is cool, He's just the most basic). I like magic casters and supports and this game has some of the most fun version of those, up there with ffxiv.

I'll be playing this and Helldivers 2 until Dragons Dogma 2 comes out (see what happens). I'll keep playing this game especially If this game continues to receive updates and content. I have at least 5 characters I'd like to max and then I'd also want to min max 2-3 of them, plus I want to beat everything on the hardest difficulty. Basically I plan to always return and play this game.

EDIT: Nevermind Gran has a ridiculous amount of skills and is extremely versatile, he's still "basic" but hack and slash but does require combos and proper skill usage to maximize his passive with skills. Having a Gran that keeps a 70% damage reduction and 35% dmg boost up is crazy + a full hp heal or nuke of a stun, the list is almost endless for how much he can do.
I dont know any of these characters but I love them

Granblue Fantasy: Relink feels like a game which was released on time, without being rushed or any cut content, the final product is very polished

Environment design and soundtracks are as good as I expected. Roaming around town, traveling to different islands & especially fighting bosses, all of which provided me with a very enjoyable experience. I'm a bit tired of photo-realistic graphics so a game with a distinguished art style is like a new breath of fresh air.

As someone who wish he could get into Monster Hunter more. Relink really hits the spot for me. The grind is really fun and worthwhile, even if I need to do quest over and over again. Because all time I spent grinding and upgrading characters made me feel like I really made progress on making my characters stronger & more versatile. I think that game did a great job on this aspect. 

Best thing about this game is the AI. Comparing to other games with a similar combat style, GBF Relink probably has the smartest AI system I have ever seen. Against bosses, they understand the openings, be able to cancel action to performing dodge / block. When bosses do large AOE attacks, they can actually take advantage of the mechanic that is used to counter that type of attacks and got away unscathed. They can even apply pressure to the boss, which made the boss stop targeting me and lock on them instead. Those few seconds when I can fully setup my attacks without having to dodge or block all the time is simply precious.

Maybe I might get a second opinion after the honeymoon phase, as the scope of this game could have been better. For instance, the story mode could be use to flesh out the characters more. Their gameplay are fun, but the interaction with the main squad was not seen during the story was quite a let down for me. Hope that in the future we can see expansions that include these characters and their interaction with the main crew. 

But for now, pretty sure that I'll be putting in a huge amount of hours in this game. For a $60 game, it was worth it for me.
If you want to have fun and treat yourselves to a bit of action without gacha crap or p2w shit, just have fun.

As someone who has been waiting for this game since I first got into Granblue Fantasy via Versus in 2020, I can say that Relink is everything I had hoped for and much, much more. The core gameplay is fun, satisfying and rewarding. It just feels *right* to perfect-dodge an attack and to get rewarded with additional invincibility frames. The game also offers loads of different ways to tailor your character to your playstyle, with a vast amount of grindable loot to add extra effects, ranging from general stats increases to temporary buffs that trigger in specific situations. 

In terms of presentation and atmosphere, Relink is impeccable and exactly how the world of Granblue Fantasy was meant to be enjoyed. The developers put an almost unimaginable level of detail into this game, most of which is easy to miss. You may want to take your time and just look at things while enjoying the absolutely beautiful (and epic) soundtrack.

If there is something I would criticise about Granblue Fantasy Relink, it's mostly related to the story. It's fairly standard stuff that primarily serves as a justification to bombard you with some of the most epic boss fights you can imagine. Also, do not expect your character to actually appear in story cutscenes if they are not part of the main crew.

That said, I give Relink a 9.5 out of 10 score. It's an almost perfect game, and with more content on the horizon and nearly unlimited source material to draw from, it's sure to keep me playing for a long time.

There is an issue that needs to be brought to light.

At this time, it's hard to recommend GBFR as there are two different "Load Save" bugs. It can happen at any point when you attempt to load a file.

1) "Unable to load save data"

2) "Broken data." 

Attempt to load a save and you may receive one of two errors. Unsure what can trigger the error. I do suggest quitting the game thorough the in-game menu options and hope this is a preventive measure. (No Alt+F4 or anything of the like)

From what I have gathered from forums and some testing myself, there is no work around for either errors from what I can find. Hoping both of these issues are able to be patched.

 While waiting for a fix you can start a new game and grind your way to where you were in your previous save, but no guarantee that your new save wont suffer the same fate.

Other than that I love this game and it's great. Just disheartening being unable to continue my progress. I'll be waiting for a patch in the meantime.

Co op is enjoyable but it has no level syncing so while a group of friends works on clearing the story to open co op missions be aware if you do not plan accordingly being overpowered and underpowered will be a huge impact to fun as completing the main story asynchronously will sky rocket your level. 

Each story chunk is roughly 1-3 hours with 3-4 co op missions per chunk. The co op missions so far have been real real short encounters (survive 3 waves, kill this boss) and back to town.

While the coop missions have been lack luster in any form of plot or substance, as they threw narratives out the window and focused on combat. Combat has been very enjoyable lots of action, fast lights and sounds, and loads of bars filling up to give you that hit of dopamine before every anime finisher.

This is a solid, refreshingly wholesome Action-Combat JRPG with a good chunk of Monster Hunter and Xenoblade thrown in for good measure. Combat is impactful and fluid, though can be a bit sticky at times, with boss fights being expansive, visually stunning, and lots of fun to go up against. The story is pretty standard, if you've played any Final Fantasy you get the gist and the tropes, but it's presented in such a beautiful world with tons of really light hearted dialogue and fun. This game was very clearly made both in Japanese and in the Localized english version to be targeted at younger teens, and honestly I'm all for it. It knows when to be serious but everybody is just having fun going on a big adventure and it's really relaxing to just get lost in and enjoy for what it is. 

There's an expansive post-game multiplayer akin to Monster Hunter fights and long term grinds for every character, character builds are a lot of fun to screw around with, and there's more content planned for the future, so it'll be around for some time to come.

I've waited around 5 years for this game to release and i had very low expectations going in, tons of delays accompanied with lack of showcases really made me believe that this game was going to either flop really hard, or not even be released at all. So after spending a good amount of time with the game i can very confidently say that this is the most fun i've had playing a game in a good while. The story is engaging with beautiful cinematics, the combat is fast, fluid and exhilarating.. every character on the roster has a different move set and playstyle which really changes the way you approach each encounter. 

The OST is beautiful and they really incorporated granblue fantasy iconic art style into the world. There are a ton of little easter eggs that gacha players will really appreciate like when you walk around seeing all the duplicate NPC and rackams suicide move to name a few. The roadmap also makes me excited for the future of the game, excited to see faa in action and i can't wait to try out Siete and Song. 

Some improvements i'd love to see:
- Option to automatically hide the HUD outside of combat
- Option to resize HUD, there's a lot of screen clutter 
- Option to tone down effects, the visual vomit can be a little much sometimes

Story was alright but the real draw is the game play. It has a monster hunter feel in the end game where you fight bosses that are slightly more difficult for better and better rewards. With so many characters to choose from it would be hard not to find someone you like.

It feels like a Tales game mixed with a Monster Hunter game plus a good helping of it's own thing.
The combat feels good, and there's lots of characters with unique play styles so you'll be able to find one that just "clicks".

You can play solo, with an AI team that you build up yourself.  However, I recommend playing online, especially once you get to post-campaign stuff, since it's quite fun.

Amazing Story line that is fascinating, entertaining, most importantly captivating; i even had a good few laughs. I hardly every see this in games. i find myself bored fairly quickly with story lines, but that's probably because real life is stranger than fiction these days. You are the hero defeating evil, with the unexpected redemption and forgiveness, which is refreshing, compared to the devil worship forced on the gamer community these days.

The game play is good without question. End game is entertaining, im not sure for how long though to be honest, rinse and repeat does have its shortcomings. Random generated treasure hunt maps in a future update would be fun (with random objectives), and some pvp content like teams vs teams, capture the flag, and protect your beacon would make this game trend.

I recommend buying it and playing it, take your time, explore, look for secret pathways for treasures and crabs. Yes you can speed through it, even on hard. All i can say is though, enjoy it and take your time with it.

A sublime experience that sets the bar to a new high.

The action combat in the game feels pretty fluid and each character has their own moveset and playstyle. Some even have multiple ways to play them.

The game feels like a mix of Phantasy Star Online, Monster Hunter and Final Fantasy XVI with some Final Fantasy XIV boss mechanics. It starts off easy enough but players are expected to get used to having multiple things thrown at them so paying attention and reacting to whats going on will be important to improve and prepare for future fights and difficulty.

The end game is pretty much what one would epic if they have ever played a Monster Hunter game. Complete missions to gain materials to help improve your character, create builds for your playstyle and grow ever stronger.

The only con's I have for the game is that its near impossible to play with friends that are of lower level then you as you'll be too strong for the missions of the lower level without the power syncing that is unlocked after you beat the game and the power syncing only works with randoms, not with friends you play with.

As well as some boss's having far too little health, making some fights last only two minutes. Most bosses could do with an increase in health as four players can make quick work of enemies rather easily.

Overall, the game does feel very polished and feels like the developers really tried their best at making the game the best it could be.
It was worth the wait!

Yo no conocía nada de Granblue hasta ahora, salvo el juego de peleas. Pero después de 50 horas de juego, puedo decir que me gusto mucho este juego y su universo. 
La historia esta bastante buena, no te mata la cabeza con tramas complejas, ni te deja todo fácil. Y eso esta bueno para mi gusto.

El apartado visual en general es hermoso, la campaña tiene vistas increíbles del escenario, los personajes lucen bastante bien, los efectos en general son muy buenos también, salvo que en los combates aveces me cuesta ver al enemigo de tanto efecto que hay (mas que nada en enemigos pequeños, como humanos)
En cuanto sonido, es bastante bueno y va acorde con la ambientación de fantasía del juego. La música es realmente buena, tiene varios ost que volvería a escuchar en lugares como YT mientras hago otra cosa.

El gameplay es muy divertido, los combates son cada vez mas dinámicos y difíciles a medida que avanzas en la historia y haciendo las misiones de caza (tipo Monster Hunter) y jugando en cooperativo con amigos (4 jugadores en total) es mucho mas divertido aun.

Durante la versión 1.0.3, al juego le encontré dos problemitas:
- Al abrir el juego, la pantalla se quedaba en negro después de mostrar los logos de la compania.
- El modo coop online tenia una especie de bloqueo de región que no te permitía jugar con gente de otras partes del mundo, y tenias que cambiar la región de descarga de steam para poder jugar con ellos (No estoy seguro de si era un bug o estaba hecho así)
- El matchmaking para jugar misiones rápidas no funcionaba.

Al dia siguiente (creo) en la versión 1.0.4 se solucionaron los problemas antes mencionados, el matchmaking funciona, ahora podes jugar con tus amigos que viven en cualquier lado del planeta parece, y el juego ya no salta pantalla negra cuando lo abrís (por lo menos a mi no me ha vuelto a pasar después del update). Y eso me da la impresión de que los devs están atentos.

Le doy un 9/10 y lo recomiendo.

It's honestly one of the best games I have ever player, its a very polished co-op game with cool mechanics. Monster Hunter meets cute anime waifus. All of the characters are very unique and play differently keeping the game fresh.

Apparently the game's executable file cannot even launch for people with 3rd generation Intel CPUs or below because it requires the AVX2 instruction set. There are only 2 other games on Steam that have had this issue (Uncharted: Legacy of Thieves and Star Ocean 6) and both of them patched it out about 2 months after release. 

This means I can't play the game because I run an i5-3570K. My motherboard doesn't support a newer CPU generation either, meaning I would need an entirely new gaming rig just to launch the .exe file despite having a modern SSD, GTX 1070, and 32GB RAM. Strangely, the PS4 launched the same year as the 3rd generation Intel CPU line yet the game is playable on PS4.

I've got about 8 more days before my refund period expires so that's about how long I'll wait before I refund the game.

I read that this game was a mix of Final Fantasy and Monster Hunter so that's why I picked it up. I was not disappointed.

The combat style, the item progression system, and the quest system are similar to Monster Hunter. As far as questing I like this even better than Monster Hunter because they just jump right into it. For example, a boss fight is just a boss fight, you don't spend 10 minutes trying to locate it.

The actual fights themselves feel much more like Final Fantasy or an Anime style. You have weapons, magic, and superhuman abilities. The bosses are just as epic so sometimes it's difficult to know what's happening on the screen, but you know you're having a good time.

I'm having a blast with this and I'm only getting started. I hope to see you in game.

I have just completed the story at 17 hours. It was generic as heck from moment one and I had no patience. I skipped every cut scene after chapter one and have no regrets, but therefore should not comment on the story, but... there really isn't one.

Combat is fairly simplistic, but is very responsive and you can pull off doges and blocks that feel great. Every character, of which there are many, has their own play style that seems to give a slightly different feel to the pattern or flow of combat.

Upgrading is the main goal of the game, both in the story, and in the post game. You can level every character, but they each have an offensive and defensive skill tree that are fairly large and give you a sense of constant character progression. These trees also unlock new abilities. Weapons are also upgradeable with a two part system of leveling them with crystals, and then unlocking the level cap multiple times. This system is further enhanced by giving each character permanent upgrades like stat bonuses for each weapon by reaching their various level caps. This gives great reason for farming crafting supplies from the many quests available.

The quests range from boss fights to horde attacks and point defense. Multiplayer post game content is likely where this game shines best, but as I've only just reached end game and am friendless, I shall refrain from comment.

TL:DR 
This is an anime game without the plot, but has plenty of character progression elements to give you a reason to play... That is if you like Tales/Ys/'Generic Anime Game' character action.

Incredible game, I've already spent way too much time on it. Don't listen to anyone complaining, if you want to play an action JRPG this game is for you.

If you've played the gacha, expect the MSQ of this to basically be a glorified sidestory length-wise, probably about 10-15 hours, give or take. I haven't touched GBF in about 4 years now, but besides like one, maybe two?, 5-second callbacks to some more recent characters from the main game, you should be absolutely fine following along with this game's story as a newbie; it's pretty self-contained and you can get up to speed with the world and featured characters anyway with Lyria's Journal and the first few Fate Eps for each playable character.

It's a really fun Action RPG, even though the MSQ might feel a little short, but it more than makes up for it with it's post-game, I've just unlocked Extreme difficulty quests as of writing this, but even once I get to Maniac and whatever's beyond, I can see myself still putting many, many hours into this just getting lost spamming quests.

All the characters are pretty fun to play in their own right, and the way they've translated their skills from turn-based to action RPG works really well. Off the top of my head, Narmaya and Lancelot feel right at home if you've played DMC, while Rackam and Eugen make me miss Dragalia Lost and it's gun-using characters. Siegfried and Ghandagoza have timing mechanics to their basic attacks that feel like I'm playing Hi-Fi Rush lite.

Really glad this game finally came out. I'm really happy I can enjoy this IP again without enduring gachapon hell (GW grinding should be classified as a war crime).

[b]Review:[/b]
[b] This game is amazing. I haven't felt this way about a game since I played Monster Hunter World! [/b]

MHW was the one CO-OP action RPG experience that absolutely blew me away. It's not to say there weren't other good ones I played, but MHW was on a whole different level. And the more I played it, the more fun and engaging it become. Most games can't do that, even good ones. They'll have certain times where it'll peak, and certain times where it'll be a bit stale...but MHW was the one game where as you kept playing, the bar of expectation just kept getting raised only to be surpassed over and over again. Just when you thought you were at the "peak" of that amazing game, it would keep surpassing your expectations with the next fight or new mechanic or upgrade.

[i]And now Granblue Fantasty Relink is starting to make me feel that way too (although I've only put it in few hours so far). It just keeps getting better and better and better.[/i] 

All the systems in this game just go together so well. It reminds me of some of my favourite parts of other genres. The fun combat and progression from JRPGs. The mission based content, build versatility and uniqueness of each weapon/character from Monster Hunter. The end screen, build versatility, and hop-in-hop-out from Roguelikes. The character collecting and party based progression and party builds from Gacha and JRPGs... And there's so much more of course.

And the level of polish is amazing too. The music, the artstyle, the little easter eggs. Oh man...

[b] This game is probably going to be my GOTY and one of the best action RPGs I know I'll ever have played.[/b]

It's super unfortunate that this game will be overshadowed by more well known IPS releasing around the same time, and won't get nearly the amount of recognition it deserves..

Cygames did a fantastic job for the 2 hour mark. It gives you a little bit of everything and enough to say, "hey I can keep going or its not for me." Within the short time frame, it feels familiar like MH but with anime elements. Combat feels extremely smooth and it didn't feel repetitive. From the looks of the trailers, i thought it would be a mindless button smash but its got tactical mechanics. Playing against Mobs, elite bosses and a final boss within 2 hours felt great. Pacing wasn't too rushed or dragged out. 

After Completing the main story mode within 12 hours, on Hard difficulty. The story isn't mind blowing that you'll remember it. But the pacing is quick and each chapter felt extremely short, so it doesn't drag on. The combat mechanics and diversity of each character is what kept me going back and trying new play styles. Its a great introduction for all your basic needs.

Endgame, its similar to Monster Hunter and its now just a grind fest for your favourite characters. Playing on harder difficulties and seeing which set of 4 you want to party with. Multiplayer you'll need some communication on the tougher quest, which should have text or voice chat. There's a ton of flashy animations happening and the UI is packed with information. There's enough for a good 40 to 80 hours, if you're willing to reach max level and for half the roster. 

Overall, its a good game with fantastic combat mechanics. Flashy anime visual effects. Tons of rewards and gear to obtain. Grab your Squad of 4 and Slay those Goblins!
Very amazing.

Very fun game and honestly didn't have any performance issues. (specs below)

The good:
- Fun gameplay and mechanics.
- Bosses does feel like a MMORPG raid.
- Lots of characters and builds to choose from.
- Beautiful graphics and artwork.
- Matchmaking.
- Story so far is very good. Very JRPG lol.
- Servers feel good, didn't get any rubber or lag problems.

The bad:
- English translation is bad. If you know how to read in Japanese, I recommend playing with JP interface. If you only know how to listen/speak, play it with English Dub, that way you won't notice the bad translation. If you don't know JP at all it won't matter, lol. The end result of the dialogues is the same for the story so you won't miss key points, but they tried so hard with localizing the characters speech that the audio doesn't fit the subtitles. 
[strike]- Game feels too easy even on hard difficulty. (still have to experience the endgame content to review it's difficulty)[/strike] From chapter 9 onward the game gets challenging and the quest hub missions gets harder and harder, it will be a real challenge to S++ all of them and most late game bosses have one shot mechanics and are extremely challenging.
- Afraid new characters and new endgame missions could be paid DLCs.

Game is great overall. RPG story is decent to good, the boss fights and music are great. There are so many characters to choose from and they all have distinct playstyles. Plays a lot like a faster Monster Hunter with skill loadouts. Game is very well optimized, I see very few frame drops.

Main complaints at this point are the lock-on targeting can be a bit wonky at times, and the camera angle is sometimes too close and sometimes auto-zooms to locations that I don't want to look at, so I have to fight with it to get back to what I wanted to see.

Only other thing is people who want to play something Monster Hunter style are going to have to play through 10-15 hours of campaign before that really unlocks an endgame. Like I said the campaign is fine though, so just do it!

Overall as my first introduction to the Granblue games I'm really impressed.
