Ok so Im going to recommend this but there is a caveat to it. I will try to be brief:
 
Granblue Fantasy basically is a Final Fantasy tactics and previous installations in the franshise inspired game and some devs like art director and music producer have indeed worked on the game. This appealed to me because I played those games in the way back machine so naturally the aesthetics of the game and setting is reminiscent to those games. If you come from Final Fantasy games, you will find that most monster types, names, some characters an settings have clothing all very transposed or inspired by D&D or FF installations. This is a great thing for me as it was familiar.

1. Story: Very cookie cutter save the princess, save the world kind of thing also present on final fantasy installations. Not a bad thing, the story moves along with some stakes but there is a problem for me with main plot characters where I couldn't find myself caring at all with Main character Gran and Lyria because there was no stakes with their link. (Not a spoiler, that is just a plot device present since the start) I would hope in future games that is present. However, this game does introduce you nicely to different characters an all characters have interactions between them in gameplay. Super nice touch. Voice acting in english is surprisingly good or similar to Genshin Impact. Not surprised if some actors/actresses of genshin worked on this game. 

2. Gameplay: This is an action RPG reminiscent to some as to Monster Hunter, Genshin Impact esque kind of game which is true to some extent. Here is where CAVEAT for recommending this game comes. This is a character building game where there is some benefits to element weaknesses. That is cool. There is some massive oversights in this game. 

a. While I like characters interactions with each other, they are YAPPING over each other CONSTANTLY AND INCESSANTLY to the point that its incredibly annoying sometimes. They cannot take turns to talk. It becomes a nuisance until your brain shuts off and just ignores them.

b. This game has the worst camera work of all time in any videogame Ive ever played ever in my 30 years playing videogames. You need to turn off settings to alliviate this somehow but still terrible and the POV cant be adjusted either which basically locks you behind your character too close and you lose sight of what's going on specially on very large arenas with large targets and get killed on some random mechanic.

c. Cygames needs to FIRE the whole department that design mechanics for this game and whoever greenlit it. They clearly didnt playtest their own game. HOLY SHT they are terrible. The Lazy fks over there only understand how to do mechanics by basically tying every mechanic to your character's feet or directed specifically to you. So basically if you love overlapping big ass chasing aoe's with other things chasing you at the same time or overlapping on top of other characters that may be around you also with no way to escape it, this is your game. If that means difficulty to you. There is no spacing or method to the madness, there is no static mechanic thing to learn. Some mechanics plain do not give you any way to react to it. It becomes an unlucky, you die... kind of situation that becomes unpleasant. You just pray you are not the one getting barraged by some random sht going your way and die because its undodgeable or unblockable. It is the single worst mechanic gameplay ive ever played in my life. This is what happens when you pay someone 8 hours to work and they work 1 and waste 7 playing on a cellphone. 

d. I feel that the whole growth of the character, what you need to farm and character trees are unessesary convoluted. Most people wont know what to spend points on their mastery trees or how to properly build characters to do what you want them to do. Monster Hunter used Farming Monster parts and Decorations. Here you have so many currencies and things to upgrade that you dont even know where to start or what to do. It becomes incredibly overwhelming and tedious to even know what you need. Most characters can do more than 1 job (tank,dps,healer) not all are good at everything but they have some element or hybrid you can do but even then, most people wont be able to figure out what talents to use for what. 

e. The ascension quest is absolutely the worst fight Ive ever played in my entire life where al crap convert into 1 big pile of dung. The most unbalanced, mechanically devoided, random ass garbage I had to endure. Even with a character well beyond the power needed for it. Its a fest of random, nonsensical mechanics with no method to the madness at all. A true nightmare where you are just glad its over and you dont feel satisfied for mastering it to overcome. Its just desperation to be over because of how bad it is. Thats how I will leave it.

 
P.S. I think that if you are a fan of final fantasy games, you'd be right at home with this game and you'll probably like the story. Is simple but effective. If you like monster hunter, you will find incredibly frustrated with the stupidity of mechanics and camera work. If you are a Genshin Impact player Uninstall your computer and go find a job.

There are multiple bosses in the game that only appear once you've beaten the hardest quests in the game, meaning there is always something new and exciting to look forward to. I beat the last available boss around the 50 hr mark, but I'm having such fun with the gameplay mechanics that I only want to play more with new characters.

I'll keep it short.

-The combat is flashy and impactful, in the same way that FFXVI's is.

-The main gameplay loop is basically structured like a Monster Hunter game.

-Character and Weapon progression takes a lot from both Gacha and Musou games, without any of the gambling.

-The Universe and overall Arstyle are both clearly inspired by the Final Fantasy games of old, more specifically V, VI and IX. (which makes sense considering those who actually created the Granblue IP used to work on those old FF games)

-The Boss fights themselves feels like they came straight out of FFXIV in the best ways possible.

It's like a dream come true. I've been waiting for too long for a PC character-collection RPG (gacha type games) that has no predatory microtransactions, no time-gated progression, no bread-crumbing content across year to keep you in the dark but still commited and cannot move on.  I'd almost lost hope, 7 years waiting without any information is a whole kind of let down. But in the end, FREAKIN FINALLY !

And on top of it, it freakin delivers with 5-star rainbow sprinkles. Beautiful character and world design, great animation, skill effects. Plenty of characters and each characters have distinct enough playstyle to make you want to play everyone. And THANK GOD it is actually possible to play everyone without burning your pockets or waiting for stars to align to play those characters. So, because this is a collection-RPG by design, i'll weight out this game like those type of games :

- Story : Good enough to make you pay attention to it and not skipping. Also, cutscenes & animations are top-notch. Soundtracks are a banger but sometimes a little bit too familiar with other JRPGS (no flair/unique)
- Character : Perfect. Yes, some character are stronger so there will be someone out there making tier-lists, but think about it like Monster-Hunter. Every character is great once you know how to use them.
- Grind : If you want to max everyone it's possible, but I think you need to focus on maybe 6-8 character you liked first so you don't feel the grind because your character Power Level kinda matters a lot. And there are some helpful tips like only recruit other character after you reach Lv 60 to save resource.
- Endgame Content : They already said to keep this game updated with content (new bosses, new characters, and stuff), but even without all that, I think this game already have a solid content to make it a full game and not live-service game in disguise.

Bottom line, I think this is an easy 8/10 game for general consensus. But it's 10/10 for me personal reason stated above. Not only that but you could also send a message to other game companies to make games like these.

Looks good, feels good. With no prior knowledge of Granblue Fantasy (except knowing that its a gacha game), this game has certainly impressed me. 
I would usually put a game down if it has not captured my interest within a few minutes, and this game has certainly done a fine job in retaining my interest.
The pacing is great, and combat is fun. It is not difficult, and certainly very forgiving in terms of its dodge timing, and it makes for a great casual hack'n'slash session.
There are many characters to use, each with their own unique skill, so it is enjoyable to switch around occasionally and find a specific playstyle to stick to.
The boss battles are times when you really go ham with your teammates, and those times, are really fun when it gets chaotic. 
Boss and skill animations is better than what I had expected, and cinematic is well done, along with the sound design.
As expected from an already well-established gacha game, the voice-acting is all up there.
Game has a pretty good in-game encyclopedia as well, letting you view things such a lore, character models, music, etc., which I think is great for players who are unfamiliar with GBF.

However, if I have to be critical, there are some nitpicks that I can point and feel out.
Facial expressions felt a little bit too static for how good the voice acting is. It makes everything feel a litte bit off... like it's missing some soul. The characters are lively in their body language, however the facial expression really brings the whole thing down a notch. I think its fine during cutscenes, but whenever there is dialogue (when there are dialogues boxes), it really feels "blank".
Boob physics, where are they?! I have my settings on MAX.
Environment. I think it is nice, but lacking some "life". Maybe more interaction between the characters and the environment would be nice. Something simple such as the foliage swaying against the wind or something, or when the characters bump onto them, causing them to move, would really give it a nice touch. If you look close enough, you can see the leaves move a little, but are just repeated back and forth animations and doesn't really feel like part of the area.
It is lacking things that makes me go "wow, I want to move towards there and take a look", the environment doesn't entice me enough to explore it. It doesn't incentivise me to look for things, for example, collectibles you can find, easter eggs, or hidden spots that has a nice scenery. It's a pity because I think that there is much potential in this point, but it's just there. I really wanted to pause and soak in the atmosphere, but I couldn't. And it could also be just a me thing, but passing through NPCs instead of bumping into them just feels out of place. And then, you have also NPCs (in a group) that have huge hitboxes... It's only some of them, but it semi-breaks the immersion. 
Companion/dating system. While it is not of utmost importance, it just feels like a missed opportunity. Relationship events, bonds, etc. I mean it came from a gacha game. I feel like this is a good chance allow players to experience more(?) 

Story-wise, I am currently enjoying it so far, but it just feels like I'm going along on a ride. It's not bad but, it just feels like it needed a little bit more punch. 
Combat is great though. Really, really good. The boss battles are epic, and it feels real good. Also, if you enjoyed playing Monster Hunter/God Eater type games, the gameplay loop will be right up your alley.

Great game.
Story length is about 10-12 hours. It's not a ground breaking story. It's safe, but well polished. The world itself is much more rewarding for people that have played the mobile game, but characters have fate episodes that gives insight into the playable characters.
The real meat to the game comes afterwards in missions that come in a Monster Hunter style gameplay loop of progression. Boss fights feel like a action RPG like Monster Hunter while also striking a medium with something like Final Fantasy XIV enemy AoE mechanics. 
Fights with enemies don't feel like reused despite several resources coming from reused assets. Fights stay fresh by ramping up the challenge with new ranks which comes with a fights that have a faster pace and new moves. There are different objectives than just fighting bosses as well such as surviving enemy waves or protecting an objective.

9.5/10

Let me grab your imagination: You're a young kid who just got their new console for Christmas, you run back home from school, burst through the doors into your house and plant yourself in front of the TV and you put in THE game, THE game that is different for everybody but we all know the feeling that it gave us. 

As stupid as this sounds, Granblue Fantasy: Relink reminded me of that exact feeling. 

This isn't for everyone, but for people that feel they've forgotten the wonder and enjoyment of gaming they used to have as a kid this might serve as a beautiful reminder.

10/10.

Devil May Cry combat, Genshin Impact graphics, Monster Hunter endgame & coop, Uncharted environmental destruction & action sequence.

This game seamlessly combined all the best elements from my favorite games. I just reached endgame and I see myself keep playing it for hundreds of hours just like what I did with Monster Hunter games.

The game is a lazy mess. If anything it's a gacha port in disguise. It has great voice work and the combat is a good (but flawed) system.

There is no Ultrawide support , no DLSS3, and very limited graphics options? 

Story is only 15-20 hours long and summed up is a on rails system of chase evil, defeat evil, evil evolve/defeat evil, evil evolve/defeat evil and OH NO Evil EVOLVE, what will we do.. defeat it? They took a page out of Destiny with characters backstory in a "Fate" system (which while voiced at least) is also lazy.

Quests boil down to beat boss (X monsters) in 2-3 min, and the constant can't beat boss because they so powerful trope during story, so fun! 

All this for the asking price of a AAA game. When you have good JRPG's like the Tales series, Star Ocean or even Dragon's Dogma, it's difficult to give this a pass.

Granblue Fantasy
The best game since this world has begun. forever

Update fixed the crashing so yay.
Anyways Granblue Fantasy: Relink is a brilliant masterpiece of a video game. The gameplay is so much fun and even more making builds. I was massing around and make a support tank build and it worked really well. Overall 9/10 game, only real problem is that you can't rebind controls on a controller in game which you can on a keyboard so yeah, I hope that can get added.

Gbf: Relink is clearly more lenient towards GBF mobile ver. players, this is because the story took place in the middle of the plot and not from the beginning ie: how Gran/Djeeta meet Lyria and the rest of the gang. But they do mention bits here and there which can be kind of helpful but may be confusing at the same time for the players who had never played GBF mobile ver. before.

Story wise, it's your very typical JRPG story where you can find it pretty much everywhere anywhere, it's not good but it's not bad either, pretty cliche plot if I must say. You can literally guess how the entire story going to end up. But hey, as a GBF mobile ver. player, the fact that I get to see the characters in 3D and capable of moving them around instead of just looking at a chibi ver. and clicking buttons, it's a nice feeling.

Game play wise, it's fun, every characters work differently and you need time to master them. The dodge and guard mechanics are the one that I find it the hardest to master, I just hate these mechanics overall because I enjoy being brain dead button mashing. Graphic is fantastic, the bloom, the shadow, the everything is just so colorful and fascinating to look at, not even joking. 

So I've seen some reviews that talks about censorship and localization. I am siding with the localization part, but not the censorship part. I find some of the lines the characters spoke and the translation be a bit off and it kinda honestly ruined my experience because I be like ??? and have to make sure what I listened from the voice actor/actress match up with what I am reading, which clearly they don't. But whatever, I couldn't careless about the conversation anyways. As for the censorship, I find it weird that some players are purchasing Gbf: Relink just to look at female characters' panties? Okay, hear me out, I am against censorship too but it depends on the game itself. This is because Gbf: Relink isn't a game that focus on fan-servicing so seeing some of the reviews complaining about this is just funny on my end. Games like Neptunia series, Senran Kagura series which is a fan-service type of JRPGs and if they get a censorship(which I believe some of the series did) I will just not bother and look for something else. Now that, is a bad censorship, but who would've thought people actually complained about not being able to see panties in Gbf: Relink when the game itself is mainly focusing on its gameplay, action, raids, and grinds. Kinda funny tbh. If you want to pay a price that is close to 3A games just to look at panties, you can spend this money onto Koikatsu Party instead, highly recommended!

I usually don't write reviews about games, but I love this game so much. I've been playing GBF since the JP release, following the franchise, and this is the best game to release so far.

WHY YOU SHOULD BUY THIS GAME:
++ Gameplay is a blend of fast-paced action and strategic depth
++ Cooperative multiplayer
++ Monster Hunter endgame grind
++ Bossing is so fun
++ Build your character how you want to play

The biggest negative... not getting the skin codes on Steam.

ALSO:

Characters are definitely not balanced, and without prior knowledge of the GBF "Skill -> Sigil" system, it's a learning curve for newer players.

... and yeah, make it easier to know if you are hitting damage cap.

While I was initially worried if it would run on steam deck, I'm happy to say it runs just fine. I play in windowed, with the frame limit at 40.

The game play loop feels rewarding, battles are fun, the variety of play styles each character has keeps things fresh, and grinding for materials to upgrade weapons doesn't feel like a chore. I honestly can't wait to get into post game content, and with news of free updates including "paid content" (I assume it'll be costumes) according to their road map, I can only get more hyped to see where this game goes.

I only have two gripes with the game so far, one being the lock on camera leaving much to be desired in terms of following the enemy, I also don't think we need the ability to lock on to objects in battle when free aiming at it would be fine. It got in the way while cycling through enemies, but that may just be me and my skill issues. Second is something Cygames might be workin on already which is the in-game keybinding options, not supporting controller inputs.

Other than that, rock solid game. The review bombing over the PS5 demo access and pre-order bonuses is the weakest argument against the game, that's Sony's hand at play so yell at them aggressively advertising Relink  for their platform. (Not that the bonuses were all that great) The "censorship" stuff is just as weak, just chill out and wait for modders to give you whatever it is you're after, it's not that serious people.

Since I love JRPG, this game was one that i was really expecting with high hype. 
But my hype was gone when i started to pay attention to story. The big major flaw of this game is TRANSLATION i have no idea who was the one who did it but i can assure you, THEY DO NOT KNOW JAPANESE. It's bad to the point when what they're saying make NO SENSE of what they're doing. 
In the early game Gran saves Lyria and after some time she say something around the lines:
"About what happened that time, i'd like to thank you for save me."
It was translated as:
"I HEARD what you did to save me...".
What??? "I HEARD" ..."I HEARD". Seriously, she's the one who was saved, she was literally there in the event, she DIDN'T heard what Gran did, she SAW him!!

Don't even make me talk about Fate Episodes. All fate episodes translation tells you a different story of what you hear and what you read.
For God's sake is a jRPG, focus on RPG, why the hell the translation is so bad?? It's even worse than Legend of Heroes series and they're awful in translate things.

So yeah translation is so bad that will make you confuse, if you don't read any line in game, maybe story will make more sense to you. I hope that some fan do a patch to a correct translation (I can dream, right?). Right now you can safe jump all text, trust me you're not losing anything.

A very competent action JRPG, but not perfect. Game looks great, and the combat is very satisfying with great boss fights, so the core of a great game is there. 

However, the game suffers from a very generic (and short) story, during which you cannot play co-op with your friends. While relative to other character action games there are a somewhat large selection of characters to choose from that all play meaningfully different from each other, the individual move pool for each character is pretty limited and will get repetitive very quickly unless you are constantly switching characters, which is unlikely unless you are spreading around your resources.

TL;DR If you are a big fan of the franchise or the genre, is probably well worth the full $60 price. However, if you are on the fence enough to be reading deep through reviews, wishlist it and wait for a sale.

Summary: 

Monster Hunter like game with a weak short story campaign before tedious replayable missions. Better looking and faster/smoother combat than MH. Lazy and uninspired progression with no equipment showing on characters. Craftable weapons and accessories with flat stat increases. No skins either.

Full review: 

I think there are some great things about this game but more negative that outweigh it for me. It’s beautiful to look at though every character looks like they are related, generic anime artstyle and design. And the combat feels responsive and fun. I do like a grindy replay-able gameplay loop in concept. The execution of the gameplay loop is what I don’t like. 

It is somewhat like Monster Hunter but you don’t make any actual equipment except weapons and accessories. What you craft has flat stat increases (boring). You can’t see any upgrades on your character to reward you for your progression. You’re grinding to get more power to kill more things faster but that’s it. You don’t ever get to eventually look like a badass monster hunter or hero. As far as I’m aware from what I’ve seen myself and through research, there is only some dye later for recolor.

The mission rank requirements often have stupid things like “kill with a thrown object 3 times”. The missions remind me of this Viva La Dirt League comedy skit about side quests in RPGs being randomly generated. 

The story is forgettable, this is the first single player game I’ve ever just started to skip every dialogue and cutscene because it was just boring and sometimes even annoying. Luckily it’s short. 

I could see myself playing it longer just to see if there is more on offer later but the things I already mentioned could easily make me just stop playing because that’s not rewarding enough for me.

Some of the best combat I've ever experienced, and maybe my favourite of any game. The game runs smoothly, all the characters have interesting kits and are fun to play. The gearing/customization system is good and gives you plenty to sink your teeth into if you so choose. 

The boss battles are fantastic, which makes the end game of doing them on repeat still an enjoyable experience. 

I love this game, worth the price of admission!

(WIP Review)
I've been waiting for this game ever since its 2016 announcement. 

After such a long wait, I remained cautiously optimistic. As a Granblue Fantasy fan, I know I'll like this game, but there's always the possibility that this can turn out to be a shallow cash grab or a broken mess considering this is Cygame's first internally developed AAA major release.

Now that the game is out. I'm actually completely blown away. It isn't just good. It actually turned out to be one hell of a fantastic experience, surpassing every expectation I had.

[h2] Story Mode [/h2]
Let's first address the big elephant in the room: the length of the story.
Depending on how much exploration, additional challenges, quest counter quests that you do, the campaign will take you about 10 to 20 hours to complete. 
This might seem extremely short for a JRPG but don't let this duration fool you. The story campaign is actually only roughly 10% of the total content that this game has to offer. 
The "real game" begins after the credits roll. 

Also, while the story itself is short, and the writing is also quite generic, it more than makes up for it by having superb production quality and is filled to the brim with epic cinematic set piece moments. The short duration also means the pacing is extremely tight and never feels like it's dragging on. There is zero down time and I'm constantly being blown away by each subsequent chapter offering an even more impressive set piece moment than the one before.

Don't let the short duration fool you. It is a really epic journey absolutely worth experiencing.

This story is also stand-alone and there are additional optional side stories to explain what came before so you don't really need any prior knowledge about the franchise.

[h2] Quest Mode [/h2]
This is the real main meat and potato of this game and supports up to 4-player online co-op.
While you unlock quest counter relatively early in the game, you have very limited selection of quests you can do.
The game truly opens up after rolling the credits, and it turns into a monster hunter questing structure. All the epic boss fights you've experienced in story mode can now be challenged with up to 3 other friends.
I'm currently relatively early in quest mode but the game director has confirmed there to be more than 100 quests to tackle. People who have fully beaten the game also said that you can easily sink more than 100 hours into this game, depending on how deep you want to delve into it. 

Questing feels rewarding as you're always earning valuable materials, experience or currencies. The quest themselves are also tightly paced so they never feel like they drag on for too long, making material farming that much more enjoyable.

[h2] Playable Characters [/h2]
This is one of the biggest highlight. There are a total of 19 playable characters (including the secret unlockable character you get at the end of the story), and all of them play with a unique style. This is an extremely impressive roster size. 
In a typical JRPG, we'd usually see around 4~8 playable characters on average. This game has double that amount.

All the characters also have very varied voice lines and interaction with other characters in the party during combat sequence. Even the non-story characters (the ones exchanged using tickets) have unique lines to say during story chapters, making it interesting to revisit story mode as different characters later on to see what they all have to say.

Most importantly, they all feel good to play as.

[h2] Summary [/h2]
This game surprised me in the most pleasant way possible, and is some of the most fun online co-op action experience I've had in a long time. It is like a wonderful hybrid of character action game combat + monster hunter questing structure + JRPG story. The only issue I had was one instance of crash at the end of chapter 1 (which I worked around by switching the game to windowed mode to get past that segment), but the game has since then been patched and I've not experienced any more technical issues since then. I've also not experienced any noticeable bug during gameplay. The level of polish and production quality are way higher than expected.

Once upon a time, in a world much like our own but peppered with a sprinkle of magic, there lived a peculiar duck named Daffy. Daffy was no ordinary duck. For starters, he had a bright blue beak that glowed in the dark and a penchant for wearing polka-dotted bow ties. Daffy lived in the quaint little town of Quackville, known far and wide for its magical mishaps and goofy inhabitants.

One sunny morning, Daffy decided he wanted to bake the world's largest pancake. Why? Because it was Tuesday, and in Daffy's mind, Tuesdays were perfect for doing something extraordinary. So, he set out to find the ingredients, waddling his way through the town with a shopping list that read: "Eggs – lots, Flour – tons, Milk – a small lake’s worth, and Magic sprinkles – just a dash."

His first stop was at the bustling Quackville market, where he purchased enough eggs to make the chickens gossip for days. Next, he visited the windmill on the edge of town for flour. The miller, a wise old owl named Oliver, upon hearing Daffy's plan, couldn't help but hoot with laughter. "A pancake that large will need a magic touch," Oliver advised, handing Daffy a bag of enchanted flour.

With all the ingredients gathered, Daffy returned home, only to realize he had forgotten one tiny detail – he didn't have a pan large enough to cook the world's largest pancake. Unperturbed, Daffy enlisted the help of his best friend, a magical squirrel named Squeaky, who had the power to transform objects into different sizes.

Together, they transformed Daffy’s swimming pool into a gigantic pancake pan. The whole town of Quackville gathered to watch as Daffy and Squeaky mixed the ingredients using a canoe as a stirring spoon. When it was time to flip the pancake, Daffy, with a sprinkle of magic and a dash of courage, commandeered a trampoline and executed a flawless somersault, flipping the pancake mid-air to the cheers of the amazed crowd.

The pancake was a resounding success, and Daffy declared a town feast. The pancake was so large that it fed the townsfolk for days, with leftovers still to spare. The day was marked in Quackville’s history as "The Great Pancake Day," celebrated every year with pancakes and a town-wide trampoline contest, all thanks to the goofy ambition of a duck with a bright blue beak and a love for Tuesdays.

And so, Daffy’s tale became a legend in Quackville, a story of how a duck’s whimsical idea brought a town together, proving that sometimes, the goofiest ideas can lead to the most delightful outcomes.

I don't write review on Steam but I have to do this, for myself as a fan of gbf and everyone else that's coming into the game fresh. Do note that this might be a bias review coming from an experienced mobile game player for many years. I have been waiting for this game since it was teased years ago and it's finally here

I cleared the main story and starting to do maniac level on coop as of writing. I will try my best to keep this review as spoiler free as possible. Lets start with :



Complaints

- This is my biggest one, where there is no map or mini map available in the game (that navigation compass thing on the top doesn't help especially in back alley in the bigger town). Things like knowing where is the locked treasure chests, the location of omens that I missed, collecting notes and  "stuff" would be a lot easier with a map or mini map available

- Some bosses require players to broke X amount of parts but the broken parts indication on monster is not obvious enough that most of the time I have no idea if the part we are attacking is broken or not (in my opinion, Monster Hunter did a very good job at this, its very easy to tell if the monster parts is broken or not)

- This is probably just me but I can't sort filter on side quest to set it to show completed side quests on top first and this annoyed me as hell. Also although it was nice that we can fast travel to the npc to report the completed quest, I wish we can fast travel across other town as well (cygames might as well let us do this since we are teleporting anyway, why must we have to be in the same town to teleport to the said npc?)

- Although they already added assist and full assist mode in the setting to help with non experienced players, I still wish to play the main story on coop with my friends since most of the time I'm travelling with a party of 4 throughout the main quest anyway simply because I wanted to enjoy the game with friends that waited for this game to release for many years

- I wish they make the cpu a little smarter because eventhough cpu have superior element against the monster or bosses, they don't  know how to be the first to trigger the ougi. This will help a lot since the first to ougi is the one who will be deciding the elements of the whole chain burst so we are losing a huge chunk of damage when not doing superior elemental damage to the monster



The good stuff

- Luckily enough my experience since the beginning is smooth. I have never encounter any crash, lag, etc that a lot of people been complaining since the game releases on steam

- Epic boss battle and epic boss battle! This is so good that I'm constantly amazed at it and also the last boss fight is super epic that I almost cry due to that epicness! 

- The characters are unique on their own which makes the gameplay very fun! With more coming in future dlc, I wish we can get some playable primal characters from huge gbf rosters. I just want to see them wreak havoc in the map! (Zooey waifu, please come home!) Yes, I also know that a lot of people are demanding the flying potato to be playable too

- If you're like me who wonder around in town and truly enjoy the world itself, the npc in town actually have little progression on their story every time you clear a new chapter of the main story and back to the town. These kind of titbits in rpg is amazing and I like it alot 

- The beautiful art, the world, the bustling town, everything is so alive and I feel like I finally get to experience gbf world inside out since the mobile game is in 2D. So this experience is just out of the world for me

- Great soundtrack and bgm that I already taken for granted since I'm expecting nothing less than that. Yes, it will get repetitive when you grind through the coop but it's still great music regardless

- Finally we get voiced Djeeta in the story! To be honest it was really good but also feels weird at the same time because we don't get much voiced Djeeta in the mobile game



As for the conclusion, I wholeheartedly recommend this game to those who enjoy playing jrpg and also action games. Some might say the main story is short but I would prefer it to be shorter and epic rather than dragged long and boring. After all this was meant to be like Monster Hunter where you clear the story and then enjoy more epic fights in the end game (grinding included). As a fan of gbf, I wish this game can make it to the top and shine!

I very surprised with this game. It is worth every penny, imo. Mostly everything in the game can be earned 'in-game'.

What I disliked: The camera feels a bit slow when turning during fights, but that is my only con for now.

What I expect in the FUTURE: Really all the games has to do is add more of what is already in the game such as adding more characters, skills, cosmetics, new zones, Hard modes, and most of all more Boss fights.

The story (quite short as is) is sub par however the localization is absolute trash which drags it down to trash tier, not the first time I've seen a situation like this but dang this one is REAL BAD. Lots of phrases are tweaked to just be nonsense to the point where I'd prefer machine translations, I can't even picture the audience this would be localized for.

"I can't walk anymore"
"Same, my dogs are barking"
Yes, it's that bad - these people are terrible at their job.

Kinda funny because they could have saved money and made the game better at the same time by just machine translating and not applying the minor censorship. No need spending money for a whole set of voice lines reading the trash that the localizers vomited up or giving us a custom version - just give english menus plus some semi-decent subtitles and the people who buy these games will be mostly happy.

Save money + happier customers = bigger profits! Capitalism ho!

This game is a reason a simple yes/no makes zero sense for a review, so while I do recommend the game it has problems.

So the good part is, the game looks nice, especially the 3d anime cutscenes.  Story doesn't drag on with dialogue and usually gets you into the action.  Multiplayer worked for me and a friend, but we are in the same region.

The combat is simple to get into, but has depth.  The boss fights are basically MMO boss fights, so there is a lot of mechanics and changing mechanics.  Its not monster hunter, but I understand the comparisons since a lot of content is fighting these multi-stage boss encounters.  Trash fights are not as interesting, but fills the *warriors itch.  Getting high ranks on quest board missions is a good time.  The game is hella fun if you enjoy fights with actual mechanics and not just mash button gameplay.  

The bad edited: Seems to have mostly been fixed, they even added dualsense compat because I had some trigger action on the ships cannons today.			

This game was not meant to be played with an erratic freelook, but it doesn't excuse the fact that using a mouse is the antithesis of enjoyability.  You expect more control with a mouse than you do an analog stick, and it ends up feeling clunky and unresponsive no matter what sensitivity or setting you use.  Controls wise the game would actually play better on KBM, since it allows you to bind controls that are behind layers on controller, but mouselook is just so damn bad that the experience is kind of ruined.


So while I play games for fun, and I enjoy this game enough to endure whatever problems it has.  These problems shouldn't exist, especially not the controller issue. If you enjoy games that provide some challenge I would suggest you endure as well.  You're gonna be in for a good time.  Optimizing these fights such that I take zero damage is exciting, and doing it with a friend makes it even better.

[h1]Why did I go with GBF Relink over Persona 3 Reload, Yakuza or Suicide Squad? [/h1]

✅Great voice acting -  ENG is surprisingly good and JP is made up of Pro's.
✅Challenging gameplay - It is grindy and you will think that it's just button mashing beating down everything as if it was a musou game but once you get to proud mode (The last difficulty) it gets exceedingly harder and parties will wipe. Once you beat the boss after struggling and trying multiple parties and builds it feels ecstatic, a satisfying sense of accomplishment. 
✅Unique character gameplay which will reward you greatly if you master them and the skill tree gives you option to fit in different play styles with just one character.
✅Works on steam deck but would rather use a more comfortable controller.
✅Great visuals anime style
✅Nothing "woke" was ever mentioned, which is a positive for any game.
✅$60 release as opposed to the cringe $70 default by Corpos that releases AAA titles.
✅No Denuvo
⛔️Terrible Localization. You can never learn Japanese when the subtitles have zoomer catch lines.
⛔️High PC requirements will cause headaches for some people

8/10
This is AMAZING

Solid Game overall. Basically a mix of Monster Hunter (gameplay loop), Xenoblade (combat/party and character diversity) and heavily inspired by Final Fantasy (many systems, story/lore, themes etc) 
Pros:
- Fluid Combat
- Decent graphics with very pleasant art style and good character facial animations
- Large character variety and even larger pool of characters in original base game to potentially add to Relink
- Flashy and satisfying animations
- Decent amount to grind that can be done co-op or solo
- Auto battle feature like the gacha game ;^)

Cons:
- Disgustingly bad English subtitles even with the very limited Japanese knowledge
- Story is pretty meh/cliche and a bit drawn out towards the end, they should of just started the story from the very beginning, a bit of disservice to newer players of this franchise
- Menu'ing can be a bit tedious 
- Issue with 12th gen CPU causing blackscreen on launch + game to stop responding during specific cut scenes. Work around was disabling e-cores in bios or downloading process lasso

What if a hack and slash action game was also ffxiv raid bosses and once you finish the somewhat short but very fun 11-ish our campaign suddenly became an open postgame that progresses like a classic monster hunter game with multiplayer quests to progress through to constantly have new heights to aspire to and have more things to do with your character, and that's assuming in the postgame you only wanna take one character into multiplayer and don't wanna mix up and experiment.

gameplay 10/10

epic boss fights

- fleshed out systems (progression, combos, characters, team comps, even the communication system, etc.)
- QoL (you can open chests while sliding down sand dunes. i was surprised).
- decent cast of characters with varying playstyles. 
- somewhat difficult. i'm playing on the hardest difficulty and most of the challenge is trying to tell what's happening behind all of the visual effects during combat.
- combat is smooth and satisfying, especially when compared to other action anime games. 
- characters are charming. not too sure on their depth and development (there are fate episodes which is basically learning about specific characters).
- exploring is fun and rewarding
- zeta and ferry are cute. io too.

some issues i have:

- dialogue during bossfights. thankfully, most of the dialogue isn't important
- story is whatever. don't play for the story.
- AI companions aren't bad at all, but... there will be times when they die. and if they die too often or you're too slow to revive them, you're forced to restart the fight. doesn't matter how well YOU dodge, counter, etc. there are ways to prevent this from happening though, it was just annoying the 2-3 times it happened.
- commissions lack enemy variety. i just finished chapter 6 and basically you take a mission and fight an enemy you already fought. not only that, commissions also have sub goals like "kill X amount of enemies, kill X enemy, etc." the only one that's actually bad is "complete mission within 2 minutes." the fact is, a lot of the mini boss/boss enemies have time waster phases. 

this game has been really fun. i hope it warrants some kind of sequel or DLC.

UPDATE 2: About 30 hours in, finished postgame story (entered actual endgame as the last difficulties are unlocked after this). This game gets the monster hunting formula spot on, the build flexibility is awesome, the character (weapon) variety is great and each character is complex enough to make grind sessions interesting. I wish there were more ranged characters though.

The story is nothing out of the ordinary, acts as a spin-off to granblue fantasy's main story, happening in-between the main adventure. The boss fights go from plain at first to really fun at mid to late story, especially the latter fights.
Everything is dubbed, which is barely talked about at this point, as if it was granted. The localization has been a hot topic of discussion but I find it good enough. People would have a meltdown if Lowain was in the game (I love lowain).
The music and visuals are really good, they translate the feeling of the mobile game which is the point.

Matchmaking got fixed with the last update, so they need to work on what was described below as many still rely on fixes to run the game to begin with. But I have faith this game can be a banger in the monster hunting genre, somehow. I hope they make expansions for it.

UPDATE: Found a fix by setting process priority to high, this unexplainable fixes all freezes, most common freeze spots I could find up to chapter 5 proceed without issue. Now that I can actually play the game, I can say it's good, but they really need to get to patching these. Finding fixes took a whole day.

---
I've been affected by freezes since starting the game. You must NOT TOUCH ANY INPUT until the main game logo shows up, or else the screen will freeze. 
In-game, several cutscenes starting from the airship scene leaving the first town (mid-tutorial, or so I imagine) will freeze unless skipped. Meaning I have to skip scenes in a 60 bucks game just to be able to play.

GPU usage is abnormally high, the game should not be choking on a 3070 this hard.
I hope they address these issues soon, because I have been wanting to play this for years.
You can look up more examples of scenes crashing, while also finding troubleshooting steps like running in dx12, not going fullscreen, changing graphic settings... none worked for me.

At this point I'm afraid to try more because I'm close to the refund policy threshold.

I hope I can change this review to something positive eventually.
I love this game, and i NEED even more content EXPANDING the roster AND PLAYABLE STORY. This is worth every cent its sold for.

The game is fanstastic, but it still have some issues.
For once, the main story is painfully generic. Like, awfully so. The pacing is not great and the way some of the characters act feel so cliche it hurts. 
Localization is, however, not one of the issues. A lot of "tourists" as the GBF calls those that are newcomers to the franchise and are unaware of the story in the gacha game think that the localization of the game is flawed (and this is ok), and has been influenced by whatever the hell "western values" means. Truth is, the localization for the Gacha is very similar, as both are done in-house by Cygames. The localization is exactly the one the devs intended and have intended for the last 9 years. 
That aside, the gameplay is fantastic if you are looking for something that scratches your MonHun itch. Like in most MH titles, the game is structured in a similar fashion, with a very easy story serving as a fantastic tutorial for the actual hard endgame content. Around proud difficulty it starts to genuinely pick up. Likewise, the fights, which start quite simple, wildly escalate out of control and become absurd in the best of meanings. 
I've been waiting for years for this game, and they delivered.

I've been patiently waiting for a game that is aRPG with the addition of being allowed to play with friends, after playing multiple aRPG games throughout the last 3-4 years, its been evident that the experience could be elevated by involving an aspect of multiplayer/co-op.

This game has proved that exact statement, its one of those games that was stuck in development hell for almost 7 years but comes out prevailed keeping the same fundamental ideas and grounded approach to what makes RPG games great. With the addition of co-op i find myself playing this game for endless hours and the additional announcements of new characters and content to be added in the coming months.

This would be one of those games that you would believe would surface from being live-service but that mode never usually works out for most games and im glad that this game isn't a live service, produce content every 4-5 months or have the same model as MH with big expansions giving you the incentive to come back to the game... I would find myself being more inclined to the later

Overall the game is great, it had its problems with the multiplayer region lock but it seems that the developers are doing their very best to improve the pc experience. I did bump into a few crashes in cutscenes that would have me restarting chapters because it was during a cutscene but it never deterred me from pushing through it so that i can continue enjoying the game.

This game caught me by surprise.  I have known of Grandblue and tried to get into the gatcha but never stuck.  I didn't hear about this until about a month before launch and became pessimistically excited. I grabbed it and am now on chapter 7.  I must say it is fantastic.  The english voice cast is way better than I would have expected.  The performance from me is amazing, not a single dip, pop in, tear, etc.  The combat is good enough, but the variance between the difference characters is where it shines.  Each character is super unique and fun to learn and play.  The boss battles are some of the best in this type of game I have fought in a while.  The latest chapter had me giddy with excitement as I took them on.  Highly recommend grabbing this one.

An excellent action-RPG that is perhaps a little light on content for the casual player, but has a lot of post-game content and character-specific things to grind for to entertain those who want to keep coming back.
Features online co-op for up to four players in non-story missions, but the party AI is actually competent enough that you can consider playing with others optional if you're committed to playing this solo (or if you're picking this up many years from now after the playerbase has died down).

Pros:
[list]
    [*]Beautiful visuals and overall spectacle. The vast majority of cutscenes are done in-engine too so you never feel as though you're "taken out of it" in the middle of, or between fights by jumps in visual fidelity.
    [*]Eighteen different playable characters each with their own unique playstyle.
[*] Responsive and satisfying action-RPG gameplay.
    [*]An excellent soundtrack.
[*] Very likeable character cast, albeit one-dimensional.
[*] Lots of post-game stuff to grind. The game doesn't stop at the credits!
[/list]
Cons:
[list]
    [*]Only 6 of the 18 characters (the ones you start with) have any story relevance. All the rest at best contribute with a little bit of unique story mission dialogue (which in and of itself is actually nice attention to detail).
    [*]Somewhat light on content if you have no interest in the post-game grind or doing side-content (somewhere in the realm of 15-20 hours).
    [*]The plot is incredibly generic and doesn't try to subvert or remix common JRPG tropes/story beats in the slightest. The spectacle is top-notch, but don't expect anything that will stick with you in any capacity in the long run.
[*] English localisation is unnecessarily divergent and injects a lot of quirkiness (i.e., modern-marvel-movie-style quips) into the dialogue where it doesn't need to be. Even someone like me who doesn't understand Japanese beyond a few stock anime phrases was able to notice this.
[/list]

Edit 2: Post 1.0.4 update I am assuming that the game breaking cutscene crash has been fixed as no one has mentioned it in any discussions since, due to this I am changing my rating to the well-deserved positive as I had said I would. Now that the issue preventing me from doing so has been removed I can happily recommend the game as it is Incredibly fun and look forward to seeing how much further it will go.
Edit 1: I'd like to simply put here that there is a workaround for the cutscene crash. I replicated this from another user, restart your PC(at least once since you started having the crash) and play through that boss fight without ever plugging in the controller, and once you reach the cutscene skip is as quickly as physically possible. HOPEFULLY it works, as soon as you are back in the normal game you can plug the controller back in(if you have it) and resume normal play. This does not change my review, as the problem is still a Problem, but I thought I would just try and see if I could help others get around it until they fix the cutscene crash.
Original review:
Oh dear god how I wish I could just slap a thumbs up and call this a good game. Because it really is, it just has some very. VERY bad problems that prevent me from recommending it IN IT'S CURRENT STATE.
Crashes during cutscenes, Various with extremely unpredictable triggers(including a nigh unavoidable(actually unavoidable for me and a few others) hard crash that is guaranteed to trigger instantly at the post final boss' cutscene). [Absolute definition of "game-breaking" bugs]
The rare frame drops are confusing but minor annoyances at worst.
The PC port is... Quite janky, especially with the never-sufficiently-hated aim acceleration that makes all mouse movements very floaty and hard to be precise with. Thankfully I do have a controller for just these kinds of games, but for those without that luxury it WILL be a problem.
there are a few smaller issues but those are the ones I most noticed through my nearly 12 hour playthrough, mostly in one sitting, in which I have technically "beaten" the main story, minus of course the aforementioned complete inability to progress beyond the unavoidable crash cutscene..
Please Cygames fix at least the cutscene crashes as soon as is reasonable. I REALLY want to change this review to positive and will do so as soon as it's fixed.

This game is possibly one of, if not THE, funnest Action RPGs of all time. I heavily enjoyed Cygames' previous foray into action RPGs with Dragalia Lost and have been playing Granblue Fantasy for almost three years now. Granblue is a series that is near to my heart, and this game captures the charm of Granblue while combining it with the gameplay of Dragalia, Xenoblade, FFXIV, and heck, even Warriors games to create the funnest action RPG I've played in ages. 

The game combines action really well with the teambuilding and strategy of Granblue with things like grid building being in this game with the Sigil system, but it is much easier for newer players to understand. This game is also very beginner-friendly to the Granblue or Cygames-verse and doesn't require much supplemental reading, however I would suggest reading the first 30 chapters of the gacha game, a summary of them, or watching the anime that is up for free on Youtube to at least understand the characters, however the game also explains their backstories through fate episodes, so you won't be left in the dark if you haven't played Granblue before.

Overall, this is one of the best games I've played for gameplay and I can not WAIT for more content like Seofon or Faa-san.

An excellent cross between MonHun, PSO, and Stranger of Paradise. The story actually has surprisingly good moments, and of course an excellent soundtrack by the legendary Nobuo Uematsu. Online play is fun, the characters are all very different from one another with unique playstyles and gameplay mechanics. The open world zones are nice, but used sparingly. The online quests seem to be much smaller in scale, unfortunately.

The story rounds off about a pleasant 15-20 hours or so, with an extensive amount of post-game content to keep players going for another couple hundred hours.

First of all, I want to say I have never played GBF series before. I just jumped in because ppl around me who do play is excited about this.

One thing I appreciated is that it is a complete game, I'm glad it didn't take anything from the live-service crap many other studios are doing, and I kinda feel excited to learn that there will be more DLC characters in the future.

I really liked the combat too, it boil downs to 2 button combo but it's still fun especially with the help from your party members, where they're not a showpiece like most games and actually do stuff. Chain ult is very cool, it does gives me the "fantasy" party vibe and I loved it.

However, There are 3 different systems on just 1 single weapon, let along you have multiple weapons on a character, and each character all came with all sorts of other grinds like sigils and msp. Like I said I never played GBF before, I did not know it was like this. I'm OK with JRPGs with stats leveling and comfortable with farming some super rare materials, but this game is just too much. It is more grindy than MH, and MH was at my sweet spot in terms of needed grind.

The true deal-breaker for me is that you cannot unlock all playable characters unless you play online-mode (repetitive contents recycled from campaign), it's not like you can't play at all, but some stages like the one where you had to pick up coins, and since NPCs only follows you, you will not get the desired reward for playing through the whole mission.

I still like it tho, I won't recommend it to anyone like me who don't enjoy too much grind, but I might pick it back up during sales to finish the campaign because it is indeed fun to play.

A solid 7 out of 10 game in my mind. Solid.

Fun combat that's just a tad too simplistic and stat-dependant for my liking; Fun bosses that are just a tad too reminiscent of MMORPGs for my liking; Exciting story mode that's just a tad too cutscene-heavy for my liking.
That said, the visuals are flat-out gorgeous and it runs like a dream.
Oh also! Kudos for not featuring an incredibly obnoxious character in the primary cast, that's a rare quality these days.

I hope the devs will continue to add more quests and especially more boss fights to the game, because as it stands it's a Monster Hunter-lite ARPG that boasts the amount of bosses appropriate for a one-and-done singleplayer affair. Which is to say too few for this format.

Again, very fun game, but without further support I personally would consider it somewhat middling at this point, despite having enjoyed it quite a bit. 

Hopefully Dragon's Dogma 2 will reach the heights I was hoping this game would aim for after all those years of dev time.

I'm not sure why they decided to only make the ps5 editions have half decent bonuses for special and deluxe edition.

I bought this on a whim and never really expected it to leave an impression on me, but I fell in love with it after only a few hours. It's like a wonderful book you've always dreamed of reading, but never really thought it could exist. And suddenly it is in your hands, and it's even better than you've hoped for.

If final fantasy was a gotcha game + monster hunter with a dash of polish and minus predatory live service had a baby... this game would be it!

Although the colour pack 1 not included in the special edition is a weird move but ok...?

Jokes aside, The game is beautiful! Story is a little short but interestingly fun... Gameplay is fun! NPC party members are not brain-dead obstacles! Every character is unique! I hope there will be more contents, missions, characters, items, expansions down the line <3

TL:DR - 9/10

P.S. i don't usually make reviews so this game is exceptional!

Wow, just wow. If you are on the fence about getting this game due to the few low reviews (because they had a few issues on launch) or the $60 price tag, I have to tell you - just f*cking get it. The story is so rich and absolutely phenomenal. For this game to be this polished as a first release is so impressive. The graphics are gorgeous, the play style is so much fun, and there are so many characters to choose from and you can easily switch between them for a different play style (IF you get bored). This game does a beautiful job of blending together all the best parts of so many different kind of games - it pulls from JRPGs for the story and mechanics, it gives Fire Emblem/Final Fantasy with the skill tree and equipment upgrading, and it gives Monster Hunter world with the questing style of including CO-OP to play with your friends. This is the kind of game that you itch to play and provides so many hours of game play. 10/10 best game of 2024!
This is the greatest game of all time, I have been playing almost nonstop for days already and will continue to play more and more. Can't wait for updates!

This game is really incredible for action RPG enjoyers. It does have a feel of monster hunter with the big bosses you fight as a team as well as some beat'em up elements when you fight hoards of goblins, soldiers etc. Sometimes both as the same time!

The game starts easy, but the difficulty grows as you go along, and sometimes you might hit a wall and need to strengthen your character. Strengthening your characters feels REAL good, you can definitely see the power of your character increase allowing you to overcome tougher bosses you may not have been able to beat before. And there's a lot of ways to improve such as mastery tree, strengthening weapons, strengthening sigils, imbueing weapons etc. 

There are a lot of bosses, but there's no denying you will be fighting some same bosses with different element or twists to them. So if you get tired of fighting the same boss and grinding, this may affect your enjoyment. I don't mind personally as I want higher scores and better rewards.

I recommend this game if you enjoy progression games like monster hunters, and action games like devil may cry, and of course to any Granblue Fantasy fan.

Feels like playing PSO, or a less gachafied Dragalia Lost. Story's okay, a bit cliche, but it does a good job of filling you in on the relative details and terms from the original game's setting. Excellent music, and it feels like the area designers really had a field day. The story took me about ~15 hours to beat, with some really good setpieces and good atmosphere, and I'm looking forward to sinking my teeth into a pretty substantial grindy postgame.

Like 15 years on Steam and maybe a thousand games, and I don't think I've ever, ever left a review for a game. I'm not a GBF fan at all, and was a bit down on the reviews before launch. But the art/animation and what I thought was another entry in my favorite genre (JRPG) motivated me to buy anyway... and this game is simply fun. Fun. Remember fun?

Look, the story is as barebones as it gets. Which is a shame, because it's clear there's a lot of quality lore and franchise history to pull from. The sidekick character is utterly awful to listen to. And the game lacks a good amount of PC settings, has limited frame rate support, and zero ultra wide support (though, it is relatively well optimized, I'll give it that).

But everything else? It's great. It's got high quality character action and stands toe to toe with Platinum's best. It's got more JRPG elements (gear, leveling, systems, parties, etc.) than the newest Final Fantasy. Its world is beautiful. The music is exceptional. The art and graphics are S-Tier. The world, while relatively linear, feels grand and alive. And the combat and boss battles are incredible. And apparently the end game brings PSO/MH-levels of hunting and grinding. Can't wait!

This game is unexpectedly good, and more importantly, a lot of fun. Why unexpectedly? Well, the original Granblue Fantasy is a mobile game, and those rarely spawn solid non-mobile sequels/spinoffs. 
What hooked me right away was the quality of the art (when you look into the distance, and especially at the skyboxes, it looks like they were oil paintings), the VFX, and especially so the soundtrack. Man, the soundtrack.

It manages to be a very competent JRPG with action (!!!) combat. Yes, it does suffer from the stereotypical 'numbers must get bigger exponentially' syndrome, but when playing the story mode for the first time, that's barely noticeable. If you just upgrade your weapons and unlock skills, you'll get through it just fine if you're a somewhat competent player.

The leftovers from the mobile game are, as far as I can tell, things like the Fate Episodes, which, in essence, give you backstory for each of the unlockable and playable characters, with slight stat increases as rewards or sometimes additional gear slots. Unlike the cutscenes in the rest of the game they aren't animated, but mostly text scrolls, which I felt was a little out of place and made me want to simply skip through them to get the stat buffs. The other major thing is how you unlock additional characters, in some sidequests you get Crew Tickets, which you can use at a trader to recruit new characters. The selection is decent and pretty much 50/50 m/f, so you don't end up 'collecting' 'just' women like in other JRPGs (unless you choose to).

Another highlight for me, is how the entire main story is fully voiced. Every cutscene, every little conversation, all of it. This adds very solid value when compared to other games where the characters just speak about half of the first sentence in every conversation. The quality of the (japanese) VA is impeccable, with some pretty big talents all around. I usually fast-forward through JRPG dialogue, here I actually wanted to go through it normally because of the voice-acting.

My two major gripes are to do with the plot, and the crabs. The goddamn crabs. They've hidden at least 45 crabs throughout the world and there is an accessory which grows in power based on how many crabs you have found. You end up turning over each and every metaphorical rock, smashing any destructibles you come across, in hopes of there being just one more damned crab.
The plot made me want to reach through my monitor to smack some sense into some of the characters. The villains are comical (even for anime standards), the main characters are daft as heck (pretty standard for anime), and sadly three quarters of the game are spent just with those kind of engagements. Maybe this means I actually cared about the plot somewhat, I'm not sure.

Some of the boss fights are pretty incredible as well. With hints of MGS: Revengeance and a dash of FFXIV.
Occasionally missions change up the usual action combat by giving you special 'conditions', I won't go into details for spoiler reasons but they felt amazingly well timed and refreshing whenever they did come around.

I don't really write reviews but I think this game deserves it. Based on my progress I estimate around 20 hours for the main story and basically all side-missions. Afterwards you unlock a higher difficulty to play through it all once more, as well as the ability to revisit story maps if you want to 100% the collectibles and unlocks. So probably around at least 50-ish hours if you want to have seen everything the game has to offer at least once. There's also 'Monster Hunter'-esque multiplayer.

The pricetag is somewhat of a downer, but considering I went into this game fully expecting yet another mediocre JRPG with the qualities of a trash port, I don't regret paying full AAA money for this.

I've seen some people say this is essentialy Genshin without the gacha and I disagree, the combat here has way more to offer than Genshin could ever aspire to.

The game runs perfectly fine on my system (R7 5700X, 32GB Ram, RTX 4070Ti) and I've only experienced a single crash, where the game froze during a cutscene, reloading fixed it.

On my completely arbitrary, and not at all inspired by IGN, rating-scale I'd give this game an 8.5/10. 
Definitely a great game for what it is, and yet another great game at the start of this year.
Love it

This game could be a good recommendation if not for the loads of issues surrounding it (Some of which I predicted correctly, as it's CyGames we are talking about, and their reputation with ports and localizations have gone down the drain lately).

[list]
[*] Strange localization decisons regarding adding slang and whedonesque writing where there were previously none in the Japanese script, and some character costume changes that were obviously done thanks to Sony's horseshit. Why they felt like they needed to add the whedonesque quips, a reference to Smokey Bear's slogan in one of the quest names, and a Donald Trump MAGA reference in another is beyond me, but literally nobody finds it charming.

[*] Mouse emulating an analog stick, apparently doesn't play nice on non-US layout keyboards. No way to turn off the obnoxious mouse smoothing.

[*] No mouse input in menus. You have to mess around with WASD, Enter, and the left mouse button to navigate anywhere.

[*] No ultrawide or 16:10 support, hardcoded resolution options. You only have the choice of 720p, 900p, 1080p, 1440p, or 2160p, and the game doesn't take whatever display resolution you have. There's more people using ultrawide and 16:10 displays than there are 2160p display users, so the "muh market share" argument makes zero sense when you consider that most of these 3D games can support arbitrary resolutions and aspect ratios very easily (or at least with some oversight).

[*] Limited graphics options, no DLSS3/XeSS/FSR3, performance could be better. 

At 1080p and max settings, performance isn't bad, but could definitely be better. Performance is about the same on my desktop with a RX 6900XT and i5-13600K, but at 1440p instead of 1080p. I will at least say that GPU Sync (as shown in Intel PresentMon is close to the amount of time it takes to draw a frame (Which is a good thing), and from my time looking at a few frame captures in RenderDoc, nothing egregious shows up at first glance. It does not hold a rock solid 120FPS on my gaming laptop at 1080p at least, but it’s still better than the PS5 version performance wise. The game barely even hits a rock solid 30FPS during gameplay with the lowest possible graphics settings at 720p on the Steam Deck, at least without mods.

[*] Only goes up to 120FPS (although I will commend the developers on using doubles for their framelimiter instead of floats or integers, so it's really precise and doesn't have nearly as many rounding errors), and the physics become more stiff the higher you go from 30FPS (Y'know despite the developers shipping the game with a 60FPS performance target in mind lol).

[*] No PlayStation prompts despite claiming the game has native support on the Steam page (apparently you have to disable SteamInput for this, but from my testing, it doesn't work with my DualSense). People claim it has SteamInput support, but no, it’s just using XInput emulation that comes with SteamInput already. The game technically only supports Xbox controllers out of the box.

[*] Cutscenes constantly freezing and softlocking the game. I have personally stumbled across this issue once so far.

[*] It's crashing for a bunch of people and refusing to start up for others. A couple patches have released to help this, but startup times are still abnormally long.

[*] Region locking for matchmaking based on the current region that is selected for downloading games on Steam (WTF). As a result, matchmaking takes forever.
[/list]
Either this game was stuck in development hell and it shows, the PC port wasn't ready and CyGames did not release a demo on PC for that reason (something to hide), or from their past record with mediocre PC releases on Steam they don't give a single shit about UX on PC. There's no reason the game should be in the state it's in for $60-80, even if the game underneath was absolutely worth the 6 year wait. These things absolutely mar an otherwise great game in the year of 2024.

Now with the current issues out of the way, the game looks nice, has fast loading times (outside of when the game starts up where it takes it’s sweet time), and has spatial audio at least. The gameplay is great, and the story is alright for what's essentially a tie-in game that compliments the mobile game, finished it and it took around 15 hours or so to finish the main story. Rolan is a badass.

And on the topic of mods to help mitigate some of the current issues, for those wanting an ultrawide fix, the FPS to have it's cap moved up to 240FPS, 16:10 support on the Steam Deck, and support for resolutions higher than 4K (on PC) or lower than 720p (on the Steam Deck), check out Lyall's mod for this game. With it and with a 960x600 custom resolution, you can actually lock to 40FPS on the Steam Deck without many dips. It also expands the top and bottom with aspect ratios narrower than 16:9, so you can have a proper experience on the Deck without black bars:

https://github.com/Lyall/GBFRelinkFix

Great game.  Visuals, music, combat, character designs, environments and set pieces are all great.  
It's kind of two games in one.  First is the typical JRPG stuff.  You follow a standard linear story with a set cast of characters. 
 You can play any of the characters, but the main character has to stay in the party(of 4) for the story.  For my tastes, the story and dialogue are a bit too PG/simple, maybe even cheesy at times, but it's still fun to go through.  English voice acting is decent.  I did all the hunt missions as they came available, and didn't require any grinding to beat the game.  Took about 17 hours, but I'm normally slow at progressing.
The second game is the Monster Hunters style, which happens after the ending.  Various levels of difficulty unlock on the hunt missions.  You grind out hunts to get more materials to upgrade your weapons, sigils(like armor pieces almost), mastery points(talent tree) etc.  There's more unlockable characters, for a total of 19, to change up your playstyle.  Only negatives I've seen is there's not a lot of monster variety, so you're killing the same stuff over and over, but the grind is fun because the combat is great.  Also, all the hunts can be played 4 player coop, or solo with AI party.
Summary, if you're just playing for the story, it might be a bit short for full price.  If you plan to engage at all with the endgame, well worth the price.  Oh, and no microtransactions/gacha stuff except for some color pallete swaps.
Now, make one for Princess Connect. And Aniplex should make one for FGO.

I love the gameplay and the story worth the price. Has a lot of room for improvements but for now I am satisfied with the game and will recommend it to people who wants to grind and enjoy a good story.

The game starts off pretty good and really draws you in with that feeling of classic JRPG wonder and excitement. Then reality hits you like a truck when you get to the first town and realize two things:

1. The side quests are little more than a random NPC with a minimalistic textbox listing fetch quest requirements.
2. The 'Extra Crew Members' are recruited through a character card system rather than actually being found out in the world as part of your journey.

If this doesn't seem like a red flag for JRPG fans then I dont know what else to say. 

Sure the combat is fun, but the skills themselves are somewhat basic and the 1 / 2 combo system is EXTREMELY limited. Not to mention the UI itself is poorly designed and your character will CONSTANTLY have a little popup floating around their head telling you what arts level they're at which you CANNOT get rid of.

The worst part is that the game seems to assume you are a big fan of the original mobile game because it throws an entire crew and storyline at you with no codex, no backstory and virtually no explanation or anything as far as WHY this crew of people is working together to go... somewhere?

Anyway, product refunded because of how soulless this game feels mostly. Hopefully the Tales Of studios take note of the combat and work their magic on an actual story driven experience.

A long time ago I came across a rather obscure RPG on the dreamcast that I knew nothing about, that game was Skies of Arcadia.  It was one of the first truly cinematic JRPGs about a tightly knit airship crew sailing skies full of floating islands.  The game was highly imaginative and ever since that game I was looking for the next great skyship adventure.  Skies of Arcadia II never came.

Several years back, as a big fighting game fan, I came across Granblue Versus.  The world and colorful crew of the Grandcypher immediately scratched that itch.  I found that GBF was actually a massive IP that had been running for some time and was exactly what I was looking for, but I was not one for mobile games and the game did not have much of a western footprint outside of Versus -which I loved.

Then COVID came and killed GBF.  At that point, I figured the great sky ship adventure was over.  But then we got the Rising announcement, which brought the game back in full force.  Then there was the commitment to Re:Link.

Going into Re-link, the game immediately took the best things about Skies of Arcadia, Monster Hunter, and Namco Tales games and mashes them together in a giant carnival generated for pure fun.  This series and game was exactly what I was looking for following tales.  I already had favorite characters and some lore from Versus and being able to play a full fledged action RPG set in this universe was exactly what was needed.

This game has probably the best RPG action combat system ever created.  The battles and bosses are immensely fun with true challenges on harder difficulty.  The crew members are all very unique in their playstyle and you can spend hours optimizing and coming up with team compositions, some of which may work better than others depending on what you are fighting.  I haven't messed too much with the Co-Op but it looks fun and servicable.

The game absolutely deserves to be sitting at over 100k steam users post launch.  The game and world is painstakingly crafted and all the years of development show in the presentation and fun.  There are absolutely crazy fun battles in the story and missions, intense airship battles, hordes of mobs, and gigantic monster hunter bosses with crazy raid boss attacks.  All the systems feel fair.  The controls are snappy and intuitive, which is very different from the chunkiness of monster hunter.  Every character feels uniquely powerful and customizable.  While there are battle shouts they are no where near as drowning as Xenoblade.

While there were post launch intel processor blackscreen issues, these are for the most part fixed.

I definitely highly recommend the game, this is one of the best JRPGs to launch and is built on an expanding formula.  I look forward to seeing more Granblue here in the west, I will buy it all in whatever form its in as long as the quality persists.

The game was certainly great and fits well with what I just need from a Japanese RPG. I also followed and watched the Anime as well as played the Mobile Version of the game. This was simply something that I was heavily looking forward to since its announcement years ago. Add the fact that Dragalia Lost (a game that have several GBF inspired characters) shut down a while back, I was certainly dead set to try this out. 

I play the game on an ASUS ROG ALLY, and I can guarantee that I never experienced any problems described by others here who I believe has way better SPEC PC than what I'm using.

Difficulty scaling was very good in my opinion, it wasn't hard transitioning from just Story and then going all out Hard/Very Hard/Extreme/Maniac/Proud. Characters are by far balanced, so much so that the game gives you the freedom to customize their play style whether as an AI Companion or played manually by you/me the player. Progression is rather linear, so it might be a sign that there will be no such thing as Duels/PVP in this game. Acquisition of several in-game items or materials can be a bit tedious and repetitive (considering this is the End Game) grind.

I surely hope there will be more content to this game even if it'll just for the next 2 years at least.
