As someone that have been playing GBF for more than 7 years, this game felt like a gift for GBF fans/players. Even non-gbf players can just jump in and enjoy the game thanks to its amazing OST, visuals and characters personality, the gameplay is also very smooth and fun, the "grind loop" is nice and rewarding too. 

Also please, just don't pay attention to these "censorship blahblah" posts, these humans are just too bored and spend too much time on internet looking for soft porn. Every design in Relink is good and respect the originals designs (again, I have been playing for more than 7 years) , so far there's 0 issues with the game other than typical port issues, but even so Cygames always works towards improving the stability of their games. 

If you are afraid of this game future, its confirmed that, at least till May, we are going to get new monthly content (raids, 2 new characters...). You can take it as Cygames testing player reception, if this game do well they will keep supporting it regularly.

EDIT: now that I have finally reached and nearly finished all of proud difficulty and after 50 hours i can safely say i absolutely love this game. There is a lot to love if you're a fan of JRPG combat with some monster hunter elements to it. 

The gameplay and systems surrounding how to improve and build your character are what glued me to this game from the first few hours. While the gameplay during the story can be slow until the last few chapters the gameplay once you reach the quest system is where the game actually begins and is fantastic. Grinding out the mastery points and materials needed for your character and multiple others is fun because the gameplay and bosses is fun to begin with. I loved the steady progression i felt in both my character(s) and bosses i fought as i moved up from Hard difficulty all the way to and through Proud difficulty. with 19 characters to pick from and 2 more coming in March, All of them feeling unique from one another will give you plenty to dig into and have fun with as you try out and build different characters and there respective playstyles. 

Now for the story i wasn't a fan of it but i didn't hate it either. it does its job and is just bland, nothing special but thats fine i wouldn't say thats the main pull of the game at all. you can pretty easily speed through the story within 8-14 hours depending on how fast you're clearing the fights and skipping all dialogue/cutscenes. 
 
Music is fantastic as to be expected from Nobuo Uematsu and Tsutomu Narita. Not much to say other than enjoy it. 

Now its not all 100% positive. Matchmaking and quick quest is still kind of funky and i will either fail to connect or get disconnected from peoples lobbies/quests from time to time. First off their are still some remaining issues with the PC version and people having issues booting the game. a patch was already released to address this but it didn't completely fix the issue from what it looks like. I have had absolutely no issues on a 6950XT GPU and 5800x3D CPU. 

Now this ties into performance, speaking for myself running the game maxed out(excluding blur thats turned of) at 120fps on 1440p is very easy and is 100% consistent. Their does seem to be a small bug where some cutscenes/areas in the village specifically where high amounts of Depth of Field is present seems to ramp my GPU utilization but doesn't affect my FPS. in combat the game runs smooth without any issue what so ever. 

I do have some complaints about the UI and how information regarding character power and damage is presented but thats a constant in every JRPG you will play, unfortunately a constant with the genre. However i will say that the game failing(to my knowledge) to explain the "DMG CAP" Mechanic is frustrating. To anyones who's played the Gacha game theyre very very familiar with how this works, however to those that don't i'd suggest adding some DMG CAP sigils to every character. it is highly annoying that basically every character in endgame(proud difficult maxed out builds) will more than likely require 4 DMG CAP V maxed out sigils and maybe imbued on your weapon, double the frustration when the game doesn't really explain it(i didn't notice it explained anywhere anyway)

Overall Granblue fantasy relink is a game i have waited for nearly 7 years for and its arrival and quality of it is well beyond my hopes and imagination. I have had nothing but a blast playing the game solo, with friends and randoms i join in lobbies and matchmaking and will continue to do so for many many hundreds of more hours.

Great Action JRPG with a short story that does not waste any time.

I just finished up the main story, and while it's on the shorter side, I was never bored while playing.
While other games just artificially lengthen the time of their campaigns, this one is just burning one firework after another.
That said, be aware that this game's story is pretty easy and does not pose a big challenge for any seasoned player.

So: If you like your story lengthy and hard, look elsewhere.

The characters are all great and the combat stays fresh since they all have their unique style.
You do not even need to play as the main protagonist, just switch it up to the back and play with the character you like most.
 
After the story is completed, the game opens up into post-game - which you can play alone or with up to 3 other players.
There is full matchmaking support for all quests and the matchmaking has been fixed with the latest patch.

This is then the point where you can grind to your hearts content and start min/maxing your builds and desired characters.
The game switches up to a bite sized mode now where you can specifically grind items needed for your build.

There is still much leveling and unlocking to do (both weapons and characters) and this should take me quite some time.
I will update this review once I feel like I have seen all that the post-game has to offer.

There are already updates announced until May and I really hope the success makes them support this game longer than they initially planned.

This is not a live-service game - so you get the whole story experience from the start.

Edit: My play-through was done completely running Linux with Proton Experimental.

This game is really, really good.

A perfect blend of JRPG elements that you know from turn-based equivalents (leveling, equipment, classes, questing), a real-time battle system inspired and developed by the talents of Platinum Games (Bayonetta, Metal Gear Rising, Nier Automata) and beutiful artwork and music by legends such as Nobuo Uematsu (Final Fantasy I-IX). 

It is the dream Action-RPG of every kid who wished that Final Fantasy or Dragon Quest was a real-time action game. The Characters, world and story are full of love (and money from mobile-gacha). A highly polished experience that no one should miss out, it is seriously that good. 

Go for it, smell the roses, and don't forget to charge your finishers with Danchou.

Granblue Fantasy:Relink is an action RPG set in the world of the browser game Granblue Fantasy. With beautiful world, music and character designs and some flashy, chaotic and fun combat which has surprising amount of depth to it despite the simple controls and combos. The main story is nothing to write home about and is rather short, but Sigil, weapon and skill choices allow for variety of builds in the endless grind for higher numbers in the large amounts of side quests. The game is clearly made mostly for fans of the original browser game and many of the references and moments might be lost to anyone not already familiar with it, but it includes an expansive wiki and short "fate episode" stories to help introduce new fans to the setting, making it a good entry point to anyone interested in the Granblue world.

While the game might have not lived up to expectations that build up during the 8 years of development hell, and as old fan of the browser game its hard to ignore many of the missed opportunities, I still highly recommend Relink to both old and new fans of Granblue world or Action games.

- The Combat, is hands down is my number 1. From Perfect Parrying/Guard to Perfect Dodges, abilities that give you rewards for doing so. Teamwork is HUGE, and it's pretty. Link-Bursts, Bad-ass Super Moves, it makes you feel like your own anime moment. If you chain your supers with your teams? You get huge bad-ass explosions. 'Nuff said  

- Casual or Min-Maxing, The sigil system which to put it easily, it's Monster Hunter's Perks/Charm system. You can crunch your numbers to the point you have to include raising your Damage Cap.

- The Roster, not to shabby to be honest. You like the heavy hitters? Got them, Fast slashing type of folk? Got it, You like trading blow for blow on the enemy? Got that too, and support. Which by the way, you can use the sigils to make almost all of the roster support, dps, tank, healer.

- Music, well. I made it to end game, and I'll tell you. Those bosses have some real DBZ vocal energy. It's goooooood.

- You can play solo and still have the same fun as with a group. The AI are pretty smart.

- Endgame has some bad-ass bosses, and also pretty challenging. Ranks for difficulty: Easy/Normal/Hard/Very Hard/Maniac/Proud and to get to Proud Rank? It makes you work for it but man is it good.

[ CONS ]

- Matchmaking is..50//50. Looking at like 1-4 minute wait times.

- Semi-Live Service game, not much is known about the future after the content drops. (Three to be exact) After that? It's clouded.

- Grind, if you want to survive in Maniac + Proud. If you are planning to go that high be ready. The grind isn't bad, honestly. Way better than Destiny 2.

- Stupid freaking parrot saying sugoi or very good for the 8395287359827th time after transmuting a sigil.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------                 I give it a  8.9/10. A fun game, keeps ya busy good to keep you playing for a time to come. Worth it in my opinion and it leads me

It's finally here, Granblue Fantasy Relink, the first 3D action game from the Granblue Fantasy IP (which is originally a japanese mobile gacha game) beyond the GB:Versus fighting game. And boy does it feel good to finally be able to experience the universe this way. If you are a fan of Granblue Fantasy, you will likely not be disappointed by this game.

But what is the game like? Well, it's heavily Monster Hunter inspired, with its own deviations. It carries over the Ability system with skills that Versus already has, which expands on the rather basic combo systems that your characters have as "movesets". It is also a lot faster than Monster Hunter, and is loaded with over exaggerated anime powerlevels and special effects. It can be assaulting on the eyes (and ears) when you're fighting, but I personally don't mind that much. On top of the skills and movesets, you have the Link and the Charge Attack system, which are important parts of the game. Both are power meters which build during combat. Link will pop a power up/time slow window for your whole party for burst, and Charge Attacks are "ultimate" skills, which you are supposed to chain with your other party members. CA's especially are an integral part of the original mobile game but aren't quite as extreme in this game. They are still important damage bursts that you should get used to, since they're part of every longer fight.

Story wise it definitely won't blow you away and is pretty much in line for the usual Granblue level writing.

If you're a fan of the franchise, I definitely recommend buying the game. After my 27 hours of playing I had very few stability issues (it crashed like twice while loading into a coop match), though others seem to have more issues. Gameplay wise I encountered no bugs whatsoever, it's actually very polished. 

tl;dr: if you like anime special effects and monster hunter, you should consider buying this game. If you want to play it for coop especially, you should finish the Story chapters first, as it will unlock more characters and game mechanics vital for the coop stage. That will take around 12-14 hours. After that it basically feels like monster hunter.

So far it's fucking fantastic. While the story it self isn't anything amazing, the voice acting and action sequences are incredibly well done. 

The combat is on the slower side but that does not detract from its enjoyment. All characters have unique movesets and distinct playstyles. And pulling off full bursts is very satisfying. 

The crowning jewel however are the bosses. They all have unique mechanics and are incredibly fun to take out. They take the best parts of FFXIV trials and raids, and reshape them around a more streamlined RPG experience. 

My only complaint really is that character stories are all just storybook text windows. The progression also feels a bit uninspired, its just a lot of grinding for flat stat upgrades for your gear, and a skill tree that feels less like a way of customising your character and more like a roadblock for progressions sake. But none of that is a big issue, as this clearly is a game oriented around grinding at end game, and the character stories are really well voice acted.

Great game, worth waiting 8 years...
but, where is the refresh button?

Core gameplay is a really good time. Progression is sorta good. Aesthetics, sounds, Japanese VA and music are very on point. Feels responsive and fast.
There are a few BUTS though.

These BUTS include:
- You need to get through stability issues. Blackscreen on launch (turning off font autoscaling in Steam helped me, but it might not be same recipe for everyone), frame drops, CTDs (didn't occur for me but a lot of people complain).
- You need to get through arguably weak main story which will take ~12 hours. Only then a wonderful world of questing grind is open to you, which is a main dish of the game (normal and hard difficulties avaliable during main story are just a little taste).
- There is no way to try out the characters before you unlock them so if you get someone purely by the eye, and then realize you don't vibe with their mechanics or moves, you will need to grind for another character unlock, and this may take you a while.
- DLC prices are ridiculous for what they offer.
- It's worse if you don't intend to play this with a controller.
- For gacha non-players game does not provide enough context for who are all these people, and why are there shrimp weapons etc.
- For gacha players there are no rewards for gacha, unlike the PS version.
- Translation/localization is dubious. It's still readable, and won't break your brain as if you are reading an AI generated text, but you might suffer from cringe here and there.
Great combat, great postgame replayability. Somewhat cliched story but that's not what you buy this game for.

Short version: 
The 3D anime artstyle is beautiful! There are a lot of characters with different playstyles that are all fun in their own way, and you can eventually unlock them all. Boss fights are hype as hell and the combat loop is gonna be the meat of the game if you play longterm.

Long version: 
The game already has established characters from the 10 years that Granblue has been out and the game builds onto that with another adventure! I think new people getting into GBF who are interested in the plot and characters won't feel too lost, and there are small stories (Fate Episodes) you can unlock that will give brief explanations of all the characters backstories and new stories for this game. 

The plot itself is alright. It can feel a bit wishy washy and writing can get a bit weird, and then lead up to really hype moments. Again, the main meat of the game is gonna be in the combat loop and repeatable missions to farm for equipment, levels, and skills.

Remarkable.  The main single player story is a wild action romp that seems determined to one up itself after each chapter.  You know how most RPGs might open with a cool cinematic moment, but within an hour you're killing 7 boars, or collecting someone's lost mail?  Yeah, not here.  This game feels like getting shot out of a cannon.

The campaign may be "short", maybe around 10 hours, but it is so dense with stunning spectacles it's worth the price of admission on its own.  It's a breakneck series of over-the-top bosses and cinematic set pieces.  Combat, while chaotic, feels highly satisfying once you get used to the game's systems.  The art and music are glorious.  Just don't expect a great narrative - the plot is about as vanilla as gran himself.  Fight the bad guys, save the world.  You've seen this before, though perhaps without a small dragon companion who calls people "dude" and "buttface".

After the campaign, there is the promise of many MANY hours of questing and grinding in the pursuit of ludicrous levels of power in a loop clearly inspired by the Monster Hunter series.  I've logged a LOT of monster hunter hours, so I'll be delving into this title's end game as well, and while so far I've only had a glimpse, it appears to be rather vast.  How long this post game content will hold my interest I can't say yet, but there doesn't seem to be a shortage of things to do.

The following is just a quick review of the game in my opinion. If you wanna check out the full review head on over to https://leveledupgamings.blogspot.com

Rating

9. The only thing this game truly falls short of is its customization, main storytelling, and shallow character backgrounds. Few times would people say that a live service game is something they would want in a game and this rare occurrence is true for Granblue. Hopefully we continue to see this title being supported because it has so much going well for it that I want to continue to see the future of this world and characters. 

Pros:

Stunning Art Design: The game features beautiful anime-style graphics with meticulously detailed environments and character designs that immerse players in the world of Granblue Fantasy.
Smooth Performance: The game runs smoothly with minimal technical issues, offering silky smooth gameplay and minimal load times, especially on high-end systems.
Fluid Combat Mechanics: Combat in Granblue Fantasy Relink is fluid and responsive, allowing players to execute intricate combos and unleash powerful abilities with ease.
Diverse Character Abilities: Each character possesses unique skills and playstyles, encouraging experimentation and strategic decision-making in battle, enhancing the depth of gameplay.
Extensive Skill Trees: The game offers extensive skill trees for each character, providing depth and longevity to gameplay as players strive to maximize character abilities and customization options.
Engaging Side Content: In addition to the main story, the game offers a variety of side quests and monster hunts, reminiscent of games like Monster Hunter, providing additional content and replay value.

Cons:

Lackluster Main Story: While the game excels in character development and background stories, the main story falls short, feeling predictable and lacking depth, leaving players wanting more.
Shallow Character Backgrounds: Some characters lack sufficient background information, leaving players with a desire for more depth and backstory to enhance attachment to certain characters.
Limited Customization: The game lacks extensive customization options, particularly in comparison to modern RPGs, leaving players craving more opportunities to personalize their experience.

I am only about 6 hours at the time of writing this, but I can definitely say I am hooked. The game is graphically pretty, has beautiful music, the combat is fluid and fun, and the world feels lovingly crafted. I am very happy with my purchase so far, and hope the post-game will be just as enjoyable.

I remember seeing the very first gameplay trailer for this game 6 years ago and I thought it was too good to be true. It makes me incredibly happy that this game is finally out and is very polished.

As someone who is very burnt out on RPGs with 50+ hour long campaigns, this game is exactly what I'm looking for. The main story is short and simple. It has very little filler and you are constantly moving from one  cinematic moment to another. 

The action combat is very fun, addictive and smooth. There are a wide selection of characters to choose from and they all have different kits that completely change the way you engage with the encounters. The gameplay feels like a blend between Tales of Arise, Monster Hunter and Final Fantasy XIV.

I would highly recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of RPGs with action focused combat. I think it's also important to mention that you do not need pre-existing knowledge about the Granblue Fantasy series to  enjoy this game.
FF14 and MonHun's lovechild.
Extremely good game. No knowledge of Granblue Fantasy is required to get into it, so I highly recommend it even if you don't know anything at all about Granblue.

WARNING: Minor Story Spoilers 

Have you ever felt that empty feeling after finishing a 100+ hour JRPG? ReLink did that for me within a short 16 hours. It is a game that respects your time and gives you that complete anime experience of starting off killing goblins to killing gods with the power of friendship to save the world. Coming from someone who has stuck with the series since middle school and now graduating university, seeing the world I've devoted so much time to be properly showcased really meant a lot. Previously those world ending adventures felt so insignificant with 2D sprites and turn based combat, for Cygames to be able to recreate that world as an action RPG with thoughtful gameplay made me care for those stories in a game I spammed skip through. It is a cheesy, charming, adventure that has a lot of depth to it thanks to it's origins as a grindy mobile JRPG with a substantial post game.

Side Note: IF ANYTHING PLAY THIS GAME FOR THE MUSIC, PLEASE ITS SO GOOD

tldr: Grindy Monster hunter style instanced missions with crazy flashy FF 14 style raid bosses action rpg with a anime af soundtrack.

Don't get me wrong. I've waited this game for so long and I've enjoyed it so far and I'm currently in chapter 4 trying to beat that certain giant spear user on Grandcypher (edit: beated him and now I'm past a certain unlimited blade works user). But believe me, you should fire your QA (if they existed in the first place anyway). No demos, no playtest, no nothing, and yet here's your conclusion: bad launch. I rarely post reviews like this but, I couldn't take it anymore.

You guys JP devs should learn from Palworld, should learn from Falcom, why their game could run smoothly but this one don't (engine problem? idk idc if you're asking from consumer's pov). That's why in modern day gaming you should obtain as much as possible about user's data through demo and playtest, especially us PC users, our custom rigs. Consoles? Okay fine, probably they also need to check whether they meet the player's expectation or something, but demo's and playtests aren't solely purposed on that for PC.

Is it highly costed? Idk. But after a loooooonnnggg development time, you guys should've expected these kinds of things (errors and whatsoever).

Now me and my friends have to wait longer before we can play together. Minimum sysreq? We've passed that, seriously (we don't even bother buying games that aren't meet our sysreq).
Edit: except for AVX2, if this is required, then just say so (just like pso ngs did) with AVX1 and THIS is why you need to playtest with people. I mean, real people).

Is it hard to optimize PC port? Maybe. But you've got a team, you've got us to pay you for that, you can see how much statistic you'll be hoarding from the hypes. I don't think you need advice for this, right?

Anyhow, everything in game is so far quite good, for now. Except a few things that people already mentioned in the discussion threads. 
Transliteration is meh from my opinion, you can do better. I don't know any western culture in certain conversations but, there are some dialogues that are not needed to be "extra literated". I can't remember which ones since there are too many of them.
Edit: For example this Gran's line: "Chikara o kaishite kudasai!" it's more like, "Please lend me your power (help)! not "You've got to help us!" and I think it's far different in terms of politeness.
I don't know about censorship, but... perhaps certain men of culture already representing my opinion.

Overall, the mechanics, the grind, battle system, is fine, I like it. You can also do better with this. Perhaps a 8 players raid in the future update? Or something better.

So, cheers! If within this few days you don't have any fix for those issues, I guess there will be a refund.
Thank you and best regards.

So Granblue Fantasy: Relink. A game that was announced damn near a millennia ago it feels. At the time of writing this I’ve just finished the story and gotten a few multiplayer quests in after (I wanted to wait until after completing the story to bother doing any).

Honestly after playing what I have, which is so far a bit less than 17 hours, I can say that this is definitely a good game! If you’re a player who likes Action RPGs, Anime, Monster Hunter, MMO style raids, want a co-op game to play, or you’re just some sort of fiend for grinding I can pretty confidently say you’ll have a good time. 

In terms of combat in this game, it’s pretty simple admittedly, but it suits itself well for the game. Your basic combat comes from two buttons, X & Y (Square and Circle for those on Dualshocks). With those two you’re able to use your basic combos, which vary by character. Alongside that you have your dodge, block, and “link” (also used for other actions) buttons. But aside from those you also have your 4 skills. (6 or 8 available to each character it seems I forgot while I was writing this) Each character within the game has different sorts of combos and skills which makes them all rather unique. If you want to play as a brute of sorts, a ranger, or a spellcaster, these are all available to you, and on top of that, you can tune them even more to fit how you want to play due to the customization! There’s also good team mechanics within the game as well. The main two in question being team ultimates and team link. Team ultimates are exactly as they are, somewhat. So each character has their own respective ultimate, but when used in rapid succession of each other on the same enemy, you get a burst effect at the end that is another extra large chunk of damage off of the enemy. This burst will also be the element of the first person who used their ultimate for those who may play soon that are reading this. Team link is the other mechanic, so when you stun an enemy, you’re prompted to press a button to jump to that stunned enemy and do an attack. Doing this builds the link percentage. When it reaches 100% if everyone uses a link on a stunned enemy at once (has to be in rapid succession upon stunning again) it slows time, increases your damage and gives other buffs depending on how you’ve built your character.

Now in terms of the character customization mentioned, this is what really determines how you play. This is affected by your character (of course), level, weapons, sigils, and mastery tree. And as for how these all come into play:
Character- First is the character, your main skills you’ll have available to you will be here. There’s quite a few characters in the game and they all play pretty differently. You have some charcaters that unleash flurries of attacks, some heavy hitters, tank like characters, magical users, and the likes. As I mentioned controls are simple but how they’re applied are different, some of the characters whom are heavy hitters you can perfectly time their attacks for more damage, some moves you hold for more damage and other stuff like that. I would say to look at each character’s move list before you unlock them to see if their normal kit is something you would like. Each character starts at a set level (rises as you go through the main story) and then you raise it through missions and the like as you would normally. As you level up you also gain mastery points which you use toward your mastery tree to buff your character and get the remaining abilities and things like that.

Weapons- This takes a bit less to explain. Your weapons are standard per character, it will always be the same type. You have to level these weapons for more damage and other stats, however a bonus thing that changes per weapon is the traits. Some already have passives on them, but you can also imbue weapons with new passives to help with different things like damage, critical rate, critical damage, and things of the like. I haven’t seen a lot of these so far so im not sure what’s all available there but those are some I’ve seen so far.

Sigils- Sigils are an item that you can equip to your character that gives some sort of passive effect. This will very much so help with how you want to play. These sigils come in many varieties and seem to come in some basic categories. These are Basic Statss, Attack, Defense, Support, and Special (which are more varied, but can also fall under other categories). I personally play supportive for example, so I have some sigils on to keep my health high, and increase my healing output so when I’m not helping with damage im keeping everyone up. Stuff like that.

Missions in game I could most compare to an average action rpg, meeting monster hunter. You’re not going out trying to hunt that singular monster in an open map of course, but primarily you’ll have quests where you clear out groups of enemies, collect something, secure something or something of the sort, pretty standard. The other missions are the big boss fights In which you see in the trailers, they’re raid bosses by nature. There’s only but so many at the start. However, as you complete missions you gain access to more missions to play as well. I would say my fear here is in the endgame in which I just got to. Something that may deter people is how much you have to grind to get the newer and different missions. I haven’t gotten really any unlocked yet, however like I mentioned, I haven’t played too much yet since reaching endgame. I’ve heard of it being a lot to unlock missions but cannot confirm just yet. But if it’s like monster hunter in terms of the grinding I don’t think I’ll mind it too much.

As for the story of this game. I can’t say as much for how good a story is because I don’t often play the story/campaign for most games, but to get to endgame here you have to go through the story regardless. So most of my time so far has been just story content. And to my surprise, this game’s story kept me pretty interested. I was able to sit and watch/read everything regarding to the story in this game. I would say at least in my opinion it was interesting, I grew to like many of the characters, and there were many moments where I could catch myself just smiling at whatever was happening. There’s definitely a bit at least for tropes and stuff you’d expect, but despite that I was enjoying it. Plus there’s a bit more for story with the fate episodes as well (which even if you don’t care about the story you want to check these out for stats). With me at first just going through the story missions (I did maybe 2 side missions, but took all hub quests I could. However I prioritized no hub quests, just passively completed them) the story took probably 14 hours of my current play time while playing on the hard difficulty. 

In terms of negatives. I had a couple. My biggest was at one particular mission, after completing it, during the cutscene the game would crash. I went through the mission a couple more times to make sure it was the cutscene causing it, and it was. After skipping that cutscene, I didn’t experience any other crashes. My second was how the game runs, I could definitely just have stuff to work on with my pc to upgrade or it could just be the game at this moment, I’m currently playing on standard graphics, and can’t keep a consistent 120fps which is the higher frame cap. I’m currently running an i7-12700f, 32 gb of ram, and a rtx 3060. (if anyone knows something that might help lmk). But otherwise the game runs fine at 60, and I don’t feel as if that takes away from anything in this game in particular. Those are my only two negatives though in my experience.

But in conclusion, I so far have been able to thoroughly enjoy the game, and I’m glad it finally came out after all this time. I think- or more so I know a lot of people will enjoy this game, and rightfully so. I know I’ll at least get my money’s worth of enjoyment out of it, it is def worth trying

This is an Edited Review.
They did appear to fix the 2 major game breaking issues i had with the game that prevented any type of significant progression for me: getting into the game consistently and game locking up on main story cut scenes.

I did like the game, when I was able to play it and continue to like it but could not in good conscious recommend a game that was not working as intended to anyone, let alone for its hefty asking price tag.

After a Revisit.

Graphics and Gameplay are superb.
Music and Sounds is great.
Lots of tech trees and weapon to upgrade.
It does have that Monster Hunter take for questing and that's where the co-op comes into play in which you play that instance with either AI Bots or Live people depending on your preferred style.
Localization is eyebrow rising in a few points which leads me to believe liberties were taken with it.  Very Odd word choices for a few characters.  

To Sum,
They had a bad Steam PC Launch, Period. (They should have released the Demo on Steam like they did on the Playstation but choose not to).  The Game Breaking Issues appear to have been addressed now.  You don't have to watch the anime to get an idea of what's going on here but it is a fun world and good entry that i expect to 

I'm still grumpy about the poor PC launch.  I'm grateful to the Steam Community with all the tips and tricks in the discussion area during that time to try to get me into the game.  Now I'm cautiously optimistic that the game wont crash as I continue to work thru the story and game.  So I'm more positive than negative on it now.

It been a while since I had this much fun playing a game

Played on the day it came out, and to be perfectly honest, I had tons of fun. 

If you're looking for some Pros & Cons well here they are

Pros:
Beautiful Art Style/Graphical Fidelity, perhaps the best of its kind.

Engaging Combat with tons of mix matching and experimentation. The game allows for a deeper exploration of build than initially available at the beginning.

Good Level Design (IMO you may or may not like it depending on what you enjoy) 

Superb Boss Fights. They will not be on the same level as say Fromsoft boss fights, but they have that MMORPG raid mechanic feel to them, and is quite engaging and fun.

Action is fluid, and the Party system works just right.

More than enough characters to try out and play with. There's quite a few good selections and I'd say most of them are unique from each other.

Cons: 
Because of the nature of the game, it will be heavy on exposition, cutscenes and dialogues. Perhaps this is a positive for your, or it may not

Story is 4 or 5/10. It's meh, It is your standard fantasy ride with Good Guys vs Bad Guys dynamic, with a few small "plot twists."

Party Members talk way too much during combat. It may be for the callouts, but it can get very annoying.

Not enough Boss Varieties. I have talked about how good some of the boss fights are in this game, but there aren't many of them. They repeat in pattern with slightly different variations in attack sets/elemental powers. In addition, game has way too many "gimmicky" bosses IMO. Cut it to one or two please Cygames.

Overall I'd rate the game 8/10 and only after 22 hours. I just barely started the End Game of the game, with only one character on Lvl 100 and some at 90+ so this rating may change in the future. They are planning on releasing more characters in the future too so that's something to look forward to. If you like MH-like games, or perhaps a good Action RPG I'd recommend folks to try this game out, its great fun and I'm just starting out.
20/10 Game, feels like a mix of original phantasy star combined with monster hunter.  It's even better with friends.

Don't usually write reviews, but felt like this game deserved it.

Visually, it's a knockout. Character designs are sleek, environments are beautiful, especially with the LODs being water paintings, and the animations are a visual treat. It's like they took the essence of a top-tier anime and embedded it into the DNA of the game.

Storywise, it's a pleasant surprise. Relink brings a bit of depth, unexpected twists, and character arcs that keep you engaged. A casual player will probably enjoy it, but the game is made for what comes after, so if you're not looking to repeat and build your party further past the story, I'm not sure I can recommend this game, unless you're content with about 10-20 hours of story.

Now, let's talk party characters – for me, it's all about Siegfried. His moveset is extremely rewarding and enjoyable when you master it, there's something satisfying about nailing that perfect timing combo chain. Siegfried's combat style caters to the types of players who enjoy characters with a high skill ceiling.

Combat, in general, is the real star here. Controls are responsive, and the battles strike that sweet spot between tactical finesse and the sheer joy of unleashing devastating combos. Whether you're a casual player looking for a good time or a hardcore sweat seeking a challenge, the gameplay caters to both ends of the spectrum. And the co-op play? It's a game-changer, especially when you're tackling epic bosses with your crew.

Major shoutout to Nobuo Uematsu and Tsutomu Narita for the soundtrack – it's the hidden gem that elevates the entire gaming experience. It really adds to the epic feel during boss fights and cutscenes.

In a nutshell, whether you're a casual player looking for a laid-back adventure or a hardcore sweat seeking a challenging quest, Granblue Fantasy: Relink has got you covered. It strikes the perfect balance between accessibility and intensity, and for Siegfried enthusiasts like myself, it's the ultimate playground for perfect timing combo chains. 

Good luck and get ready to cook some goblins.

While the port is bare bones with no specific graphic settings compared to contemporary specialized PC ports, the game is optimized enough for me to do questing with no noticeable frame drops or even at all @ 120fps Ultra. The recent patch fixes most of the issues brought by the earlier reviews though whether it works for you or not may vary. But most notably some of the issues have been fixed: There is no longer a region lock, most crashing incidents are addressed, matchmaking time has been significantly reduced with little to no connection errors.


While the talk of the town is the port, The game itself? Phenomenal. If you think the port is garbage or does not work for you, then if you have a ps4 or ps5, get it there. It's a cool trial/raid-y focused game that i personally love as a result of enjoying games like Dragalia Lost, FFXIV or even Monster Hunter. If you like those instance based kinds of games (and controls really great too), then i recommend this game no matter the platform.

I only have 2 personal gripes (nitpicks honestly) i have with the game:

 1. How very forgiving the critical gauge is with the gauge slow enough to accommodate 3 or more party members reviving on their own consecutively without any help (face buttons or teammates reviving) even at the later difficulties resulting to an easier difficulty than what it deserves to be. Though i understand the decision prioritizing a better experience for very casual players to experience everything the game has to offer. It would've been better if they adopted a chance system like in Dragalia Lost where it's an individual life count vs a gauge where the revives still encourage you to be careful even if you mess up once or twice and still does not trivialize the difficulty of the fights. Fingers crossed Lucilius' fight has a considerably faster critical gauge depletion.

2. Guard and Perfect Dodge working on all types of outgoing damage also makes most encounters easier than it looks. Overdrive phase's mechanics become trivialized when these two defensive options can easily mitigate the damage. Guard especially prevents preemptive and reactive synergy that makes these types of games challenging to learn because you can simply hold guard. An early example of this is when the player can simply hold guard to not get damaged during furycane's OD phase rather than standing where you cant get hit by the tornadoes. It could probably be better if certain outgoing damage can be guarded/dodgeable while most attacks in Overdrive (especially during phases where its all about the "mechanics") bypass guard and become non-iframable by perfect dodge.

Otherwise, this game is everything that I wanted Relink to be, even became what I never knew I wanted all along.

Gameplay is reminiscent of GodEater and Metal Gear Solid: Revengence ( the MemEs jAck!), fights consists of exchanges between blocks and dodges while getting in their safe zones and attacking them where the sun doesn't shine. GBF players would be familiar with many of the Mobs/ Bosses, their fights reimagined in a 3D space where they can finally not blame their weapon grid for when they fail a boss. Oh yeah, it also incorporates GBF's Burst system as well, and it is satisfying to see each time it is executed ( exhaustion pending).

All in all, GBF: Relink is a great fix for those waiting for MH:Worlds, those itching to see how Gran's battles feel like as he adventures across the realms. 

My only gripe is that I wished they allowed gamepad button binding - but I believe developers are aware of this and am working on it.

All in all, a fantastic game.
Sure, it had its downsides on release day with the start up issues, but those were rather minor since the game itself ran without issues.
Had only 1 crash in a cutscene and had to re-do a boss fight. But aside that, I played over 23 hours and it just worked fast and performed well.
The story is short and very anime you could say. Some may like it, some may not.

But where the game really shines in my eyes, is how well the multiplayer is made. It works fast, easy and is reliable. 
You can even set the game so that you cannot be spoiled by others in your lobby.

Heck you can even play quests you have not unlocked in your own world as the Host but still play them if your friends have them. The game straight up tells you that you will not get the ranking for it. But you can still do the mission, get EXP and materials.

Sure, it sucks that you cannot play the main story with your friends and I wish the Devs would make that possible since 95% of the time, you have the party of your choice anyways alongside you. I don't see a reason why this cannot be done. Maybe in the future since in Postgame, you can replay the story as you like and collect what you missed out on.

I really hope the Devs don't screw it up with overpriced DLC characters down the road or locking quests behind a paywall (if they do, ideally so that only 1 person in the party has to own the quest for all to play it, like some games do it).

It is basically Tales of Arise, from another developer and story. All the 18? somewhat characters play differently enough that they are valid to be so many and not just bloating.

Mission structure is objective to defend, kil bossl, time defense, time attack etc. Its very akin to Monster Hunter with a hub where you get quests and select missions / set online lobby / etc. You will be very at home with its online tools and mission structure if you have experience with monster hunter. 

Combat is active and real-time, char building is mhm you have 12 or 13 Sigil slots, where Damage CAP lvl 65 basically mandatory on every character which will take you 5 slots of your 12 or 13 slots to customize a character, its a bad way of stopping power but it is what it is, nothing is perfect. The game is a hellish amount of fun to play, combat is more or less identical to Tales of Arise with chain links and ultimates across the party, biggest difference is you can NOT swap character on the fly in a mission, only outside of missions.

Back on topic of builds, some are charged attacks, some are skill spammers and some are combo damage dealers which gives a fair bit of variety and spicing in up makes it also easier to split your Sigils across your team. If you have four combo characters it will be a pain to get all of the same Sigils, a fair split makes it easier to fix it up.

As of 2/3/2024, there was a patch that seems to have fixed the crashing problems, at least for me. No black screens or cutscene crashes *So Far*. According to the update post, they're still investigating the causes however. That means purchasing this game right now may still be a gamble, so be wary. If you do buy it, don't forget you can refund if the problems pop up on your end. That said, I'll review the game based off its merits now instead.

Anyways: Game is fun. Very fun. Like what everyone else has stated, it's an intricate mix of Tales Of combat (Tales of Arise, Berseria, etc) and Monster Hunter, though more emphasis on the Tales Of. The main story is about 20 hours, however the true meat of the game seems to be afterward (just like with Monster Hunter). Progression feels similar to mobile games (in a good way) in that you're upgrading equipment levels, unlocking them with materials, and upgrading further. Character progression is more about allocating points you get from leveling up and doing missions into a mastery tree that gives you stat boosts, skills, and so on. 

While I haven't gotten very far due to issues you can read further below, I can say what I have played is very enjoyable, and the general gameplay loop is so far quite satisfying. If you're into Tales Of or Monster Hunter, this is gonna be right up your alley. This one was well worth the wait. Just wish PC didn't get shafted but it is what it is.

Story: Anime/10 - This game is basically a spin off of the Granblue Fantasy mobile game thus there is *alot* to unpack if you're at all curious about it. But at Relink's core is a very much "High Adventure" kind of story, where you're traveling to a new "Skydom" (think kingdom but in the sky) with a band of well established heroes and you get into all sorts of melodramatic trouble. If you're into anime, you'll probably enjoy it. If you're not, then you can skip cutscenes if you want. You're given a summary of events in the cutscene in text if you do.

One thing to note - there are "Fate Episodes" you can view that give you a glimpse into each character's backstory. Doing these episodes also unlocks stat boosts. 

Gameplay: 9/10 - Controls are relatively simple and intuitive. Combat is fast and frenetic. Enemies aren't just punching bags either - they'll happily surround and attack you if you're not careful. While I wouldn't call the game difficult, I would say there is some challenge - especially when you're trying to go for certain mission bonuses. Those of you that don't like "Time Attack" type missions aren't gonna be happy, because nearly every side quest I've played so far has them. 

So far every single character I've played has been fun and have different combat styles. You start out the game with 6 (1 being your named character) and can have 4 on your team at any given time. The one negative mark I must give is that you can't switch characters on the fly during battle. "Oh that enemy's a flyer, lemme switch to my ranged character" is not something you can do here sadly. 

Your team however can sync their "ultimate attacks" together, which makes for a pretty awesome moment that does an immense amount of damage if you pull it off. You can set your team to either save (or Hold) their ults for when you do yours, or you can let them do theirs whenever. Either option is useful.

Graphics: 8/10 - Very good looking game, but I've noticed some some textures that seem a bit on the low side. Not enough to be bothersome.

Music - 9/10 - alot of orchestral music here and there, and you'll hear the game's main theme's leitmotif alot.  The music swells when it should and quiets down when it should. Very well done.


Negative Bullet Points:
* No Playstation button prompt options (Why.)
* Cannot switch playable character in battle. Can only do so out of battle and you must go into the menu to do so.
* Graphical options are kinda lacking. Got the basics, but it would've been nice to have more options like most PC games do nowadays. No DLSS or FXR options either.
* Benched characters level up slower than played ones - This game has TONS of characters you can obtain, so if you want to try a new one that you already have in your roster, be prepared to boost them up first. Characters you have NOT obtained yet though, seem to get your main character's level.

On the topic of Localization - I absolutely despise localization that changes personalities or censors things. There is some censorship in this game - though thankfully minimal. Some girls wear hotpants instead of panties. One rather busty lady had a few extra inches of cloth given to her top. Really wish this crap didn't happen. Even if the game is a 10/10, I automatically shave off points if it has censorship.

Did some digging about the dialogue. According to those who actually know Japanese, most of the localization is either adding Western cringe or being overly enthusiastic. Frankly the dialogue hasn't been any different from what I've seen in most JRPGs other than a few more recent popular Western phrases. I'm not at all a fan, but it's not enough to drag the whole game down for me.


Note that I have not played online yet, and I can't say anything about endgame because I'm not there yet either. But so far - other than the botched launch - I've been enjoying this game. That said, I haven't forgotten about the launch issues. I bought this game day one because I was hyped up for it for years. But sometimes we need to relearn the reason why we should wait for reviews. The lesson has been taught once again and I won't make the same mistake with any of Cygames' games again. I'll keep my earlier "review" down below that talks about the launch problems along with a rant about the way Cygames is treating the PC playerbase.

Overall score so far: 8/10. Would be a 9 if there was no censorship.

---

Alright. I give up.

Gonna preface this with: My rig is perfectly fine. Windows 10, 3070ti, Intel i7, 16gb RAM. Not the tiptop of the line but certainly no slouch. Can play anything I throw at it. When the game WORKS, I can play it on ultra 120 fps no problem.

Black screen crashes at start up. If you're able to even get into the game, you're not out of the woods yet because it seems every cutscene has a low chance of also crashing. The final straw was a crash during a cutscene right after defeating a tough boss. Like it legit deflated me. Was riding on a high cuz the fight was really fun and I was trying out a new character and the cutscene itself was full of tension and bam - crash. 

Fact is this: PC got the extreme short end of the stick. Sony must've thrown a huge bag of money at them because Playstation had a demo, released early, more DLC content, better special editions, everything. PC's version finally releases and we're once more kicked in the nuts and/or tacos with a bad port job, minimal graphical options, only xbox button prompts (WHY. The game is also on PLAYSTATION. Why not add a toggle for PLAYSTATION buttons???), tons of launch issues, black screens, crashes, I just can not even.

Been waiting for this game since it was announced years ago. The game ITSELF, when it WORKS, is great. But everything I mentioned above makes me both regret my purchase and gives little incentive for me to purchase any other game made by Cygames. Sad thing is with all my troubleshooting and stints of the game actually working - I'm far too past the 2 hour mark to refund it. 

I'm sure (hope) it will be fixed eventually. It seems they've noticed the issues and have promised a fix at some point. But for now - stay clear. You might be one of the lucky ones with no problems. You might not. I don't suggest taking the gamble right now, but it's up to you.

As a wise man once said - my disappointment is immeasurable and my day is ruined. I'll change my review when (if) they fix the problems.

After finishing the main story, I feel like I can give an initial review. 

I'm gonna start with the cons:
-This should have had a demo for PC players. I feel like if we would have had a Demo, we could have ironed out the issues that plagued many of us for the past two days. You only garner ill will if you don't have a demo that properly portrays your game (if it's good, which I can wholeheartedly say this game is) or you decide to not put one out for one platform or another 

-The camera needs a touch more polish. Sometimes you have to wrestle the camera away from the game's aggressive camera system. I play Gahndagoza (?) and he is a big boi. The system doesn't feel like it likes him very much as it seems to put the camera into the ground. 

-Targeting goes along with that. Sometimes the game targets enemies way in the back instead of the one right in front of or next to you. Changing targets also needs work.

-They really should have just done a MH lobby system along with Co-OP story. An auto-lobby that puts 8-16 people in a lobby to progress together through the story with. Most people don't seen to want to match together until after story, when you get the option to be put in a random mission, but that is only for missions you already completed!

-This is not something you will want to pay full price for the story for. I got to credits, did a few sidequests, on Hard, in about thirteen hours. I knew this going in, as most likened it to MH where you play the real game after credits, so it doesn't bother me, but I still feel like it was too short since there's stories for all the characters that are mostly slideshows with voice acting.

-Localization. Yes, I know it's a hot topic at the moment, but this one isn't very good. From Marvel-esque "Well, that just happened!" to it being like an old Asian film where the subtitles have a single word, but the character is clearly saying a full sentence. It's just not good and I hope they do better in the future, which I hope we more of this type in the series!

Alright, now onto the pro's:
-This game is truly gorgeous. Like, I don't typically care for the style of games most of the time, but this is all beauty and spectacle! Everything is just so colorful and well done that it pops out at you and you can't help but take it all in for a bit.

-Sounds and Voice acting (Sub-wise, anyways) is no joke, either. Bringing greats from anime into here really helped my own enjoyment (many One Piece voice actors and Vyrn's VA is Happy from Fairy Tale). The sounds are distinct, too, which many games have issues with. I always know when a skill is off cooldown, I got healed, or an attack is headed my way out of sight.

-The gameplay, though, as it should be, is the real star of the show. Fights are so fun that you can't wait for the next. Bosses that each have their own dazzling mechanics to try and teach you before they challenge you after you complete the credits, environmental mechanics to use for or against you, and just phenomenal character move sets to tie it all together.

-Speaking of the characters, they have done an absolute banger job here. No character feels the same. Each of them feel like a different weapon in MH in that they have their own gimmicks, play styles, and such. The characters can be using the same weapon types and still feel completely unique. 

-The progression mechanics feel great, too. Each character has different skill trees for passive and active abilities (in an offense tree and defensive tree), different weapons to craft and level off passives that work even when not wielding that weapon, and a pseudo-decoration system with the Sigils that can also be upgraded that will cement how you want to play that character. It's the kind of grind I like, personally.

In short, even though I have a few nitpicks and negative opinions, I love the game. I really hope they continue supporting this game and make more of this in the future!

Looked forward to this game for years and it exceeded my expectations anyways. Just an overall FUN action game with a solid progression system. Excels in making you and your team feel powerful. 

Has a good amount of content as well. Story mode is decently lengthy and has some incredible set pieces/events but then you also have the coop quests (which can be played solo if you want). You can also replay everything on harder difficulties which changes up a few things. 

There's also a bunch of variation in the characters and how you customize their skills and sigils. It's nothing super complicated or extensive but it's definitely enough to be engaging and fun. For instance you can lean more into buffs, focus on dealing damage, bringing additional healing or debuffing the enemy. There's plenty of these types of decisions in this game for every character.

I haven't experienced any technical issues so I have been able to just enjoy the game. YMMV as usual.

I have dabbled in other Action/J-JRPGs, though this one hits different. 

- I really enjoy the back stories of the characters, they're more interesting than some other run-of-the-mill generic stories. I appreciate games that have story rooted in realistic experiences.

- I appreciate that there are tiers to the gameplay that you can choose from depending on the challenge you're seeking; story mode, normal mode (story with regular combat), then hard mode, which I haven't played myself, but I have friends who appreciate a challenge and are enjoying it so far. 

- I noticed some similarities to Monster Hunter in terms of the primal-god/beasts' patterns and behavior, like AOE attacks, rotating laser attacks, spotted attacks that you have to dodge with precision to avoid death. There are also goals to complete a quest within a time limit without ending up in critical condition or other. 

- If you enjoy being rewarded for exploration, this game definitely takes care of that. 

- The combat combos are a lot of fun, I find joy in playing as Zeta or Lancelot for their rapid abilities. 

- The English voice acting is childish to say the least, which is why I tend to prefer Japanese with Sub, but you can't really appreciate the story being told during combat if you can't understand the language, so that ruins that aspect of it for me. *shrug*

Bug: I play using PS5 controller and have found that not only myself, but other players have issues with the input lag/disconnecting while in menus whenever using a controller. I've read that it's been disregarded as an issue pertaining to the game itself but rather a controller issue, which I find to be unrealistic if it's happening to a large span of folks without any change/interaction on the end user's part. The company needs to acknowledge this issue since it's causing quite an annoying and undesirable experience for players including myself.

This is a rare game that I would rate "maybe" or "meh" if Steam allowed it, but as such I'm giving it a "Not Recommend".

I bought the game wanting a deep, open-world JRPG, a la FF8 or Skies of Arcadia. Sail around the map in a big airship, assemble a party, collect loot, upgrade weapons, etc.

Sadly, after about 3 hours in, and at the start of Chapter 5, I have not seen any kind of world exploration system. You just "depart" to the mission location via a button-press, and then immediately jump to being on the ground at the mission location. No exploration, no sailing, no nothing. 

Why bill the game as "airships" if you never actually get to pilot the airships? The first paragraph of the Steam description uses the words "captain"- but you don't captain anything- "skyfaring"- but you are never in the sky except as a transition screen, or in a set-piece on-deck boss battle- and "sail", but the only sailing you see the ship do is as an icon on the world map.

Next up, there is the marked lack of depth of all the systems.

Skill trees? they're just a linear progression that occasionally has a few parallel branches (never more than 3), that don't ever offer anything unique, just a few different activated skills. Compared to something like FFX, the skill trees are downright anemic.

Loot collection? There's a few different materials that you collect, that you mostly just ignore until you need to upgrade something. At 3 hours in, I've counted maybe 20-25 different items? No armor whatsoever, that I've seen. No weapon drops. No accessories, nor any other element that allows you to play the game in any specific 'role'.

Weapons are upgraded like a F2P auto-battler, where you spend a material to boost them up by 10 levels, then have to pay a "limit unlock" fee to be able to pay to upgrade them the next 10 levels; no hunting for unique items to turn them into different variants, no socketing gems or other upgrades. Just spend a resource up to a limit, pay to unlock higher limit, repeat.

Whether you enjoy the various "deep" systems that other JRPGs like FF (materia, junctioning, in-game TCG minigames, water-soccer, guardian forces, weapon upgrades, etc) or Mana Khemia/ Atelier series (ingredient collection, investigation, experiments/ alchemy, class assignments, etc) include or not, they at least mean that it feels like there is a LOT to do **IF YOU WANT TO** in those games. In this, there's just not. 

I *WANTED* to collect a bunch of cool loot. I *WANTED* to explore a bunch of cool floating islands. But I can't, because they're just linear paths that you take a loading screen to get to, that lead you to a few groups of 5-10 enemies, and then a boss fight. And the chests along the way have the same 25 items for you to collect.

Sad.

Edit: Also, I can confirm that the "localization" (read, English subtitle staff deciding to just write whatever the hell they want) is really really bad.

After completing the storyline of Granblue Fantasy: Relink and now delving into the endgame, engaging in co-op quests with friends, I’d like to share my updated experience. Please note that this review has been edited to reflect improvements from update 1.0.4, addressing previous technical issues. The game shines with an engaging story up to Chapter 8 and offers entertaining co-op quests that are a blast when played with friends. However, not everything is as perfect as it seems.

Positives

- Story up to Chapter 8: The narrative is captivating, offering a rich mix of adventure and character development.
- Co-op Quests with Friends: These stand out as a highlight, providing a lot of fun, especially when playing with friends.

Negatives

- Story from Chapter 9 Onwards: The quality noticeably drops. The storyline feels stretched and poorly thought out, with too much repetition and little novelty.
- Repetitiveness in Co-op Quests: The game suffers from a lack of variety in these quests, as enemies and scenarios constantly repeat, which becomes monotonous over time.

Neutral

- Graphics and Style: The visual style is generally appealing but feels outdated in places.
- Audio: The Japanese voice acting is excellent, but the quality of the translation often leaves much to be desired, affecting immersion.

In summary, Granblue Fantasy: Relink offers significant strengths in its story and co-op gameplay but also had notable weaknesses, especially in content quality past a certain point. With the latest updates, many of the technical concerns have been addressed, enhancing the overall experience for fans of JRPGs and co-op enthusiasts.

[h1] Butchered Translation[/h1]
[h2]Problems with translation[/h2]
Since people are not getting it... Let me add a simple example. This is NOT localization, this is just completely changing the dialogue, for no purpose.

[b]When you talk to Rosetta in town after meeting the crew, she says:[/b]
[u]Japanese:[/u]
そうねぇ。それじゃあ、
この街の楽しことを調査してもらえる？
[u]Romaji:[/u]
Sō nē. Sore jā, 
kono machi no tanoshi koto o chōsashite moraeru?
[u]Literal Translation:[/u]
Let me see. Well then,
Can you research fun things to do in this city?

While the in-game Translation is:
Let's see,
Guidebooks are pretty useful. Ever thought about writing one?

[b]Another one...[/b]

[b]Offering help to Roland:[/b]
[u]Japanese:[/u]
ふむ。。。確かに、 
人手は多い方がありがたいですが。。。
[u]Romaji:[/u]
Fumu... Tashika ni,
hitode wa ōi kata ga arigataidesuga...
[u]Literal Translation:[/u]
yes... surely, 
I would appreciate it if there were more people. . .

While the in-game Translation is:
Very well,
I won't look a gift horse in the mouth.

Please explain to me, in which way this is not changing what the real phrase should be? And also, the "raw" translation makes more sense then adding this "context".

And this is one example. The game pretty much changes everything. And if you still don't believe me, go looking for other reviews, even positive ones, people give more examples than this...

Again, for someone who knows a Japanese, this is making wonder if I'm mistranslating it in my head or they are butchering the real japanese dub.

[h2]Performance and Graphics[/h2]
[h3]Graphics[/h3]
The game is [b]GORGEOUS[/b]. Absolutely amazing. I've been waiting for it for about 6 years since I saw the trailer, and was not disappointed, it looks fantastic.

[h3]Performance[/h3]
While I feel the pain in some reviews, I am yet to experience any problems at all. The game runs smooth, 120fps, not dips, no lag, no issues. I run also with v-sync 60, smooth.
No crashes, no problems. But this is me, does not mean the game doesn't need fixing. Please keep an eye for the patch and bug fixes if you have this problems, I hope your pain goes away when they fix it fellow PC Master Racers.

[h3]==========================================================[/h3]
[h2]Original Review[/h2]

I would NOT recommend it just for this, and CyGames needs to fix this as soon as possible. Not everyone lives or is from english speaking countries, and the cringe is hard.

Also, do yourself a favor and stay away from dub.

I really did give this game a try; beat the story and did a bit of the side missions post game, but the overall game, from the loop to the mechanics are not that great. Passable, and some people will enjoy this, but it feels like a game that would've been released back on the PSP or Vita. There's not really one part of this else than spectacle that is that engaging. I feel if you like those anime beat em up games, or some musous this may be more engaging for you than it is for me.

POSITIVES
Nice anime art style & art design in general
Granblue was always had good art and this is no exception. Hideo Minaba's style really shines through in this and you can see it everywhere. There's a lot of charm in the games particular anime style.

Good flashy visual spectacle for fights
The fights and cutscenes for them are presented well enough. Reminds me of Bayonetta in some cases, although not as engaging.

Nice character selection/variety
Selection of different characters from slow to fast, from ranged fighters to heavy weapon wielders. They all do different enough things to make trying each one a different experience

NEGATIVES
Combat
It's a bit too repetitive. Once you've played one character for a few missions you will have understood the entire gameplay loop for said character. The approach for most enemies is the same (dodge when you need to dodge, spam X and sometimes intermix Y when you need to attack, use skills when off cooldown). For me this compares to something like Tales of, but Tales of has achieved more engaging combat than this since gamecube with combos and skill variety you can figure mix and match. Those aren't my favorite games either but it's the immediate comparison. Some people compare this game to Monster Hunter but it's nothing like it, and the mechanical depth of each character is severely lacking.

Mechanical Depth
There's not much going on in this game. Your skill set up is out of ~8 on each character, which you pick 4 to use actively in battle. They have fairly long cooldowns so they're use them to usually set up for maximal damage for the X and Y attacks. Nothing really combos into each other either. On top of that it feels like attacks should track more in this game given how much enemies just move around. Attack chains can be super long, but by the time you finish them the enemy has already moved away and now you've missed or have to redo the chain, it doesn't feel great.

Boss phases (bloodlust)
Most people probably like the bosses but the bloodlust phase is just annoying. It's basically a period that just consumes your time where you can't engage in damaging the enemy. So you are running around dodging attacks, and that's it.

RPG Depth
This is barely better than something like FF16 or GoW on this case. It's basically just minor stat increases hopefully adding up to something larger. Nothing really changes how your character performs all too much or how you build them. The biggest RPG decision making is which character you go into battle with, which is kind of decided by elemental weakness comparison, otherwise you're minimizing damage.

Multiplayer
Just do the same missions the game kind of expects you to do in the base game. Even with Post game it's kind of the same mess. There are some extra and more interesting things to do in extreme but not to such a degree I'd ever say this is the "real game". It's just overall a bit lacking. Also TO GET TO MOST OF THAT ONLINE CONTENT YOU NEED TO BEAT THE GAME. This means an up to 10 hour story to get to the post game/most of the quest content. Overall It just feels like the multiplayer was tacked on, and this part more than anything gave me that old VITA feel.

Story
It's an anime sidestory that doesn't matter for a plot of a game majority of the people playing probably won't even know. There's nothing particularly special or depthy about it. It's inoffensive I guess, but it does nothing, and you won't be compelled by the setting or characters unless you already have prior engagement with the gacha. Even then it's just nothing crazy.

Small stuff/Quality issues
It's polished for the most part, I never ran into a bug, but there are several minor issues that just add up to being annoying with the game. The camera is slow by default without sensitivity changes. The lock on sucks. Movement is okay, but nothing great, and the game has a few movement/platform puzzles that feel bad to do given the controls of said movement. Sometimes the bosses require a bit of precision to dodge their attack phases as well, and you can just slide a bit into the fire and get hit on a lot of attacks.

This game for me is around a 5/10. if I was much younger and playing this on an older console I'd probably remember it fondly, but given the current era and quality of games this doesn't feel worth 60$s. I don't think I would've beat it if I wasn't playing it so causally on the steamdeck.

As of the 1.0.4 update my main gaming set up (AMd 5600x with 32g ram, 3060ti) is fixed and not launching with a black screen anymore. I'm now able to get to the main menu and play the game. With a solid 70-90fps, 1440p on ultra settings. For those that haven't played the game.  I highly recommend you play this game for though's that love RPG and JRPG's. The games graphics are incredible. Game plays smoothly with zero crashing since the update.  This Game is very GPU demanding. My 3060ti runs at 100% utilization the entire time i'm playing the game. the only time it isn't is menu or the town. My CPU only get up to 50-70  utilization. 

Original review: when i tryed to launch the game on my main rig i would get a black screen every time never get to see any main menu. I tryed every driver update i could think of, nothing. So i decide to install the game on my old rig (intel I5-7500 with 16g ram. Radeon RX580). I'm not kidding, the first time i launched the game it truly loaded to the main menu and i was able to play the game at a solid 60 frame with no drops. Thats at 1080p with standard graphic settings.  This game is everything i expected out of the game from playing over 50hrs of the demo. After putting in a solid 2 hours in the game i have experience crashes during cut scene. Though i haven't had any major frame drops in the town, it stays solid 60 frames even when battling bosses and hordes of monsters.  My overview of the game is staying negative until I'm able to play the game on my main rig and not having any type of game crashing
Fantastic game! Definitely recommend.

I knew nothing about Granblue Fantasy going into this game, however, that will have no impact on your experience.

This game nails many of aspects of what makes a great action RPG:
- A ton of characters each with unique mechanics. 
- A lengthy progression system with just the right amount of complexity. Not to simple, but also not to complex.
- Engaging combat system with a diverse set of enemies and boss mechanics.
- Superb cinematic quality.
- NO GACHA

However, the story is somewhat short (15-20 hours), doesn't have the most interesting plot, and the dialogue can be cheesy at times. BUT this game's gameplay mechanics, progression, and overall polish makes up for everything and more.

I haven't quite made it to the endgame just yet, but from what I've heard its where the game really starts to open up.
Great Game

Just finished the main story and it was one of the most fun ive had in a 15 hours of gameplay of any game (1-2 hours of coop play too, so it took arround 13 hours or so to finish the story with all side quests done). General quality of the game is insane, you can see how much effort and love devs put into it. Combat is awesome, story is fine nothing special, playable characters are diverse enough to not feel too similar, every chapter/main quest area is awesome and you do/see different stuff in each chapter, bosses and their transition from cutscene to gameplay are fucking sick. There are so many small details like; meanwhile with playing a character you unlock (so any character besides the main crew of 6) they say appropiate stuff during story moments and boss fights or meanwhile fighting the boss some kind of action happens at the background that is clearly visible to you if you look that way. 

All in all i am extremely satisfied with the main story and the ending, and supposedly endgame is the real deal here just like monster hunter games. Gonna continue onto the endgame and can't wait for devs to release more content and characters in the future.
